X Big banks like Bank of America (BAC), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Wells Fargo (WFC) have soared since Donald Trump's election, but IBD 50-member Home BancShares (HOMB) outranks them all in Forbes' latest list of the 'Best Banks In America.' The Arkansas-based parent of Centennial Bank ranked No. 8 on this year's list, which looked at 10 metrics to measure…

The Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing survey index out Wednesday rose to 57.7 in February as factory activity accelerated for the sixth straight month. That's the best reading since August 2014, giving the Federal Reserve more reasons to raise rates this month.Wall Street economists expected the ISM gauge to rise to 56.2 from 56.0 in January. Readings above 50 signal expansion, while those south of 50 suggest contraction.The new orders index jumped to 65.1 from 60.4, while the current production gauge hit 62.9, up from 61.4. The only somewhat soft spot was employment, which still expanded, but at a slower rate, slipping to 54.2 from 56.1.The steady improvement in the manufacturing sector is part of the solidifying economic backdrop that could lead the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates again on March 15. Markets were pricing in 69% odds of a March hike on early Wednesday, according to the CME Group FedWatch tool. The odds doubled to 62% on Tuesday after two Fed policymakers gave a strong signal that they backed a near-term rate increased.The Dow Jones industrial average soared above 21,000 for the first time, with the Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 also hitting record highs following President Trump's speech and speculation of a Fed rate hike.Banks, which stand to benefit from the steeper yield curve that generally comes with higher rates, were among the big winners on the stock market today. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS), both Dow components, climbed 2.8% and 2.4%, respectively. Bank of America (BAC) rose 3.1% and Wells Fargo (WFC) 2.9%. Bank of America hit its best levels since late 2008, while JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs and Wells Fargo set all-time highs.The strength comes despite concerns that the auto sector, which had provided a big boost in manufacturing output in recent years, is now seen as a potential drag, amid a potential peaking of sales and rising inventory levels.Early reports of U.S. auto sales in February, which will released throughout the day on Wednesday, were generally positive. Ford Motor[ticker symb=F] set a record for SUV deliveries, though overall sales slipped 4%, just below Edmunds estimates. General Motors (GM) reported higher U.S. sales, though they fell short of Edmunds views. Ford shares edged up 1.4% intraday while General Motors climbed 2%.In other economic news, the PCE deflator, the Fed's favorite inflation gauge, showed a 1.9% yearly gain in January, the highest since 2012 and close to the central bank's 2% target. The core PCE reported 1.7% inflation. But the same report also found inflation-adjusted consumer spending falling by the most since 2009.RELATED:

Bank stocks like Dow components JPMorgan (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS) opened higher Wednesday on the strength of ADP's monthly jobs report, which blew past expectations.The economy added 298,000 private-sector jobs in February, the best gain in nearly three years far past estimates for 183,000. The torrid acceleration shown in the ADP report comes ahead of the official government job figures for February, which are set for release Friday.The 10-year Treasury yield, which helps determine rates on mortgages and is a measure of inflation expectations, had risen to 2.56%, continuing a recent revival back to near postelection highs. Higher yields and a wider yield spread should be good for banks profits.Bond yields have been rallying on growing expectations for a Federal Reserve rate hike at the end of the March 14-15 meeting. Fed officials have signaled that a move is likely, with markets pricing in a 91% chance that it'll happen. Investors now see about a 50-50 chance of a second hike by June's Meeting.JPMorgan Chase rose as high as 92.85 soon after the opening bell, but closed down 0.2% to 91.21 in the stock market today. Goldman Sachs reversed to close down 0.3%.Bank of America (BAC) settled up 0.2% while Citigroup (C) advanced 1%, with both also well off the day's best levels.Wells Fargo (WFC) reversed to finish down 0.15%. Morgan Stanley (MS) rose 0.15%.IBD'S TAKE: Many businesses don't exactly benefit when interest rates rise. Bank stocks are different in that they actually do. JPMorgan and Goldman leaped to record highs last week after two more dovish Fed officials, John Williams and William Dudley, indicated that a rate hike could be on the horizon and that economy was gaining steam.Then, last Friday, Fed chair Janet Yellen said a rate hike this month "would likely be appropriate," assuming the economy didn't suddenly falter. She also indicated the Fed would likely institute three rate hikes this year.RELATED:JPMorgan Cautious On Benefits From Tax Cuts, Fewer RegulationsJPMorgan, Charles Schwab, Goldman Jump On Trump's Regulatory Rollback

U.S. stock indexes stumbled Monday afternoon, with a step down in volume being the only consolation.The Nasdaq lost 0.4%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.3% and 0.2%, respectively. Volume in the stock market today was running lower on both major exchanges vs. the same time Friday.Price losses in declining volume are generally considered less threatening than those in accelerating turnover.Initial public offering Snap (SNAP) fell 7% in its third session on the NYSE. Several analysts began coverage of the stock with a sell rating.Snap, an internet stock, lost 32 cents a share in 2015 and then lost 44 cents in 2016. The Street expects Snap to again lose 44 cents a share in 2017 and then lose 26 cents in 2018.While Snap also has failed to post a profit in any of the past eight quarters, revenue soared 890%, 1,255%, 666% and 406% in the past four quarters.The FANG stocks — Facebook (FB), Amazon.com (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Alphabet (GOOGL) — were, with one exception, making routine moves in below-average volume. The exception was Netflix. The internet TV network rose about 1% in volume about 35% above normal.Those four stocks together make up about 14% of the Nasdaq's weighting. Toss in Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT) and the figure rises to 25.7%. Apple fell 0.4% in volume 20% below average. Microsoft edged up 0.5% in trade 40% below average.The market-leading bank sector showed similar action. PowerShares KBW Bank (KBWB) exchange-traded fund gapped down 1.2%, but volume was about 80% below average. The ETF reflects the Nasdaq KBW Bank Index. The largest weightings in the ETF are Wells Fargo (WFC), which was down about 1% in volume 40% slower than usual; Citigroup (C), off about 1% in trade 33% below average; and U.S. Bancorp (USB) down more than 0.5% in volume 15% behind its usual pace.In the Big Cap 20, which has six bank stocks, five of the bank stocks were down in below-average volume. KeyCorp (KEY) was the exception, falling 1.3% in volume 11% above average.RELATEDWhy Apple Got A Price-Target BoostHow To Boost The Odds For A Secure Retirement

Bank stocks, including Dow components JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS), rallied Wednesday as the odds for a Fed rate hike this month continued to surge following bullish commentary from the central bank's policymakers.The upswing in financials helped lift the Dow Jones industrial average above 21,000, as the major averages had their best day of 2017.Shares of JPMorgan jumped 3.3% to 93.60, hitting a fresh record high in the stock market today. Bank of America (BAC), whose large U.S. operations make it more sensitive to interest-rate fluctuations, leapt 3.3% to its best since 2008.Citigroup (C) added 2.9% to 61.54, hitting an eight-year high intraday but closing below a 61.73 buy point. Morgan Stanley (MS) gained 2.5%, setting its top levels since 2008, while Wells Fargo (WFC) climbed 3.2% to a record high.Goldman, whose large trading desk could benefit from market volatility — including the kind that might come from President Trump's tweets — rallied 1.9%, also setting an all-time best.The gains come a day after San Francisco Fed President John Williams, a policy dove, said a rate hike "is on the table for serious consideration" at the Federal Reserve's two-day meeting beginning on March 14.New York Fed President William Dudley, seen as being more dovish on rates, also expressed optimism Tuesday about the economy, saying "animal spirits have been unleashed a bit" since the election.And last week, minutes from the most recent Fed policymakers' meeting said that many in the meeting felt a rate hike should come "fairly soon." The odds for a March increase in the federal funds rate — the benchmark interest rate charged on overnight loans — rose to 66% Wednesday, after surging past 60% on Tuesday. On Monday, the odds were 31%.IBD'S TAKE: Banks are among the only S&P 500 stocks that actually benefit from higher rates. After years of low interest rates following the financial crisis and recession, Wall Street has been throwing its money at bank shares since the election.Analysts are expecting the Trump administration to pave the way for lower regulations, tax cuts and a massive infrastructure investment. Those measures, they say, would add jobs, push up wages and inflation expectations, prompting the Fed to raise rates to temper borrowing and overheating.When the benchmark rate rises, those extra costs ripple through the financial system, allowing banks to charge customers more for loans and other products and services.RELATED:

Analyst actions on Thursday included price-target hikes for Cisco Systems (CSCO), NetApp (NTAP), Applied Materials (AMAT) and CBS (CBS), while Wells Fargo (WFC) got a downgrade.UBS raised its price target for the networking equipment company to 37 from 35, and Deutsche Bank hiked its target to 40, after Cisco topped second-quarter earnings estimates and increased its dividend late Wednesday. Both firms have buy ratings on Cisco.UBS analyst Steven Milunovich sees M&As in Cisco's future, saying even big deals will be considered. While a tax cut on profits held overseas, as planned by the Trump administration, could help facilitate a deal, Milunovich doesn't see a repatriation as being essential for a deal to happen.Shares of Cisco closed up 2.4% at 33.60 on the stock market today. The stock is now extended from a 31.99 buy point cleared this week.RELATED:Cisco Earnings, Revenue Edge Views; Dividend Hike Light? IBD'S TAKE: Shares of Cisco broke above a five-month trading range on Monday and has kept climbing. Early Thursday, shares were just barely less than 5% above the buy point, meaning it's not quite too extended. Check out IBD Leaderboard to find other leading stocks near a buy point.Analysts hiked their price targets on the maker of storage and data-management products after it topped fiscal Q3 estimates and grew revenue for the first time in 13 quarters.UBS lifted its target on NetApp to 37 from 32, but kept a sell rating. Analyst Steven Milunovich noted lower gross margins, which suggests discounting helped revenue grow.Piper Jaffray lifted its target to 49 from 46, with an overweight rating. Analyst Andrew Nowinski thinks NetApp has "turned the corner" and that revenue can rise by mid-single-digit percentages.Shares advanced 4.2% to finish at 40.56 after rising as high as 42.18 in the morning.RELATED:NetApp Turnaround Comes Into Focus With Earnings BeatRBC Capital Markets raised its price target from the chip-equipment maker to 35 from 30, keeping a sector perform rating after Applied Materials beat Q1 estimates and offered better-than-expected guidance. Analyst Amit Daryanani expects the company to increase its share of wafer fab equipment spending and noted that display revenue continues to surprise to the upside.Shares of Applied Materials rose modestly initially, but reversed to close down 0.9% at 35.18.RELATED:Applied Materials Beats Q1 Targets, Guides Higher, Stock Rises RBC Capital Markets raised its price target for the diversified media company to 78 from 70, keeping an outperform rating, after CBS reported Q4 earnings that topped estimates. Revenue was weaker than expected, partly due to NFL ratings.Shares of CBS gained 0.3% to 65.42.Credit Suisse downgraded the banking giant to neutral from outperform, with a 56 price target, citing valuation. The stock touched an all-time high this week and has surged about 29% since the election on expectations of higher interest rates, deregulation and tax cuts.Shares of Wells Fargo dipped 0.7% to 58.12.RELATED:Fed Chief Yellen's Hawkish Tone Lifts Bond Yields, Bank StocksCummins, Wells Fargo Boast Healthy Yields, Bullish Charts

The major stock index ETFs shot to fresh all-time highs Wednesday, with their strings of gains increasing to the fifth to ninth days.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) was up 0.5% Wednesday. It's in its seventh day of straight gains, having gained 2% since Feb. 6 and 5% since the beginning of the year.PowerShares QQQ (QQQ) was up 0.6%. It's in its ninth day of straight gains, having risen 2.7% since Feb. 2 and 8.6% so far this year.The health care sector was the top contributor to the S&P 500's gain. Health Care Select Sector SPDR (XLV) surged 1.1%. Top holdings Pfizer (PFE) leapt 2.3%, Amgen (AMGN) 2.2% and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) rose 0.7%ETFs tracking the financial sector notched another strong day. Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF) was up 0.8%. Among its holdings, big gainers were Bank of America (BAC), up 2.6%, Charles Schwab (SCHW) 2.2%, Citigroup (C) 1.1%, Morgan Stanley (MS) 1.0%, Wells Fargo (WFC) 1.0% and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) 1.1%.But American International Group (AIG) dove 9% after reporting a loss of $2.72 per share for Q4. The insurer's stock crashed through its 50-day moving average down to near its 200-day line.Energy and real estate were the two worst performing sectors, continuing lower for the second day in a row. Energy Select Sector (XLE) was off 0.4% and Real Estate Select Sector (XLRE)was off 0.3%. Fed Chair Janet Yellen's hawkish comments about interest rates put downward pressure on rate-sensitive sectors. XLRE is testing support at its 50-day moving averages.Gold was trading tightly for the third day in a row, just above its 10-day moving average. SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) was up 0.4% at 117.45.Here's a look at the performance of major exchange traded funds across key asset classes on the stock market today.The Relative Price Strength (RS) Rating measures a stock's price performance over the last 12 months vs. all stocks and ETFs, on a scale of 1 to a best-possible 99.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), +0.5%, RS 55PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), +0.6%, RS 64SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), +0.6%, RS 60IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), +0.3%, RS 64IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), +0.6%, RS 70IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), +0.4%, RS 38Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), +0.7%, RS 60SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), +0.4%, RS 20United States Oil (USO), -0.2%, RS 52IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), -021%, RS 20PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), -0.2%, RS 34IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), +3.1%, RS 1RELATED:Growth ETF Strategy Taps Rally That Trump Has Ignited In 7 S&P SectorsStrength Of Steel ETFs Comes From Miners

Billionaire investor Warren Buffett praised "ambitious" immigrants' contribution to the "miraculous" American story, rejected claims that stock buybacks are "un-American" and ripped Wall Street investment fees in his annual letter to Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) shareholders on Saturday. Meanwhile, Berkshire reported declining operating profit but big unrealized gains in last year's investments in Apple (AAPL), American Airlines (AAL) and other carriers paying off.The typically optimistic Buffett said that stocks are "virtually certain" to rise in years to come. And he hailed America, with an implicit rebuke of anti-immigrant sentiment."One word sums up our country's achievements: miraculous. From a standing start 240 years ago ' a span of time less than triple my days on earth ' Americans have combined human ingenuity, a market system, a tide of talented and ambitious immigrants, and the rule of law to deliver abundance beyond any dreams of our forefathers."As the subject of repurchases has come to a boil, some people have come close to calling them un-American ' characterizing them as corporate misdeeds that divert funds needed for productive endeavors. That simply isn't the case: Both American corporations and private investors are today awash in funds looking to be sensibly deployed. I'm not aware of any enticing project that in recent years has died for lack of capital. (Call us if you have a candidate.)He pointed out that many companies that Berkshire invests in, including Bank of America (BAC), have been buying back shares. "We very much like this behavior because we believe the repurchased shares have in most cases been underpriced. ... When a company grows and outstanding shares shrink, good things happen for shareholders."Buffett said that wealthy Americans have been suckered out of more than $100 billion over the past decade seeking "superior investment advice.""When trillions of dollars are managed by Wall Streeters charging high fees, it will usually be the managers who reap outsized profits, not the clients," he wrote. "Both large and small investors should stick with low-cost index funds."But Buffett had nothing but praise for Vanguard founder Jack Bogle, who popularized ultra-low fee index funds."If a statue is ever erected to honor the person who has done the most for American investors, the hands-down choice should be Jack Bogle," Buffett wrote.Buffett didn't offer hints about his possible M&A plan and was mum about Kraft Heinz (KHC), which made a short-lived $143 merger bid for Unilever (UN) this month. Berkshire Hathaway and Brazil's 3G Capital own about 50% of Kraft Heinz.Net income rose 15% to $6.29 billion, boosted by a $1.1 billion gain from investments and derivatives. But operating profit fell 6% to $2,665 per Class A share, below analyst forecasts for $2716.60.Berkshire's equity portfolio was worth $122 billion at year-end vs. $102.5 billion on Sept. 30. Big holdings such as Wells Fargo (WFC) and American Express (AXP) were big year-end winners as financials rallied.Buffett also boosted its stakes in Apple, Delta Air Lines (DAL), American Airlines, United Airlines (UAL) and Southwest Airlines (LUV).Berkshire acquired 61.2 million shares for $6.75 billion at an average prices of 110.17. That stake has risen by $1.6 billion as of Friday's close at 136.66. Berkshire holds a 44% gain in its Southwest stake, 35% in United and 21% in Delta Air.RELATED:What Would Warren Buffett Do? He'll Tell You On SaturdayBuffett's Berkshire Piles On Shares Of Apple, Airlines, Cuts Wal-Mart

XU.S. stock indexes were mixed Wednesday, with the Dow Jones industrial average down the most and small caps up the most.The Nasdaq rose 0.2%, and the S&P 500 lost 0.2%. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.6%, as IBM's (IBM) 5% loss pulled down the Dow. The small-cap Russell 2000 advanced 0.3%.Volume was up, according to preliminary data. Turnover was about 10% faster on the Nasdaq and about 1% faster on the NYSE. Trade has been mostly below average in recent weeks.Blue chips were mostly down, even apart from IBM, which is now 11% off its high. The Dow industrial average component with the best gain was Intel (INTC), up moderately in soft trade. Intel is consolidating mostly under its 10-week moving average line, which is a negative. Intel is 6% off its high.The pressure the uptrend is encountering has hit some stocks hard. The selling has been especially tough for three of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) stocks. The S&P 500 has slipped 2% off its high. But some of the concentrated Berkshire holdings have lost much more: Wells Fargo (WFC) is 13% off its high. IBM is 11%  off its high. American Express (AXP) is 7% off its high.Those three stocks alone account for about 34% of Berkshire Hathaway's assets.The so-called Trump trade also has struggled. Cement stocks and money centers have pulled about 11% and 9% respectively off their highs.Yet, one money-center stock was doing well initially Wednesday. Morgan Stanley (MS) gapped up 4.2% in strong volume but then reversed to trim the gain to 2%. The company beat the Street's estimate on earnings. Analysts expected earnings to rise 60% to 88 cents a share vs. the year-ago quarter. But results showed an 82% earnings pop to $1 a share.Money centers that have reported have generally had good quarters. Of the 11 stocks trading above 15 and that have reported Q1 results, 10 topped the Street's consensus estimate and only one missed. But the reaction to the beats has been subdued.The market doesn't appear to be in a generous mood.The S&P 500 lost its March 14 distribution day because of time. Distribution involves a sizable loss in a major index in rising volume. The action points to institutional selling.RELATED:Chip Gear Stocks Are Soaring: Here's WhyQualcomm Gets Downgrade, Will Report After Close

XGoldman Sachs (GS) fell short of Q1 forecasts Tuesday, blaming weak trading revenue on political uncertainty and low volatility, while Bank of America (BAC) reported better-than-expected earnings, led by strong trading and net interest income.Estimates: Earnings per share of $5.31, nearly double that of a year ago, when results from some banks were driven lower by the commodities crash and a slowing economy in China. Revenue is seen jumping 33% to $8.445 billion.Results: EPS of $5.15 on revenue of $8.03 billion. Revenues from bond, currency and commodities trading was little changed at $1.69 billion. Equities trading fell 6% to $1.67 billion. Investment bank revenue grew 16% to $1.7 billion. Investment management revenue rose 12% to $1.5 billion."The operating environment was mixed, with client activity challenged in certain market-making businesses and a more attractive backdrop for underwriting in our investment banking franchise," said CEO Lloyd Blankfein in a statement. "As the economy improves, we are well-positioned to not only meet our clients' diverse needs, but also to generate operating leverage for our shareholders."Dividend: Quarterly payout was raised 15% to 75 cents a share.Stock: Goldman fell 4.7% to 215.59 on the stock market today, tumbling to its worst level since Nov. 30. Goldman Sachs was a major drag on the Dow Jones industrial average, and sent financial stocks lower.Fellow investment banker Morgan Stanley (MS), which reports Wednesday, dropped 0.7%.Estimates: A 67% jump in EPS to 35 cents, as revenue rises 10% to $21.611 billion.Results: EPS of 41 cents on revenue of $22.2 billion. Fixed-income trading swelled to $2.9 billion, above views. Net interest income grew 5% to $11.1 billion, in line with some views.Stock: Shares rose and fell, closing off 0.4% at 22.71.Bank of America, analysts have said, is more sensitive to changes in U.S. interest rates than its peers, given its large amount of business it does here. The bank's fourth-quarter earnings were helped along by cost discipline and fewer losses on bad loans, a recent Edward Jones research note said.The earnings from Goldman Sachs and Bank of America follow those last week from JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC).Investors have become more anxious that bank stocks' postelection run might not reflect the reality on the ground. Interest rates are rising, but doubts have grown over how fast the Trump administration might be able to carry out its more bank-friendly economic agenda.Shares of big banks have fallen since March as those expectations cool. JJ Kinahan, chief market strategist at TD Ameritrade, said last week that banks could stay within the range they're in now until details on tax policy become more concrete.JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon urged patience."You all should expect, as a given, that when you have a new president, and they get going, that the nine months after the 100 days is gonna be a sausage-making period," Dimon told analysts on the bank's first-quarter earnings call. "There will be ups and downs, wins and losses, stuff like that."JPMorgan and Citigroup beat estimates on the top and bottom lines, while Wells Fargo's EPS was above views. Trading results were strong for JPMorgan and Citigroup, helped in part by the outlook on interest rates.But JPMorgan's consumer and industrial loan growth was roughly flat quarter-to-quarter. Management said some of the slowdown might be due to past big acquisitions and because companies have other options, such as bonds, for financing.Citigroup also tempered its expectations for loan growth. And Wells Fargo saw auto-loan originations drop due to stricter underwriting standards, while home-loan originations also fell.RELATED:JPMorgan CEO Signals Patience As Trump's Growth Agenda Stalls

U.S. stock indexes made some headway in early trade, as several banks reported view-beating results.The Nasdaq rose 0.3%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each added about 0.1%. Volume in the stock market today was higher on the NYSE, but lower on the Nasdaq vs. the previous session's pace.Banks were in the earnings spotlight as two megacaps, two big caps and two midcaps reported quarterly results.JPMorgan Chase (JPM) rolled in with an 11% pop in earnings to $1.65 a share, topping expectations for a 2.7% gain. The megacap stock rose more than 1% in volume 325% above average.Wells Fargo (WFC), the other megacap, checked in with a 1% advance in earnings to $1 a share, topping the consensus view. While that represented only a 3% rise, the Street's consensus estimate was for a 2% decline. The gain broke a streak of five consecutive quarters of earnings declines. The stock trimmed an early loss to 1%, but in heavy volume, as it found support at its 200-day line.Big-cap PNC Financial Services (PNC) pegged earnings growth of 17% to $1.96 a share, beating the Street's estimate. Analysts expected a 9% gain. The 17% earnings pop was PNC's best in 13 quarters. The stock advanced 3% in volume 485% above normal.First Republic Bank (FRC), another big cap, grew earnings 10% to $1.01 a share, matching the consensus estimate. The stock lost 2% in volume 326% above average.Washington Federal (WAFD), a midcap, reported earnings growth of 4% to 47 cents a share.  This edged above views for no change vs. the year-ago quarter. The stock rose a penny in quiet turnover.First Horizon National (FHN), also a midcap, posted a 15% earnings gain to 23 cents a share, in line with the Street's expectations. The stock gapped down almost 2% in volume 467% above average.Stocks that start the day with volume spikes in huge percentages often see those percentages slip a bit as the session wears on.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, steel, heavy construction and telecom infrastructure were among the early top gainers. The top losers included wholesale food and diversified operations.RELATED:What The Statistics Say About The Stock Market's Next MoveExperts See Crude Oil Prices As Close To Balanced

U.S. and European bank stocks spiked Monday as the French presidential election eased fears, triggering broad stock market gains, higher bond yields and increased odds for a Federal Reserve rate hike.JPMorgan Chase (JPM) closed 3.5% higher on the stock market today. Citigroup (C), which has a large base of operations internationally, advanced 3%. Bank of America (BAC) popped 4%. Goldman Sachs (GS) rallied 2.9%. JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, Bank of America and Goldman Sachs all remained below their 50-day moving average.Among European banks, the gains were far more pronounced. Deutsche Bank (DB), which has been hurt by litigation and still-open wounds in Europe's own economy, surged 11%. Barclays (BCS) jumped 5.9%.France's CAC index jumped 4.1% to finish at the highest level in nine years, while the Dow industrials rose 1% and the Nasdaq composite hit an all-time high.The lift came after the first round of French elections put Emmanuel Macron, the centrist candidate, narrowly ahead of Marine Le Pen, who has campaigned on a hard-right, anti-EU platform with nationalistic, anti-immigrant strains similar to those that helped carry President Trump to victory in the U.S.Macron and Le Pen now advance to a May 7 runoff. Macron, who has never been elected but is pushing a pro-reform agenda, is heavily favored. However, so was Hillary Clinton in the U.S., and many did not expect the United Kingdom to vote in favor of leaving the EU last year. But Macron appears to have a lead of more than 20 points vs. Le Pen.The outcome, Wall Street seems to think, could have been worse.A runoff between Le Pen and Jean-Luc Melenchon — a far-left candidate who also wanted to shake up France's relationship with the EU and tax the wealthy at 100% — would have triggered concerns about France's future in the euro and European Union even as the U.K. begins what could be an ugly divorce from the bloc.Meanwhile, the odds for a rate hike from the Federal Reserve by the June meeting jumped to 66% on Monday, up from 53% on Friday. The 10-year Treasury yield, a longer-term measure of inflation expectations, rose 5 basis points to 2.29% Monday morning.The European Central Bank may feel more comfortable about winding down its quantitative easing program earlier if Macron wins the French presidency.Morgan Stanley (MS) rallied 4.2%, while Wells Fargo (WFC) added 1.2%. Regional banks were strong too, with Comerica (CMA) up 2%.RELATED:JPMorgan CEO Signals Patience As Trump's Growth Agenda StallsGoldman Sacked: Wall Street Giant Blames Politics For Trading Woes

XDow Jones industrial average component JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Citigroup (C) topped Q1 estimates Thursday while Wells Fargo (WFC) beat on profit but missed on revenue.The results come as Wall Street weighs the industry's sense of President Trump and the economy after the GOP failed to replace the Affordable Care Act, raising questions over when the administration might be able to carry out its plans for tax reform and deregulation. But CEO Jamie Dimon said it's "silly" to expect a new president not to have some growing pains.Estimates: EPS up 13% to $1.52, with revenue up 3% to $24.876 billion.Results: EPS of $1.65 on revenue of $25.59 billion. Markets revenue increased 13.9%. Investment banking revenue jumped 34%.

In January, CEO Jamie Dimon said he was "neither euphoric nor depressed" about regulatory conditions but said he felt the Trump administration "will do the right thing for America." But last month, he said the president's plans for the country had revived the nation's "animal spirits."After the administration's early stumbles, CEO Jamie Dimon said on JPMorgan's Thursday earnings call that a "sausage-making period" is bound to occur early in a new president's term, and he said not to expect smooth sailing. "That would be silly."In JPMorgan's annual report released this month, the company said that while regulations were too complex, the U.S. was "probably stronger than ever before." However, it also said "it is clear that something is wrong — and it's holding us back."Stock: Shares rallied 1.7% in morning trading on the stock market today. Fellow Dow stock Goldman Sachs (GS), which reports next week, was up 0.1%. Bank of America (BAC), also reporting next week, inched 0.1% higher.Estimates: EPS up 12% to $1.23 on a 1% revenue gain to $17.757 billion.Results: EPS of $1.35 on revenue of $18.12 billion. Consumer banking revenue rose 1% to $7.82 billion. Investment banking revenue surged 39% to $1.21 billion. Fixed income markets revenue climbed 19% to $3.62 billion.

Stock: Shares rose 1.6% intraday after initially falling modestly.Estimates: EPS of 97 cents, down 2%, with revenue of $22.315 billion, up 0.5%.Results: EPS of $1.00 on revenue of $22 billion. Total average deposits were up 1% at $1.3 trillion. Auto loan originations sank 29% to $5.5 billion on tighten=r underwriting standards. Home loan originations plunged to $44 billion from $72 billion in prior quarter.
Stock: Shares dropped 1.1% after sinking more than 3% soon after the open and hitting their lowest levels since late November.

XFutures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 fell modestly early Thursday morning ahead of the final trading day of the week in observance of Good Friday.On Wednesday, the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 closed below their 50-day moving averagse, a yellow flag as groups that rallied on President Trump's election have faded in recent weeks. The Nasdaq composite closed just above that support level.Investors should listen to three banking giants reporting earnings — JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) — watch Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI) and other fiber-optic stocks and see what a key Apple supplier has to say about current and future iPhone demand.Dow industrials retreated 0.1% vs. fair value. So did S&P 500 index and Nasdaq 100 futures.IBD'S TAKE: The market goes up and down, but what are the underlying trends? Don't rely on opinions or fake news, trust the objective data and analysis in IBD's Stock Market Today and The Big Picture columns every day.Dow component JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Wells Fargo kick off financial earnings Thursday morning. Investors will want to know how banks are faring so far this year, but pay attention to what JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon and other bank executives say about the economy and Trump's impact on business's "animal spirits."Bank stocks have been drags on the Dow and S&P 500 index since early March, as concerns about Trump's tax cuts mount. Treasury yields have fallen below 2.3% to their lowest levels since November.Infrastructure stocks such as cement, steel and construction-related firms also have lost their postelection boom. Steel stocks crashed with iron prices on Wednesday.Applied Optoelectronics should soar on blowout preliminary Q1 figures released after Wednesday's close. Applied Opto leapt 20% late Wednesday, with Lumentum (LITE), Finisar (FNSR) and others following in sympathy. But will other fiber-optic stocks sustain that rebound in the regular session after the once-hot sector's sell-off this month?Finally, Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) will release earnings early Thursday as well. Taiwan Semi is believed to be an Apple iPhone chip supplier. Apple-tied chip stocks have sold off this week amid reports that the iPhone maker may cut ties with a second chip supplier and bring that work in house. Now Taiwan Semi may offer hope or concern about Apple (AAPL), which has received a long run of bullish analyst comments this year.Taiwan Semi fell 0.4% on Wednesday, but found support near its 50-day line and held above its buy point.Apple edged up 0.1% to 141.80, ending a recent downtrend. But for a second straight session shares undercut a recent 141.12 buy point intraday.A big reason why the market uptrend has continued in 2017 is because big-cap techs such as Apple and Amazon.com (AMZN) have taken up leadership. If Apple, the world's most valuable company and biggest component of the Dow, S&P 500 and Nasdaq, struggles, it will be a big drag on the major averages.Asian markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei down 1.1% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng 0.1%. The Shanghai composite edged higher and South Korea's Kospi advanced 0.5%.China exports rose by the most in two years, Australia's full-time jobs jumped the most in almost 30 years and the Bank of Korea left its key interest rate unchanged.RELATED:Banks, Metals Hit; Is 'Trump Bump' Over? XHere is your Investing Action Plan for Thursday: What you need to know as an investor. Earnings season starts to pick up in earnest on Thursday, the final trading day of the week. Three banking giants are on tap: Dow Jones industrial average component JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC), but investors also will want to…

Dow component JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and two other big banks, Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC), report first-quarter earnings on Thursday, as higher rates from the Fed seem likely while President Trump's legislative agenda stalls.Broadly, analysts see a decent first quarter for the banks. But maybe not as decent as once expected as the postelection "animal spirits" that pushed the Dow Jones industrial average higher become tamer.The Fed's actual or planned rate hikes could help banks' net interest margins — the difference between the interest banks make on loans and what they pay to depositors — as those extra costs get passed onto consumers who need credit. Fixed-income trading will also likely be solid.But the GOP's botched attempt to replace the Affordable Care Act has thrown the timing for the administration's other policy goals, like tax cuts and the slashing-away of regulations, up in the air. President Trump on Tuesday said that he may work to end Dodd-Frank rules, but the announcement did nothing for bank stocks.JPMorgan shares dipped 0.2% on the stock market today after seeping through the bottom of a flat base intraday. Citigroup lost 0.4%, and Wells Fargo fell 0.7%. Bank of America (BAC), Dow stock Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS), which report next week, were down less than 1%.The banks' earnings will also come as expectations grow a little more conservative for trading revenue overall and loan growth. Red flags are flying in the auto loan sector as auto sales peter out, and March jobs figures also came in far below estimates."Commercial borrowers still need clarity from Washington on employee healthcare costs, regulation and tax reform," Keefe, Bruyette & Woods said in a research note on Monday. "So we think many commercial borrowers are on hold until they can get more certainty on these topics."Wall Street expects JPMorgan's first-quarter earnings per share to climb 13% to $1.52, with revenue rising 3% to $24.876 billion.As KBW noted Monday, JPMorgan at its investor day said it expected only a modest bump in trading results. The investment firm said there could be "some noise in the quarter" surrounding credit conditions due to delays in tax refunds. But it said the credit environment overall was likely "benign" and that residential mortgage trends were likely to remain solid.Investors will also be seeking any color from CEO Jamie Dimon on the economic and political climate in the U.S. and abroad. While U.S. banks have capitalized on a retreat from their European counterparts, the U.K.'s move to formally trigger an exit from the European Union could also create upheaval for the financial world.In JPMorgan's annual report, released last week, the bank said it was preparing for a hard exit from the U.K. The company also said it suspected there would "constant pressure" from the European Union "not to 'outsource' services to the United Kingdom but to continue to move people and capabilities into EU subsidiaries."The bank in that report also noted the rising sentiment against globalism. But it said that the U.S. trade agreement with Mexico helped guard the nation against populist anger. And it said "there is no inevitable or compelling reason that China and America have to clash," despite the trade issues between the two nations.The bank also remained optimistic about the U.S., but said "it is clear that something is wrong — and it's holding us back."Wall Street expects Wells Fargo's EPS to dip 2% to 97 cents, with revenue up 0.5% to $22.309 billion.Wells' results arrive on the heels of a six-month investigation by an oversight committee into the high-pressure sales practices that led to last year's fake-account debacle, in which the bank was accused of creating unauthorized accounts in consumers' names.The bank has settled claims over the matter and ended sales goals in its retail banking division — that is, the division that offers loans and credit cards to people. But it has struggled to regain consumer trust. Openings of consumer checking accounts fell 43% in February.The committee's findings, released Monday, found flaws in the bank's decentralized structure, which it said gave too much independence to leadership that was unwilling to address the problem and foisted blame elsewhere."It was common to blame employees who violated Wells Fargo's rules without analyzing what caused or motivated them to do so," the report said. "Effect was confused with cause."The bank also announced that it would claw back an additional $75 million total from John Stumpf, the bank's former CEO who stepped down last year, and Carrie Tolstedt, the former head of Wells' community banks.But KBW said the report unearthed nothing new, a positive for the bank, so the scandal could be less of a focus during the earnings call than in months past. The firm also said that Wells' margins could be better than its peers' average.Analysts expect Citigroup, which is more internationally exposed than its rivals, to get a 12% boost in EPS to $1.23. Revenue is expected to creep up 1% to $17.763 billion. Some in the analyst community have expressed concerns about Citi's potential vulnerability to growing protectionism."We believe Citi's emerging market exposure is manageable at this point because we fall in the camp that global reflation will occur and emerging markets risks will not emerge near term," KBW said in its report last week."In fact," KBW said, "should we see a meaningful pickup in global growth, then emerging market growth could accelerate and that would be a positive for Citi's revenues that are not fully reflected in our estimates."RELATED:Fed Hikes Interest Rates But Doesn't Signal Faster Tightening PaceBanks Among Few S&P 500 Beneficiaries As Higher Rates Loom

U.S. stock indexes battled to nice gains Monday afternoon, but something was missing: strong volume, which would've pointed to institutional support.The Nasdaq rose 0.6%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average added 0.6% and 0.7% respectively. The small cap Russell 2000 trailed with a 0.5% pop. Volume in the stock market today was running sharply lower on both major exchanges. Two of the biggest gainers among secondary indexes were the KBW Nasdaq Bank Index, up 1.1%, and the Philadelphia semiconductor index, up 0.9%.Among the big, money-center stocks, Wells Fargo (WFC) surged more than 2% as it bounced off its 200-day line. Morgan Stanley (MS) added 1.3%, on track to end a five-session losing streak. Morgan Stanley will report first quarter results Wednesday.Morgan Stanley gets a respectable 90 Composite Rating on a scale of 1 to 99 from IBD Stock Checkup. Homebuilder stocks, which have been rising in the industry group ranks, did well Monday. D.R. Horton (DHI) inched close to a 34.16 buy point, but volume was low and the stock couldn't quite clear the entry. D.R. Horton's base is first stage. A breakout from a first- or second-stage base is more likely to work than those from a later stage.Blue chips were up by a 14-1 ratio in the Dow industrial average. Nike (NKE) rose 1.6%, but volume was soft. Boeing (BA) was close behind with a 1.4% gain.The iShares Gold Trust (IAU) exchange traded fund slipped to a 0.1% loss. Going into Monday's session, the gold play had risen in nine of the past 10 sessions.RELATED:Netflix Earnings After The Close: What The Street ExpectsWhat The Stats Say About The Market's Next MoveHow To Track The General Market Direction: See The Big Picture

Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen sounded a slightly hawkish tone on Tuesday, warning about the risk of monetary policy becoming too accommodative.In her semiannual monetary report to Congress, Yellen told the Senate Banking Committee: "Waiting too long to remove accommodation would be unwise, potentially requiring the FOMC to eventually raise rates rapidly, which could risk disrupting financial markets and pushing the economy into recession.After the release of her remarks at 10 a.m., the Dow Jones Industrial Average shifted from fractional losses to slim gains on the stock market today. The 10-year Treasury yield jumped to 2.47%, rebounding over its 50-day line, while short-end Treasury yields also rose, along with the dollar.Shares of bank stocks, which could benefit from higher rates, pointed higher. Bank of America (BAC) rose 2.8% to its best levels since November 2008. Wells Fargo (WFC) advanced 1.6%, Citigroup (C) 1.5%. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) perked up 1.6%, hitting an all-time high. Goldman Sachs (GS) climbed 1.3%, near its late 2007 peak. Both JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs are components on the Dow industrials, which set a fresh record high on Tuesday.Yellen's overall tone was balanced and offered no clear indication of whether 2017 is likely to see two rate hikes, as markets currently expect, or three, as Fed member projections indicated in December.IBD'S TAKE: President Trump's fiscal plans may not have much of an impact on Federal Reserve policy this year. Wall Street increasingly sees any real impact of stimulus being pushed into 2018 and the White House hasn't even unveiled its phenomenal mystery tax-cut Plan B.Still, Yellen's language was a bit surprising after she spent most of last year talking about asymmetric risks being to the downside, since the Fed has little traditional ammunition with its key rate still near zero. On Tuesday, Yellen sounded more like she did in 2015, when the Fed wanted to be proactive to avoid getting too far behind the curve.Previously, Yellen has said that it's not clear the economy needs stimulus to reach full employment. She made clear that she wouldn't offer any advice to Congress except to use any stimulus to boost productivity and not ignore the longer-run budget problems.Despite analyst talk that Yellen put a March hike on the table, fed funds futures point to an 18% chance of a move next month, up from 13% on Monday. The odds of an early May hike inched up to nearly 41% from 36.5%. Markets are still betting on the first hike in June.RELATED:Dow Stocks JPMorgan, Goldman Rise As Fed Signals More HawkishnessFed Is In No Rush To Hike With Eyes On Trump Agenda

The stock market closed mixed Wednesday, with the Dow Jones industrial average lagging the major indexes.The Dow closed 0.2% lower while the S&P 500 edged up 0.1% and the Nasdaq composite gained less than 0.2%. The S&P and Nasdaq erased mild losses earlier in the day, continuing a pattern of mild price changes.Small caps lagged again, with the Russell 2000 dropping about 0.2%. Volume was moderately higher, according to early figures. Winners led losers by a 9-to-7 ratio on the NYSE and by 6-to-5 on the Nasdaq.After the close, cybersecurity company Qualys (QLYS) slid in extended trading. The company's fourth-quarter sales missed views and its guidance was weak. Chipmaker MaxLinear (MXL) also tumbled after hours. Its Q4 results beat estimates but the Q1 revenue forecast was light.There was some cheer for the struggling retail sector. Department stores, discount shops, apparel chains, restaurants and auto parts stores were among the 12 best-performing industry groups in today's market.Some retail stocks fell earlier Wednesday after President Trump took to Twitter to attack Nordstrom (JWN) for dropping his daughter Ivanka's fashion line. But Nordstrom shares rose in late trading and closed with a 4% increase.Nearly all eight stocks that make up the department-stores group were up, though they are barely starting to recover from 52-week lows or worse.The retail sector has deeper problems than Trump tweets or political boycotts. Brick-and-mortar stores continue to be pressured by Amazon.com (AMZN) and other online sellers.The mobile-home and RV industry also led, as Thor Industries (THO) broke out of a cup-with-handle base. The RV manufacturer surged past the 106.43 buy point and closed in buy range. But the base is a later-stage pattern, and volume was less than enthusiastic on the breakout. An analyst at Robert W. Baird & Co. upgraded Thor to outperform from neutral, citing optimism among dealers and upside potential on margins, according to TheFly.com.Steel, heavy-construction and some other cyclical stocks lagged. Banks and financials also were weak as bond yields continued to drop, threatening margins. Bank of America (BAC), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Wells Fargo (WFC) touched their 50-day lines, where they now test support.On Thursday, earnings are due out from Activision Blizzard (ATVI), Beazer Homes (BZH), Coca Cola (KO) and Cummins (CMI). Nvidia (NVDA), a chip stock that's been trying to break out, also announces results Thursday after the close.The most noteworthy economic report Thursday is the weekly jobless claims, which is released at 8:30 a.m. ET.RELATED:The President Finally Weighs In On Nordstrom's Ivanka Trump DumpBofA, Dow Stocks JPMorgan, Goldman Test Support As Yields Fall

Want to put Fidelity Investments' world-class research resources to work for your retirement accounts and your taxable portfolios? Of course you do.Knowing how the Boston-based asset management giant has deployed the assets of shareholders in its stock mutual funds and balanced funds can help you make decisions about your own buys and sells.For example, in the fourth quarter Fidelity trimmed its exposure to several big technology bellwether stocks. Not all Fidelity funds may act in lockstep, but overall the fund complex lightened its net share count in Facebook (FB) by 5.1%, according to Todd Rosenbluth, director of ETF & mutual fund research for CFRA, an independent research firm.Facebook is ranked No. 4 on IBD's Internet-Content industry group, thanks in part to a strong 91 Composite Rating from IBD and 87% average earnings per share growth over the past three quarters. 99 is the highest possible rating, which is on a scale from 1-99.Fidelity's Facebook holding is now at its lightest quarter-end level since the end of 2013, Rosenbluth says in a new report for MarketScope Advisor.Facebook has rallied 16% since the beginning in a year to an all-time high. Subsequent disclosures by Fidelity will reveal whether it's been a buyer of Facebook shares in the current period.The fund complex also trimmed its net share count in Google-owner Alphabet's C-class shares (GOOG) by 5.6% and its A-class shares (GOOGL) by 1.4%. Alphabet has rallied 6% so far this year. It faded after clearing the 816.78 buy point of a flat base on Jan. 23. It's retaken the buy point.Graphics chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) was a third tech big name to be trimmed by Fidelity. Fidelity also trimmed Salesforce.com (CRM), a provider of customer relationship management software.IBD'S TAKE: Nvidia ranks No. 1 in IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group, buoyed by a solid-gold 99 Comp Rating and six straight quarters of EPS growth acceleration. For details, check the stock's vital signs at IBD's Stock Checkup.Still, tech remained Fidelity's biggest sector, accounting for 26% of the fund family's shareholders' money. That was an increase from Sept. 30's 24% and June 30's 23% weighting.And many Fidelity funds, including some of its largest, remained owners of stock in which the overall complex made net trims.For instance, now-$35.3 billion Fidelity Growth Company Fund (FDGRX) held Alphabet, Facebook, Microsoft, Nvidia and Salesforce.com in its top 10 at year-end.And there were several tech names in which Fidelity made net increases in its share counts during Q4.Fidelity boosted its share count in software giant Microsoft (MSFT) by 9.3% to 148 million shares. That was the highest share count since the end of 2014, Rosenbluth wrote.That was the highest share count since the end of 2014, Rosenbluth wrote."A few other stocks that had double-digit percentage share increases include Autodesk (ADSK)," Rosenbluth told IBD, referring to the developer of computer-aided design software applications.Financials were Fidelity's second-largest sector, with 15% of shareholders' assets. That increase took place as Fidelity increased its exposure to some big U.S. banks.Bank of America (BAC), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Wells Fargo (WFC) all saw double-digit percentage share count growth, Rosenbluth wrote. He added, "CFRA thinks investor optimism for banks improved amid expectations for higher interest rates and regulatory reform."President Trump and Congress are widely expected to lighten the regulatory restrictions on some banks.In addition, Fidelity made a double-digit percentage increase in its share count in Capital One Financial (COF).The $414.3 million Fidelity Blue Chip Value (FBCVX) held Alphabet, JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo in its top 10 at year end.Fidelity had a 9% weight in industrials as of the end of Q4. Fidelity managers made a 53% net addition to their share count in aerospace and defense contractor Northrop Grumman (NOC) in the quarter. They added 6.7% to their shares in General Electric (GE).Comcast (CMCSA) and Verizon (VZ) were two stocks in which Fidelity managers made double-digit share increases.Tech was not the only space in which Fidelity funds made cuts. Fidelity managers made double-digit decreases to telecom titan AT&T (T), energy explorer and producer Chevron (CVX), medical products maker Medtronic (MDT) and to athletic apparel, footwear and equipment maker Nike (NKE).Each of those decreases appears vindicated at this early point following the quarter. Comp Ratings for each of those stocks current range from an anemic 27 for Chevron to Nike's 59.All of Rosenbluth's data applies to Fidelity's 232 stock and balanced funds (mixtures of stocks and bonds), which together hold nearly $1 trillion in shareholder assets, according to Morningtstar Inc.Fidelity runs an additional 70 funds that hold bonds or commodities, accounting for an additional $233 billion in shareholder money.RELATED:P-s-s-st! Here's What Fidelity Has Been Buying And Selling

XPresident Trump's directionless policy agenda and his bear hug of dovish Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen are wreaking havoc on market expectations, with an assist from international uncertainty.The 10-year Treasury yield on Thursday sank to 2.23%, a level not seen since the week after Trump's election. Wells Fargo (WFC) tumbled 3.3% to its worst close since Nov. 9, the first day of the postelection rally, after reporting weaker-than-expected revenue. Dow component JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Citigroup (C) cleared analyst estimates with their first-quarter reports, but saw modest early gains turn into losses of about 1%, with both stocks stuck below their 50-day averages.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 index both appeared headed for a third straight lower close as weakness continued to extend beyond financials to infrastructure stocks, another group that soared on the Trump agenda. The Dow, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq composite are all trading below their 50-day moving averages.Dow construction equipment giant Caterpillar (CAT) slipped 1.9%, while steel maker U.S. Steel (X) tumbled 5.9%. U.S. Steel crashed 10% on Wednesday, its worst loss in nearly a year, as steel makers and miners plunged with iron ore prices.IBD'S TAKE: While the stock market rally has stalled out in the U.S., emerging markets stocks are rallying. Learn why they're rising, and which emerging markets are outperforming their peers.This week's action appears to represent the biggest reversal of the Trump effect to date. The reversal is more obvious in the Treasury market, where yields have fallen to their lowest levels in almost five months, than in equity markets that are still not too far from the lofty postelection peaks. Perhaps the clearest evidence of the change is visible in Fed rate expectations.Despite the Fed's stated intention to raise rates twice more this year and also to begin unwinding its balance sheet by a change in its reinvestment policy, which represents a third tightening, markets are now only pricing one more hike this year, according to the CME Group FedWatch tool. What's more, the second rate hike isn't seen until at least March of 2018. That's basically where expectations stood before Trump's election led the Fed to take a hawkish shift.Trump's announcement this week that he is putting repeal of ObamaCare back at the top of his agenda, even though prospects for success look negligible, seem to have cemented doubts that Trump will be able to enact pro-growth tax cuts and infrastructure. That's a bitter pill for investors who had been banking on big corporate tax cuts in the Trump era.The White House also revealed this week that it is undertaking a broad search for options to offset the cost of tax reform. While the possibility of success can't be completely ruled out, the outcome will likely hinge on whether Trump can get near-unanimous support among GOP senators for a big deficit-increasing tax cut at a time of high and rising debt levels.The latest blow to Fed expectations and banks came when Trump told the Wall Street Journal in a Wednesday interview that he liked low interest rates and would consider reappointing Yellen as chair at the end of her term in February 2018. There are three Fed governor openings that Trump has to fill, and there's now substantial doubt that he'll appoint any hawks. That's quite a surprise, considering that Trump said Yellen's low rates had created a "big fat, ugly bubble" during the campaign. Prospects for faster growth and higher rates that allow for a wider margin between lending and borrowing rates had made banks among the big winners of the Trump rally.RELATED:Stock Rally Tiring As Trump Policy Agenda Runs In CirclesThis 'Explosive' Protectionist Signal From Trump Looks Like A Dud

XStocks stumbled out of their morning gains on Thursday and slid to a weak finish as banks and resource companies led the late declines.The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 skidded 0.7% each. The Nasdaq Composite fell 0.5%. Small caps outpaced the losses, with the Russell 2000 ending down 1%.The Dow industrials ended the week down 1%, the S&P 500 was off 1.1% and the Nasdaq had a 1.2% loss. It was the first weekly close below the 50-day moving average for all three indexes since November.Automakers made the day's strongest gain among industries as Tesla (TSLA) swerved 2% higher in afternoon trading. The maker of luxury battery-powered cars announced it would launch its first tractor-trailer-type truck in September. The move put Tesla shares 6% above a 287.49 buy point from a cup base.Makers of fiber-optic networking gear continued their rally, led by Applied Optoelectronics' (AAOI) 11% gain. The move left the stock still below its 10-week moving average, and down 25% from its March 27 high after two weeks of brisk selling.Biotechs posted a strong session that sent La Jolla Pharmaceutical (LJPC) and Axovant Science (AXON) each up about 10%. Axovant streamed 45% higher for the week, after announcing Monday that former Medivation CEO David Hung would take over the chief executive's seat as Vivek Ramaswamy moves up to lead Axovant's parent, Roivant Sciences.Steel- and oil-related industry groups turned in eight of Thursday's 10 worst performances among industries, despite fairly flat oil prices, with West Texas Intermediate closing at 53.18 — up nearly 2% for the week. Chevron (CVX) clocked the largest decline among Dow industrials, down nearly 3%.Among the big banks reporting first-quarter earnings, JPMorgan (JPM) took a 1.2% loss, Citgroup (C) dropped 0.8% and Wells Fargo (WFC) tumbled by more than 3%.China's TAL Education Group (TAL) topped the IBD 50, rising 4%. The gain left shares flat for the week, stretching its chart to a four-weeks-tight pattern and maintaining a 108.70 buy point.Federal government offices will be open Friday, with economic releases expected from the Labor and Commerce departments at 8:30 a.m. and 10 a.m. ET. The stock market will be closed.RELATED:Netflix, D.R. Horton Earnings: Do Call-Option Trades Make Sense? Fiber Optic Group Stages Easter Rally, But Is It Due For Consolidation?

JPMorgan Chase (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon indicated he was willing to give the Trump administration more time to carry out its economic agenda, while top executives at the largest U.S. bank by assets and at Citigroup (C) grappled with the potential revival of Depression-era regulations.The remarks come after the failure by the White House and GOP-controlled Congress to replace the Affordable Care Act raised questions about when the administration could execute on tax reform and deregulation."You all should expect, as a given, that when you have a new president, and they get going, that the nine months after the 100 days is gonna be a sausage-making period," Dimon told analysts on JPMorgan's first-quarter earnings call. "There will be ups and downs, wins and losses, stuff like that."But he said Trump's plans for tax cuts, looser regulations and infrastructure spending could help all Americans if enacted. CFO Marianne Lake said a business-friendly agenda would eventually translate into loan growth, which she said has turned quieter recently.Some analysts had expressed concern that commercial borrowers could be more cautious as policy goals risk getting mangled in Congress.Dimon said not to "overreact" to issues surrounding loan growth, saying companies had other options for expansion. He noted JPMorgan's credit-card segment looked "OK,"  while mortgages saw obvious effects from higher rates and that auto loans are getting hit by auto sales, which flagged in March.Overall, Dimon remained upbeat on the economy."U.S. consumers and businesses are healthy overall and with pro-growth initiatives and improving collaboration between government and business, the U.S. economy can continue to improve," he said in a statement.Meanwhile, despite hopes for bank deregulation under Trump, White House economic advisor Gary Cohn reportedly expressed support for something akin to a revival of the Glass-Steagall Act, the 1930s law that separated commercial and investment banking that was repealed in 1999.In response, Lake said JPMorgan's diversified business model was "a source of strength" for the company and financial markets during the financial crisis. She also said separating the bank's businesses doesn't feel "consistent with a level playing field and pro-growth agenda in the U.S."Meanwhile, Citigroup's CFO, John Gerspach, also said he wanted more clarity about where the administration stood on Glass-Steagall, whose repeal, many argue, contributed to the gutting banks experienced during the crisis.Shares of JPMorgan reversed lower as falling Treasury yields squeezed the yield curve, sending the bank's stock down 1.2% on the stock market today. Citigroup dipped 0.8%, while Wells Fargo (WFC) tumbled 3.3%. Goldman Sachs (GS), which reports next week, lost 1.1%. Bank of America (BAC), also reporting next week, fell 1.4%.JPMorgan's Q1 earnings per share jumped 22% to $1.65, above estimates for $1.52. Revenue rose 6% to $25.59 billion, topping views for $24.876 billion. Investment banking revenue jumped 34%, helped by strong IPO activity. Markets revenue rose 13%, with equities up 2% and fixed-income revenue up 17%.March ended up being better than expected, reflecting "some recovery in volatility," Lake said, with market activity picking up in response to European elections and the stronger interest-rate outlook in the U.S.Meanwhile, Citigroup said EPS jumped 23% to $1.35, beating estimates for $1.23. Revenue rose 3% to $18.1 billion, above forecasts for $17.757 billion. Investment banking revenue surged 39% to $1.21 billion. Markets revenue grew 18%, with equities up 10% and fixed income climbing 19% to $3.62 billion.Wells Fargo's EPS rose 1% to $1, beating views for 97 cents, while revenue of $22 billion missed views for $22.315 billion. Auto loan originations sank 29% to $5.5 billion on tighter underwriting standards. Home loan originations plunged to $44 billion from $72 billion in prior quarter.Bank stocks have slipped from their postelection highs, and Trump's comments Wednesday about the dollar being "too strong" could weigh on Treasury rates.However, JJ Kinahan, chief market strategist at TD Ameritrade, said banks could hit a "sweet spot" as the Federal Reserve gets more bullish on raising interest rates."What I mean by that is, with the potential for rates to rise … and the historically low rates we're still in the middle of, they may start to see even more demand for loans as people want to lock in the rates for a longer period of time," he said. The better trends in equities could also bode well for the market overall, he said.Still, he cautioned that JPMorgan's decision to set aside more reserves for consumer credit was something to keep an eye on. Wells Fargo's weaker results in its large mortgage business in Q1 could also be a concern as it tries to repair its reputation following a massive sham-account scandal.If nothing else, he noted, the bank still managed to beat EPS estimates."In a turbulent internal environment, they've still delivered overall," Kinahan said.

Bank stocks like Dow components JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS) got a lift Tuesday after Fed Chair Janet Yellen appeared to leave open the possibility to a rate hike in March, suggested the economy is now at full employment, and warned waiting too long for a rate hike would be "unwise."But she said it's too early to know how the new administration's policies would play out and how they would affect the economy, according to prepared remarks for a hearing before the Senate Committee on Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs.Yellen did, however, say that the unemployment rate was "now in line" with the median of Fed policymakers' "estimates of its longer-run normal level." Last month, Yellen said unemployment was near that level. That may signal the Fed will take a more hawkish stance to prevent the job market from overheating and stoking inflation.Shares of JPMorgan rose 1.6% to 89.56 on the stock market today, hitting a record intraday high. Goldman Sachs rose 1.3% to 249.46, the highest since its all-time highset in 2007 and still within buy range from a 245.67 buy point. Bank of America (BAC), whose more U.S.-centric operations mean it stands to gain more from higher rates, climbed 2.8% to its best levels since late 2008.Citigroup (C) added 1.5%, after reclaiming support at its 50-day line a day earlier. Morgan Stanley (MS) gained 1.7%. Wells Fargo (WFC) rallied 1.6% to 57.98, clearing a 57.43 buy point.Two-year and 10-year Treasury yields, which influence the value of different types of loans and offer a window into investors' inflation expectations, also rose.IBD'S TAKE: Bank stocks like JPMorgan, Goldman, Bank of America and Citigroup have risen on hopes President Trump and the GOP-controlled Congress will cut regulations and taxes while also making a bigger push to improve U.S. infrastructure. Banks are among the few stocks that benefit when the Fed raises rates to keep borrowing and growth in check.  "At our upcoming meetings, the Committee will evaluate whether employment and inflation are continuing to evolve in line with these expectations, in which case a further adjustment of the federal funds rate would likely be appropriate," Yellen said in her written testimony."As I noted on previous occasions," she later added, "waiting too long to remove accommodation would be unwise, potentially requiring the FOMC to eventually raise rates rapidly, which could risk disrupting financial markets and pushing the economy into recession."The remarks come after Fed policymakers opted earlier this month to leave target range for the federal funds rate unchanged. The central bank in December raised the rate — which determines interest charged on overnight loans banks make to one another meet the Fed's daily reserve requirements — and forecast three rate hikes this year, up from two.RELATED:JPMorgan, Charles Schwab, Goldman Jump On Trump's Regulatory Rollback

Goldman Sachs (GS), which helped send the Dow Jones industrial average above 20,000 last week, fell below its 50-day line and secondary buy point Tuesday, while JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Morgan Stanley (MS) are testing their 50-day averages amid a market sell-off and concerns on global trade under the Trump administration.Bank stocks surged immediately after the election on hopes for higher interest rates, lighter regulations and faster economic growth. They leveled off in early December but picked up some momentum last week as positive earnings reports lifted investor sentiment. But Goldman shares tumbled 2% to 229.32 on the stock market today, as bond yields also fell, weighing on rates that banks charge on certain balances. The stock tested its 50-day line last week, then bounced higher, representing a follow-on entry point.JPMorgan lost 1.6% and Morgan Stanley 1.5% as they neared their 50-day lines. Bank of America (BAC) shares slid 1.35%, still comfortably above their 50-day.Citigroup (C) shares were off 1.4% to 55.83, falling further below its 50-day. The bank is especially exposed to international markets, which were shaken after President Donald Trump announced his travel ban on people from Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria, and Yemen. Citi also announced Tuesday that it would merge its media and telecom investment banking units.More U.S.-focused lenders like Wells Fargo (WFC) were less affected, though hopes are fading for a massive infrastructure-spending bill, and the growth hopes that would've come with it, as Democrats in Congress take a harder line against cooperating with Trump amid the travel ban backlash.Shares of Wells Fargo ticked up 0.45% on Tuesday.RELATED: Fed Preview: Policymakers Can't Figure Out Trump, So They Won't TryBreakout Watch: This Bank Stock Outranks BofA, Wells Fargo, JPMorgan

Investors' money was drawn to Vanguard in 2016 like paper clips to a powerful magnet.Investors were attracted by low costs and many passively run funds that hugged the performances of their benchmarks. The result: Shareholders favored Vanguard with net inflow to its mutual funds that vastly outpaced its rival firms'. Vanguard lured in a net $182.997 billion to its mutual funds, according to Morningstar Inc.All other mutual fund complexes with inflow — there were 314 if them — had combined net inflow of $151 billion.Another 511 complexes had net outflow.The closest single fund family to Vanguard was Dimensional Fund Advisors, which pulled in a relatively paltry net $21.417 billion.Dimensional runs $316.07 billion in assets. Vanguard runs nearly nine times more money in its mutual funds: $2.793 trillion.The flow is the movement of money in and out of open-end mutual funds, excluding money market funds and funds of funds.Several of the industry's largest fund families suffered the heaviest net outflows in 2016.Franklin Templeton Investments (BEN), with $378.66 billion in mutual fund assets, hemorrhaged $43.23 billion in net outflow, the industry's heaviest net redemptions last year.No. 2 in net redemptions was Fidelity Investments, with $1.22 trillion in total net assets in funds, which lost $24.48 billion in net outflow.Bond specialist Pimco, with $286.53 billion in total net assets, had the fourth-most net outflow: $16.83 billion.Two more spots back was Wells Fargo Funds — owned by Wells Fargo (WFC) — which has $92.04 billion in assets and had 2016 $15.45 billion in net redemptions.For Vanguard, it was the third year in a row of increased net inflow to its mutual funds. Net inflow has more than doubled since 2012's $87.069 billion. It was $75.753 billion in 2013.Vanguard, based in Malvern, Pa., has also had a flood of net inflow to its exchange traded funds, totaling $94.26 billion.The combined net inflow of $277.257 billion was massively more net inflow to mutual funds plus ETFs in 2016 than its rivals, according to a recent IBD report.That report also detailed the division between flows to and from the actively run mutual funds and ETFs in each fund family and passive funds.The next largest combined fund-ETF net inflow was $107.822 billion to iShares, the ETF group run by asset management titan BlackRock (BLK). But BlackRock alone bled a net outflow of $8.414 billion — basically, from its mutual funds. So the overall BlackRock/iShares complex had a combined net inflow of $99.431 billion.The third-highest mutual fund-ETF combined inflow went to SPDR State Street Global Advisors, which pulled in a net $54.694 billion.Whether it was flow just to mutual funds or to funds plus ETFs, shareholders largely had low costs on their minds. "By far, 2016 belonged to Vanguard," Morningstar editor Tom Lauricella and senior analyst Alina Lamy noted in a recent report. "The low-cost juggernaut dominated the flows landscape to a remarkable degree."The report noted that Fidelity's buildup of index funds in recent years enabled it "to offset some of the bleeding on the active (management) side of (funds) with $37 billion in index-tracking inflows."
RELATED:Guess Which Stock Mutual Funds Drew The Most Money In '16Vanguard's CEO McNabb Describes How You Should Invest In 2017

Dow components JPMorgan (JPM), Goldman Sachs (GS) and other big banks fell Wednesday, testing key support as the 10-year Treasury yield continued its slide.However, the dip in bank stocks comes as analysts expect fatter payouts from banks in the era of President Trump.JPMorgan shares fell 0.9% to 85.96, while Bank of America (BAC) lost 1% to 22.67 and Wells Fargo (WFC) dropped 1.3% to close at 55.63 on the stock market today. Goldman dipped 0.6%. All of those stocks are off session lows as they found support near at their key 50-day lines.Morgan Stanley (MS) retreated 2.2% to 43.91, still maintaining a bit more distance from that line. Citigroup (C) slid 1.5% to 56.32, treading below its 50-day line since January.The yield on the 10-year Treasury fell five basis points to 2.35%, near their lowest levels of the year and extending a slide on Monday and Tuesday.The 10-year Treasury yield influences the rate on mortgages and other types of debt, and has eased off highs reached in December. Wider yield spreads between short- and long-term rates boost banks' net interest margins.Yields rise when expectations of inflation and economic growth increase.Bond yields surged after President Trump's election, with investors betting that tax cuts, infrastructure investments, and a shearing away of regulations would cause the economy to heat up, push up wages and prices, and force the Fed to hike rates more frequently to keep growth in check.Banks and other financial stocks got yet another lift last week after Trump took executive action ordering a review of the Dodd-Frank post-crisis financial-reform measures — although any changes would have to come from Congress. He also ordered halt to a rule, set to take hold in April, that would require retirement advisors put their clients' needs above others on the job.Morgan Stanley analyst Betsy Graseck, in a research note on Monday, said an easing of regulatory pressure could also help open the taps for banks' capital return plans.Morgan Stanley said that due to a less stressful round of stress tests — the annual evaluation of U.S. banks' ability to keep lending and operating amid potential convulsions to the economy — dividends from the banks it covers could rise 8% and gross buybacks 40% from the third quarter of this year to Q2 of next year.Graseck added that "we expect buybacks will increase over next several CCAR cycles, along with more capital allocated to lending and banking activities."IBD'S TAKE: Even though banks have leveled off from their postelection surge, they're still among the only stocks to benefit from higher interest rates. CCAR refers to the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review stress test, which assesses banks' capital levels and the soundness of banks' capital planning, including shareholder returns. The other test is known as the Dodd-Frank stress test, which evaluates whether banks have enough of a financial cushion to withstand a shock to the system.The guidelines for the latest stress tests, released Friday, exempt 21 banks from the portion of the tests that evaluates their capital plans. This year's "severely adverse scenario" for the tests also excludes negative short-term Treasury rates.She estimates that the banks she covers have some $120 billion in "excess capital," led by $29.1 billion held by Citigroup. Bank of America had $21.2 billion in excess capital, while JPMorgan had $19.7 billion.While any changes to Dodd-Frank might not occur until next year, Morgan Stanley said it believed "significant change on the enforcement of existing regulations can come from the new agency heads who are likely to be appointed over the next 18 months."A new vice chair of supervision at the Fed "could drive a more quantitatively oriented approval process to the stress test," the firm noted.Results from the stress tests will likely be released closer to the summer.RELATED:U.S. Banking Giants Gain As Deutsche Bank, European Financials Teeter

Shares in Wells Fargo also reversed to close down 0.4% to 54.98.RELATED:JPMorgan, Goldman Sachs Lead Bank Stock Rally, But Not For LongCitigroup hiked its price target on Teradyne to 39 from 32."We are increasing our target price on higher collaborative robots (cobots) sales and multiple expansion," said Citigroup analyst Atif Malik in a report. Deutsche Bank set a price target of 28 on Tenet, and a PT of 145 on United Health Services. The brokerage set a price target of 183 on United Health Group, and PTs of 84 on Centene and 172 on Cigna.
