President-elect Donald Trump slammed the high cost of drugs and the F-35 once again, pressuring related stocks. But General Motors (GM), Amazon (AMZN), consumers and small businesses are bullish. Apple (AAPL) hit a buy point, while JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and other bank stocks reported earnings.Donald Trump continued to go after companies and industries and he didn't talk much about tax cuts or other stimulus, but the major averages held up well. The Nasdaq rose 1% to all-time highs. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.4% and the S&P 500 0.1%. Drug and biotech stocks tumbled on Trump's pledge to go after high prices. But Apple broke out of a base, joining Alphabet (GOOGL) and Netflix (NFLX). Bank stocks rose modestly Friday after JPMorgan, BofA and Wells Fargo reported earnings and Treasury yields rebounded.President-elect Trump doubled-down on his criticism of high drug prices, saying Wednesday that the industry is "getting away with murder." He said that "new bidding procedures" are needed, suggesting support for legislation traditionally favored by Democrats, not Republicans. Drug and biotech stocks sold off hard on the comments. Trump also returned to attacking the costly Lockheed Martin F-35 fighter jet, saying he'll save billions of dollars as he pushes more competition. Lockheed, which has said that it is reducing per-jet costs after years of overruns and delays, said that it's promised to "aggressively" reduce F-35 expenses. Lockheed's CEO met with Trump on Friday, their second such meeting since the election. Lockheed rose modestly Friday, but fell 1.3% for the week.RELATED:Trump Says Drugmakers 'Getting Away With Murder', Cites F-35, Ford, FiatTrump Vows Fighter-Jet Competition, 'Big Things' On Lockheed F-35Three banking giants kicked off earnings season for the sector on Friday with differing results. JPMorgan Chase beat on earnings and revenue while Bank of America (BAC) topped on earnings but fell short on revenue. Wells Fargo (WFC), still dealing with the fallout from its false accounts scandal, missed on the top and bottom line. All three rose modestly on Friday.RELATED:JPMorgan Beats, Bank Of America Q4 Results Mixed; Wells Fargo MissesThe IBD/TIPP Economic Optimism Index rose 0.8 point in January to 55.6, a fresh 10-year high after soaring 3.4 points in December. Americans have become much more upbeat since the presidential election, as stock markets have soared on hopes that Donald Trump will cut taxes and regulation and ramp up infrastructure spending to boost economic growth. Meanwhile, the NFIB's small business optimism index spiked in December to a 12-year best. A net 50% of small firms see business conditions improving vs. -7% in October.RELATED:Economic Optimism Hits New 10-Year High As Trump Rally ContinuesTrump Bump: Small Business Optimism Soars To 12-Year HighGeneral Motors sees 2017 EPS of $6-$6.50 up from its 2016 target of $5.50-$6.00. Analysts have expected $6.01 for 2016, but then a decline to $5.71 this year. GM, which recently reported a surprisingly strong 10% gain in U.S. sales for December, also added $5 billion to its stock buyback program. Ford, meanwhile, added $200 million — or 5 cents a share — to its regular quarterly dividend. Ford sees earnings falling this year amid heavy investments, but "improved profitability" in 2018. GM shares rose 3.75% for the week, hitting their best levels in nearly two years. Ford fell 1%.The EPA accused Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) of cheating diesel emissions standards in some 104,000 recent trucks and SUVs. Fiat Chrysler denied any wrongdoing, but shares fell 10% Thursday after hitting a record high earlier that day. Earlier in the week, Volkswagen (VLKAY) pleaded guilty in relation to its diesel emissions testing, agreeing to pay a $4.3 billion fine. Prosecutors charged 5 VW officials living in Germany.Tesla Motors (TSLA) hired two Apple execs, one of whom will head up the automaker's Autopilot software efforts. CEO Elon Musk once mocked Apple, which has its own unconfirmed "Project Titan" electric car initiative, as a "Tesla graveyard." Tesla also sketched out how it will charge fees for using its Supercharger fees, but only for drivers who order after Jan. 15. Tesla shares rose 3.8% to seven-month highs.RELATED:General Motors Soars On Bullish Earnings Forecast; Ford Looks To 2018The Federal Trade Commission is expected to approve the drugstore merger between Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) and Rite Aid (RAD) before the Obama administration ends on Jan. 20, the New York Post reported, citing sources. Walgreens announced the $9-a-share deal back in October 2015. Shares of Walgreens rose 0.9% while Rite Aid climbed 3.1% to 8.66. Smaller rival Fred's (FRED), which is buying 865 Rite Aid stores as part of the effort to ease antitrust concerns, fell 8.6%.RELATED:Walgreens-Rite Aid Merger OK Seen Before Trump Takes OfficeFresh off another strong holiday season for the e-commerce giant, Amazon said it would expand its "full-time, full-benefit" U.S.-based workforce to 280,000 by mid-2018, from 180,000 last year. Amazon's workforce was 30,000 in 2011. Amazon is adding positions "from engineers and software developers to those seeking entry-level positions and on-the-job training." Amazon's gain is likely to come at the expense of traditional brick-and-mortar retailers and other rivals. Amazon rose 2.7% for the week, closing in on all-time highs.RELATED:Amazon Plants A 'We're Hiring' Sign To Reach 100,000 New JobsThe holidays were rough on retailers not named Amazon.com (AMZN), as online shopping and subdued store traffic hung heavy. But it wasn't all bad: Morgan Stanley analysts called Lululemon (LULU), which lifted the low end of guidance, a holiday "standout" following its appearance of the annual ICR conference. Francesca's (FRAN) and Genesco (GCO) now expect results toward the upper end of previously announced guidance, and Ollie's Bargain Outlets (OLLI) raised its outlook. Wells Fargo analysts like Lululemon and off-price retailers such as TJX Cos. (TJX), but said the said the retail sector is generally almost "uninvestable."Retail sales rose 0.6% in December, slightly below views, and just 0.2% excluding autos. Nonstore sales, including Amazon, led the way while department stores struggled.Oil prices fell hard early in the week, then bounced back somewhat as traders try to balance current and future U.S. production gains against OPEC output curbs. But crude futures closed down 3% to $52.37 a barrel, their biggest drop since early November. North American oil companies' spending on exploration and production will rise 27% this year after falling the prior two years, but higher oilfield service costs will account for some of the increase, according to Barclays analysts. Hess Corp. (HES) and Parsley Energy (PE) said they would boost spending this year. The EIA said U.S. crude stockpiles increased by 4.1 million barrels, well above the 1.2 million-barrel increase analysts expected. U.S. production rose 1.9% to 8.95 million barrels per day, the biggest increase in 20 months, with total production level hitting an eight-month high. Russia and Kazakhstan are cutting back output and Saudi Arabia has reduced deliveries to Asia as part of the OPEC deal, but Iraq is reportedly trying to boost exports even further.RELATED: U.S. Oil Companies To Unleash Spending But Costs Will Rise TooOil Prices Near $50 Floor As Iraqi Exports Raise OPEC Deal DoubtsU.S. Crude Stockpiles, Production Soar, But Prices Rise As OPEC CutsOPEC, China Lift Oil Prices But U.S. Producers Ready To PounceDelta forecast flat to 2% unit revenue growth for the first quarter, after cheap fuel and heightened competition sank the metric for two years. The company said margin pressure from higher fuel and labor costs "is likely to peak" in Q1, but that margins should begin expanding by the second half of the year. Delta also said that Donald Trump's victory has already boosted demand and hopes a Trump administration will bring opportunities for tax and regulatory reform, infrastructure improvement, and greater consideration of its case against Middle East rivals. The big U.S. airlines say those carriers have expanded in the U.S. on their governments' dime, an accusation those carriers have denied. Meanwhile, American Airlines (AAL), United Airlines (UAL) and Southwest (LUV) also lifted their Q1 unit-revenue forecasts.RELATED:Delta Air Lines Sees Market Share Pressure Over AtlanticShares in Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI) soared 31% on Thursday to a record high after the maker of optical communications devices preannounced Q4 results with both revenues and EPS exceeding expectations.  Internet firms are upgrading data centers to 100 gigabit-per-second technology. Analysts said Applied Optoelectronics has been boosted by demand from Amazon, Microsoft (MSFT) and Facebook (FB).Demand from China has also been driving revenue growth for fiber-optic component makers, but there's been speculation demand has softened. Oclaro stock rose after it said business in China has been strong as normal at a Needham & Co. conference while shares in Acacia Communications (ACIA) fell on more cautious comments.RELATED:Applied Optoelectronics Booms On Facebook, Amazon Data Center BuildsAt the 35th annual JPMorgan Healthcare Conference, Merck (MRK) immunotherapy drug Keytruda was accepted for priority review in combination with chemotherapy to treat lung cancer. Celgene raised its 2017 earnings guidance. Ariad Pharmaceuticals (ARIA) takeout by Japanese Takeda Pharmaceuticals for $24 per share. and Medicines Co. (MDCO) announced strong interim data on an LDL buster different enough to avoid a patent battle with No. 1 biotech Amgen (AMGN). But Trump's harsh rhetoric vs. the drug industry and prices chilled optimism.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) forecast fourth-quarter EPS and revenue below Wall Street expectations. However, improvements in same-store sales trends helped lift shares during the week. Jack in the Box (JACK) said at the 2017 ICR Conference that its late-night delivery customers, which in San Francisco can have the burger chain's food delivered through a partnership with DoorDash, were more "forgiving" on food quality. Burgers and fries tend not to hold up as well in takeout containers as tacos — Jack's best-selling item — and pizza. Other restaurants are assessing how takeout services from GrubHub (GRUB), DoorDash, Uber Eats and others fit into their business. Gaming-and-sports bar chain Dave & Buster's (PLAY) said it provided an experience that "can't be duplicated at home," while Domino's Pizza (DPZ) touted its digital ordering platform and international growth potential.RELATED:Chipotle Warns, But Stock Jumps On Same-Store Sales TrendJack In The Box Finds A 'Forgiving' Late-Night-Delivery CustomerChip foundry Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSM) earned 61 cents per American depositary receipt, up 42% year over year, on sales of nearly $8.25 billion, up 32%. Analysts expected 59 cents and $8.16 billion for TSMC's Q4. But for the current Q1, TSMC sees revenue of $7.44 billion at the midpoint of its guidance. It did not give an earnings target. Wall Street has been modeling TSMC to earn 51 cents per ADR, up 34% year over year, on sales of $7.67 billion, up 25%, in the March quarter. CFO Lora Ho sees weaker demand in Q1 in part due to "above seasonal supply chain inventory at the end of 2016."RELATED:Taiwan Semiconductor Dips On Cautious Q1 Guidance

Wells Fargo (WFC) failed for the second time this year to persuade U.S. regulators that it could unwind its business in the event of a failure without wreaking havoc on the broader financial system.The rejection marks another setback for the lender still reeling from a scandal over phony customer accounts and means it's now banned from buying non-bank companies or setting up international units. While deeming Wells Fargo's so-called living will inadequate, the Federal Reserve and Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. also said Tuesday that JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC), Bank of New York Mellon (BK) and State Street (STT) had fixed deficiencies with their plans. The agencies had rejected all those banks' documents in April.Wells Fargo gets another shot at repairing its problems, the regulators said. But if it fails to do so by March 31, assets in its broker-dealer and non-bank units will be capped. Under the Dodd-Frank Act, the lender will have another two years to convince the agencies it's on the right track before the regulators can step in and force it to break off pieces of its business.The San Francisco-based lender becomes the first institution to trigger the opening part of one of the most potent powers regulators were granted in Dodd-Frank: authorities that could eventually force a bank to restructure. The rejection adds to a difficult year for an embattled Wells Fargo, still trying to remedy a scandal over its employees setting up as many as 2 million accounts without customers' approval. The bank already faced restrictions on acquisitions as part of that settlement with regulators.Wells Fargo shares have climbed 2.7% this year, the worst performance in the 24-company KBW Bank Index. Shares fell about 1% in late trading on the stock market today after closing up 0.1% at 55.84.When its living will was first rejected earlier this year, Wells Fargo was hammered for "material errors." In a plan re-filed on Oct. 1, the bank detailed what it had done to fix its deficiencies. The publicly available section of the revised plan said it sold some non-core businesses to make the bank easier to handle in a failure. The lender also said it increased capital and liquid assets to be better able to absorb losses.In Tuesday's second failure, the bank didn't remedy problems with how it has organized its various "legal entities" and how it shares its services among units, according to the Fed and FDIC.The living-wills exercise was a key element of Dodd-Frank, the regulatory overhaul prompted by the 2008 financial crisis. The collapse of Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc. that year showed what could happen when huge, complex financial firms go through a chaotic bankruptcy. The resolution plan process was meant to ensure big banks can be taken down quickly without threatening the economy. Large U.S. banks must persuade at least one of the banking agencies that their living wills are viable, and the industry has faced numerous setbacks in its submissions.The battle over the massive resolution plans has raged for years between regulators and the nation's biggest banks. It came to a head in April, when the five lenders were sent back to the drawing board. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and Morgan Stanley were both faulted by only one of the agencies nine months ago, while Citigroup Inc. got through largely unscathed.As the other big banks prepare for their next living-will deadline on July 1, the four cleared Tuesday by regulators can breathe a sigh of relief that they "adequately remediated deficiencies."

JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and other top banks picked up steam Wednesday immediately after Federal Reserve policymakers upped their forecast for interest-rate hikes that could take place next year, but then gave up some gains or reversed lower.The Fed on Wednesday said it expects three rate hikes next year, up from the two it forecast in September. The central bank also raised its target range for the federal funds rate to 0.5%-0.75%, from 0.25%-0.5%, as was expected.JPMorgan closed virtually flat, dropping 3 cents to 84.73 on the stock market today after rising as high as 86.12 soon after the fed announcement. Bank of America rose 0.3% while Citigroup (C) lost 0.6%. Wells Fargo (WFC) dropped 2%.Goldman Sachs (GS) edged up 0.6%, while Morgan Stanley (MS) added 0.7%.IBD'S TAKE: The prospect of fewer regulations under a Trump administration has sent bank stocks higher. Trump's announcement that he would focus on developing the nation's infrastructure has also lifted steel stocks. When the Fed increases its interest rates, banks can, in turn, raise their own rates and expand their net interest margins.Soon after the Fed announcement Wednesday afternoon, banks began saying their prime lending rates are going up. But not all banks will be affected by the Fed's move in the same ways.Investment bank Goldman Sachs is seen benefiting especially from higher rates and market volatility as it relies more on fixed-income, currency and commodity trading. Analysts at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods also said last month BofA's cost cuts position it better than its rivals to take advantage of higher rates.But Citigroup's exposure to overseas markets has been flagged as a concern as higher rates and the stronger dollar send investors' money to the U.S.The rate hike also boosted the 10-year Treasury yield, which also moves mortgage rates higher, and Wells Fargo is the largest U.S. mortgage lender by volume.RELATED:Federal Reserve Hikes Rates, Now Sees 3 Moves In 2017; Yellen On TapWhy BofA, Goldman Sachs Could Stand Out In Bank RallyBanking ETFs Emerge As Leaders After Postelection Rally

The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 index sold off Monday, but closed off intraday lows, as Wall Street reassessed prospects that President Trump will be able to deliver the fiscal fuel of tax cuts and infrastructure spending.Here's the immediate problem: House Speaker Paul Ryan, Trump's legislative quarterback, has a playbook that just suffered a humiliating, one-sided defeat. Yet the only GOP tax-reform plan on the table comes straight out of Ryan's playbook and centers around a 20% border-adjusted tax on imports that appears to be almost as unpopular as RyanCare among Republicans in Congress.Until Trump replaces Ryan as the quarterback, financial markets could suffer from diminished confidence that tax cuts will be forthcoming. On Monday, the Dow was dragged down by JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS), which finished down 0.1% and 1.3%, respectively, on the stock market today.IBD Best Mutual Fund Awards: View The Winners By CategorySlower growth means less need for the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, which likely would be a negative for net interest margins of Bank of America (BAC), Wells Fargo (WFM) and other big lenders. BofA fell 0.4% and Wells Fargo 0.8% Monday, exceeding the Dow's 0.2% decline and the 0.1% S&P 500 loss.The Trump team never really got behind RyanCare and quickly pulled the plug when it appeared doomed. The one thing President Trump has proved is that he's quick to cut his losses, which also served him well in clearing out of Atlantic City before the city's casino industry cratered.While the Trump administration is more divided over a 20% tax on imports, which chief strategist Steve Bannon reportedly likes because of its nationalist overtones, expect the president to give a short shelf-life to the border tax.IBD'S TAKE:  The sudden sell-off in indexes and rout in financials marks a change in market character. Read IBD's The Big Picture every day to find out whether the market's uptrend stays intact. Visit Leaderboard to see whether the best-performing stocks are ripe for buying or profit-taking.Wall Street strategists are doubtful that the border tax, which would raise about $1 trillion over a decade to help make tax cuts deficit-neutral, will be adopted, and even more so given Ryan's inability to move his signature health plan out of the House.The question for markets is how long it will take Trump to kick Ryan's border tax to the curb and start pushing the kind of tax program that has the best, though still uncertain, chances of uniting Republicans: old-fashioned, deficit-increasing tax cuts.That pivot may not happen right away, if Trump's weekend tweet blaming the House Freedom Caucus for RyanCare's failure instead signals that the president is still too consumed with finger-pointing to move on to taxes.And the conservative group may represent another obstacle as key members already have voiced their opposition to Ryan's border tax plan. While they could be potential allies on less controversial tax cuts, Trump hasn't shown he's ready to make peace.Evercore ISI senior political strategist Terry Haines has written that he expects the eventual fiscal package to raise deficits by $2 trillion over 10 years and include a corporate tax-rate cut to 20%.While Senate budget reconciliation requiring just a simple majority can only be used to pass legislation that is no worse than deficit neutral beyond the 10th year, the GOP could use President George W. Bush's strategy of letting tax cuts sunset after a decade. Or the GOP could decide to blow up the Senate filibuster and enact permanent tax cuts, rolling the dice that Democrats won't control both the White House and Congress for years to come.Neither of those options is a sure thing. Some Republicans may not be willing to shed their fiscal conscience, and the political left would surely holler about disastrous implications for Social Security and Medicare. It's also unclear how the Federal Reserve and financial markets would respond to a big fiscal stimulus and higher deficits. Higher borrowing costs and uncertainty over the future of tax rates also might reduce the effectiveness of tax cuts to a significant extent.RELATED:The Bull Case For Tax Cuts If ObamaCare Repeal FailsTrump's 3 Little Words That May Sink Ryan's ObamaCare Repeal, Tax ReformIf Border Tax Dies, Trump Corporate Tax Cut May CollapseThe Trump Economy: Jobs, Regulations, Taxes And Trade

XU.S. stock indexes stood pat Friday despite an unexpectedly low number on March payrolls and the previous evening's news of a U.S. cruise missile attack on Syria. The Nasdaq and the blue chip Dow Jones industrial average finished flat, while the S&P 500 trimmed 0.1%. Volume fell on the Nasdaq and the NYSE. Stocks showed no sharp reactions…

Stocks held modest gains in afternoon trading Thursday, one day after the Nasdaq composite suffered a bearish outside day in higher volume. Wednesday's weak action added a distribution day to the Nasdaq and S&P 500's counts, making it six on the S&P 500 and five for the Nasdaq in recent weeks.Distribution days are an indication of institutional selling in the major averages.With about one hour left to go in the session, the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq all showed gains of around 0.2%. The Russell 2000 index of small-cap stocks outperformed with a 0.7% gain. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking slightly lower than Wednesday's levels.Benchmark crude oil for May delivery was trading around $51.80 a barrel, up 1.3%. Oil rose sharply early Wednesday but gave back early gains after EIA supply data showed an unexpected build in inventories last week.Retail-related groups were among the day's best performers, although most rank near the bottom of IBD's 197 industry group rankings.Burlington Stores (BURL), tracked in the apparel, shoes and accessories group, gained nearly 2% to 95.35. Burlington is trading tightly near highs, holding above its 50-day moving average and a prior 91.77 buy point.In the stock market today, Constellation Brands (STZ) was a big winner, up 6% to 171.29 on strong earnings. It gapped up over a 165.98 cup-with-handle buy point.Another breakout came in IBD's Chemicals-Agricultural group. Shares of Chilean fertilizer name Sociedad Quimica Y Minera (SQM) jumped 6% to 36.37. It's still in buy range from a 34.94 flat-base entry.Inside the IBD 50, investment bank Houlian Lokey (HLI) added nearly 3% to 33.95. It is a bit of an anomaly in the financial sector as it holds near highs above the 50-day moving average. It's also just below a 34.76 buy point.A slew of financials are set to report earnings next week as first-quarter earnings season gets underway. Citigroup (C), First Republic (FRC), JPMorgan (JPM) and Wells Fargo (WFC) report Thursday before the open.Also in the IBD 50, chipmaker Macom (MTSI) rose 1.5% to 50.65. It cleared some resistance around 50 as it approaches a conventional entry at 53.90.Biogen (BIIB) spinoff and IBD 50 name Bioverativ (BIVV) is acting well in its early days as a publicly traded company. Shares picked up 3% to 55.39. It's still in buy range from a 54.30 buy point. Bioverativ's focus is hemophilia and other blood disorders.RELATED:Best Stocks To Buy And WatchConstellation Brands Bubbles Into Buy Zone On A Solid Beat, Guidance

Thursday was supposed to be do-or-die day for House Speaker Paul Ryan's American Health Care Act, but the bill will be on life support, at least until Friday and maybe longer. A planned Thursday night vote won't happen, and it's unclear when it will happen.Meanwhile, the Congressional Budget Office late Thursday released a new score of the revised GOP legislation, predicting a smaller deficit savings than the original bill.The Dow industrials, S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite erased modest intraday gains on the stock market today. The Dow fell a fraction, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq lost about 0.1%.President Trump told reporters shortly before the market close that "we have a chance" with the health care vote, expecting the outcome to be "very close."Earlier, the House Freedom Caucus of conservative lawmakers met with Trump without agreeing to support the bill to repeal and replace ObamaCare.White House spokesman Sean Spicer described the meeting as positive, with some members backing the legislation. But Freedom Caucus Chairman Mark Meadows, R-N.C., later said this group still has "issues" with the bill.Ryan delayed an expected press conference for a second time Friday.The possibility of ObamaCare repeal failure has weighed on financial markets this week, with the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq composite all suffering their steepest one-day losses since fall on Tuesday as conservatives began to close ranks against the bill.The Trump-Freedom Caucus meeting followed a late-night agreement with House conservatives to scrap ObamaCare rules requiring insurance plans to include a comprehensive list of essential benefits. While the deal moved conservatives closer to supporting the bill, some centrist lawmakers declared their opposition, including Rep. Charlie Dent of Pennsylvania, who heads the Tuesday Group of moderate GOP lawmakers.If ObamaCare repeal fails, some analysts were predicting a continued rough spell for financials but a potential bounce for beaten-down hospital stocks. Bank of America (BAC), Wells Fargo (WFC) and Dow component Goldman Sachs (GS) all have sliced through their 50-day moving averages this week amid concerns that President Trump's agenda of growth-fueling tax cuts and infrastructure spending could be sidelined by a failure to repeal ObamaCare.If Ryan lacks the votes and pulls the bill, "then we think there could be renewed pressure on financial stocks as investor confidence in Congress's ability to pass President Trump's economic agenda will be further eroded," wrote Keefe, Bruyette & Woods Washington analyst Brian Gardner.Meanwhile, shares of hospital operators Tenet Healthcare (THC) and HCA Holdings (HCA) could see a rebound. Hospital stocks have suffered in recent weeks as Ryan and Trump pushed a plan that could reduce the ranks of the insured by 24 million.IBD'S TAKE: If the GOP fails in its bid to repeal and replace ObamaCare, don't assume that it will hamper the rest of President Trump's economic agenda. Failure is likely to focus the GOP on delivering deficit-increasing tax cuts, retroactive to 2017, to avoid a shellacking in the 2018 elections. Mizuho analyst Sheryl Skolnick expects that the GOP will somehow find a way to get the AHCA through both the House and Senate. "If we're wrong, then on Friday we see upside to hospitals that is likely limited by overall market downside as the probability that tax reform can get done this year diminishes," she wrote.Actually, Tenet rose 4.1% and HCA 0.8% Thursday, in a sign investors have doubts that Ryan's bill will pass. But banks were generally higher too, though well off session highs: Bank of America rose 0.6% and Goldman Sachs 0.4%. Wells Fargo fell 0.1%.After the market close, the Congressional Budget Office released a score of the revised health care bill. The CBO still sees the legislation increasing the number of uninsured by 24 million. But it cut the bill's deficit savings by more than half to $150 billion, largely reflecting some tax and Medicaid changes.RELATED:CBO Reveals RyanCare Trick To 'Save' $600 BillionTrump Hails 'Wonderful' GOP Health Plan That Everyone Else HatesTrumpCare Has Momentum: These Health Stocks Are ScramblingThe Trump Economy: Jobs, Regulations, Taxes And Trade

Goldman Sachs (GS) said it's too soon to say what trading activity will be like this year after reporting much-better-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings on strong bond trades.CFO Harvey Schwartz told analysts that confidence is the best stimulus for client activity and that the latter half of last year saw a surge in client confidence."With the shifting policies around the globe, it's an extraordinary catalyst for client dialogue, for decision making and for content," he said.As the Federal Reserve looks to increase rates three times this year, Goldman stands to gain further, with Schwartz predicting "meaningful upside" in fixed income, commodities and currency trading if rate continue rising.In Q4, earnings per share quadrupled to $5.08, easily beating views for $4.82, after a mortgage-securities settlement a year earlier gouged earnings. Revenue jumped 12% to $8.17 billion. Fixed income, currency, and commodities trading revenue soared 78% to $2 billion.Shares fell 0.6% to 234.29 on the stock market today. Citigroup (C), which also reported earnings and strong bond-trading revenue, fell 1.7%. Rival investment banking giant Morgan Stanley (MS), whose fourth-quarter results on Tuesday topped views, rose 1.7%.JPMorgan Chase (JPM) edged up 0.5%, and Bank of America (BAC) climbed 2.6%. Those companies reported earnings last week, as trading revenue surged. Wells Fargo (WFC), which will accelerate its branch closures this year and next, added 0.9%.IBD'S TAKE: Banks are likely to close more branches as they try to cut costs and as more people manage their finances over their phones. Other forms of technology, like blockchain, could help the industry save billions.After a steep climb following the election of Donald Trump and the prospect of looser regulations, job growth, inflation and higher interest rates, bank stocks appear to have taken a breather in recent weeks.Bank stocks seem likely to cool down further amid signs that Trump and the GOP leadership in Congress don't agree on a key piece of hoped-for tax cuts, adding doubts to a major postelection driver of bank stocks. Goldman Sachs, Citigroup, Morgan Stanley, JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, Wells Fargo, as well as superregional and many other bank stocks suffered big losses on Tuesday on Trump's tax reform comments, but on Wednesday the president-elect said the issue would be "discussed."Longer-term bond yields, which rise on expectations of future inflation and economic growth, have also eased from postelection gains, hitting prospects for banks' interest margins. But the 10-year Treasury yield rebounded Wednesday, moving back above its 50-day line.RELATED:Citigroup Trading Revenue Climbs 31% As Profit Beats EstimatesBanks Among Few S&P 500 Beneficiaries As Higher Rates LoomAs The Dow Nears 20K, These 5 Stocks Have Led The Way

Citigroup (C) reported fourth-quarter profit that surpassed analysts' estimates as trading revenue jumped 31%, more than the bank had forecast last month.Net income rose 7.1% to $3.57 billion, or $1.14 a share, from $3.34 billion, or $1.02, a year earlier, the New York-based company said Wednesday in a statement. The average estimate of 25 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg was for adjusted earnings of $1.12 a share.Citigroup follows rivals JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Morgan Stanley (MS) in posting a jump in revenue from helping clients trade in the months surrounding Donald Trump's surprise election win in November. Chief Executive Officer Michael Corbat, 56, also has been restructuring the firm and whittling costs as he seeks to improve profitability and return more capital to shareholders.The bank's traders handling bonds, currencies and commodities generated $3.01 billion in the quarter, 36% more than a year earlier, excluding an accounting adjustment from that period. Their fourth-quarter revenue was the highest since before the financial crisis, according to data compiled by Bloomberg, and better than the $2.83 billion estimated by analysts.Revenue from equities trading, an area the bank has targeted for an additional $1 billion in annual revenue, rose 15% to $694 million. That was just short of the $708 million estimated by analysts.Combined, trading revenue rose 31% to $3.7 billion. Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach had predicted Dec. 7 that it would rise about 20% in the quarter from a year earlier.Companywide revenue fell 8% to $17 billion, missing analysts' $17.3 billion estimate, as revenue tumbled 79% to $657 million in Citi Holdings, a unit housing operations and assets tagged for disposal. Operating expenses also declined 9%, to $10.1 billion, just below analysts' $10.2 billion estimate.Citi Holdings still eked out an $87 million profit. Gerspach had said last month that he was expecting a "modest loss" at that unit. The bank has said it will stop breaking out Citi Holdings' results in financial reports this year after its assets — $54 billion at year-end — shrank to become a relatively small part of the company's total balance sheet.U.S. bank stocks surged in the final weeks of 2016 as investors speculated that Trump's policies will lead to higher interest rates, looser regulation and lower taxes. The KBW Bank Index climbed 20% from the Nov. 8 vote through Tuesday, with Citigroup rising 17%.Trump's victory and the Federal Reserve's December interest-rate hike already have burnished Wall Street earnings by spurring clients to reposition stock and bond portfolios and react to currency swings.Trading, merger advice and securities underwriting helped boost revenue in the institutional clients group by 14% to $8.34 billion. Net income in that division, run by President Jamie Forese, rose 97% to $2.47 billion, helped in part by lower credit costs.Investment-banking revenue was unchanged at $1.13 billion, beating the $1.02 billion average estimate of analysts.Revenue from the consumer banking division, run by Stephen Bird, rose 2% to $8.03 billion. The bank has been spending money to increase revenue, committing to invest $1 billion in Mexico, and expanding the credit-card business. Last year, the bank brought Costco Wholesale (COST) customers on board in what the company has hailed as a key growth initiative.In December, the bank said one of Bird's key lieutenants, Jonathan Larsen, had resigned for personal reasons. Calling Larsen's oversight of retail banking and mortgages a "critical role," the bank said in an internal memo dated Dec. 9 that it had yet to choose a replacement.Citigroup was the last of the six biggest U.S. banks to report results. Earlier Wednesday, Goldman Sachs (GS) said fourth-quarter earnings more than tripled to $2.35 billion as the fixed-income business got a boost from speculation economic growth will accelerate. In previous days, JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley and Bank of America (BAC) all said profits rose in the quarter, helped by stronger bond trading. Wells Fargo (WFC) said net income dropped 5.4% as mortgage revenue declined.RELATED:Dow Stock Goldman Sachs Crushes Earnings Estimates On Bond TradingBanks Among Few S&P 500 Beneficiaries As Higher Rates Loom

Exchange traded funds tracking major stock indexes rose on Friday, led by small banks, amid a heavy docket of earnings from financial giants.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) added 0.3% on the stock market today in early trading. This ETF, a proxy for the broad U.S. market, is eyeing a weekly loss.SPDR S&P Regional Banking (KRE) and SPDR S&P Bank (KBE) punched up more than 2% apiece in morning trade. The gains came amid key quarterly reports from sector heavyweights.JPMorgan Chase (JPM) beat analyst expectations on both the top and bottom line, seeing strength in its consumer business unit. Results from peers such as Wells Fargo (WFC) and Bank of America (BAC) were more of a mixed bag.Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF) has rallied 17.6% since the Nov. 8 election. This sector of the S&P 500 has topped every other over that period.Investors turned bullish on financials on hopes for higher interest rates, less stringent regulations and fiscal stimulus.The $23.42 billion SDPR financial ETF is trading at its highest level since the recovery from the subprime mortgage crisis began in 2009.Since Nov. 8 this year, the banking sector has far outpaced other segments of the broad financial industry such as insurers.The three top-performing ETFs in this sector postelection, screened for trading volume, include KRE, KBE and PowerShares KBW Regional Banking (KBWR).Each is up more than 24% in this period.IBD'S TAKE: As the Trump agenda emerges, read IBD Leaderboard and The Big Picture to see how market leaders are performing and to assess whether the stock market has more room to run.Here's a look at the performance of major exchange traded funds across key asset classes on the stock market today.The Relative Price Strength (RS) Rating measures a stock's price performance over the last 12 months vs. all stocks and ETFs, on a scale of 1 to a best-possible 99.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), +0.3%, RS 54PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), +0.4%, RS 57SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), +0.1%, RS 61IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), +0.8%, RS 66IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), +1.0%, RS 71IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), +0.1%, RS 42Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), -0.2%, RS 47SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), -0.1%, RS 23United States Oil (USO), -0.7%, RS 52IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), -0.3%, RS 26PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), +0.1%, RS 42IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), -0.8%, RS 1RELATED:This Small-Bank ETF Packs A Powerful Punch

New account openings at Wells Fargo (WFC) continued to tank in October amid the aftermath of a scandal involving the creation of more than 2 million fake bank accounts.CEO Tim Sloan said in a Thursday press release that existing customers were still using their accounts but "as expected, we continued to see declines in new account openings."New consumer account openings fell 27% from September and 44% year over year, said the company, citing reduced marketing activities and customer reaction to its sales practices settlement.Wells Fargo was in September fined a total of $185 million over the matter.Customer-initiated account closures rose "modestly," or 3%, from the prior month. And customer loyalty scores fell from September, though the bank has seen "some improvement" from October lows.Wells Fargo shares climbed 1.6% in the stock market today, as the bank sector rallied on testimony from Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen, who said an interest-rate increase should come "relatively soon." Bank of America (BAC) rose 1.7%. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) added 0.8%. Citigroup (C) gained 1.5%.IBD'S TAKE: Financial stocks are in great shape. But here's why you shouldn't buy bank stocks right now.When it reported Q3 results last month, Wells Fargo said customer checking-account openings fell 25% during September, while credit-card applications sank 20% and customer visits with branch bankers were down 10%."Customer visits with bankers, account openings and applications were down on lower referrals, marketing activity and product offerings," the company said in its earnings presentation.RELATED:BofA, JPMorgan, Other Bank Stock Charts Look Great Despite PullbackWells Fargo Backs Dividend Amid Scandal; JPMorgan, Citigroup TopWells Fargo Is Fined $185 Million Over Unapproved Accounts

Big banks like JPMorgan Chase (JPM) , Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) continued their postelection stock-market surge on Thursday, amid rising odds for less regulation, higher inflation and Fed rate hikes next year.CNBC also reported that JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon is being considered for Treasury secretary.Shares of JPMorgan rallied 4.6% to close at 76.65 in the stock market today, setting a record high. Bank of America surged 4.4% to 18.76, blowing past buy range after breaking out Wednesday. Citigroup rose 3.9% to 53.61, reaching the highest in 11 months.Wells Fargo (WFC) leapt 7.6%, adding to Wednesday's 5.4% pop. Goldman Sachs (GS) climbed 4.3% and Morgan Stanley (MS) gained 4.1%.The U.S. 10-year Treasury yield added 7 basis points to 2.14% after skyrocketing Wednesday.IBD'S TAKE: Bank stocks have jumped, and the Dow has touched an all-time high following Trump's victory. So have other infrastructure-spending-friendly stocks, like construction companies. Thursday's stock gains follow a strong performance for banking on Wednesday, amid greater anticipation that President-elect Donald Trump and a GOP-controlled Congress would work to curb industry regulations, including potentially gutting Dodd-Frank.After a wild, toxic, stressful presidential campaign in which the big banks were often a punching bag, analysts have also said Trump's more cordial, evenhanded victory speech — and its focus on a massive infrastructure overhaul — helped lift markets Wednesday after being pressured in the run-up to Election Day.Analysts have said Trump's focus on tax cuts and public infrastructure spending could bring higher inflation on a flood of new debt coming to the market and higher bond yields.The rising inflation, along with the current market rally, have also helped shore up the odds that the Federal Reserve might raise the benchmark interest rate, potentially boosting banks' net-interest margins.Trump's election, however, doesn't come without risks to the banking sector, analysts note."The opportunities come primarily from a steepening yield curve, increased volatility and reduced regulation," Keefe, Bruyette & Woods said in a research note. "The risks come from a retrenchment of the U.S. from the global economy and trade agreements."In a separate note, KBW said it was "more cautious" on Citigroup, given the company's exposure to Mexico, a country that could be among the most vulnerable if Trump shreds existing U.S. trade pacts.Citigroup in September said it saw "tremendous untapped potential" in Mexico.RELATED:Wells Fargo Backs Dividend Amid Scandal; JPMorgan, Citigroup TopBank Of America Gains Share Globally, Vows Blockchain EmbraceJPMorgan Chase, Citigroup, Wells Fargo Earnings Top

There's a decent case to be made that investors' fear of Donald Trump winning the White House may turn out to be a good deal worse than the reality, at least in the intermediate term.Stock indexes crashed 5% overnight with odds for a December Federal Reserve hike tumbling. But after an initial modest sell-off at the open, the major averages have reversed for solid gains, with soaring bond yields.The overnight reaction to Trump looked like it may vindicate economists who predicted the market would fall up to 12% if Trump won. But once you consider Trump's near-term priorities and the challenges of working with Congress — even a GOP Congress restrained by a filibuster in the Senate — the agenda looks more market friendly than unfriendly.Priority one for Trump on the domestic front is likely to be revving up growth via infrastructure spending, cutting the corporate tax rate and offering multinationals the chance to repatriate overseas profits at a lower tax rate.He's talked about spending $1 trillion on infrastructure, double what Hillary Clinton proposed to spend, with both candidates talking up the potential of public-private partnerships."With the focus on infrastructure, the basic resources sector is one of the best performers today," wrote Alastair George, chief strategist at Edison Investment Research in London.Both Nucor (NUE) and Steel Dynamics (STLD) surged on the stock market today, suring 12% and 9%, respectively. Shares of gold miner Newmont Mining (NEM) initially spiked as Trump's victory fueled a safe-haven bid with the dollar plunging. But as stocks and the dollar rebound, gold erased its big gains and Newmont traded 2% higher.IBD'S TAKE: Gold prices are rising sharply Wednesday. That will give a big boost to Newmont and other gold mining stocks, which are technical turning points.Biotech and drug stocks such as Pfizer (PFE) and Gilead Sciences (GILD) rallied on relief that Hillary Clinton will not be president and the Senate will remain in GOP hands. Clinton had vowed to crack on "excessive" price increases, notably on older treatments. She also likely would have pushed for the government to negotiate drug prices lower.Trump's victory means that regulatory relief for super-regional banks from Dodd-Frank regulations may go a step further than expected, paving the way for a round of acquisitions. It also may ease pressures on too-big-to-fail banks, which explains why Wells Fargo (WFC) popped 6% intraday, recovering from an overnight sell-off. Wells Fargo also may see less political pressure over its fradualent account scandal."We expect a positive snapback move once investors digest the results and factor in a more favorable regulatory environment for the financial sector," wrote Brian Gardner, head of Washington research at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods.Banks have been rising in part due to expectations for a Fed hike amid stronger wage growth and tighter labor markets. While the Fed may decide to pause before hiking if Trump's election does send financial shock waves around the globe, that's far from clear."Expect an immediate market pullback, on fear, and then a pause," said Brad McMillan, Chief Investment Officer for Commonwealth Financial Network. "Should Mr. Trump be able to reduce the uncertainty around what policies he intends to pursue, it is quite possible markets will recover as the economic fundamentals in the U.S. remain sound."Trump is likely to kill President Obama's overtime rule that's due to take effect in December that guarantees time-and-a-half pay for salaried workers earning up to $47,476 — about twice the current level. Wal-Mart (WMT) already raised pay for assistant store managers to $48,500 from $45,000, effective September, to avoid being liable for overtime, but many employers have been slower to adopt the change as Congress aims to delay it. Some, like Carrols Restaurant Group (TAST), whose 717 Burger King locations make it the Restaurant Brands International (QSR) chain's largest franchisee, have said they'll effectively demote their managers and make them punch the clock.The ObamaCare employer mandate is likely history, meaning modest-wage employers would no longer be fined if they fail to offer health insurance to workers clocking at least 30 hours per week. Along with retailers, Trump may bring relief to restaurant chains like McDonald's (MCD) that are being squeezed by competition and compensation hikes, contributing to a record gap between the cost of fast food and eating in.What are markets scared about? Trump's threats to impose tariffs on companies like Ford Motor (F) that send cars to the U.S. from Mexico, to walk away from Nafta and to crack down on unauthorized immigrants are why economists have said his agenda could hurt the economy.If Trump were to start his presidency by labeling China a currency manipulator and imposing tariffs, that could start a trade war, with China reciprocating by targeting the sales of Apple (AAPL), General Motors (GM) and Microsoft (MSFT). China, facing slower growth and an unsustainable build up in debt, could easily spark another bout of financial market turmoil as was seen this past January.How Trump proceeds on trade will be one of his most important early decisions. The good news is that Trump isn't campaigning anymore — and his was an especially insular campaign. Surrounded by pro-growth economic advisors and now in direct contact with top business leaders, Trump is likely to act deliberately, not rashly. That may mean opening up talks with both countries about how to move trade relations forward and setting out intermediate term goals to measure progress.This seems consistent with Trump's victory speech words: "I want to tell the world community that while we will always put America's interests first, we will deal fairly with everyone, with everyone — all people and all other nations. We will seek common ground, not hostility; partnership, not conflict."Trump seems unlikely to back down from his pledge to build a wall on the border with Mexico, but that, in and of itself, would have more of a symbolic than an economic effect. His rhetoric has shifted to cracking down on unauthorized immigrants who are violent criminals, and there may be fewer of those than he implies.RELATED:Drug Stocks Rally On Relief Clinton Didn't Win White HouseTrump Wins, But Fed Hike Still On: Treasury Yields, Bank Stocks SoarAT&T, Time Warner Fall After Trump Victory; Is Merger In Doubt?Overtime Rule Fallout: Fast Food Managers Told To Punch ClockFBI Reveals More Evidence That Stocks Will Fall If Trump Wins

Major stock-index ETFs rumbled higher Monday, led by small caps, after the FBI cleared Hillary Clinton in the latest email probe. The issue weighed heavily on both the Democratic candidate's presidential campaign and the stock market last week.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) jumped 1.7% in early trading on the stock market today.This exchange traded fund, a proxy for the broad U.S. market, sits 3% below its August high of 219.60.Telecom and financials topped advancing S&P 500 sectors with a 2.0% gain. Utilities trailed with a 0.4% gain.SPDR S&P Bank (KBE) surged as much as 2.7%.Bank stocks continue to gain momentum after the Fed's November policy meeting last week, which kept a December rate hike in play.Higher rates help to pad banks' net interest margins. Among financials, Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) missed on profit estimates but revenue beat forecasts.The Warren Buffett company continues to maintain its 10% stake in Wells Fargo (WFC) despite the bank's sales scandal, reports said.IShares Russell 2000 Growth (IWO) popped 2.2% in morning trade as small-caps led large-caps higher on the stock market.IBD'S Take: The stock market seems to have priced in a Hillary Clinton win. But with one day to go, Donald Trump extended his lead over Clinton, 43% to 41%, according to the latest IBD/TIPP presidential tracking poll. Gold and silver prices slumped as investors showed higher appetite for risk Monday.On Sunday, the Federal Bureau of Investigation reiterated its earlier stance that no criminal charges are contemplated against Clinton over the use of a private email server for government work.A little over a week ago, a new FBI probe of Clinton emails triggered sharp uncertainty about the outcome of the U.S. election and burnished gold's safe-haven appeal.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) dropped 1.8% Monday, following its 2.3% gain last week. Lower Treasury yields Friday pressured most financials, including Dow Jones industrial average components JPMorgan Chase (JPM) Goldman Sachs (GS) and American Express (AXP).But Visa (V), the second-best performer on the Dow industrials this year, rose to a fresh all-time high Friday. Its archrival Mastercard (MA) also reached record levels and its stock is still within buy range.The 10-year yield fell below 2.5% intraday, resuming their retreat following the Fed's rate hike on Wednesday, as policymakers did not signal faster tightening ahead.Rates on mortgages and the value of other types of credit are tied in with those yields. The yields also serve as a window into investors' expectations for higher prices in the future — potentially prompting the Fed to raise the benchmark interest rate, which, in turn, can help banks' finances as banks hike their own interest rates and other costs to compensate.Visa rose 0.2% to 90.21 in the stock market today, hitting a fresh all-time high of 90.63  intraday. The stock has been tailing upward since the beginning of the year, logging a 16% gain since Dec. 30.Mastercard climbed 0.1% to 112.83, wthin range of a 109.03 buy point of a flat base initially cleared in mid-January. Mastercard sold off at the end of the month, closing below its 50-day line on Feb. 1. But the stock rebounded, retaking its still-value 109.03 buy point and marching on to new highs.Visa has been gaining on a variety of factors. Among them: stronger consumer optimism, the acquisition of Visa Europe, and the potential in cross-border and electronic payments.Visa and Mastercard, while known for their credit cards, are not technically card issuers. They make money on transaction fees, and aren't directly affected by interest rate shifts. Issuing banks, such as JPMorgan Chase,  Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC), actually carry the balances.IBD'S TAKE: Banks and financials have been among the biggest Trump plays this year, on hopes for a combination of fewer regulations and higher interest rates. Steel stocks, potential beneficiaries of Trump's plans for a massive infrastructure investment, are among the others. JPMorgan Chase fell 1.05%, Bank of America 1.4%, Citigroup 1.3% and Wells Fargo 1.1%.Goldman Sachs and fellow investment bank Morgan Stanley (MS) fell 1.7% and 2.8%, respectively, both closing just above their 50-day lines.The Dow's American Express, which does issue cards directly and carry the balances, trickled 0.65% lower. Capital One (COF), which also issues cards, fell 2.2%, undercutting its 50-day line.RELATED:Apple, Nike, Visa Among Dow's Top 5 Gainers So Far This YearDow Stock American Express Ups Ante In High-Fee, High-End Card Race

Stocks opened higher Friday, following a disappointing read on December retail sales and mixed bank earnings.The Dow industrials and the S&P 500 climbed 0.3% as the Nasdaq added 0.4%.The Nasdaq starts Friday's session up 0.5% for the week after Thursday marked the first down session of the new year. The Dow industrials and S&P 500 are down 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively, after a tough week of Senate confirmation hearings, the first press conference by President-elect Donald Trump and commentary from Federal Reserve officials, as well as the first weakening in oil prices in a month.Reports from big banks set the fourth-quarter earnings season in serious motion early Friday.Bank of America (BAC) traded 1% higher at the open after delivering mixed fourth-quarter results. Earnings narrowly beat views and revenue stopped short of the consensus target. The company noted that the rise in interest rates occurred too late to affect fourth-quarter results, but would lead to increased interest income in the first quarter. Bank of America shares are in the fifth week of a flat consolidation.JPMorgan Chase (JPM) also reported better-than-expected earnings but revenue just missed views. Wells Fargo (WFC) fell short on the top and bottom lines. JPMorgan and Wells gained 1%.PNC Financial Services (PNC) added 1.3%, as earnings easily cleared analysts' fourth-quarter targets. Revenue just met expectations and the company trimmed its loan loss provision to $67 million, down $20 million, as overall credit quality held steady. PNC has been rattling off new highs, ending Thursday up 35% since breaking out of a cup-with-handle base in September.Monster Beverage (MNST) jumped 4% at the open. Monster climbed back above the 50-day moving average. It slide below the line earlier in the week, after Nielsen data showed the company's sales slipped last month as it used promotions to attempt to revive weakened demand.Crude oil slipped  a half percent, sending West Texas Intermediate below $53 a barrel, down a bit less than 3% for the week. Gold added 0.3% to go above $1,196 an ounce. The dollar reversed early losses and gained ground. Bonds also reversed, raising the 10-year yield 3 basis points to 2.39%.Prices paid by producers in December rose 0.3%, the Labor Department said, a slight downtick from November's 0.4% gain and in line with expectations. Core prices, minus food and energy, gained 0.2%, half of November's advance, but above expectations for a slowdown to 0.1%.December retail sales rose 0.6%, the Commerce Department estimated, jumping from November's 0.2% rise. Economists' consensus projected a 0.7% gain. Stripping out auto sales, sales rose 0.2%, down from November's 0.3% increase and far below views for a 0.5% gain.At 10 a.m. ET, Commerce Department's business inventories for November and the University of Michigan's January Consumer Sentiment survey are expected. Baker Hughes (BHI) releases its weekly rig count at 1 p.m.Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker closes out a busy week of commentary from Federal Reserve officials. He was scheduled to speak at 9:30 a.m. ET.Global markets were generally positive, with the exception of Tokyo's Nikkei 225, which slipped 0.2% Friday to end the week down 0.9%. Europe's markets gained altitude in afternoon trade, with the FTSE 100 in London up 0.4%, Frankfurt's DAX holding a 0.6% gain and the CAC 40 in Paris ahead 1%.RELATED:Bank Of America, JPMorgan Results Mixed; Wells Fargo Misses

In a post-financial crisis world, the mortgage industry is facing increased regulation, and that's a good thing for Ellie Mae (ELLI).The cloud-based software provider's role has been to make life easier for mortgage professionals by helping them automate what has largely been a paper-based business, analysts say. Higher government scrutiny is making automation of the industry more necessary than ever.So Ellie Mae -- not to be confused with mortgage agency Fannie Mae -- services U.S. lenders and mortgage originators, primarily through its flagship software, Encompass. The program facilitates a large chunk of the process, from the time a homebuyer walks into a bank looking for a mortgage to the closing of the sale, explains Barclays analyst Saket Kalia."Everything that's being done in the background, whether it's underwriting and going through the mortgage (application) and getting a home inspection or flood certificate -- all of the system flows behind that -- their current Encompass platform can really handle from end to end," he said.Kalia said that Ellie Mae's platform easily makes up more than 80% of the company's total revenue. Ellie Mae estimates about a quarter of all residential mortgages are made through Encompass. And there's room to grow.That was evident in the company's earnings report, released late Thursday. The number of active users of Encompass grew 18% from the prior-year quarter to 159,523, with revenue per average active user rising 23% to $640.There was more positive news in the fundamentals. Ellie Mae said profit growth was 60% to 72 cents a share on 46% revenue growth to $100.4 million, solidly above estimates for 59 cents earnings a share and $92.2 million in sales.The company forecast 2016 revenue to fall within a range of $351 million to $353 million, up from a prior sales outlook for $338 million to $341 million. Adjusted net income is now expected to hit $2.17-$2.18 per share, up from previous targets of $2-$2.06 a share for the year.Shares had fallen more than 4% prior to the earnings report on Thursday. The stock, however, roared back to a new high on Friday, leaping nearly 10% to close at 107.15. On Monday, Ellie Mae finished the day down 1.2% to 105.89.Analysts say there's more business potential out there for Ellie Mae, if it can snare it."The mortgage market was and still is inefficient," said William Blair analyst Brandon Dobell, who has a market perform rating on Ellie Mae stock. "(If you've) ever gone through buying a home and (refinancing) a home, it takes a lot longer than it should."The changes that came in the wake of the housing crash accelerated the adoption of technology in a fragmented industry typically flooded with paperwork.The mortgage origination process is still nowhere near being entirely electronic, said Dobell, but Ellie Mae has "really taken the guesswork out of what form to use when, what does this rule mean, did I forget a form," he said.Analysts point to Canadian-based D+H as being a roughly equal competitor. Privately held Calyx and Black Knight Financial Services (BKFS) also are mentioned, but Ellie Mae is "far and away the most dominant in (its) space," said Kalia.IBD'S TAKE: Ellie Mae shares broke out of a flat base in late September, but have dodged back in and out of that base since then, highlighted by Thursday's 4% loss. Its earnings report, issued after the close Thursday, could well set shares off on another growth spurt.And much of Ellie Mae's growth can be attributed to the compliance and regulatory changes that those outside the circle of "mega-lenders" have had to grapple with in recent years.Big banks such as Wells Fargo (WFC), JPMorgan (JPM), Citigroup (C) and others are likely to have their own in-house mortgage-origination software. But smaller lenders have come to rely on Ellie Mae's cloud-based system to incorporate the appropriate changes by deadline, a process that can be expensive and cumbersome to do on their own."Once Dodd-Frank came out, some of these smaller banks really had trouble maintaining anything that they'd written in house," said Kalia. "One thing that Ellie Mae excels at is really building in the latest compliance requirements into their software."It's been a positive for Ellie Mae's market share that there are far more small players on the market these days.In the years since the financial crisis, big banks have gone from making up 70% of the mortgage business to about 10% to 20%, according to Dobell. Conversely, small lenders have climbed from 10% to 15% of the market to a share of "probably close to 60%.""There's a been a huge, huge, huge shift in favor of the types of customers who would use Ellie Mae or a D+H product," he said. "These are the independent mortgage companies -- they are nonbank lenders like a Guaranteed Rate or a Ditech, (a) local credit union (or) a regional bank."He went on to say: "The bigger banks have really gotten out of the mortgage (business) except for small parts of it."Plus, a healthy mortgage environment has been helpful."This has really been the perfect trifecta for Ellie Mae over the last few years," said Kalia, pointing to the "rising tide in mortgages," Ellie Mae's customers processing more loans, and the company's growing market share."It's actually been a great time for Ellie Mae, with those trends," Kalia said.An expected rate hike from the Federal Reserve in December, however, will in all likelihood decrease the number of refinances that occur. And Ellie Mae would "absolutely feel an impact," he said.But Kalia added that management, which has alluded to refis accounting for about 40% of the overall business and purchase volume making up the rest, has been fairly conservative in its expectations, factoring a rate hike into the equation.William Blair's Dobell says the challenges that Ellie Mae faces now are that of a growth company, with difficult year-over-year user-count comparisons coming up.

Watch for stocks like JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Caterpillar (CAT), General Electric (GE), Boeing (BA) and Exxon Mobil (XOM)…

U.S. stocks inched up in early trade Monday morning as the market tried to end four losing sessions in a row.The Nasdaq and the S&P 500 each added 0.1%. The blue chip Dow Jones industrial average and the small cap Russell 2000 were flat. Volume in the stock market today was running below average on both major exchanges. Volume was above average Thursday and Friday on the Nasdaq. The above-average volume coincided with the Nasdaq's moves below its 50-day moving average line, not a good sign.Chevron (CVX) bounced 1.4% higher early Monday, adding to Friday's 4% pop on an 84% earnings beat for the third quarter. Chevron rose despite a 1.5% drop in the price of West Texas intermediate crude oil.Banks continued to show strength. Morgan Stanley (MS), Wells Fargo (WFC) and Goldman Sachs (GS) all were up in early action.In economic news, consumer spending for September matched expectations with a 0.5% increase. But personal income grew at 0.3%, falling shy of views for 0.4%, according to Econoday.The Chicago Purchasing Managers Index for October checked in at 50.6 — a bad miss for the business barometer, which failed to match even the lowest estimate in the range. The Street expected 54.3, and the lowest estimate in the range was 53.1. The 50.6 reading was a five-month low for the manufacturing gauge.

Bank of America (BAC) reported better-than-expected third-quarter earnings Monday morning on fixed-income trading activity and cost curbs. That followed solid results from JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and other big banks on Friday.Bank of America earned 41 cents a share in the third quarter, up from 37 cents a year earlier. Analysts had expected a decline to 34 cents. Revenue was $21.635 billion vs. views for $20.965 billion."We delivered strong results this quarter by staying true to our strategy of responsible growth and focusing on the quality of the relationships with our customers and clients," said CEO Brian Moynihan in a statement.Q3 was a return to growth for BofA, after earnings and revenue fell vs. a year earlier in both Q1 and Q2.Loans rose 3% vs. a year earlier.Adjusted trading revenue climbed 18%, with fixed-income trading up 39%, offsetting a 17% drop in equity-trading revenue. Investment banking revenue climbed 13%.Expenses fell 3.3% as BofA cut 6,000 jobs and closed 100 branches over the past year. Moynihan has targeted further cuts as other banks try to curb costs in a slow-growth environment.Bank of America said on its post-earnings conference call with analysts that it hasn't found any problems with its sales practices in the wake of the Wells Fargo (WFC) cross-selling scandal, in which millions of customer accounts were created without authorization. JPMorgan Chase said Friday that it found isolated issues, but nothing systemic.BofA shares closed up 0.3% at 16.05 in the stock market today. Shares hit a nine-month high on Oct. 10, briefly topping a key resistance level of 16.34.IBD'S TAKE: Financial stocks have rallied in recent weeks on growing expectations of Federal Reserve rate hike this year. Here's why investors are finally getting with the Fed's program.On Friday, JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo reported earnings above Wall Street estimates, with JPMorgan and Citigroup also reporting booming fixed-income trading revenue. But earnings did fall modestly vs. a year earlier for all three banks. All three stocks initially rose Friday but closed with tiny losses.JPMorgan Chase and Wells Fargo shares dipped 0.5% Monday, while Citigroup finished virtually flat.RELATED:Wells Fargo Backs Dividend Amid Scandal; JPMorgan, Citigroup Top

What if the scandal now plaguing Wells Fargo (WFC) wasn't confined only to Wells Fargo?Think about it: After the 2008-09 financial meltdown, fed funds rates plunged from above 5% to near zero. That's a lot of revenue gone. For bankers, that has changed their culture considerably, says Paul Noring, a managing director specializing in financial services for the consultant firm Navigant.Noring points out there's an adage that bankers used to "lend at 6%, borrow at 3% and be on the golf course at 3." That hasn't been true since at least 2009, and banks have had to adjust. It's possible that other banks may have dabbled in some of the same practices as Wells, he says."The drivers are that we've been in this protracted low-interest-rate environment," Noring said. "In cutting costs, you move your employees more to incentive-based operations.""I would not be surprised if there were other institutions with similar issues," he said.Wells Fargo has been under the gun since Sept. 8, when the banking giant fired 5,300 employees for creating phony accounts in order to boost sales figures and jack up bonus compensation. The bank agreed to pay $185 million in fines and will refund $5 million to customers. Wells Chief Executive John G. Stumpf has been excoriated in Congressional hearings of late over the scandal.Shares have tumbled from a high of 51 reached at the beginning of September. Shares ended trading Monday down another 1% to 43.83, their lowest level since December 2013.The reason: Customers may have been dinged for small maintenance fees on those ghost accounts without their knowledge. More importantly, maintaining those accounts -- ranging from charge cards to home equity loans -- would have shown up on their credit reports and could adversely affect them if too many outstanding accounts show up.Ultimately, that means higher interest rates for loans, Noring says. That's good for banks, not so good for consumers.So what to do? First off, the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, which prosecuted and fined Wells, says there are a number of warning signs consumers should watch for when opening a bank account:For those concerned about their current accounts, whether they be at Wells Fargo or elsewhere, Noring suggests several steps. First, check your credit score and what's showing up on your credit report. Any account that's unfamiliar needs to be questioned.Second, Noring says customers should make a written request to see all accounts in their name, known as a "qualified written request." It may take a while but banks will have to comply.Noring says the most vulnerable are the elderly and those with relatively smaller means.He adds larger banks are the most likely to commit Wells-style infractions since they're the ones with the most products to cross-sell along with checking accounts. Many have goals of getting customers to sign on for at least eight financial products. Community banks with fewer financial tools are less likely to do what Wells did.If there's one silver lining, Noring says, it's that the harm to consumers from what Wells did seems relatively minor."It is scary in many ways, but when you look at the level of consumer harm, I don't think the numbers are massive," he said. "It is going to affect the interest rate that you pay. But the question is how much and over what time."

The Nasdaq composite picked up where it left off Monday with another new high, helped by strength in select China-based growth names.The Nasdaq rose nearly 0.4%, setting intraday and record close Tuesday. The S&P was virtually flat and the Dow Jones industrial edged lower by nearly 0.2%. Small caps  outperformed, with the Russell 2000 up 1%. Volume on the NYSE was tracking higher than Monday's level. Nasdaq volume was slightly lower.Dow component Apple (AAPL) added minimally to this month's gains, rising 0.1% to 119.11. Numerous published reports said the company is working on augmented reality (AR) glasses with German firm Carl Zeiss. Apple is still in buy range from a 118.12 cup-with-handle buy point, but it's been a low-volume breakout so far.JD.com (JD) was a top gainer in the Nasdaq 100, rising 2.4% to 26.90, after JPMorgan upgraded the Chinese internet retailer to overweight from neutral, and raised its price target to 39 from 32. JD.com is in a consolidation with a 29.33 buy point. NetEase (NTES), meanwhile, added 2.2% to 239.88. It's working on a late-stage consolidation, but is still quite a ways below a potential entry at 272.68.IBD's airline group was on the day's top gainers, up around 3%. Allegiant Travel (ALGT) bounced off its 10-week moving average, rising 5.7%. Alaska Air (ALK) is also getting support at its 10-week line. Shares gained 5.2%.Elsewhere, Dow component Goldman Sachs (GS) held up well despite a downgrade by Citi to sell based on valuation. Goldman pared a 1.6% loss to just 0.1%.A trio of financial companies report earnings on Friday, including JPMorgan (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and Wells Fargo (WFC).In the stock market today, shares of Chipotle (CMG) jumped 4.9% to 414.35. The company's fourth-quarter outlook wasn't great, but investors seemed to focus instead on a 14.7% rise in December same-store sales.In the medical sector, NuVasive (NUVA) broke out of a base in active trading. Shares were up 2.1% to 69.96. It's still in buy range from a 69.04 cup-with-handle buy point. Late Monday, the company preannounced preliminary Q4 and full-year results.Leaderboard name HealthEquity (HQY) extended gains after Monday's strong move. Shares vaulted 9.5% to 47.04. It's still in buy range from a 45.10 flat-base entry. The 5% buy zone goes up to 47.35.IBD'S TAKE: HealthEquity is the second-ranked stock in the financial services-specialty industry group based on its Composite Rating of 97. See which stock gets top billing with IBD Stock Checkup.Illumina (ILMN) soared 16.6% after the company forecast strong Q4 sales and also announced a new gene-sequencing product. Shares are recovering from a deep correction.RELATED:Southwest Raises Q4 Unit Revenue Guidance, Joining Delta Air LinesTrump Bump: Small Business Optimism Soars To 12-Year High

Bank stocks retreated, dragging down the Dow industrials, as Treasury yields fell Thursday on ADP's employment gauge.The 10-year Treasury yield, which helps determine the rate on mortgages and other debts, was down nine basis points to 2.35%, after hitting a recent peak above 2.6% in mid-December. The two-year yield, which influences credit-card debt and other key loans, rose five basis points to 1.17%. A flatter yield curve is not good news for bank profitability.JPMorgan Chase (JPM) shares closed 0.9% lower on the stock market today, while Bank of America (BAC) dropped 1.2% and Citigroup (C) 1.7%. Wells Fargo (WFC) retreated 1.55%. Goldman Sachs (GS) pulled back 0.7%, and fellow investment bank Morgan Stanley (MS) lost 0.9%.JPMorgan and Goldman are part of the Dow Jones industrial average and are a key reason why the blue-chip index is lagging Thursday.ADP said the private sector added 153,000 jobs in December, below expectations, according to MarketWatch, and lower than the 215,000 added in November. The government's December jobs report is set for release on Friday.Bank stock charts generally look healthy, with share prices leveling off in recent weeks following a long run-up after the election of Donald Trump. Wall Street has been betting that a combination of tax cuts, regulatory cutbacks, an infrastructure overhaul and higher inflation under Trump and a Republican-controlled Congress will benefit banks in the years to come.The economic growth and infrastructure investment have led to anticipation of higher inflation, which has pushed longer-term yields up as investors try to make up for the dollar's declining buying power over time. When the Fed raises rates, a prospect more likely under higher inflation, banks can more easily raise their own, helping to pad their finances.The Federal Reserve has already offered more bullish signals on rate hikes for this year. According to minutes from the Fed's December meeting, policymakers "indicated that the upside risks to their forecasts for economic growth had increased as a result of prospects for more expansionary fiscal policies in coming years."IBD'S TAKE: The Fed can raise its own benchmark interest rate in an attempt to curb inflation and economic overexpansion and make borrowing more expensive. With investors banking on Trump's fiscal policy jolting the economy, Fed policymakers may get more aggressive on raising rates. JPMorgan, Bank of America and Wells Fargo report quarterly earnings next week.RELATED:More Than Bitcoin: Blockchain's Links Reach JPMorgan, IBM, Wal-MartAs The Dow Nears 20K, These 5 Stocks Have Led The WayU.S. Banking Giants Gain As Deutsche Bank, European Financials Teeter

Wells Fargo (WFC) continued to see fewer account openings last month, as the banking giant continues to deal with questions about its sales practices following allegations this year that it opened up to 2 million unauthorized consumer accounts. However, the declines on a month-to-month basis have eased.Opened consumer checking accounts in November plunged 41% from a year ago, Wells Fargo said. But those openings were down only 9% from October. October new accounts tumbled 27% from September.Customer loyalty scores, meanwhile, were down from last year but ticked up a bit from October."We know we have more work ahead of us and we remain focused on strengthening our relationships with existing customers and building new ones with potential customers," Mary Mack, Wells' head of community banking, said in a statement.Shares rose 0.3% to 55.34 in the stock market today. Like other banks, Wells Fargo got a postelection bump on the prospect of eased regulations, higher interest rates and a more favorable yield spread, but the stock had eased in recent days.IBD'S TAKE: The prospect of fewer regulations under a Trump administration has sent bank stocks higher. Trump's announcement that he would focus on developing the nation's infrastructure has also lifted steel stocks. Wells Fargo in September settled with regulators over allegations that sales staff at its retail banking division — that is, its bank branches — for years opened accounts without consumers' knowledge or permission to hit sales goals in a high-pressure culture.The Office of the Comptroller of the Currency last month revoked some of the September settlement conditions, which will force Wells Fargo to get approval for major plans and senior employment changes. The bank said it had fired more than 5,000 employees in connection with the scandal, which in October forced the ouster of the bank's CEO, John Stumpf, who was brought before Congress and grilled over his knowledge of the sales tactics. The bank also faces federal and state investigations over its practices.Now, Prudential Financial (PRU) is looking into whether Wells Fargo staff also made similar account openings for Prudential's life insurance policies.Wells Fargo once again failed to provide a satisfactory "living will," the Federal Reserve and FDIC said Tuesday. Banks are required to spell out how they would wind down their operations without destabilizing the financial system.JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Bank of America (BAC) amended their wills successfully, regulators said.JPMorgan Chase fell 1.2%, Bank of America 2.2% and Citigroup (C) 0.8%, though all three are near record or longtime highs.RELATED:Bank Stocks Push Dow Toward 20,000 After 1-Day Fed PauseWhy Bank Stocks Ended Mixed After Fed Turned More Aggressive On RatesBank Stocks Unfazed After Italy Referendum, Renzi Resignation

Wall Street on Monday shrugged off Italy's referendum vote a day earlier to reject by a wide margin reforms to streamline its government, with U.S.-listed banks largely up in early trading.JPMorgan (JPM) closed up 2% on the stock market today, Bank of America (BAC) climbed 2.9%, Citigroup (C) 2.25% and Wells Fargo (WFC) 1.4%.European markets generally advanced. The euro, which plunged to a 20-month low in Sunday trading, rallied Monday when regular trading resumed.Among U.S.-listed European banks, Deutsche Bank (DB) jumped 5.8%, Barclays (BCS) rose 2.5%, UBS (UBS) 3 and Credit Suisse (CS) 2.2%.Shares of Italian banks, which don't trade in the U.S., sold off sharply but didn't collapse. Banca Monte dei Paschi di Siena, seen as among Italy's most vulnerable banks, fell 4.2%. Banca Popolare di Milano Scarl slid 7.9%, while UniCredit was down 3.4%.
