It will trade under the ticker NTNX.RELATED:Nutanix Stokes IPO Fire; Tech Unicorn Opens 66% Higher In DebutCostco Up On Earnings, Mentor Pops On Stake, Nutanix IPO Prices HotNXP Semiconductors Rockets On Qualcomm Acquisition Report

Shares of Deutsche Bank (DB) jumped after Agence-France Presse reported that the embattled German banking giant was close to settling a U.S. mortgage-securities case for $5.4 billion -- potentially far less than the $14 billion the Justice Department initially sought.The news came amid growing concerns about whether the bank would wind up crippled after the settlement as well as broader economic problems and political upheaval in Europe that have strained the region's banks.Bloomberg reported yesterday that a handful of hedge funds had cut their positions in the bank. While concerns have grown that Deutsche Bank's problems could ripple across the global financial system, analysts have cautioned against comparisons to a Lehman-Brothers-esque catastrophe.Deutsche Bank's U.S.-listed shares jumped 14% to close at 13.09 in the stock market today, nearing their 50-day line. Shares have tumbled over the past year, and concerns about the bank have weighed on markets in recent days.U.S. banks followed. JPMorgan (JPM) rose 1.4%, while Bank of America (BAC) added 3.2% and Citigroup (C) gained 3.1%. All moved back above their 50-day lines, a key test of investor support.Goldman Sachs (GS) rose 1.5%, and Morgan Stanley (MS) climbed 3.3%. But Wells Fargo (WFC), whose CEO over the past two weeks has become a congressional punching bag over the bank's cross-selling scandal, dipped 0.2%.IBD'S TAKE: As Deutsche Bank rebounds, learn more about which bank stocks could be buying opportunities.Earlier in the day, Deutsche Bank CEO John Cryan, in a letter to employees, touted the bank's fundamentals in an attempt to soothe anxieties about "unjustified concerns" regarding the bank."It is our task now to prevent distorted perception from further interrupting our daily business," he wrote. "Trust is the foundation of banking. Some forces in the markets are currently trying to damage this trust."Cryan added that the bank had more than 20 million clients and more than 215 billion euros (around $241 billion) in liquidity reserves, which an analyst said was among the bank's less-depressing characteristics."Deutsche has many business-model issues but liquidity is not an issue," Guy Moszkowski, director of research at Autonomous Research, said over email.By comparison, Morgan Stanley, whose annual revenue was in the same range as Deutsche's, had a global liquidity reserve of $207 billion at the end of Q2. Morgan said that metric was composed of "highly liquid and diversified cash and cash equivalents and unencumbered securities."Cryan, in the letter, also said that the bank meets all capital requirements, and that its capital ratio would be further helped by the offloading of British insurer Abbey Life and the pending sale of its holdings in China's Hua Xia Bank.Some analysts had anticipated the settlement would be negotiated down from the $14 billion first proposed by the DOJ."While we expect the US DOJ (residential mortgage-backed securities) case to be settled well below the ($14 billion) first claimed, the uncertainty is an overhang and in any case we think litigation will remain a strong drain on capital generation through 2017," Credit Suisse said in a recent research note.RELATED:Deutsche Bank Is No Lehman, But Big U.S. Bank Stocks Break Support

Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) late Friday applied to the Federal Reserve for permission to expand its stake beyond 10% in Wells Fargo (WFC).Berkshire disclosed in March it had reached the 10% threshold. None of the other top-four U.S. lending banks have a single investor with an investment the size of Berkshire's stake in Wells Fargo, according to Bloomberg."Berkshire is seeking permission to retain its current ownership position in Wells Fargo and to acquire additional shares of common stock of Wells Fargo for investment purposes," Berkshire said in Friday's filing. "Berkshire does not have any specific transaction or dollar value in mind with respect to any such potential purchases."Wells Fargo is among Berkshire's four top stock holdings, which also include American Express (AXP), Coca-Cola (KO) and IBM (IBM).But Wells Fargo has struggled this year and reported a 5% drop in earnings per share last quarter. It's projected to see EPS shrink in both this quarter and the next.Wells Fargo's capital plan also received approval earlier this week from the Fed. But the lender hasn't announced any changes to its dividend or buyback plans, while peers like JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) have OK'd massive returns to shareholders.Wells Fargo shares edged up less than 0.1% in late trading, after closing down 0.6% at 47. Its stock price has dropped 15% so far this year. Berkshire closed down 0.6% at 143.99 Friday.

The big banks' earnings should suffer further when second-quarter results come out this week, but potential highlights include stronger mortgage revenues for Wells Fargo (WFC) and a better trading environment for Morgan Stanley (MS), Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Bank of America (BAC), analysts say.Still, Wall Street will be focused on the quarters to come, with Brexit and extended low interest rates potentially weighing on results over at least the rest of the year.JPMorgan kicks off earnings season for the banks, with its quarterly results set to be reported on Thursday. Analysts see the bank reporting earnings per share of $1.43, down 7% from a year earlier, with revenue down 1.5% to $24.1 billion. Trading and loan growth are expected to help the bank, but competition in the credit-card business could weigh on results, Credit Suisse said in a report Monday.Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo report on Friday. Analysts expect Citigroup's EPS to slide 27% to $1.10, with revenue falling 8.5% to $17.5 billion. Wells Fargo's EPS is seen edging down 1.9% to $1.01, with revenue rising 4% to around $22.2 billion.IBD'S TAKE: Ahead of the earnings reports, legendary investor Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway sought regulatory permission to boost its stake in this bank above 10%.The results will come after JPMorgan and Deutsche Bank (DB) last week warned that the U.K.'s vote last month to eventually leave the European Union could curb the industry's fee income and access to financial markets across the bloc. M&A dealmaking had already suffered leading up to the vote, according to Mergermarket."We believe the largest driver of stock performance at earnings will be any forward-looking comments that could help shine light on future investment banking and trading activity, or additional expenses, post the Brexit vote," Keefe, Bruyette & Woods said in a research note last week.A formal U.K. separation from the EU could also hurt finance-industry profits and prompt banks to cut or relocate thousands of jobs. Executives from Morgan Stanley, Bank of America, Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan met with U.K. Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne last week to discuss ways to keep London's financial reputation intact.And with the vote to exit the EU heightening global economic uncertainty, the Fed is unlikely to raise the benchmark interest rate anytime this year. That, along with other economic indicators, will likely strain banks' full-year net interest margins, the difference between interest banks take in from loans and what they pay to depositors, Fitch said in a statement Monday. Revenue is also likely to suffer, it added.But Brexit-related trading volatility may have been an opportunity for Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs during the quarter, Credit Suisse said in a separate report Monday."A rebound in credit markets (2Q16 was the best quarter for credit market asset prices since 2009) and elevated trading activity in and around Brexit should drive solid sequential quarter growth in trading revenues and profits," according to the firm.The other big banks report next week. Bank of America reports results next Monday. Wall Street expects EPS to fall 27% to 33 cents, with revenue down 8% to $20.5 billion. Credit Suisse also expects better trading results and loan and deposit growth for the bank.Goldman Sachs, which reports next Tuesday, is expected to report Q2 earnings per share of 3.02, a 53% jump from a year earlier, with revenue down 16% to $7.6 billion. Analysts expect Morgan Stanley's Q2 earnings per share to drop 24% to 60 cents on revenue down 13% to $8.3 billion. Morgan reports results next Wednesday.Bank stocks rose in the stock market today. JPMorgan edged up 0.7%, Bank of America 0.3%, Citigroup 0.7%, Wells Fargo 0.6%, Morgan Stanley 0.5% and Goldman Sachs 1.2%.

Technology giants in the S&P 500 are expected to turn in their worst earnings drop since the recession, dragged down by falling sales of the Apple (AAPL) iPhone.Overall, S&P 500 earnings in the second quarter will fall 4.7% vs. a year earlier, the fourth straight quarterly decline, according to analyst estimates compiled by Thomson Reuters. Revenues are expected to dip 0.9%, the sixth straight quarterly slide.Technology earnings are expected to decline 6% from a year earlier, worse than the 4% fall in Q1, according to Thomson Reuters. Tech revenue should slide 4.8%. But excluding Apple, tech profits should dip just 1%, with revenue off 2.5%.Apple's earnings per share are seen falling 24.9%, as revenue tumbles $7.6 billion from a year earlier to $42 billion. Apple revenue fell 13% in the prior quarter, the first drop in more than decade.Apple's revenue drop will more than offset a combined $5 billion pop from Alphabet (GOOGL) and Facebook (FB). Google parent Alphabet is expected to report a 15.2% rise in earnings as revenue grows by $3 billion, or 17.0%, to $20.7 billion. Facebook's earnings are forecast to expand 62%, as revenue surges by just under $2 billion, or 48.5%.Despite Apple's ongoing slump, the stock has recently shown flickers of life, moving back above its 50-day moving average. But it's still in a yearlong downtrend.Facebook rose 1.2% on Friday, retaking a 117.09 entry point, but in below-average trade. Alphabet is close to retaking its 50-day but is much nearer its highs than Apple is.IBD'S TAKE: Facebook was just one of many notable breakouts Friday, with General Electric and Lowe's among those clearing entry points. Microsoft (MSFT) and Intel (INTC) are expected to see earnings declines of 3.3% and 3.6%, respectively. Weaker iPhone sales won't just hit Apple, but its suppliers too: Skyworks (SWKS) is seen reporting a 9.7% drop in earnings, as revenue falls 7.4% to $750 million.S&P 500 energy earnings are expected to tumble 78.5%, though that's better than Q1's outright loss.The energy sector is "the main drag," but not the only one, Thomson Reuters analyst Greg Harrison told IBD. Six of 10 S&P 500 sectors tracked by the data provider are expected to show negative earnings growth.S&P 500 earnings excluding energy are on tap to fall 0.8%, the first drop in several years, after a scant 0.4% Q1 rise. Revenue should climb 2.1%.Companies tend to beat profit views by a few percentage points overall, so non-energy earnings likely will show a gain.Overall earnings and revenue are expected to return to growth in the current third quarter, as energy companies face easier comparisons.Stock markets typically rally ahead of a profit recovery, as investors anticipate stronger results. The current bull market began in March 2009, months before corporate results bounced back. But sustained profit declines usually occur during a recession -- such as the 2007-2009 slump. Not this time. And while stocks have been choppy for months, they've generally moved sideways to slightly higher.Also, the earnings upturn for the S&P 500, packed with corporate titans with heavy overseas exposure, is looking somewhat less certain after the U.K.'s Brexit vote sent interest rates sliding and boosted the value of the dollar.S&P consumer staples earnings rose 1.5% in the first quarter, but they are expected to slip 1.7% in the second quarter. Wal-Mart (WMT) earnings will likely show a 5.6% earnings decline amid flat revenue. Wal-Mart is continuing to face margin pressures after boosting its base wage to $10 an hour in February.After falling for nearly all of 2015, Wal-Mart shares have gradually recovered, rising last week to their best levels since July 2015.Financials have been another laggard, with sector earnings expected to fall 5.4% after a 10.4% tumble in the first quarter. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) is expected to see a 6.5% earnings drop as revenues dip 1.7%. Earnings for Wells Fargo (WFC) are seen off a more modest 3.3%. JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo and Citigroup (C) are due to report Q2 results in the coming week.Low interest rates have eroded the spread between the interest they can charge borrowers and what they have to pay depositors, and the further drop in borrowing costs since Brexit could mean more of the same in the current quarter.Shares of JPMorgan and other major banks remain far off their highs.Earnings in the consumer discretionary sector are expected to lead the way, rising 8.8% in the quarter. The sector includes Amazon (AMZN), which is projected to have another knockout quarter. The online retail giant and web-services provider is seen posting a 27.4% revenue boost. Amazon earnings should soar to $1.10 a share from 19 cents a year earlier.Amazon shares are at all-time highs after finding support at the 50-day line amid the post-Brexit vote sell-off.The other sectors expected to see positive earnings are health care (up 4.5%); industrials (3.1%) and utilities (1.6%). Health care demand tends to rise steadily, while domestic-focused utilities are shielded from overseas turmoil.Industrials like General Electric (GE) received something of a reprieve from the strong dollar in the second quarter, but that appears at risk of reversing in the third quarter after the U.K. vote to leave the European Union sent the dollar higher.Still, General Electric shares hit an eight-year high on Friday, closing at 32.20, just over a 32.15 buy point.Brexit isn't expected to have much of a direct impact on earnings in the near term, with the U.K. and Europe accounting for about 1% and 7% of S&P 500 revenue, respectively, Thomson Reuters' Harrison said.Yet, indirect effects from the stronger dollar and lower interest rates will be a factor. Earnings estimates for the third quarter have come down just "a tad bit" since Brexit, Sheraz Mian, director of research at Zacks Investment Research, told IBD."We'll begin to learn the full extent (of the impact) in coming days and weeks as companies share their outlook on earnings calls," he added.

JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) are expected to boost shareholder returns at a faster pace than investment banks Morgan Stanley (MS) and Goldman Sachs (GS), top regional banks, and credit card giant Capital One (COF).As investors await the next round of stress-test results Wednesday night, CLSA estimated in a recent report that returns through buybacks and dividends from JPMorgan, BofA, Citi and Wells Fargo could potentially rise to $51 billion over the next year, or nearly two-thirds of earnings, and continue increasing through 2020.The bump in capital return for the big money-center banks would follow their attempts to shore up capital, which helped them pass the first round of annual stress tests last week.In fact, all 33 banks tested passed that round, which quantifies whether banks' capital reserves would meet the Fed's minimum required levels in difficult economic conditions -- including 10% unemployment and negative interest rates on short-term U.S. Treasuries in this year's doomsday scenario. Citigroup led the charge in the improved capital levels."This reinforces our view that the money center banks offer the greatest upside potential for capital return when capital plans are announced next Wednesday," Buckingham Research analyst Jim Mitchell wrote in a research note released Friday.In the second of those two rounds, also known as the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review (CCAR), the Federal Reserve determines whether banks could reasonably deliver planned dividend and buyback increases amid financial strain.Buckingham Research, in a note Friday, said the odds were low that big banks of particular significance to the economy would have their plans rejected by the Fed. Similarly, Keefe, Bruyette & Woods said in a note on Thursday that most banks that it covers "appear well positioned to meet our capital return expectations.""Overall, we believe that stress test results are most positive for (Citigroup), (Bank of America), and Morgan Stanley -- where meaningful increases in capital returns are projected -- but the whole group should benefit if investors view the stress test as becoming less stressful for Universal Banks longer term," KBW said.CLSA, however, warned that from 2013 to 2015, one out of seven banks has had qualitative problems in the second round of the tests, even after performing well on a quantitative level.Bank stocks rallied for a second straight session in the stock market today as they and global markets continue to recover from the U.K.'s decision to leave the European Union. JPMorgan rose 2.8% while Bank of America climbed 3.9% and Citigroup 4.15%. Wells Fargo tacked on 1.9%, Morgan Stanley 2.5% and Goldman Sachs (GS) 2.2%.

Among investors in the largest U.S. companies, no pay package is less popular than the one given to Bed Bath & Beyond (BBBY) Chief Executive Officer Steven Temares.Only 23% of the shares of the housewares retailer were voted in support of its compensation plan at an annual meeting on July 1, the lowest level in the S&P 500 Index, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. Shareholders told the board that the CEO's $19.4 million pay for 2015 was too high, and that his performance goals weren't challenging enough, the Union, N.J.-based company said in its May proxy statement.New York Comptroller Scott Stringer, representing city pension funds, weighed in on the matter with a letter to Bed, Bath & Beyond investors. There's a "gaping and persistent disconnect between CEO pay and company performance," he wrote. The retirement funds, with $160 billion in assets, are among the company's 60 largest shareholders.Bed, Bath & Beyond, which sells everything from coffee to accent rugs, is reducing Temares' target compensation by 14% for 2016 and is making his performance goals more rigorous, according to its proxy statement. Janet Barth, a spokeswoman, declined to comment beyond the regulatory filing.Shareholder disapproval of Bed, Bath & Beyond's pay practices contrasts with a falling number of businesses that fail in so-called say-on-pay votes. About 1% of S&P 500 companies have lost in their most recent nonbinding votes, and the average support level is 93%, data compiled by Bloomberg show.Temares' 2015 package was his largest ever, even as shares fell by more than a third. His pay tops that awarded to Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC) CEO John Stumpf and approaches that given to IBM's (IBM) Virginia Rometty. The awards include a $4 million salary and $15.7 million in stock and options. That was an increase of about $1.1 million from his 2014 package. The exact amount of stock that 57-year-old Temares will receive may change depending on how Bed, Bath & Beyond performs against a group of 47 other companies on earnings and return-on-capital measures.A University of Pennsylvania law graduate who primarily worked in real estate, Temares joined Bed, Bath & Beyond in 1992 before its debut on public exchanges to oversee property transactions as it expanded. Its footprint has grown to more than 1,500 stores from 62 two decades ago. He was promoted to CEO in 2003, earning a $931,000 salary during his first year in the top job.Bed, Bath & Beyond's pay plan also failed with investors last year. The company determined it would make some changes after contacting 25 investors representing 68% of shares, the chain said in the May 31 proxy.Temares' target compensation was reduced to $16.9 million for 2016 in a plan that will be voted on next year. His $4 million salary, the third-largest in the S&P index, will stay the same. He receives the large salary in lieu of a smaller one and a potential bonus, because "cash bonuses promote short-term thinking," according to the filing.Still, Institutional Shareholder Services describes the CEO's salary as "excessive" and notes that it could bloat his golden parachute to $46 million if the company gets bought. The proxy adviser gave Bed, Bath & Beyond a rating of 10, its worst governance score, meaning its structure may have a greater probability of risks to its reputation, long-term value or fiduciary obligations.Bed, Bath & Beyond is joined by car-parts maker BorgWarner (BWA), chemical producer FMC Corp. (FMC), mall operator General Growth Properties (GGP), and utilities owner Exelon (EXC) in receiving less than 50% support in its most recent vote. Representatives of Exelon and BorgWarner said the companies take the votes seriously and are seeking investor feedback. The other companies didn't return requests for comment.In addition to Bed, Bath & Beyond, only Oracle (ORCL) has received less than 50% support in two consecutive years. The Redwood City, Calif.-based software maker is on its fourth failed year. Deborah Hellinger, an Oracle spokeswoman, declined to comment.Stringer noted Bed, Bath & Beyond's compensation committee members Dean Adler, Stanley Barshay and Victoria Morrison have each served on the board for more than 13 years, which "highlights the need for new directors that are able to exercise strong, independent oversight of management." Each received about 65% support after calls by Stringer and ISS to oust them. The committee doesn't have a chair, which is rare.

Here's your Investing Action Plan for Friday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming day. JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) will report earnings, while investors should keep a close eye on Federal Reserve Chairwoman Janet Yellen and shares of off-price retailer Ross Stores (ROST). Stocks To Watch The retail sector has been…

Banks retreated Thursday, testing buy points as Treasury yields fell ahead of earnings from Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo (WFC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) out Friday.Treasury yields were down Thursday after a weaker-than-expected trade report out of China sent investors toward government bonds and other safe assets. Investors have bid financials in recent weeks on the prospect of Federal Reserve rate hikes and the recent rise of long-term yields around the world. JPMorgan fell 0.6% to 67.74 on the stock market today after dropping as low as 66.82, just above the 50-day line. The stock is still in range from a buy point of 65.08, cleared in early August.JPMorgan is expected to report a 17% drop in third-quarter earnings but revenue is seen rising 2% to $23.988 billion when it announces quarterly results Friday.Citigroup shares dipped 0.5% to 48.47 after sinking intraday to 47.54, below a recent 48.24 buy point. Analysts see Citi's Q3 EPS falling 15% on Friday to $1.15, with revenue down 6% to $17.344 billion. Wells Fargo shares slid 1.3% to 44.75 well below its 50-day and 200-day lines. The bank has its own issues after a Consumer Financial Protection Bureau review found employees may have opened more than 2 million accounts and credit cards without consumers' permission. Late Wednesday, Wells said CEO John Stumpf stepped down, effective immediately, replaced by President and COO Tim Sloan.Bank of America (BAC) is slated to report results Monday, Goldman Sachs (GS) Tuesday, and Morgan Stanley (MS) on Wednesday. BofA shares fell 1.25%, continuing a recent slide after peeking into buy range on Monday. Goldman lost 1.1% and Morgan Stanley 0.6%.IBD'S TAKE: U.K.'s Brexit, bad loans at Italian banks and legal troubles from Germany's Deutsche Bank have opened the European market to U.S. banks. Regional banks, more directly dependent of lending than global Wall Street banks, were also under pressure Thursday.Comerica (CMA) shares fell 1.4% to 47.91, still in buy range, with a 46.40 buy point, out of a cup with handle base but falling toward its 50-day line.SunTrust Banks (STI) shares tumbled 2.1% to 44.76 falling toward its 50-day line but still in buy range, above its buy point of 44.42, after consolidating out of a flat base.Regions Financial (RF) stock fell 2.8% to 9.95, finding support at its 50-day line and off session lows of 9.78, but below its buy point of 10.10.RELATED:Bank Of America Gains Share Globally, Vows Blockchain Embrace

Lighting up Twitter (TWTR) Thursday morning is the new "Rogue One: A Star Wars Story" trailer from Walt Disney's (DIS) Lucasfilm. Plus, word that Snapchat parent Snap is closer to an IPO and Wells Fargo's (WFC) announcement that its CEO is retiring have keyboards clacking.The official second trailer for "Rogue One" hit YouTube Thursday morning, and it's getting "Star Wars" fans pumped.That feeling of power after watching the #RogueOne trailer pic.twitter.com/Ts8tyqmcwH— Ziggy (@mrjafri) October 13, 2016The trailer, which reveals more of Jyn Erso's (Felicity Jones) back story -- and features a cameo from Vader himself -- has already produced a theory on who installed the Death Star's fatal flaw.Someone on Mads' character in #RogueOne :
"So he's the one that designed the exhaust port"

I'm howling, ROFLMAO! pic.twitter.com/waiZmfhTXc— ViktoriaGál (@ViktoriaCsendes) October 13, 2016Full trailer here: Meanwhile, Snap reportedly chose Morgan Stanley (MS) and Goldman Sachs (GS) as the lead underwriters for its upcoming initial public offering.That has a lot of investors and reporters alike eager to take a look at the numbers behind Snapchat.this is good. also how is snap ready to ipo. https://t.co/sarcoSnRA3this S-1 is going to be like nectar from the gods— Spooky Non-GAAP Rev (@alex) October 12, 2016Still others find the disappearing-photo social network an affirmation of the power of young folks' innovation.Millennials are inspiring. Snapchat founders turned down $3billion offer from Facebook awhile ago. Now said to be worth 25b with rumored IPO— BmoreFab (@BmoreFab) October 13, 2016And news that Wells Fargo's chief executive, John Stumpf, is stepping down is stirring up emotions.Wells Fargo CEO John Stumpf giant dirty scam caught up to him. He resigns in disgrace. Wells should claw back his 200M & face Justice Dept.— Eric Schiffer (@ericschiffer) October 12, 2016Stumpf is resigning in the midst of a cross-selling scandal involving the reported creation of about 2 million fake customer bank accounts, for which the bank was fined $185 million by regulators.For his retirement package Wells Fargo CEO John Stumpf will receive 17 new checking accounts, 13 new credit cards & 10,000 bank pens— Ben Carlson (@awealthofcs) October 12, 2016Now that you're caught up, here's a look at the stock market today.RELATED:Snapchat Said To Select Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs To Lead IPOWells Fargo CEO To Step Down Without Severance Amid Cross-Selling Scandal

With JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) set to report third-quarter earnings on Friday, the landscape for the big banks has enough in common with what we saw in Q2.In other words, the Fed still opted not to raise interest rates, hurting the banks' net interest margins. The state of the U.S. consumer remained generally solid. And the global "economic uncertainty?" That was still there too."During the third quarter, banks faced another challenging operating environment, with uncertainty and volatility arising after the Brexit vote and lackluster global economic growth continued," Keefe, Bruyette & Woods analyst Brian Kleinhanzl said in a research note.The only good news some analysts see is no bad news."Unfortunately, the positive might come in just not having any negatives," Edward Jones analyst Shannon Stemm said.But Citigroup last month cited better trading in Q3 but weaker-than-anticipated investment banking, while JPMorgan remained upbeat on the economy and the state of the consumer.Other factors will be likely to dominate the financial world's attention. Many observers will likely be cued into any commentary surrounding Wells Fargo's cross-selling scandal — in which authorities said the bank's employees created as many as 2 million unauthorized consumer accounts to hit sales targets.The scandal has cost John Stumpf his job as CEO and chairman. The bank said late Wednesday COO Tim Sloan is taking over as CEO and Stephen Sanger is taking over as chair.The Wall Street Journal reported that the bank outlined plans to rebound from the scandal during a conference call on Monday. Details from those plans could be presented on Friday.The scandal over the bank's cross-selling, a point of pride for management only a few years ago, led to some intense questioning from Congress about the bank's culture and executives' knowledge of the sales practices. The financial impact during Q3, however, was limited.Wall Street expects Wells Fargo's earnings per share to fall 4% to $1.01. Revenue is seen rising 1.5% to $22.2 billion."The investment community's going to be looking for some specifics from the management team on what they're going to do to adjust sales practices, and what's that going to look like from a cost standpoint?" Stemm said."And then I think there will be follow-ons to some of the other banks, too – 'What do your sales practices look like? What are you doing to monitor both risky behavior?' What does that look like for future compliance costs?"Beyond cross-selling, KBW expects Wells' net interest margins to be constrained, even after the bank grew loans considerably in quarters past.JPMorgan, another bank KBW said was dependent on loan growth after activity rose rapidly in recent quarters, is expected to report EPS down 17% to $1.39.The bank's equity markets could be a bright spot, KBW said. Revenue is expected to climb 2% to $23.988 billion.Citigroup's EPS, meanwhile, is expected to fall 15% to $1.15, with revenue down 6% to $17.344.Citigroup in June also acquired Costco's (COST) U.S. co-brand credit-card portfolio from American Express (AXP). Citi and Costco announced their co-branded credit-card deal last March."(Q3) will be the first full quarter with Costco in the numbers and management has already indicated that the performance within the Costco portfolio is exceeding management's expectations," Kleinhanzl wrote. "If Citi can show material growth in receivables from the Costco portfolio then we would expect shares of Citigroup to do well at earnings."KBW also said Citigroup may have gotten more of a bump from fixed income, currencies and commodities trading. But the bank has said that investment banking during the quarter was "lighter than estimated."JPMorgan dipped 0.3% in the stock market today, while Citigroup lost 0.6% and Wells Fargo eased 0.3%. Bank of America (BAC) fell 0.5%. Morgan Stanley (MS) fell 0.8%, while Goldman Sachs (GS) added 0.15%.IBD'S TAKE: While U.S. banking giants face tighter restrictions from regulators, their stronger capital positions have helped them take market share from European rivals, who have yet to fully recover from the financial crisis.

Bank stocks have rallied in recent weeks as the Fed has shown more openness to raising interest rates. Other factors could extend their gains, Morgan Stanley notes.That uptrend for the banks "could continue if oil prices edge higher, inflation picks up, Yellen raises rates, corporates re-engage," Morgan Stanley analyst Betsy Graseck wrote in a research note. "Risks include a divided government post-election, weak C&I growth, and political backlash."Other risks for the banks include commercial lending, which KBW expects to weaken after the U.K.'s vote in June to leave the European Union caused businesses to put plans on hold, which in turn meant less borrowing.Bank of America reports Monday, Goldman reports next Tuesday, and Morgan Stanley reports on Wednesday.IBD's money center banking industry group, where most of the major banks are, was ranked 131st out of 197 groups on Tuesday. It has been in the bottom half of the table for many months.RELATED:U.S. Banking Giants Gain As Deutsche Bank, European Financials TeeterBank Of America Gains Share Globally, Vows Blockchain Embrace

Treasuries swung from gains to losses Wednesday as Saudi Arabia's $17.5 billion bond sale -- the largest ever from an emerging-market nation -- weighed on U.S. sovereign debt.Benchmark yields fluctuated as Saudi Arabia sold the dollar-denominated bonds, with proceeds to go toward shoring up finances battered by a slide in oil prices. The deal came as companies including Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC) and Mondelez International (MDLZ) sell debt, putting U.S. corporate bond sales on track for their busiest week in a month, with issuance set to top $25 billion."Any time you see a big new issuer coming in, there's a potential for crowding out," said George Goncalves, head of U.S. interest-rates research at Nomura Securities, one of 23 primary dealers that trade with the Federal Reserve. "It doesn't help the Treasury market, that's for sure."Treasuries have slumped in October as a bond-market gauge of inflation expectations has climbed to the highest since May. In a speech at a Boston Fed conference last week, Chair Janet Yellen laid out the argument for keeping monetary policy easy while hinting at letting the economy run hot. Traders see policy tightening this year as an odds-on proposition, even if markets are also pricing in a gradual pace of future increases.Treasury 10-year yields were little changed at 1.74% as of 4:25 p.m. ET, after declining six basis points over the previous two days, according to Bloomberg Bond Trader data. The price of the 1.5% security due in August 2026 was 97-26/32.The Saudi offering eclipsed Argentina's $16.5 billion sale in April as the largest ever from a developing nation. It followed a week of presentations to prospective buyers at which officials emphasized the kingdom's efforts to diversify the $650 billion economy away from oil.In addition to potentially luring away U.S. debt investors seeking higher yields, heavy corporate and sovereign issuance can weigh on Treasuries through the mechanics of how bonds are sold. Issuers of dollar-denominated debt often enter into what's known as rate-lock agreements, in which they bet on Treasury prices falling to guard against higher yields. Once the debt is sold, the wagers are ended.The probability of a U.S. rate increase by December is about 63%, fed fund futures indicate. The calculations assume that the effective fed funds rate will average 0.625% after the next increase. Swaps trading implies the rate will be about 0.65% in a year, and 0.77% in two years, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.The U.S. economy maintained a steady growth pace between late August and early October, as a tight labor market with nascent wage pressures contributed to a "mostly positive" outlook, according to the Fed's latest Beige Book, an economic survey by reserve banks.The gap between yields on five- and 30-year debt, a gauge of the yield curve, was about 1.28 percentage points, near the highest since June.Traders await the European Central Bank's policy-setting meeting Thursday for signals about its monetary stimulus efforts. Most economists in a Bloomberg survey predict it will prolong its 1.7 trillion euro ($1.9 trillion) bond-buying program in December and won't start to taper its asset purchases before the second half of 2017."There aren't going to be any significant changes tomorrow," said David Keeble, New York-based head of fixed-income strategy at Credit Agricole. "Without the taper talk, I think longer-dated bonds will do pretty well."

Morgan Stanley (MS) reported much-better-than-expected third-quarter earnings Wednesday as fixed-income trading revenue almost tripled, the biggest surge for that business on Wall Street.Earnings per share rose 69% to $1.02 a share, the U.S. investment bank said. Net income rose 57% to $1.6 billion.Chief Executive Officer James Gorman, 58, has sought to convince investors he can lower costs while steadying profit from bond trading, a business that weighed on returns in the past. Gorman said in June that the fixed-income and commodities business is capable of generating $4 billion in annual revenue even after being scaled back, which included a decision to cut 25% of the division's staff last year."Our expense initiatives remain on track," Gorman said in the statement. "Overall the results reflect steady progress against our long-term strategic goals."Fixed-income trading revenue rose to $1.5 billion, exceeding analysts' estimates of $1 billion. Equity trading climbed 5.6% to $1.9 billion, compared with the estimate of $1.83 billion.Companywide revenue rose 15% to $8.91 billion, exceeding the $8.14 billion estimate of 18 analysts surveyed by Bloomberg.Morgan Stanley rose 1.2% to 32.70 before the opening bell on the stock market today. That indicates that the stock will open above a 32.43 buy point.Morgan Stanley shares have climbed 1.6% this year, compared with a 0.6% gain for the 64-company S&P 500 Financials Index.Morgan Stanley is the last of the six biggest U.S. banks to report results. Goldman Sachs (GS) on Tuesday posted earnings that beat analysts' estimates on a 49 percent surge in fixed-income trading revenue. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) on Friday topped estimates on a 48%  jump in revenue from the same business. Citigroup (C) and Bank of America (BAC) surpassed predictions, too, as fixed-income revenue increased 35% and 39%, respectively. Wells Fargo (WFC), contending with a scandal in its consumer business, also beat estimates.RELATED: Bank Of America Earnings Top Q3 Views On Trading Jump, Cost CurbsWells Fargo Backs Dividend Amid Scandal; JPMorgan, Citigroup Top

Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) is still adding to his stockpile of Phillips 66 (PSX) shares, this time purchasing about 1.02 million more shares between Monday and Wednesday, according to a Wednesday SEC filing.The shares of the oil refiner were priced between 77.0824 and 77.3906.Berkshire has been steadily building its Phillips 66 stake, adding to his now more-than-15% stake through much of this year.Shares of Phillips rose 2.8% to 79.10 in the stock market today, finding support at the 50-day moving average. Shares of Berkshire Hathaway advanced 0.6%.IBD'S TAKE: Want to invest like Warren Buffett? IBD's Marketsmith has a Warren Buffett screen, focusing on the kind of value plays the Oracle from Omaha loves. Marketsmith also lets you create your own screens, and highlights stocks breaking out or near buy points. Take a free trial of Marketsmith.Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway is the largest shareholder in embattled Wells Fargo (WFC), whose product sales tactics have come under federal scrutiny after it was revealed that more than 2 million accounts were opened without prior client knowledge. The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau levied a $195 million fine last week, with reports Wednesday that federal prosecutors have opened a criminal probe.Wells Fargo fell 0.8%, off intraday lows but extending its losing streak to five sessions.RELATED:Wells Fargo Drops Product Sales Goals For Retail BankersBuffett's Berkshire Ups Apple Stake As Others Sell iPhone Maker, NetflixApple, Facebook, Berkshire, Chipotle Lead Insider TradesBuffett's Berkshire, CEOs At Tesla, GE, Netflix Lead Insider Trades

FB Financial (FBK), the holding company for regional bank FirstBank, and Bermuda-based Bank of N.T. Butterfield (NTB) rose in their debuts after pricing their initial public offerings late Thursday.That follows regional bank First Hawaiian (FHB), which has rallied since its IPO debut last month.The recent crop of successful bank IPOs comes ahead of the Federal Reserve's two-day meeting next week and amid speculation over when the central bank might decide to raise interest rates. It also comes as JPMorgan Chase (JPM) this week touted its success with millennials, and Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) showcased their international potential.Worries of a rate hike have weighed on the broader market. But a benchmark rate increase from the Fed would prompt banks to raise their own interest rates, potentially boosting net interest margins that have lagged amid the central bank's caution on a hike. Higher interest rates, however, also risk hurting borrowing and consumer spending. And it's hard for bank stocks to power ahead in a generally sluggish market.JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon this week bluntly urged: "Let's just raise rates," saying the economy was in decent shape, and Fed officials have in recent weeks seemed more open to the idea of a rate hike. In August, Fed chair Janet Yellen said "the case for an increase in the federal funds rate has strengthened in recent months."But Lael Brainard of the Fed's Board of Governors on Monday signaled that she would prefer to wait. The odds of a hike next week or in November are slim. There is about a 53% chance of at least one move by the December meeting.FB Financial, which is profitable, climbed 9.2% to 20.75 in the stock market today. The Nashville-based company, which serves Tennessee and parts of Alabama and Georgia, had priced its IPO at 19. Earlier this month, the firm said it was selling 5,882,352 shares of its common stock with a price range of 16-18 per share."The market area has attractive economic, population, and household income growth statistics that provide a favorable business environment," the company said in an SEC filing. "We believe that the strong economic growth in our market area has created a favorable operating environment for us."Q2 profit rose 42% vs. a year earlier.IBD'S TAKE: Bank stocks have rallied on more bullish remarks from Fed officials. See which bank stocks could be within buy range.Bank of N.T. Butterfield, trading on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol NTB, rose 5.3% to 24.75 on Friday. Late Thursday, said it had priced its U.S. offering of 10,638,298 common shares at 23.50 apiece, in the middle of its expected range. Butterfield, which provides specialty international finance stories, itself sold 5.96 million shares, with existing holders selling the rest.Butterfield earned $77.7 million for 2015, down by $30.5 million vs. a year earlier. But Q2 profit rose 27% vs. a year earlier.First Hawaiian fell 0.65% to 26.18, but is up 14% from its IPO price of 23.JPMorgan fell 1.2% to 65.82, but found support just above the 50-day line and a recent 65.08 buy point. Bank of America fell 1.15% and Citigroup 1.4%. Wells Fargo (WFC), currently in hot water over its sales tactics, sank 1.6% and is nearly 7% this week.Meanwhile, emergency messaging software firm Everbridge (EVBG) jumped 27% to 15.25 in its Nasdaq debut. Everbridge, which priced at 12 late Thursday, follows a recent run of hugely successful tech IPOs.RELATED:Everbridge Rises In Debut After Acacia, Twilio, Line IPOs BoomWells Fargo Eliminates Sales Product Goals After Massive FraudWhat Does HealthEquity Know That Wells Fargo, JPMorgan Don't?

Apple (AAPL) iPhone demand appears higher than conservative forecasts, giving Apple and the broader markets a lift. Wells Fargo (WFC) is still reeling from the major cross-selling fraud scandal. General Motors (GM) said its Chevy Bolt will have a higher battery range than the Tesla Motors (TSLA) Model 3, as Tesla and others gave autonomous vehicle updates. Two huge agribusiness mergers were announced.The major averages followed the Sept. 9 sell-off with several large and up-and-down days. Fed Gov. Lael Brainard's dovish comments Monday helped reassure investors that a September rate hike was highly unlikely. Meanwhile, Apple powered ahead on stronger-than-expected demand for its iPhone 7. Apple, which boasts the world's biggest market cap, is part of the Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow industrials. The Nasdaq retook its 50-day line and rose 2.3% for the week. The S&P 500 and Dow, up 0.5% and 0.2%, respectively, remained below that key support level.Apple started selling its 10th-generation smartphone, the iPhone 7, on Friday along with its second-generation smartwatch, Apple Watch Series 2. AT&T (T), Sprint (S) and T-Mobile (TMUS) said iPhone preorders were better than for last year's iPhone 6S, while Verizon (VZ) said they were in the normal range for an iPhone launch. Apple said it sold out its initial production run of iPhone 7 Plus and jet-black color iPhone 7 handsets. Samsung's recall of its Galaxy Note 7 smartphones because of battery fires could help Apple gain smartphone market share, analysts said.Apple rose 11.4% to 114.92, its best weekly gain in years and blasting past a 110.33 buy point on Wednesday.August retail sales fell 0.3% and industrial production sank 0.4%, both worse than expected. But struggling apparel stores, groceries and restaurants reported higher sales. September's Philly Fed manufacturing index jumped far more than expected, while the New York Fed's Empire State index remaining negative. But the most important economic news may have come Monday, when Federal Gov. Lael Brainard signaled she would prefer to be cautious with rate hikes. That reinforced expectations that the central bank will take no action at this week's policy meeting.Wells Fargo shares continued to slide over the cross-selling fraud scandal, losing nearly 7% for the week. After paying a $195 million fine and firing 5,300 workers, Wells reportedly faces a federal criminal probe. The Senate Banking Committee is set to hold a hearing on Tuesday. Meanwhile, Deutsche Bank (DB) tumbled 9.4% Friday after the Justice Department said it wanted $14 billion to settle a probe into its mortgage securities from 2005-2007."Let's just raise rates," JPMorgan (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon said during the week, following more bullish sentiment from Fed officials over a potential rate hike that would likely boost banks' finances. At the Barclays Global Financial Services conference, Bank of America (BAC) said Q3 investment banking had improved, while the quarter so far for Citigroup (C) appeared more mixed. Both touted their international prospects.Intel expects third-quarter revenue of $15.3 billion to $15.9 billion vs. its prior range of $14.4 billion to $15.4 billion. That's a 7.8% yearly gain at the midpoint, the best since Q3 2014. The chip giant largely credited "replenishment of PC supply chain inventory" but also is "seeing some signs of improving PC demand." Intel also raised gross margin targets. Intel shares rose 3% Friday, briefly hitting its highest levels since January 2001.Oil prices were on track to fall for the week as reports indicated that production is rising faster and demand increasing at a slower pace. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries released its monthly oil report Monday that production from nonmembers will increase by 200,000 barrels a day in 2017 vs. a prior outlook of a decline or 150,000 barrels per day in its August report. On Tuesday, the International Energy Agency said in its monthly report that global crude demand will only rise by 1.3 million barrels a day this year as Q3 demand slows at a faster pace than expected. On Wednesday, the Energy Information Administration reported a surprise 559,000 barrel drop in domestic crude stockpiles. But production rose by 0.4% to 8.493 million barrels per day. Also the IEA debuted its World Energy Investment report, which found that investment in the energy sector in 2015 fell 8% year-over-year to $1.8 trillion.General Motors' all-electric Chevrolet Bolt, due out this fall, will have an EPA-estimated 238 miles per charge, topping Tesla's promised range for its Model 3, which won't be out for another year. Tesla said its new Autopilot software upgrade would rely more on radars than cameras, an update that Musk says would've likely prevented a fatal crash; Mobileye (MBLY) said it split with Tesla over Autopilot safety issues. Ford (F) highlighted EV and self-driving development in its strategic plans. Uber rolled out a self-driving fleet in Pittsburgh made up of souped-up Ford Fusions.RELATED:Is GM's Chevy Bolt EV A Tesla Model 3 Party Pooper?Mobileye Rips Tesla Autopilot Safety As War Of Words IntensifiesFord Sees Self-Driving Cars Making Up 20% Of Sales By 2030Tesla Autopilot 8.0 Will Focus On Radar, Not CamerasTesla Wins Record Grid Battery Storage Deal After Methane DisasterIt was a busy week for mergers and acquisitions, with Bayer (BAYRY) reaching a deal to buy Monsanto (MON) while fertilizer makers Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan (POT) and Agrium (AGU) agreed to merge.After a series of raised bids, herbicide and seeds giant Monsanto finally accepted a $128-a-share takeover offer from Bayer. The $66 billion deal, including debt, also includes a $2 billion breakup fee in the event of antitrust objections. Monsanto shares fell more than 3% for the week to 103.45 amid speculation that regulators may block the deal.Fertilizer producers Potash and Agrium announced a merger in which Potash shareholders will receive 0.4 share and Agrium investors will receive 2.23 shares of the new company for each of their existing shares. The deal comes as farmers cut back amid weak crop prices. HP Inc. (HPQ) announced a $1.05 billion deal to buy the printer business of Samsung Electronics. Samsung has agreed to make a $100 million to $300 million equity investment in HP after the deal closes.Industrial gas giants Praxair (PX) and Germany's Linde broke off merger talks over the fate of Linde's Munich headquarters.RELATED:Bayer, Monsanto Agree On $66 Billion Deal; Investors DoubtfulOracle reported that fiscal Q1 earnings rose 4% to 55 cents while revenue climbed 2% to $8.6 billion, both below estimates. But Oracle's cloud business is booming: The business software giant said SaaS (software-as-a-service) and PaaS (platform-as-a-service) revenue rose 77% from the year-earlier quarter, to $798 million. Oracle guide Q3 EPS and sales views lower but sees cloud offerings up about 80%, above Wall Street targets. "The challenge for management is to deliver on its promises to get margins back up as cloud investments scale," said Jason Ader, a William Blair analyst.Oracle stock fell 4.8% on Friday, closing below its 200-day line for the first time in six months.Twitter began live streaming of the first of 10 Thursday night NFL games. On Wednesday, the struggling social network launched an app that lets Apple TV, Amazon (AMZN) TV and Microsoft (MSFT) Xbox get Twitter's live streaming video, including the NFL games, and other content. And as soon as Monday, the sacrosanct 140-character limit to tweets will get fudged. Reportedly, Twitter will exclude certain ancillary items from the character count, including photos and GIFs. Twitter stock rose 5.5% rising above its 10-week and 40-week moving averages.RELATED:Twitter Brings Its Live Video, Other Content To Apple, Amazon TV

Wells Fargo (WFC) said it will eliminate all sales product goals for retail banking employees as of Jan. 1, in an effort to regain customer and investor confidence after a widespread sales scandal."Our objective has always been and continues to be to meet our customers' financial needs and drive customer satisfaction," said CEO John Stumpf in a statement. "We are eliminating product sales goals because we want to make certain our customers have full confidence that our retail bankers are always focused on the best interests of customers."The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau announced last week that it was fining Wells Fargo $185 million for employees creating millions of additional accounts for customers without their knowledge in order to meet sales goals. Wells Fargo fired 5,300 employees.Richard Cordray, head of the CFPB, told CNBC on Monday that his agency hasn't seen similar practices "on any kind of systematic basis at any other bank."Wells Fargo also stands out vs. its banking rivals as a stock. Shares fell 2.4% on Friday, dropping below its 200-day line, then edged lower Monday after undercutting its 50-day average intraday. Wells Fargo fell 3.3% to finish trading at 46.96 on the stock market today.Meanwhile, JPMorgan Chase (JPM) is still in a buy zone after breaking out of a consolidation with a 65.08 pivot point. Bank of America (BAC) is consolidating at eight-month highs. Citigroup (C) is approaching resistance at the 48 price level. JPMorgan lost 0.8% to 66.53, Bank of America dropped 1.1% to 15.72 and Citigroup lost 1.8% to 46.92.RELATED:Where Do Millennials Bank? JPMorgan Says It Beats BofA, Wells FargoBank Stocks Hold Ground As Fed Buzz Builds: Which One Is A Buy Now?

JPMorgan Chase (JPM) on Monday urged the Federal Reserve to "just raise rates" and touted its popularity with mobile-oriented millennials.JPMorgan argued in a presentation that it is outperforming rivals in attracting millennials, with more from that generation gravitating toward its Chase checking, savings or credit-card accounts than toward Bank of America (BAC) and Wells Fargo (WFC).The bank's attempt to position itself as the top choice for millennials, who now outnumber baby boomers, comes as big financial institutions try to offer more mobile services to tap the spending of an increasingly smartphone-oriented portion of the population that manages more of its money online."Millennials make up the majority of our new deposit customers, and we lead competitors in primary relationships with millennials," according to slides accompanying a presentation given at the Barclays Global Financial Services conference.Fifty-seven percent of Chase's recent checking-account acquisitions have come from the millennial population, Gordon Smith, CEO of Consumer & Community Banking, said in the presentation.Twenty-two percent of millennials preferred Chase as their primary financial institution for checking and savings accounts, compared to 19% with Bank of America and 14% with Wells Fargo, the presentation said, citing research that TNS Retail Banking Monitor conducted from Q2 2015 to Q1 2016. The figures and rankings were similar for credit-card accounts. Active mobile users had risen 18% during the first half of the year.Smith's presentation materials also said mobile payment services like Apple (AAPL) Pay had yet to fully take off but added that Chase wanted to be "wherever our consumers want to spend."He also remained upbeat on the economy, adding he was "not seeing customers taking on excessive levels of debt" and that he was not concerned about a slight rise in credit-card 30-day delinquencies and net charge-offs. Mortgage delinquencies and net charge-offs had continued to trend downward, company data showed.Smith's remarks about the economy echoed comments made earlier in the day by JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon, who urged the Fed to move ahead with raising rates during an event at the Economic Club of Washington.After contending that that the U.S. economy was "actually doing OK," Dimon said that "twenty-five basis points is a drop in the bucket." He added: "Let's just raise rates."JPMorgan shares finished 0.6% higher in the stock market today.IBD'S TAKE: Bank stocks have rallied on more bullish remarks from Fed officials. While few are buys right now, read this story to find out which bank stocks are buys. Bank of America shares rose 1%, while Wells Fargo fell 0.4%, finding support at its 50-day average.Last week, Wells Fargo agreed to pay $190 million to settle fraud charges that included thousands of bank employees opening fake accounts with customers' money. On Friday, shares dropped 2.4% to dip below their 200-day average.RELATED:Bank Stocks Have Work To Do, But Could Be Worth Watching

As major banks in the U.S., Japan and especially Europe continue to be battered by the Brexit storm and squeezed by historically low or even negative interest rates, some global investors are finding relative calm in an unexpected place: emerging market financial institutions. IBD's Banks-Foreign group has, for the past eight weeks, ranked in the top 50 among the 197 industry…

JPMorgan (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon expressed doubt about the U.K.'s ability to sell financial services freely after the nation voted to leave the European Union, and Deutsche Bank (DB) warned that the Brexit would hurt banks' revenue. But industry executives said they'd work to keep London a major world financial hub."If we have that passport after Brexit, we likely would not have to make any change at all," Dimon told the Il Sole 24 Ore, a media outlet based in Italy, according to Bloomberg.Financial "passporting" allows banks with operations in the U.K. to more easily do business with the rest of the European Union."But I think the European Union will not accept that," Dimon continued. "It will put more conditions on the U.K. and might force banks to become smaller in London."JPMorgan shares rose 0.65% to 60.58 in the stock market today. Shares of the big banks have struggled to reclaim their 50-day and 200-day lines, as well as the ground they lost following the Brexit vote late last month.IBD'S TAKE: Despite fears of Brexit fallout hitting banks' results, the Fed's latest stress tests showed top lenders like JPMorgan can weather a severe economic downturn and still return billions of dollars in capital to shareholders.While Dimon said he hoped a formal separation from the EU might not happen -- the vote was technically non-binding -- he added that the bank could shift "a few thousand" employees to other areas if the impact from the separation got too difficult to deal with, Bloomberg said.What the financial terrain would look like if the U.K. did leave the EU is unclear, but the pound plunged to 30-year lows amid the economic uncertainly created by the vote. Analysts have worried that a decision to leave the bloc would gouge banks' profits, hurt housing prices and force banks to move employees out of London.Meanwhile, executives from JPMorgan, Morgan Stanley (MS), Bank of America (BAC) and Goldman Sachs (GS) met with Chancellor of the Exchequer George Osborne, Bloomberg said.They issued a statement saying they would work together "to help London retain its position as the leading international financial center."Bank of America shares rose 1.2%, Morgan Stanley added 2.2%, and Goldman Sachs edged up 1%.Deutsche Bank also warned of "a smaller fee pool" and "a lot of uncertainty" for the banks following the vote, according to Bloomberg.Even before the vote, merger activity suffered in the U.K. amid the uncertainty. During the first half of the year, there were 638 U.K. merger deals worth $58.2 billion, the lowest value in six years and down from record levels last year, the firm Mergermarket said in a report this week."Firms postponed deals, cautious of the impact exchange rates and questioning what they will actually be buying into, unaware of how future negotiations will affect them," Mergermarket said in the report.JPMorgan, Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) are slated to report their quarterly earnings next week. Analysts will be on the lookout for further commentary on how the Brexit might affect banks' future results.

They say good things come to those who wait. But in the stock market, good things come to those who prepare.Here are three simple ways to quickly get ready for the week ahead and fine tune your action plan and watch list as Q2 earnings season kicks into high gear.Earnings reports can drive stocks sharply higher -– or lower. So during earnings season, it's crucial to have a game plan for every stock you own or have on your watch list that is set to report soon.The Earnings Preview column, published on Fridays, highlights companies that are on deck to report their latest quarterly numbers, from big-cap stocks like Apple (AAPL), Facebook (FB),  Amazon.com (AMZN) and Tesla Motors (TSLA) to lesser-known names like Mobileye (MBLY), Veeva Systems (VEEV) and Acacia Communications (ACIA).One sound piece of stock market advice is to "plan your trade, and trade your plan."The Investing Action Plan column helps you set your strategy for the week ahead, then execute and adjust that plan with daily updates throughout the week.You'll get a heads-up of what potentially market-moving events to look for, such as Federal Reserve announcements or stress test results for Bank of America (BAC), Wells Fargo (WFC) and other financial institutions. Plus, with the daily updates, you'll get a quick review of those events, what the results mean for investors and what to watch for next.No matter what type of market we're currently in, you want to continually refresh and revise your list of stocks to watch, with a focus on top-rated leaders that are nearing a potential buy zone.A quick way to zero in on such names is to check the chart analysis in IBD Stock Lists.You'll find alerts to potential bases and buy points in the concise, one-line analysis provided for each stock in lists like the IBD 50, Sector Leaders, IPO Leaders and IBD Big Cap 20.Excerpt from IBD Extra Newsletter

Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C), Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan (JPM), Morgan Stanley (MS) and Wells Fargo (WFC) and 27 other banks passed the first round of Federal Reserve stress tests on Thursday, despite losses of $526 billion forecast in the central bank's most dire economic scenario.Investors will now turn their attention to the second round of stress-test results, which the Fed releases Wednesday. Wall Street tends to focus more on that round, as the Fed determines whether the banks' requests for bigger dividends and stock buybacks are reasonable given the impact the firms would sustain under the test scenarios.The Fed said the 33 banks tested this year would sustain $385 billion in loan losses under the 2016 test circumstances, which include a sharp drop in housing prices, 10% unemployment and negative rates on short-term U.S. Treasuries, a notable difference from the tests last year. Consumer loans accounted for 52% of forecast loan losses among the banks, the Fed said.The Fed also noted that its hypothetical conditions were softer on investment banks' profits, but that the negative short-term interest rates were harder hit by the negative rates."As compared to last year's severely adverse scenario, firms that are active in trading and market activities saw smaller losses in net income as a result of less severe stress in the equity markets, but firms more focused on traditional lending activities were more affected by negative short-term interest rates and greater stress in the real economy," the Fed said.Analysts largely expected the banks to get through the first round unscathed, although the Fed could still reject their capital plans next week.Among major banks, Citi came out with the highest Tier 1 common capital ratio -- a way of quantifying banks' most durable assets and the most-watched metric for the tests -- at a 9.2% minimum in the Fed's darkest scenario. Morgan Stanley had 9.1%, Goldman Sachs 8.4%, JPMorgan 8.3%, BofA 8.1% and Wells Fargo 7.2%. The Fed requires at least 5% to pass.Huntington Bancshares (HBAN) came closest to falling short, with a ratio of 5%.JPMorgan rose 1% after hours on the stock market today, Bank of America added 1.7% and Citigroup gained 2.7%, and Wells Fargo edged up 0.6%. Investment banks Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, seen as potentially more vulnerable to recent market swings, were up 0.8% and 0.9%, respectively.The Fed first posed the economic scenario to the 33 banks in January. Banks responded with their stress-test results and capital-return plans in April."Today's results have reaffirmed what we already knew — U.S. banks are strongly capitalized and remain well-positioned to serve as a critical economic driver going forward," American Bankers Association CEO Rob Nichols said in a statement following the release of the stress-test results."Even under the worst imaginable conditions, banks' strong capital positions and solid balance sheets would allow them to continue lending and meeting the needs of their clients, customers and communities."

Shares of JPMorgan (JPM), Citigroup (C), Morgan Stanley (MS), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Bank of America (BAC) rallied ahead of the outcome of the U.K.'s "Brexit" referendum, with investors anticipating that the nation will vote to stay in the European Union and, in turn, preserve the financial-industry status quo.As uncertainty lingers ahead of the vote, hedge funds and banks are using private exit-polling data for the vote, likely to anticipate any big market moves that might come from the results, according to the Financial Times.JPMorgan rose 2% in the stock market today. Bank of America was up 2.8%, Citigroup 3.7%, Morgan Stanley 2.6%, Goldman Sachs 2.6% and Wells Fargo 1.6%.European banks were also up. Deutsche Bank (DB) jumped 5%, HSBC (HSBC) 2.6%, Barclays (BCS) 3.3%, Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) 2.1%, Credit Suisse (CS) 4.3% and UBS (UBS) 3.4%.Deutsche Bank also confirmed Thursday that it will shut a quarter of its German branches, leaving it with 535 vs. an original target of only 500.U.S. banks have warned that many jobs in the U.K. could be cut or relocated if the U.K. departed the EU. Analysts have predicted that such a decision could damage the British pound, send unemployment higher, drive banks' EPS lower and restrict the U.K.-located banks' access to European financial markets.

Goldman Sachs (GS), once the most profitable firm on Wall Street, reported a 47% increase in third-quarter earnings as revenue from bond trading surpassed analysts' predictions.Net income rose to $2.09 billion, or $4.88 a share, from $1.43 billion, or $2.90, a year earlier, the New York-based company said in a statement Tuesday.Chief Executive Officer Lloyd Blankfein, 62, has cut jobs, given responsibility to more junior employees and lowered compensation to reduce expenses and preserve flexibility to ramp up trading when activity returned. This quarter shows the benefit of the strategy, which attracted some skepticism among analysts as competitors such as Morgan Stanley (MS) decided to retreat instead."We saw solid performance across the franchise that helped counter typical seasonal weakness," Blankfein said in the statement.Fixed-income trading revenue rose to $1.96 billion, beating the $1.7 billion estimate of five analysts surveyed by Bloomberg. Equities-trading revenue of $1.78 billion surpassed the $1.69 billion estimate. The sales-and-trading division is overseen by Isabelle Ealet, Pablo Salame and Ashok Varadhan.The bank is battling sluggish revenue prospects and trying to show investors it can generate a return on equity above its cost of capital after years of returns often in excess of 20 percent were the envy of the industry.Goldman Sachs enacted at least four rounds of job reductions in New York this year that accounted for more than 400 dismissals. It also extended cuts in its fixed-income division to roughly 10% of staff, double what it normally culls each year, and eliminated dozens of managing directors, executive directors and vice presidents across the mergers and debt and equity capital-markets teams.In recent weeks, Goldman Sachs has reduced its projection for job cuts in Asia. The firm now intends to trim about 15% of its investment-banking jobs in Asia outside Japan, fewer than the 25%, or 75 positions, initially considered last month, a person with knowledge of the matter said Monday.The company has also sought to develop new businesses to help generate revenue and boost returns. The bank this month began offering loans through its online-lending platform Marcus by Goldman Sachs, which offers unsecured consumer loans to creditworthy borrowers. It also has an online deposit-taking franchise that it purchased from General Electric (GE). this year. Consumers can open a savings account there with as little as $1.Goldman Sachs's stock slumped 6.2% this year through Monday, lagging behind the 0.2% drop for the S&P 500 Financials Index.Goldman Sachs is the fifth of the six biggest U.S. banks to report results, with Morgan Stanley set to announce earnings on Wednesday. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) kicked off the U.S. financial industry's earnings season Friday, topping analysts' profit estimates on a 48% surge in fixed-income trading. Citigroup (C) and Bank of America (BAC) surpassed predictions, too, as fixed-income revenue jumped 35% and 39%, respectively. Wells Fargo (WFC), contending with a scandal in its consumer business, also beat estimates.

Stocks closed Monday with modest losses as earnings season kicked into full gear, with Bank of America (BAC) and Hasbro (HAS) among notable companies reporting.After the regular session close, Netflix (NFLX) topped quarterly views on both the top and bottom line, as well as its U.S. and international subscriber forecasts. Shares leapt 19% in extended trading.The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average each finished with a 0.3% loss. Volume was lighter across the board vs. Friday, according to preliminary data. Losers beat winners by about a 3-2 margin on both the NYSE and the Nasdaq.Department store, oil and generic drugmakers led the downside in the stock market today, as West Texas intermediate crude prices slid nearly 1% to $50.30 a barrel. Toy makers, gold miners and steel stocks were among top gainers.Hasbro (HAS) gapped up and soared more than 7%, surging past its 50-day and 200-day moving average lines in heavy trade. The stock is crafting a flat base with a potential buy point at 88.63.  The maker of board games, as well as toys based on Walt Disney's (DIS) "Star Wars" and  "Frozen" blockbuster hits, reported Q3 earnings that trounced views, thanks to strength in the girls category.Bank of America was fractionally higher, despite reporting better-than-expected Q3 earnings and revenue. It became the latest big bank to post solid results, following Friday's reports from Citigroup (C), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Wells Fargo (WFC).Domino's Pizza (DPZ), up as much as 1.5% early, pared its gain to 0.6% by the close. Volume was about twice the usual pace. The stock is 2% off its high and holding above its 50-day line ahead of its Q3 earnings report before Tuesday's open. Analysts expect a 34% jump to 90 cents a share on  12% higher sales to $541.47 million.In economic news, the New York Fed's Empire Manufacturing index contracted for a third straight month in October, at -6.8, well below economists' projections for 1.0. Manufacturing production climbed 0.2% in September.Economic data on tap for Tuesday include the September Consumer Price Index and the National Association of Home Builders' housing market index for October.Earnings due out Tuesday include Goldman Sachs (GS), Intel (INTC) and Yahoo (YHOO).RELATED:Stocks Edge Down; Tesla Stretches Downtrend; Why TI, Hasbro Are Rising Bank Of America Earnings Top Q3 Views On Trading Jump, Cost Curbs Netflix Earnings, Subscribers Beat; IBM, Del Taco Top

Major stock ETFs closed lower Monday as investors digested more financial earnings and hawkish Fed remarks. Bank of America (BAC) released results that beat estimates before the open, in a continuation of the positive start to the earnings season from the big banks.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) slid 0.3% on the stock market today.This exchange traded fund serves as a proxy for the broad U.S. market and sits 3% below its August high. It fell 0.9% in choppy trade last week, its second down week in a row."The big banks have given us a reassuring start to the Q3 reporting cycle," Sheraz Mian, research director at Zacks Investment Research, wrote early Monday. "If this trend continues next week, when a broad and representative cross section of corporate America is on deck to come out with quarterly results, then we will have a tangible reason to get optimistic about the overall earnings picture."In his note, Mian pointed to strong earnings from JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) last week, and to Goldman Sachs' (GS) report due Tuesday.The solid start to Q3 earnings seems to be getting overshadowed by fears about the Fed, with investors focused on the future path of interest rates.Financials fell on Monday, while the defensively oriented utilities and the real estate sectors contributed to gains in the S&P 500.Utilities Select Sector SPDR (XLU) posted a 1.3% gain last week, as companies in  defensive, dividend-heavy sectors outpaced the S&P 500 as a whole.XLU's relative strength line has turned higher in the past two weeks, but remains in a longer-term downtrend.On the IBD Leaderboard, Direxion Daily Financial Bull 3X Shares (FAS) edged lower despite the better-than-expected quarterly earnings from Bank of America. The leveraged financial ETF has been hitting resistance at its 50-day moving average.Gold prices rose modestly Monday, while West Texas Intermediate crude futures declined to just under $50 a barrel.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) bounced 0.3% higher on technical buying. The ETF has fallen under both its shorter- and longer-term trend lines after three down weeks.Gold and silver prices were virtually unchanged as investors look for new fundamental information to drive the markets, Jim Wyckoff, a senior technical analyst at Kitco News, wrote early Monday.In his remarks at a luncheon in New York, Federal Reserve Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer cautioned that prolonged low interest rates could lead to a recession and make the economy more vulnerable.The GLD ETF tracks the spot price of gold. It is trading 8% off its July high after economic data raised the likelihood of a rate hike by year-end.Rising rates weigh on gold, a nonyielding haven asset, while boosting the dollar in which the metal is globally priced.Here's how major exchange traded funds across major asset classes performed today, with IBD Relative Strength Ratings.The RS Rating is a measure of a stock's price performance over the last 12 months, compared with all stocks and ETFs, on a scale of 1 to a best-possible 99.Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), -0.3%, RS 54PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), -0.3%, RS 67SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), -0.3%, RS 50IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), -0.1%, RS 58IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), -0.1%, RS 64IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), -0.3%, RS 41Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), -0.2%, RS 69SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), +0.3%, RS 46United States Oil (USO), -0.6%, RS 58IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), +0.2%, RS 41PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), -0.2%, RS 46IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), -0.5%, RS 2RELATED:S&P 500 ETFs Fall For A Second Week

Even as the Federal Reserve signals that tougher standards lie ahead for its annual stress tests, banks like JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C), Bank of America (BAC) and others could still get more generous with their payouts as the tests become more routine, analysts suggest.After the Fed approved 31 of 33 bank capital plans late Wednesday, JPMorgan announced a $10.6 billion buyback, Bank of America OK'd a $5 billion repurchase and a 50% payout increase, and Citigroup unveiled a $8.6 billion buyback and more than tripled its dividend. Morgan Stanley (MS) hiked its dividend 33% and announced a $3.5 billion buyback.The results "highlight the capital strength that enabled the sector to broadly increase payout requests," Fitch Ratings said in a statement Thursday, later adding that banks are "becoming increasingly comfortable with the annual process."As massive as the shareholder returns unveiled Wednesday were, there appears to be room for more among giants like JPMorgan, Citigroup and Bank of America, based on the ratio of dividends and buybacks vs. earnings expected over the next year.Comerica (CMA) and M&T Bank (MTB) lead banks with net payout ratios of 119% each, followed by Morgan Stanley at 105%, according to Credit Suisse. Meanwhile, JPMorgan's is 73%, while the ratio for both Goldman Sachs (GS) and Wells Fargo (WFC) is 65%, Citigroup's is 63%, and Bank of America's is 49%.Shares of Morgan Stanley climbed 3% on the stock market today. JPMorgan added 1.5%. Bank of America and Citigroup rose 0.6%. Goldman Sachs climbed 2.1%.Even before the stress test results came out, analysts have been expecting the banks to get more aggressive with shareholder returns after finally emerging from the aftereffects of the financial crisis.A CLSA note this month said JPMorgan, Citigroup, Bank of America and Wells Fargo are likely to hand out a bigger chunk of profits over the next four years, meaning greater gains for investors who stuck with them through lean times.Portales Partners this month said it expects banks "to get more creative in their capital return requests, as the companies are becoming more familiar with the process" of submitting capital plans for the stress tests, as well as resubmitting them if the Fed has any concerns with risk assessment or whether banks' dividend and buyback plans could overburden their finances if the economy falters.But even as banks push the envelope on capital returns and become more accustomed to the yearly drill of visualizing their state of affairs in an economic crisis, the Fed has warned of potentially stricter capital requirements in future tests."The Fed noted that, despite general progress, banks still need to improve internal controls around various elements of capital planning," Fitch said.

Thursday, like the month of June as a whole, came in like a lamb and went out like a lion for major stock ETFs. Investors digested news that more stimulus efforts may be coming from the Bank of England.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) bolted 1.4% higher into the close, after creeping up in morning trade. Its underlying index recovered for a third straight day following a sharp Brexit-inspired sell-off.SPY eked out a 0.4% gain for June after clawing back most of the steep losses that followed Britons' vote to leave the European Union. The bellwether U.S. exchange traded fund posted a 2.5% gain for the second quarter -- its third positive quarter in a row -- and a 3.8% gain for 2016 so far.Financial stocks took the ETF spotlight Thursday as investors cheered news that a majority of 33 banks passed the second and final round of the Federal Reserve's annual stress tests, opening the door to a dividend and share buyback windfall.The largest financial sector exchange traded fund wobbled between gains and losses in early Thursday trade, but closed a solid 1.6% higher.Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF) has a 33% weighting in commercial banks but also holds REITs, insurance companies and capital market heavyweights.Its smaller siblings, focused more exclusively on the banking sector, also advanced.SPDR S&P Regional Banking (KRE) popped 2.3% on the stock market today.SPDR S&P Bank (KBE) added 2.0%.Late Wednesday, the Fed approved the capital plans for 31 of 33 banks. The U.S. units of Deutsche Bank (DB) and Banco Santander (SAN) failed to gain the nod, while approval for Morgan Stanley (MS) was conditional.Still, Morgan Stanley announced a 33% quarterly dividend hike to 20 cents and a $3.5 billion share buyback. JPMorgan (JPM) approved a $10.6 billion buyback while keeping its dividend the same. Bank of America (BAC) declared a $5 billion share repurchase program and a 50% payout increase to 7.5 cents. Citigroup (C) will buy back $8.6 billion in stock and raised its payout to 16 cents from 5 cents.Goldman Sachs (GS) said its plan includes both buybacks and a dividend hike, without offering details.
