Wells Fargo (WFC) kept its capital plans unchanged.XLF counts many of these bank majors among its top 10 holdings. The exchange traded fund is poised for a weekly gain that would snap a four-week string of losses.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) rose again Thursday as it trades near a 52-week high. GLD has posted gains in three of the past four sessions as the Brexit referendum vote sparked a frenzy for safe-haven assets.The commodity ETF tracks the price of gold.VanEck Gold Miners (GDX), which invests in gold stocks, jumped 2.1% Thursday.GDX has advanced 63% from a $17.14 buy point in 102 days, making it a best-performing ETF of 2016 so far.Here's a look at how major exchange traded funds, tracking various asset classes, performed today, with Relative Strength (RS) ratings.Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), +1.4%, RS 59PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), +1.2%, RS 43SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), +1.3%, RS 59IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), +2.0%, RS 59IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), +1.9%, RS 47IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), +1.5%, RS 30Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), +1.0%, RS 51SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), +0.5%, RS 85United States Oil (USO), -1.9%, RS 43IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), +0.2%, RS 63PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), +0.2%, RS 47IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), -3.2%, RS 9

Big banks JPMorgan (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) got through the second and final round of the Federal Reserve's annual stress tests unscathed, resulting in a shareholder-returns bonanza shortly after the test results were announced late Wednesday.But Morgan Stanley's (MS) capital plan only got conditional approval, and U.S. segments of Deutsche Bank (DB) and Santander (SAN) failed once againStill, Morgan Stanley said it will move forward with a 33% quarterly dividend hike to 20 cents and a $3.5 billion buyback. JPMorgan OK'd a $10.6 billion buyback but kept its dividend the same. Bank of America announced a $5 billion repurchase program and a 50% payout increase to 7.5 cents. Citigroup will buy back $8.6 billion in stock and raised its payout to 16 cents from 5 cents.Goldman Sachs (GS) didn't give specifics but said its plan included buybacks and a dividend hike. Wells Fargo (WFC)  kept its capital plans unchanged.Morgan Stanley stock were little changed in pre-market trading on the stock market today after rising late Wednesday JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, Citigroup climbed 2.4%, Wells Fargo rose and Goldman Sachs all rose fractionally. Deutsche Bank, which the IMF said "poses the greatest risk to the global financial system," sank nearly 4% while Santander fell 2%.Other banks also announced bigger returns to shareholders.The Fed only gave conditional approval to Morgan Stanley's capital plan, in which it projected how it would perform under difficult economic conditions for this year's stress tests. As a result, Morgan must resubmit its capital plan and address broader concerns from the Fed by Dec. 29. If Morgan can't deliver on those promises, the Fed said, its governors "would expect to object" to the resubmitted plan, potentially hindering Morgan's shareholder returns.While the Fed did not technically object to Morgan Stanley's capital plan, the central bank said the company "exhibited material weaknesses in its capital planning process," including in governance, modeling and other safeguards."These weaknesses warrant further near-term attention but do not undermine the quantitative results of the stress tests for the firm," the Fed said, referring to the portion of the tests that quantifies what banks' capital levels would look like under financial turmoil.The Fed said Deutsche Bank and Santander, both of which also had their plans rejected last year, had tightened up some aspects of their capital planning methodology but still struggled with "material unresolved supervisory issues that critically undermine (the) capital planning process."The results follow a pattern of stress-test one-upmanship between the banks, which have been shoring up capital since the financial crisis, and the Fed, which has tried harder each year to catch the banks off-guard in the scenarios posed in the tests.While the banks that passed can move forward with their dividend and buyback hikes, tougher standards on the horizon could keep payouts restrained this year. Fed Governor Daniel Tarullo warned this month that banks in future tests might have to make a "significant increase" in the assets they set aside to cushion against a potential economic crisis.The final round of results from the stress tests -- known as the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review, or CCAR -- came after all 33 tested banks last week passed the first round of the evaluation, which quantifies how banks' finances would be affected against a barrage of market shocks.The Fed outlined the economic scenarios for both tests at the beginning of the year. In the weeks that followed, the banks submitted their capital plans, which this year forecast how they would do amid 10% unemployment, negative interest rates on short-term U.S. Treasuries -- among the conditions in the Fed's worst-case scenario.The first round of test results can serve as a preview of sorts to the second, in which the Fed actually indicates whether it accepted, rejected or had any reservations with the banks' capital plans. If it does have an issue, banks could have to temper plans to issue buybacks and boost dividends in order to pass.The second round of tests contains both a quantitative element and qualitative element. The quantitative element measures banks post-stress-test capital levels and whether they could sustain any new dividend and buyback plans. The qualitative element evaluates the soundness of the banks' capital plans and how they were developed.Analysts largely had not anticipated major problems with the banks' stress-test results.

U.S. stocks extended their rebound Wednesday as they followed European bourses higher. Nike and American Express boosted the Dow with big gains, while banks rose ahead of the Fed's stress test results.The Nasdaq rallied 1.9%, the S&P 500 jumped 1.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average added 1.6%, as the major indexes closed near session highs. The Dow and S&P 500 are close to regaining their 50-day lines. Volume was mixed, lower on the NYSE but higher on the Nasdaq, according to preliminary numbers.Oil stocks again led the upside amid a drop in the Energy Information Administration's weekly U.S. stockpiles report. West Texas intermediate crude surged 3% to $49.32 a barrel.Automakers and shoe and apparel makers also outperformed in the stock market today. Tesla (TSLA) cruised 4% higher in fast trade for a third straight advance. The stock is 5% and 4% below its respective 50-day and 200-day moving average lines. The electric car maker made headlines June 21 after making a surprise bid for solar installer SolarCity (SCTY) in a stock swap valued at about $2.7 billion. Tesla CEO Elon Musk is chairman of SolarCity.Nike (NKE) sprinted 4% in speedy turnover. Shares fell Tuesday in extended trading after the athletic footwear and apparel maker reported fiscal Q4 sales that missed views. Analysts overall remain bullish on Nike's long-term outlook -- a few analysts trimmed their price targets but maintained a buy rating.Nike and American Express (AXP), which continues its recovery from steep post-Brexit drops, were the top gainers on the Dow. AmEx rose 3.5%. Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan (JPM) were up more than 2% each ahead of the second round of stress test results, which were announced after the close.The Fed OK'd capital plans for Goldman, JPMorgan, Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC). But it gave only conditional approval to Morgan Stanley (MS), which will need to resubmit.The U.S. units of Deutsche Bank (DB) and Banco Santander (SAN) failed stress tests. All 33 banks tested passed the first round of the evaluation last week.Citigroup, which gained 4% in regular trading, was up more than 2% after hours.Which big banks earn top ratings? Find out now with IBD Stock Checkup.IBD 50 component NetEase (NTES) soared nearly 5%, breaking out past a 179.20 cup-with-handle buy point in above-average volume. It's still in buy range from the entry. Other big movers included GrubHub (GRUB), up 6%, biotech Medivation (MDVN), up 5.5% and Planet Fitness (PLNT), up 4%.Consumer prices climbed 0.2% in May, a percentage point below April's increase and in line with forecasts. The National Association of Realtors' pending home sales index fell 3.7% in May to 110.8 amid tight supply and rising prices. Economists expected a 2% dip.Key economic data due out Thursday include weekly jobless claims and the Institute for Supply Management's Chicago purchasing managers index for June. St. Louis Fed chief James Bullard is also scheduled to speak.

Bank of America (BAC) is reportedly set to eliminate as many as 8,000 retail banking jobs to cut costs, as fewer people go to brick-and-mortar banks and more use digital media to transfer funds, pay bills and other banking tasks, a report said Wednesday.The top U.S. bank by deposits also plans to hire an unspecified number of sales staff, including loan officers, small-business bankers and personal investment advisers, the Financial Times reported, citing knowledgeable sources.However, the number of new hires at Bank of America isn't expected to be near the number the Charlotte, N.C., bank plans to let go via attrition and layoffs, the report said, so even with those new hires, a net loss of thousands of employees is expected. Bank of America shares closed up 0.6% in the stock market today. After reporting double- and triple-digit profit growth every quarter in 2015, the bank reported a 22% year-over-year drop in earnings per share last quarter, and analyst consensus is for an 18% decline this quarter.It joins other banks that have cut staff to lower costs. Last month, the Wall Street Journal reported JPMorgan Chase (JPM) planned to lay off 100 from its private banking operations. Bloomberg earlier this month said Goldman Sachs (GS) cut dozens of management positions. Deutsche Bank (DB), Barclays (BCS) and others have also reported layoffs or were reportedly preparing to do so.Bank of America is in the Banks-Money Center group, which is ranked a weak 168 on IBD's list of 197 industries. Among other large banks in the group, top home mortgage lender Wells Fargo (WFC) dipped 0.2%. Citigroup (C) rose 0.1%. JPMorgan lost 0.2%, and Deutsche Bank's U.S. shares tacked on 0.6%.

In an ideal world, dividend stocks would go in only one direction — up. In the real world, the next best thing is finding an income stock that rises after triggering an entry, thereby giving the investor a profit cushion to work with. Where might the dividend investor find such stocks in today's stock market? One possibility is the bank stocks. IBD…

Stocks saw opening losses Tuesday expand in the stock market today, as energy, steel, mining and banking shares struggled amid a nearly 2% drop in near-term crude oil futures and a sales scandal engulfing one of America's leading financial institutions, Wells Fargo (WFC).However, Apple (AAPL) continued to fight the good fight for the bulls with a more than 2% gain to 108.41, helping to stem the slide in tech issues. It rallied on positive iPhone 7 orders from wireless carrier Sprint (S), which said that pre-orders in the first three days were quadruple vs. the same time a year ago.Apple shares are getting closer toward a potential breakout past a 110.33 entry in a cup-with-handle formation. The stock is also trying to end a more-than-yearlong trend of lower price highs and lower lows.Wells Fargo (WFC) dived more than 2% to 47.31 in heavy turnover on reports that the mortgage-selling bank has eliminated sales goals for its retail banking staff. On Friday, the stock slumped below its long-term 200-day moving average near 49.50 in heavy volume, suggesting a long-term downtrend remains intact.The slide in banking shares also comes one day after Federal Reserve Board Governor Lael Brainard urged prudence in deciding when to kick off another rise in short-term interest rates. Her comments flew in the face of other leaders at the U.S. central bank who over the past week expressed reasons for a modest hike in the cost of money.Near-zero interest rates have depressed net interest margins for lenders across the country.The S&P 500 sank 1.2% while the Dow Jones industrials fell almost 1.1%. On the Dow, Goldman Sachs (GS) fell nearly 2% and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) 1.4%. The Nasdaq composite lost 0.9%. Small caps got knocked hard, with the Russell 2000 off 1.3%.Apple's move has sort of a multiplier effect on the market due to its big family of suppliers. Broadcom (AVGO), whose chips help filter signals sent between cellphones, edged less than 0.5% higher to 165.26. Shares are trying to clear a 163.87 narrow cup-with-handle buy point.In the IBD 50, Acacia Communications (ACIA) is giving back Monday's gains, falling 5% to 106.50. So far, the correction from a 128.73 all-time high appears normal, even if a breakout from a high, tight flag had failed. Watch to see if a cup or double-bottom-type base forms, which typically see no more than a 30% to 33% drop from the base's intraday high to intraday low.Acacia is a supplier of silicon-based technology that allows fiber optic communications network providers to run 100 gigabit-per-second data networks efficiently. In the second quarter, the Maynard, Mass., firm posted a 376% boost in earnings to 81 cents a share on a 101% jump in revenue to $116.2 million. That was Acacia's first $100 million-plus quarter, and growth accelerated from increases of 40%, 67% and 79% in the prior three quarters.RELATED:Acacia CEO Not Afraid Of IntelFiber Optic Telecom Technology Provider Crushes Second-Quarter ViewsHello, 100-Gigabit Data Speed: Why Acacia Leads The Field

JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC), Goldman Sachs (GS) and other bank stocks seesawed after Federal Reserve policymakers kept its benchmark interest rate unchanged and cut long-term rate forecasts.The Fed's new projections show policymakers expect three rate hikes through the end of 2017, down from five at their June meeting. The estimate for the federal funds rate in 2017 has slipped to 1.1% in 2017 from a 1.6% view in June, 2018's views dropped to 1.9% from 2.4%, and the longer-run forecast is now 2.9% vs. 3%."The Committee judges that the case for an increase in the federal funds rate has strengthened but decided, for the time being, to wait for further evidence of continued progress toward its objectives," the central bank said in a statement after its two-day September meeting this week.Shares of JPMorgan finished 0.6% higher on the stock market today, while Bank of American and Goldman Sachs rose 0.3%. Citigroup (C) climbed 0.8%, and Morgan Stanley (MS) added 0.7%. Wells Fargo (WFC), whose CEO faced some harsh questioning from the Senate on Tuesday over its sales practices, fell 1.6%.IBD'S TAKE: Some bank stocks have traded more tightly as Wall Street speculates whether the Federal Reserve will decide to hike rates this year. See more details about which bank stocks might be in buy range. Wednesday's Fed decision, which keeps the target of the federal funds rate at a range of 0.25%-0.50%, prolongs the low-rate environment that has kept banks from charging more interest on loans and straining their net interest margins.The move drew an abnormal amount of dissent. Fed policymakers Esther George, Loretta Mester and Eric Rosengren voted against the move, wishing instead to raise the rate to a range of o.50% to 0.75%.While that statement said that the U.S. economy had gained momentum from the first half of the year, they expect that the economy will "evolve in a manner that will warrant only gradual increases in the federal funds rate."The statement added that "the federal funds rate is likely to remain, for some time, below levels that are expected to prevail in the longer run."RELATED:Sen. Warren: Wells Fargo CEO Should Resign, Face Criminal ProbeWhere Do Millennials Bank? JPMorgan Says It Beats BofA, Wells Fargo

Wells Fargo's (WFC) John Stumpf should resign, give back his compensation and face criminal prosecution for a scandal in which the bank opened unauthorized accounts for thousands of customers, Senator Elizabeth Warren said."So you haven't resigned, you haven't returned a single nickel of your personal earnings, you haven't fired a single senior executive," the Massachusetts Democrat said Tuesday as the bank's chief executive officer testified before the Senate Banking Committee."Instead, evidently your definition of accountable is to push the blame to your low-level employees who don't have the money for a fancy PR firm to defend themselves," Warren said. "It's gutless leadership."Wells Fargo agreed to pay a record $185 million to authorities including the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau after a review found employees may have opened more than 2 million accounts and credit cards without consumers' permission. Stumpf, 63, told lawmakers he was "deeply sorry" and detailed a five-year timeline of attempts the bank made to deter misconduct.Warren told Stumpf he should "give back the money you took while this scam was going on and you should be criminally investigated by both the Department of Justice and the Securities and Exchange Commission."The lender is also contacting all of its customers nationwide to ensure their accounts and credit cards are products they need and want, said Stumpf, who is also the bank's chairman."The Wells Fargo board is actively engaged in this issue," Stumpf said. "The board has the tools to hold senior management accountable, including me and Carrie Tolstedt, the former head of our retail banking business. Any board actions taken with our named executive officers will be appropriately disclosed, and I want to be clear on this, I will respect and accept the decision of the board."Stumpf is under political pressure to punish senior managers, such as calls by Warren to claw back millions of dollars in pay from Tolstedt.The bank had announced in July that Tolstedt was retiring. On Monday, it said Claudia Russ Anderson, who had overseen risk in the retail banking unit, is taking a six-month unpaid leave for personal reasons."Carrie chose to retire," Stumpf said, adding that he and Chief Operating Officer Tim Sloan told her the bank wanted "to go in a different direction." She was eligible for retirement "and she decided to retire" after that conversation, Stumpf said.Senator Sherrod Brown, an Ohio Democrat, told the CEO that the bank's response has been inadequate, and said, for example, that Wells Fargo hasn't yet calculated what effect lower credit scores resulting from the fake accounts might have had on customers' finances. Senior management downplayed the importance of the problem and continued to award performance bonuses to those involved as recently as two months ago, Brown said."You would think the lessons of the financial crisis, which came at such a high cost to our country, would change the way banks do business," Brown said.Other witnesses Tuesday include U.S. Comptroller of the Currency Tom Curry, who said in prepared remarks that he's directing bank examiners to review sales practices at all "large and midsize banks," and that the agency could pursue its own enforcement action against people at Wells Fargo. CFPB Director Richard Cordray also was scheduled to speak.Stumpf, who testified with a bandaged right hand the firm said he injured while playing with his grandchildren, provided a timeline of the bank's own investigation into the matter. In 2011, a dedicated team began to monitor and root out improper sales. The firm started terminating roughly 1,000 of its 100,000 retail banking employees annually for violations. By 2012, the lender began lowering some sales goals for compensation.In 2015, an OCC review of Wells Fargo's sales practices revealed shortcomings that prompted the agency to demand changes -- including telling the bank to compensate customers for any harm suffered. The company had to bring in an outside consultant, Curry said. Wells Fargo hired PricewaterhouseCoopers in August 2015 to help determine whether customers were hurt, according to Stumpf.The CEO outlined other ways Wells Fargo has tried to prevent unauthorized accounts from being created, including working with regulators and creating a new branch compliance program.A group of Democratic Senators, led by Warren, last week wrote a letter pressing Stumpf with questions on pay. The lawmakers singled out Tolstedt, writing that there appears "to be multiple grounds on which to trigger the clawback provisions to recoup some or all of Ms. Tolstedt's incentive rewards."The House Financial Services Committee, led by Chairman Jeb Hensarling, said last week it also plans to conduct its own investigation and will hold a separate hearing later this month. Hensarling, a Texas Republican, said he plans to request that Stumpf appear for that hearing, too. Tolstedt as well as other corporate officers will be called for transcribed interviews, the lawmaker said.

Banks haven't delivered much bang for the buck in the past year, and are trying ETF investors' patience some more.The financial sector crumbled to the bottom of the S&P 500 heap Friday after Brexit -- the U.K.'s exit from the European Union -- came to pass. That plunge came on the heels of upbeat news for Wall Street banks: Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C), Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan (JPM), Morgan Stanley (MS), Wells Fargo (WFC) and 27 other banks passed the first round of Federal Reserve stress tests, an annual rite of passage that puts them through the wringer.All 33 banks showed they could absorb serious market shocks and maintain their capital cushions even in a "hypothetical firestorm of 10% unemployment, negative interest rates, deflation, etc.," said S&P Global Market Intelligence analyst Erik OjaNow financial companies are being seriously challenged on another front. The Brexit result will likely create several headwinds for U.S. banks, according to Oja."We now see a further decline in long-term U.S. interest rates, a stronger U.S. dollar, and low probability that the Fed will raise short-term rates in the foreseeable future," he wrote Friday. "This will further pressure net interest margins at banks, and lead to lower oil prices -- with negative credit effects on banks' energy lending."The importance of the financial sector to investors can hardly be overstated. It accounts for roughly 15% of the S&P 500. The impact of its policies ripple across from American households to mom-and-pop shops to giant U.S. corporates.Todd Rosenbluth, S&P Global's director of exchange traded funds research, concurs that the Brexit news is sobering for this key sector."We think financial ETFs with hefty exposure to banks will be negatively impacted," he said in an email. As examples, Rosenbluth cites the bellwether Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF) and iShares U.S. Financials (IYF).XLF sank nearly 5% on the stock market as investors digested the Brexit result. Year to date through June 23, XLF was down 1.1% for the worst performance of any S&P sector.By comparison, SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) has risen 4.5%.Banks got beat up as the Federal Reserve kept Americans guessing about its next rate move. In December, the Fed hiked interest rates for the first time in nearly a decade. This year, it has waffled about the timing of the next increase. Banks benefit from higher interest rates, which boost their net profit margins.SPDR S&P Bank (KBE) and SPDR S&P Regional Banking (KRE) have slumped  4.0% and 2.3% respectively so far in 2016.A more gloomy rate outlook post-Brexit could spell trouble for regional banks. Although the largest banks did surprisingly well in the latest stress tests, regional banks did not fare as well, Oja wrote."They had a difficult test with negative interest rates," he added. Still, market watchers point out that U.S. banks overall are on solid footing.The heavyweights, in particular, have strong capital positions and solid balance sheets. "The money center banks are probably in the best capital shape that they have been since the financial crisis started in 2008," Charles Peabody of Portales Partners, a broker dealer, wrote in a June 8 note. The firm expects this banking group to be a major source of dividends and buybacks for shareholders this year and next.At BlackRock, strategists expect the UK's divorce from the Europe Union to trigger a long period of political, economic and market uncertainty.They said: "We see the vote leading to declines in global shares and other risk assets. Yet indiscriminate selling could translate into opportunities. U.S. and Asia markets are only marginally affected by the U.K.'s exit from the EU, and are supported by a mix of easy monetary policy and economic growth."The immediate negative reaction to the news is exactly what ETF strategists at CLS Investments are homing in on. Both U.S. financial and Europe financial ETFs are looking attractive to CIO Rusty Vanneman."We're looking to buy," Vanneman told Investor's Business Daily on Friday. The firm has been a better buyer of financials in 2016, moving from an underweight to overweight position in the sector. "Our plan is to get to an overweight, and this sell-off will provide an opportunity for us to add to those positions," he added.He finds iShares MSCI Europe Financials (EUFN) particularly attractive from a valuation standpoint given the recent drubbing for the likes of HSBC (HSBC), Credit Suisse (CS) and Deutsche Bank (DB).

The U.K.'s surprising and historic decision to leave the European Union overshadowed all other news this week, roiling global markets and raising doubts about the European economy and post-war order.But it was a busy week for business news. In a well-timed release, the Federal Reserve said JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and other giant banks passed their "stress test" scenarios. Elon Musk's bid to merge Tesla Motors (TSLA) and SolarCity (SCTY) raised doubts, even among long-time devotees. Wal-Mart (WMT) and JD.com (JD) teamed up. Adobe Systems (ADBE), Red Hat (RHT) and FedEx (FDX) gave weak guidance, and the Federal Aviation Administration finalized drone regulations.Gloom overtook world markets after Britons voted to leave the EU amid a wave of nationalist sentiment. The vote will begin a long process of negotiations to determine what parts of the existing business landscape will stay or go for a range of industries that operate in the region. JPMorgan Chase, American Airlines (AAL) and their global peers were hit hard. U.K. Prime Minister David Cameron said he would step down, while right-wing populists elsewhere on the Continent called for similar referendums in their nations, potentially expanding financial and cultural fissures within the bloc. The Federal Reserve said it is "prepared to provide dollar liquidity through its existing swap lines with central banks, as necessary," but questions remained about how much left was in its arsenal to ward off any coming market turmoil.U.S. stocks had rallied through Thursday, in large part because polls got it wrong and predicted that the U.K. would stay in the EU. Stocks suffered huge losses Friday after the Brexit results pushing the major averages into the red. The Nasdaq lost 1.9% for the week while the S&P 500 and Dow industrials closed off 1.6%. European markets suffered deeper losses. Big losers included carriers such American Air, while Tesla Motors tumbled on its ill-received SolarCity bid. Treasury yields hit four-year lows. The dollar skyrocketed vs. the pound but tumbled vs. the yen.Tesla made a surprise offer to buy solar energy company SolarCity in a stock swap valued at roughly $2.7 billion. Tesla CEO Elon Musk is chairman of SolarCity, which is run by Musk's cousins.Analyst reviews of the deal hit a negative tone, calling it a fundamental change to Tesla's business model that could thwart its aggressive efforts to expand production of its all-electric vehicles and add to cash flow and financing concerns. Tesla shares tumbled 10.45% on Wednesday, its worst one-day loss since May 2014. Tesla  fell 10.4% for the week. SolarCity initially spiked on the deal, but closed up just 4.1% as investors doubt a deal will happen. Musk, the top shareholder of both companies, said he won't vote on any merger agreement.The Federal Reserve passed all 33 banks -- including majors JPMorgan, Bank of America, Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) -- in the first round of its annual stress tests, as expected. Investors will now focus on the second round of results, set for release Wednesday, that will determine whether banks can carry out their submitted plans to return capital to shareholders. But just because banks can weather a storm doesn't mean it will be fun: Bank stocks were among the biggest losers Friday on the Brexit fallout, erasing gains from earlier in the week.Adobe reported better-than-expected adjusted earnings per share on in-line sales for its fiscal second quarter ended June 3, but investors focused on its disappointing sales guidance for Q3.The maker of digital media and marketing software earned 71 cents a share excluding items, 3 cents above views, on sales of $1.4 billion. It was Adobe's fourth straight quarter of 20% or greater sales growth and its seventh straight quarter of double-digit gains in adjusted EPS.For the current quarter, Adobe is targeting non-GAAP earnings per share of 72 cents on sales of $1.445 billion, based on the midpoint of guidance. Analysts had been modeling 71 cents, up 31%, on sales of $1.47 billion, up 21%.Adobe shares were down 3.55% for the week, undercutting a buy area.Chinese internet giant Tencent Holdings (TCEHY) announced a deal to buy an 84% stake in mobile video game company Supercell for $8.6 billion. The transaction values the Finnish game developer at $10.2 billion.Helsinki-based Supercell makes free-to-play mobile games such as "Clash of Clans" and "Clash Royale." It makes money by selling virtual goods that help players advance in its games. Supercell's games are played by more than 100 million people each day.Tencent is a leader in online games. It owns "League of Legends" maker Riot Games and distributes games in China for Activision (ATVI), Electronic Arts (EA) and others.Wal-Mart (WMT) announced an alliance with China's JD.com (JD), with JD taking ownership of Wal-Mart's Yihaodian marketplace, its China e-commerce business, in return for an approximate 5% stake in JD.com in the form of newly issued shares. The move may help both Wal-Mart and JD compete against Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba (BABA).JD.com is the second-largest online retailer in China after Alibaba. Wal-Mart has struggled to build its China business.Wal-Mart rose 1.4%, hitting a 10-month high. JD closed up 2.5% for the week.Twitter (TWTR) expanded its push into machine learning with the acquisition of Magic Pony Technology, a London-based startup that specializes in visual processing.Terms of the acquisition were not disclosed, but the price tag was reported to be $150 million.Magic Pony's technology ranges across computer vision, machine learning, high-performance computing and computational neuroscience.Also, Twitter gave its users more room to unleash their creativity, expanding the length of its video play to 140 seconds from 30, as it battles for viewers with the likes of Facebook (FB) photo and video sharing site Instagram, which has now grown to 500 million subscribers.The Twitter change is designed to help video creators boost their audiences and make money in the process.Existing-home sales rose 1.8% in May to an annual rate of 5.53 million, the highest in nine years, the National Association of Realtors said. But new-home sales fell 6% to 551,000, the Commerce Department said. April new-home sales were revised down sharply to 586,000 from the initial reading of 619,000. Tight supply has limited purchases of new dwellings. But homebuilders Lennar (LEN) and KB Home (KBH) reported better-than-expected quarterly earnings.Meanwhile, new jobless claims fell 18,000 in the week ended June 18 to 259,000, the Labor Department said. That was a bigger drop than expected, and put the total back near a 43-year low set in March. It's a good sign for the June employment report after May's surprisingly weak payrolls gain.The Transportation Department and FAA finalized regulations for the commercial use of drones, which officials say could generate more than $82 billion for the U.S. economy over the next 10 years. The rules are seen as less restrictive than expected. Under the new regulations, the unmanned aircraft must be kept within the pilot's line of sight and cannot be operated at night, but those restrictions could be lifted under a waiver. Among the publicly traded companies impacted by the new rules are Amazon (AMZN), Wal-Mart, GoPro (GPRO) and AeroVironment (AVAV).Red Hat reported fiscal Q1 revenue and billings slightly above views, as well as in-line earnings. But it forecast full-year profit that was a bit light, citing a new planned acquisition. Some analysts said larger enterprise deals were a bright spot. The open-source Linux software company increased a stock buyback program to $1 billion from its earlier $500 million authorization. Red Hat is expected to update its public cloud strategy at an investor day slated for June 30.Red Hat stock tumbled 4.8% for the week, falling below a recent buy point.FedEx reported strong fiscal-fourth-quarter earnings per share and revenue growth, both topping analyst estimates. But the company forecast adjusted EPS of $11.75-$12.25 for the current fiscal year. The midpoint of $12 was below consensus of $12.05. FedEx also didn't say how its recently acquired European shipper TNT Express would affect results. Shares fell 4.5% on Wednesday, a day after it issued Q4 results. Shares are off 7.2% this week, undercutting the 200-day line.The No. 2 U.S. package shipper plans to spend about $5.1 billion this year for ongoing expansion of the FedEx Ground network, as well as for planned aircraft purchases to support the FedEx Express fleet modernization program. Rival and No. 1 shipper UPS (UPS) crept out to a 17-month high on Thursday before tumbling Friday to fall less 1% for the week amid the Brexit turmoil on the market.

Stock futures rallied strongly Thursday, joining a global rally as Britons began voting on whether to stay in the European Union, with the latest polls signaling a shift to remaining in the EU. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and other big U.S. banks rose ahead of stress test results due out tonight. Meanwhile, Red Hat (RHT) tumbled on weak guidance, while Tesla Motors (TSLA) extended losses on the ill-received plan to buy SolarCity (SCTY).The Nasdaq 100, S&P 500 and Dow industrials futures all signaled roughly 0.9% gains at the opening bell on the stock market today. On Wednesday, stocks erased early gains to close modestly lower. But after the market close, new surveys suggested that U.K. voters were leaning against Brexit. Voting won't end until 5 p.m. ET, with actual results hours after that.European bourses jumped, with the U.K.'s FTSE up 1.4%, France's CAC-40 climbing 2.3%, and Germany's DAX advancing 2.1%. The British pound hit a 2016 high, while oil prices also climbed.U.S. shares of European banks were big winners. Deutsche Bank (DB) rose 6%, while Barclays (BCS) climbed 4%.As for U.S. banks, JPMorgan, Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) shares all pointed higher in the premarket.In addition to hopes that the U.K. will remain in the EU, bank investors are expecting positive stress test results. The Federal Reserve will release the first round of tests after the market close, with all 33 major financial firms expected to have sufficient capital cushions. On June 29, the Fed will rule on banks' payout plans for dividends and buybacks.Red Hat fell nearly 6% to 75.27 in premarket trade. The open-source software leader reported in-line earnings late Wednesday but cut its EPS outlook on a new 3scale acquisition. Red Hat broke out of a cup-with-handle base at a 76.40 buy point on April 20, but it seemed poised to undercut that level.Tesla Motors fell about 1% in premarket trade to 194.50. That's after tumbling 10.45% on Wednesday, Tesla's worst loss in more than two years. Investors and analysts questioned CEO Elon Musk's plan for Tesla to buy SolarCity. Musk is chairman of the solar installer, which is run by his cousins.SolarCity, which spiked as much as 11% Wednesday, closed up just 3.3% as investors questioned whether the deal will actually happen. Shares dipped 1% early Thursday.

Median shareholder payout from many of the biggest U.S. banks could rise to as much as 77% of earnings from 68% last year if their dividend-and-buyback plans pass the Federal Reserve's annual stress tests, analysts say, with money centers like JPMorgan (JPM) and credit-card banks American Express (AXP) potentially leading the returns.And banks' finances are generally seen holding up when the Federal Reserve on Thursday reports the first results of the tests, in which the Fed analyzes how well 33 banks' capital cushions could absorb shocks to the market and their finances. In the second round of evaluations, released on June 29, the Fed not only evaluates whether banks' finances pass muster amid broader economic turmoil but also whether their plans to return money to shareholders would be justified as a result, potentially restraining their ability to repurchase shares or hike dividends.Those passing grades would come despite a volatile market over the past year, rising consumer debt and tougher testing standards. In January, the Fed asked banks to assess how they would handle an economy with 10% unemployment and negative interest rates on short-term U.S. government bonds -- stricter criteria than in years past. Banks responded with their plans in April.But analysts feel that the banks are on solid enough footing today to withstand those rigors -- after Bank of America (BAC), Goldman Sachs (GS), Morgan Stanley (MS) and JPMorgan had to modify their capital return plans to pass the tests last year."More broadly, we see limited downside risk given that nearly all of the companies under coverage have seen material improvement in capital ratios" since the previous tests, Buckingham Research analyst James Mitchell said in a note Monday.The big money-center banks -- like JPMorgan, Citigroup, BofA and Wells Fargo -- "are probably in the best capital shape that they have been since the financial crisis," Portales Partners said this month in a research note, which predicted that such banks would turn out the biggest shareholder returns."I'd be surprised if any of the big four had a big hiccup this year," Morningstar analyst Dan Werner told IBD, referring to JPMorgan, Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo (WFC) and Bank of America.Portales predicted that on average, roughly half of earnings this year and next from those banks would come back to shareholders in the form of buyback programs and dividends.Those increases would be in part driven by low payouts last year and an improved capital buffer, Mitchell said. He also said those big banks would see a bigger payout increase, 20%-44% as measured in dollars, than any other kind of bank Buckingham covers.Credit-card banks like Capital One (COF), Discover (DFS), and American Express (AXP), were also likely to "enjoy above industry average payouts" over the next year, Portales said."It's surprising the credit-card banks have been more resilient, even with the large consumer losses that they predict and that they model," Werner said. "I think the capital levels at those banks have generally been stronger, just because of the nature of the business."But beyond JPMorgan and the credit-card banks, the picture for potential returns is less clear.On one hand, Buckingham Research said Monday that Morgan Stanley had tremendous potential for "upside surprise," citing in part its move away from volatile fixed-income, currencies and commodities trading. Credit Suisse on Monday also said Morgan was among those best positioned to return a high percentage of its capital.However, Keefe, Bruyette & Woods remained cautious on Morgan, after the bank had to modify its capital plan last year. Portales analyst Paul Gulberg told IBD that investment banks Morgan, along with Goldman Sachs, were more exposed to the U.K.'s potential decision to leave the EU and other world market chaos, and could "get hurt a little bit."Coincidentally, the U.K.'s referendum on leaving the EU also takes place Thursday. Analysts have warned that a so-called 'Brexit' could roil the financial landscape in Europe and reverberate into U.S.-based banks. Some U.S. banks detailed what effect Brexit would have on them in their stress-test responses, the Financial Times reported this week.Keefe, Bruyette & Woods has also warned that post-stress-test payouts could be topping out."Overall, payouts are near the upper end of what we believe is the long-term range of 70% to 80% of earnings over the CCAR cycle for the median bank," the firm said in a note last month, referring to the second round of testing, known as the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review.Payouts this year could also be affected by proposed adjustments to the stress tests' methodology in the future.Federal Reserve governors this month said some large banks could have to set more money aside to pass stress tests down the road. Credit Suisse analyst Susan Roth Katzke said in a note that while those new requirements might not take hold until 2018, payout ratios could be affected as soon as this year."The Fed has done its best to not be so predictable with its models," Werner said. "It sounds like it's a little bit of a cat and mouse game – they don't want to banks gaming the models, but at the same time the banks are trying their best to get a more predictable result."JPMorgan and Wells Fargo rose about 2% on the stock market today on optimism about the Brexit vote as well as the stress tests. Citigroup climbed more than 4% while Bank of America, Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs advanced more than 3%. American Express, Capital One and Discover Financial rose roughly 2%.

Here's your Investing Action Plan: What you need to know as an investor for the coming week. All eyes will be on the United Kingdom as voters there decide on the country's membership in the European Union, while banking giants will await results of the annual stress tests. Facebook (FB) shareholders will decide the company's post-Zuckerberg voting balance, Federal Reserve Chair…

The third quarter could finally be the bottom — after a year of the embattled, oversupplied energy sector pulling earnings of S&P 500 companies into negative terrain.Earnings for S&P 500 companies are forecast to dip 0.5% from a year ago, according to Thomson Reuters data. Given that actual results usually top analyst forecasts by a couple of percentage points, this could end a four-quarter earnings decline as the hangover from the oil price crash subsides. Revenue is set to grow 2.6%, ending six quarters of declines.Energy earnings are seen plunging 67%, but that's an improvement from declines of 85% in Q2 and an outright loss in Q1. In Q4, energy earnings are expected to see 3.8% growth as crude prices have rebounded from 12-year lows early this year to above $50 a barrel on Thursday. Leaving out the energy sector, S&P 500 earnings are estimated to grow 2.9% in Q3."The idea is that the worst is behind us," said Sheraz Mian, who manages Zacks' equity research department. "We saw some early tentative signs of improvement in the last earnings season as well, even though growth was in the negative.  . . . But results were nevertheless an improvement over what was expected."Financials will add a lift, with sector earnings forecast to tick up 1% vs. drops of 4% in Q2 and 12.6% in Q1. JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) report on Friday, Oct. 14. Most banking stocks — with the notable exception of scandal-hit Wells Fargo — have been rallying in recent weeks on expectations for a Federal Reserve rate hike.Broadly, the estimates reflect easier comparisons, particularly in energy and materials, whose results have slumped with the price of commodities. And the strong dollar still weighed during the quarter. But it didn't weigh as much as it could have because expectations have dimmed over the year for the Fed to be more aggressive about raising interest rates.Expectations in the months to come — including 8.4% earnings growth for Q4 — are higher but obtainable, Thomson Reuters analyst David Aurelio said. But while loftier forecasts typically get revised downward as the reporting season advances, earnings are still likely to grow in Q4 and early 2017 despite lingering economic anxiety."I think the overall sentiment doesn't seem to have this positive outlook," he said. "But when you look into the numbers, they're telling you a very different story."The tech sector's earnings are expected to grow 4.5% in Q3 and 10.1% excluding Apple (AAPL), Aurelio said, demonstrating the company's weight in the index. In fact, taking Apple out of the S&P 500 overall would result in a slim 0.1% profit gain.But Aurelio pointed to pockets of resilience in the tech sector outside of Apple, which has been bogged down on concerns about slowing iPhone demand.In particular, he likes the odds of the semiconductor equipment segment, whose earnings are expected to grow 61% amid greater demand for technology that provides efficient memory storage. Applied Materials (AMAT) is among the leaders in the group, with earnings seen jumping more than 125% on nearly 40% revenue growth."It's historically always been a gauge for where things are going, because it's supplying the equipment to make the devices that go into other devices," he said. "It's supplying the equipment to make the chips."The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index of stocks has climbed 50% from a mid-February low to a 16-year closing high Thursday.Elsewhere, there are mixed signals. After posting double-digit-percentage earnings gains over the past year, the consumer discretionary sector is poised to slow to only 4.1% growth, according to Thomson Reuters.The expected slowdown comes largely from the auto industry, in particular Ford (F), with its anticipated 51% drop in earnings. The automaker in July indicated that sales could soon hit their peak, amid concerns about discounts and an auto-loan bubble. Take Ford out of the equation, and consumer discretionary's earnings would grow 7.9%, Aurelio said. General Motors' (GM) earnings should dip 4% after several quarters of more than double-digit gains.Amazon (AMZN), which is included in the consumer discretionary group, is seen doing some heavy lifting for the sector, with earnings growth expected to surge 371% in Q3.Elsewhere in the consumer-facing sector, restaurants across the board have warned of less customer spending, and retailers continue to suffer at the hands of Amazon.The materials sector, forecast to rebound to 7.1% earnings growth after a year of declines, is also seen getting a boost from a single heavy lifter.The section's drive into positive territory was due to the copper sub-industry, Aurelio said. The lone S&P 500 member of that mining subsector is Freeport-McMoRan (FCX), whose earnings are projected to soar 227%. Excluding Freeport, the materials sector's earnings would decline 0.6%.Labor costs in a variety of businesses — in retail, restaurants and even the airlines — could also mean lower profits. And while the health care sector is often immune to the cycles that hurt other businesses, earnings growth for the space is expected to slow to 5.5%. The sector overall is heading into tougher comparisons after getting a boost from the biotech industry in the past.So just as the shock from the oil bust is finally starting to fade, there's the sense that other big companies are losing momentum."The growth cycle effectively has run its course for large-cap America as a whole," Mian said.Analysts expect industrial firms to report a 1.2% earnings decline, and that likely doesn't reflect Honeywell (HON) news. Honeywell late Thursday cut the top end of its 2016 earnings forecast, citing weak Q3 aerospace sales. Honeywell shares plunged 7.5% Friday, with aerospace customers and rivals also slumping.PPG Industries (PPG), maker of industrial coatings, paints and glass, crashed 8.3% Friday on a Q3 profit warning. Fellow S&P 500 paint component Sherwin-Williams (SHW) retreated 1.9%.

The major averages were well off early highs Friday but held modest gains heading into the last hour of the regular trading session.The Dow Jones industrial average led with a 0.4% gain, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq added around 0.1%. All three indexes were on track for a second straight weekly loss. Volume was lighter across the board vs. the same time Thursday.Building-related stocks, gaming software and solar issues led the upside in today's stock market action. Laggards included department stores, biotechs and gold miners.Banks gave up their early gains despite view-topping results from Citigroup (C), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Wells Fargo (WFC). Shares were up 0.6% and down 0.1% and 0.1%, respectively. But Goldman Sachs (GS) led the Dow with a 2% gain.Oil stocks underperformed too, as West Texas intermediate crude oil settled at $50.35 a barrel, down 9 cents. The U.S. oil rig count rose for a seventh straight week in the latest week, according to Baker Hughes data, and the 15th of the past 16 weeks.On the IBD 50, Activision Blizzard (ATVI) rose 2%, extending a bounce off its 50-day line and back into buy range from a 43.15 flat-base entry. Volume was light, however, and all purchases remain highly risky with the market uptrend under pressure. Oppenheimer began covering the video game maker with an outperform rating and a 53 price target. Also on the 50, New Oriental Education (EDU) gained 3%. After an orderly pullback, shares of the Chinese test prep and language training provider are in buy range from a 45.47 entry. Analysts expect low double-digit earnings and sales growth when the company reports fiscal Q1 results on Oct. 25 before the open.But Acacia Communications (ACIA) continued its volatile ways, reversing lower for a 3% loss in fast trade. On Thursday, the fiber optics products maker staged an upside reversal for a 6% jump to halt a five-session slide. It's still up nearly 300% from its May 13 offering price. IPOs tend to be more volatile than their older peers.In economic news, September retail sales rose 0.6%, in line with forecasts. The Producer Price Index climbed 0.3% in September, edging past views for a 0.2% increase.RELATED:U.S. Oil Rig Count Rises For 7th Straight Week But Permian Rigs Dip Wells Fargo Beats But New Checking Accounts Sink; JPMorgan, Citi Top

Major stock ETFs ended Friday narrowly higher with the financial sector leading the broad market's advance on solid bank earnings.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) eked out a 0.1% gain on the stock market today. A proxy for the broad U.S. market, this exchange traded fund sits below the 50-day moving average and 2% below all-time highs.SPY took a 0.9% weekly loss, its second down week in a row.Utilities were the best-performing sector of the week, up 1.3%. Real estate and consumer staples were also among the strong performers, as investors sought safety and yield.Health care was the poorest performer, down 3.1%.Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF) posted a 0.5% gain on Friday, but ended well off session highs and in the red for the week.The ETF offers diversified exposure to banks, insurers and other financial services.Its second-largest stock holding, JPMorgan Chase (JPM), crushed views in its quarterly report on the strength of capital markets revenue.Reports from Wells Fargo (WFC) and Citigroup (C) also beat expectations. However, only Citigroup ended the day higher, up 0.3%.SPDR S&P Bank (KBE), which offers targeted exposure to the banking industry, rang in a 0.5% gain.On the IBD Leaderboard, Direxion Daily Financial Bull 3X Shares (FAS) added 0.9% Friday as financials bounced back.The financial sector is one of the poorer performers in the S&P 500 year-to-date, with XLF managing a 1.9% advance through Oct. 14.IBD'S TAKE: The September minutes released on Wednesday revealed that the Fed hawks are gaining sway.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) fell for a third week.The commodity ETF tracks the spot price of gold. It has weakened on higher odds of a Fed rate hike by December. Rising rates increase the opportunity cost of holding this safe-haven asset.Here's how major exchange traded funds across major asset classes performed today, with IBD Relative Strength Ratings.The RS Rating is a measure of a stock's price performance over the last 12 months, compared with all stocks and ETFs, on a scale of 1 to a best-possible 99.Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), +0.1%, RS 52PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), +0.1%, RS 66SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), +0.2%, RS 52IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), -0.1%, RS 60IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), -0.4%, RS 66IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), +0.2%, RS 38Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), +0.3%, RS 66SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), -0.6%, RS 52United States Oil (USO), -0.4%, RS 56IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), -0.2%, RS 42PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), +0.5%, RS 42IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), -1.0%, RS 2

John Stumpf, responding to allegations that Wells Fargo (WFC) opened millions of unauthorized accounts, said his bank failed its customers and the American public.In remarks prepared for the Senate Banking Committee, Stumpf said the scandal was not an "orchestrated effort" and that the company never wanted employees to open accounts that they didn't need or want."I am deeply sorry," Stumpf said in a copy of his testimony that was obtained by Bloomberg. Stumpf, chairman and chief executive officer, is scheduled to appear before the panel Tuesday in Washington."I am going to explain this morning what happened and what we have done about it," Stumpf said in the prepared remarks. "Wrongful sales practice behavior goes entirely against our values, ethics and culture."The San Francisco-based bank agreed earlier this month to pay $185 million to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and other regulators to resolve claims that employees opened more than 2 million accounts that consumers may not have known about. Stumpf is testifying Tuesday before the committee, chaired by Republican Richard Shelby.IBD'S TAKE: Wells Fargo shares rose Monday, but have fallen sharply since the cross-selling revelations. Meanwhile, two bank IPOs had a successful debut on Friday.Other witnesses include U.S. Comptroller of the Currency Tom Curry, who said he's directing bank examiners to review sales practices at all "large and midsize banks," and could pursue its own enforcement action against individuals at Wells Fargo, according to prepared remarks. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau Director Richard Cordray is also scheduled to testify.Stumpf's testimony walks through a timeline of the bank's own investigation into the matter and firing of employees. Efforts to detect and deter unethical conduct were put in place "out of concerns that some employees were not doing what was right," according to Stumpf. Starting in 2011, the bank assigned a dedicated team to monitor and root out sales practice violations. Sales employees began being terminated for misconduct as a result of the investigation. Starting in 2012, the lender began to reduce certain sales goals for compensation.In 2015, an Office of the Comptroller of the Currency review of Wells Fargo's sales practices revealed shortcomings that prompted the agency to demand changes -- including telling the bank to compensate customers for any harm they suffered from bad sales practices, and that the company had to bring in an outside consultant to review what was going on, Curry said. Wells Fargo hired PricewaterhouseCoopers in August 2015 to help determine whether customers incurred financial harm, according to Stumpf."Despite all those efforts, we did not get it right," Stumpf said. "We should have done more sooner to eliminate unethical conduct and unintended incentives for that conduct to occur. Even one unauthorized account is one too many."Stumpf also outlined other ways Wells Fargo has tried to prevent unauthorized accounts from being created, including working with regulators and creating a new branch compliance program.Stumpf's testimony isn't likely to quell concerns lawmakers have about what the bank is doing to hold some of its top executives accountable. The remarks don't discuss executive compensation or give any information about whether the board plans to consider clawing back pay for some top managers, including Carrie Tolstedt, the retired executive who led the unit where the alleged misconduct occurred.A group of Democratic Senators, led by Elizabeth Warren, last week wrote a letter to Stumpf asking questions about pay. The lawmakers singled out Tolstedt, writing that there appears "to be multiple grounds on which to trigger the clawback provisions to recoup some or all of Ms. Tolstedt's incentive rewards."The OCC, which regulates Wells Fargo, began receiving complaints in 2012 from consumers and employees about "improper sales practices," Curry said. In his remarks, Curry said the agency has started "a review of individual misconduct and culpability."The House Financial Services Committee, chaired by Jeb Hensarling, said last week it plans to conduct its own investigation and will hold a separate hearing later this month. Hensarling says he plans to request that Stumpf appear for that hearing too. Tolstedt as well as other corporate officers will be called for transcribed interviews, Hensarling said.

Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) have broken out this week on growing Federal Reserve rate-hike speculation and relief over Deutsche Bank (DB).After AFP reported that Deutsche Bank could settle a mortgage-securities case for far less than the Justice Department asked for, potentially warding off a bigger shock to the global banking industry, Bank of America and Citigroup on Friday bounced off their 50-day lines. Meanwhile, Fed officials' comments and recent economic data have reinforced expectations for central bank tightening by the end of the year.Banks and bank stocks should do well if the Fed raises rates because it allow them to increase the spread between its lending rates and borrowing costs. Banks' net interest margins have been squeezed in recent years.JPMorgan Chase (JPM), meanwhile, also rebounded off its 50-day. JPMorgan broke out in early August from a handle in a consolidation and remains within range of the 66.58 buy point. JPMorgan rose 1.6% to 67.69 Wednesday.Citigroup climbed 1.9% to 48.65 in the stock market today, hitting its best levels since early January. Citigroup cleared a 48.28 buy point in an 11-month consolidation.Bank of America advanced 2.% to 16.11. BofA is 4.9% above its 50-day line, still within the chase zone. Ideally, for a stock to be within buy range, it should be no more than 5% above the 50-day line.Wells Fargo rose 2.8%, but from a two-and-a-half-year low. Wells Fargo is still reeling from the cross-selling scandal.IBD'S TAKE: The Banks-Money Center industry group, which includes the big banks, moves in tandem with the Federal Reserve's announcements on interest rates. To learn more about top industry groups and taking profits quickly rapid changes in the market, see this story about Swing Trading strategies. Meanwhile, some super-regional banks also have broken out. SunTrust Banks (STI) broke past a 44.71 buy point of a consolidation pattern begun in late May on Tuesday. On Wednesday, SunTrust rose 2.2% to 45.73, still in range. SunTrust had found resistance several times just above 44 in recent months.Meanwhile, Comerica (CMA) rose 2.8% to 49.21 Wednesday, extended from buy range but still performing solidly.Wednesday's bank stock gains come as ADP reported that companies added 154,000 jobs in September, short of estimates for 170,000 but still solid. Meanwhile, the ISM nonmanufacturing index shot up to an 11-month high last month. On Monday, ISM's manufacturing index signaled a return to factory expansion.RELATED:New High Analysis: Session Yields Slew Of Financial BreakoutsU.S. Banking Giants Gain As Deutsche Bank, European Financials TeeterBank Of America Gains Share Globally, Vows Blockchain EmbraceJPMorgan, Goldman, Citi Waver As Rates To Stay Lower For Longer

Three Wall Street firms hiked price targets on Intel (INTC), Citigroup increased PTs of Facebook (FB) and Applied Materials (AMAT), and Needham upped PTs of Lumentum (LITE) and Finisar (FNSR) amid an emerging supercycle for optical parts makers.Citigroup hiked its price target on Facebook to 158 from 148. "Investor concerns about the impact of decelerating ad load growth on ad revenue growth for core Facebook appear overblown," said analyst Mark May in a report. Ad load growth refers to the number of ads Facebook can serve up to its users. Another worry is Snapchat's growth. "Investor concerns about the impact from Snapchat's growth on core Facebook's user and user engagement growth appear unfounded," May added.Facebook shares dipped 0.3% to close at 128.65 on the stock market today. The stock is above a buy point of 128.43, but investors should be cautious about making any buys in the current market.RELATED:Fed, Facebook, Disney, Netflix Lead Weekly Investing Action PlanJefferies upped its PT to 49 from 44, Needham hiked its PT to 43 from 38, and Mizuho Securities raised its PT to 42 from 38. Intel on Friday raised its Q3 revenue target. Intel has been winning more business for the Apple (AAPL) iPhone, with modem chips in many new iPhone handsets. "We like the setup on the stock as our checks indicate accelerating demand for high margin server microprocessors from hyperscale players (internet companies)," said Jefferies analyst Mark Lipicas, in a report.Intel shares fell 1.4% to close at 37.16 after climbing 3% on Friday, hitting a 15-year high intraday.RELATED:Intel Stock Earns Price-Target Hikes On Apple, PC DevelopmentsNeedham raised its PT on Lumentum Holdings to 50 from 40 and hiked Finisar's PT to 36 from 32. Needham also reiterated a buy rating on Fabrinet (FN). IBD's Telecom-Fiber Optics group is ranked No. 1 out of 197 groups amid surging demand for 100 gigabit-per-second optical devices for data centers and metro area networks and strong demand in China.Lumentum jumped 3.4% to finish at 40.55 while Finisar climbed 1.9% to close at 28.74.RELATED: U.S. Optical Firms Dominate Supercycle As Chinese Rivals LagCitigroup increased its PT on Applied Materials to 37 from 32, citing demand for smartphone screens and 3D flash memory. The maker of semiconductor manufacturing gear hosts an investor day on Wednesday.Applied Materials rose 0.8% to end the trading day at 30.30.MKM Partners downgraded Arista Networks to neutral from buy and its shares dropped 3.5% to 82.03. Arista is No. 1 in IBD's computer networking group.In other analyst moves, Bank of America upgraded Cerner (CERN) to buy, Robert W. Baird upgraded Wells Fargo (WFC) to outperform, and Stifel downgraded Viacom (VIA) to neutral from buy on reports that the media company's board of directors has decided to table plans to sell a minority interest in film studio Paramount. Cowen increased GrubHub's (GRUB) PT to 38 from 33 and hiked Panera Bread's PT to 250 from 240. Piper Jaffray bumped up Electronic Arts' (EA) PT to 89 from 88. It's No. 3 in IBD's Software-Computer Gaming group while Activision Blizzard (ATVI) is No. 1. Morgan Stanley upgraded General Motors (GM) to outperform.

Bank stocks are holding up relatively well amid a sharp market sell-off Friday as more Federal Reserve officials prime the U.S. for a potential interest-rate hike. But JPMorgan Chase (JPM) remained the only big-bank stock within buy range as of Friday afternoon.JPMorgan Chase fell 0.9% to close at 66.65 in the stock market today, as it was downgraded on Friday by Macquarie Research. But it's still above a 65.08 buy point cleared in early August from a handle in a consolidation.Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren said Friday that waiting too long to raise rates could damage the economy."My personal view, based on economic data that we have received to date, is that a reasonable case can be made for continuing to pursue a gradual normalization of monetary policy," Rosengren said to the South Shore Chamber of Commerce, Quincy, Mass.Several other policymakers have made similar comments. But Rosengren had long been considered a policy dove. His comments raised the odds of a September-meeting rate hike, but most investors see the next move in December.The Fed rate-hike buzz is a headwind and a tailwind for bank stocks. Rate hikes would probably help banks boost net interest margins. But with the general market selling off, it's hard for financials to advance.IBD'S TAKE: Bank earnings are long gone, but Fed news -- and key economic data that shift rate-hike expectations -- can give bank stocks a quick boost or cut them off. If you're holding financial stocks or ETFs heading into the Fed policy meeting on Sept. 20-21, consider this risk-limiting earnings options strategy.Superregional bank SunTrust Banks (STI), meanwhile, has flirted with a 44.29 buy point over the past week or so, and ended Friday trades down 1.1% to 43.39. Great Western Bancorp (GWB), meanwhile, faded from a 35.01 entry by dropping 0.7% to 32.03, but was still trading within a flat base pattern.Citigroup (C), Bank of America (BAC), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS) were not within buy range. Citigroup is facing resistance at the 48 price range.Bank of America fell fractionally to end the day at 15.74. Citigroup dropped 1.3% to 47.17 while Morgan Stanley lost 1.4% to 31.59, while Goldman Sachs lost 1.8% to 168.57. Wells Fargo (WFC) slid by 2.4% to 48.72, dropping below its 200-day line.Wells Fargo on Thursday agreed to pay a $185 million fine after authorities said 5,300 workers surreptitiously opened credit-card and deposit accounts in customers' names in a scheme to juice sales numbers. Wells has fired those workers.RELATED:Big Bank Stocks Are Leading, But Only This One Is A Buy NowDow Nears Key Support; Are Bank Stocks Ready To Lead?Fed's Yellen, Fischer Send Mixed Messages, Leave Markets Guessing

Citigroup (C) on Wednesday said it expected improved trading but "lighter than estimated" investment banking in the third quarter, and the financing giant echoed Bank of America (BAC) in emphasizing its opportunities outside of the U.S.Citigroup said that trading revenue for the third quarter would be up in the mid-single digits in the third quarter, helped by fixed-income and currency trades, CFO John Gerspach said at the Barclays Global Financial Services Conference, according to wire services. Investment banking revenue for the quarter was weaker than expected.In slides accompanying the presentation, Citigroup said it was focused on three areas, North America, Mexico and Asia. In particular, Gerspach sees "tremendous untapped potential" in Mexico, touting improvements in Citigroup's card business there saying at the conference that the nation was "a country that is still on the come," according to Reuters.Citigroup said revenue trends were improving in Asia and Latin America, with card revenue and retail banking helping the consumer banking market in Mexico pick up steam.Citigroup shares fell 0.4% to 46.75 in the stock market today, though it's still near the top of a recent consolidation JPMorgan (JPM) sank 0.2% while Goldman Sachs (GS) lost 0.5%.  Morgan Stanley (MS) closed 0.3% higher.JPMorgan, at the same conference earlier this week, said more millennials preferred it as their primary financial institution for checking, savings and credit-card accounts.The conference comes as U.S. banks outshine and take market share from their European rivals in investment banking. While some international markets have struggled, a Bank of America official at the Barclays conference this week said the opportunity for global expansion "has never been better."IBD'S TAKE: Bank stocks have rallied on more bullish remarks from Fed officials. Read this story to find out which bank stocks could be within buy range. Wells Fargo (WFC), closed down 0.9% after tumbling 6% in the prior three sessions, has been dealing with the fallout of a $185 million fine it paid following allegations that its sales staff created fake accounts or opened them in customers' names without their OK to boost sales figures. CEO John Stumpf, in an interview with the Wall Street Journal published Tuesday, blamed those employees, saying that "there was no incentive to do bad things." But Wells reportedly faces a federal criminal probe.RELATED:Wells Fargo Reportedly Faces Federal Probe Over Sales TacticsJPMorgan, Big Banks Find Ways To Win Despite Fed, Brexit Headwinds

Wells Fargo (WFC) eliminated product sales goals for its consumer bankers as the company seeks to reassure regulators, lawmakers and customers after employees opened more than 2 million accounts without clients' approval."We want to make certain our customers have full confidence that our retail bankers are always focused on the best interests of customers," Chief Executive Officer John Stumpf said Tuesday in a statement.The Senate Banking Committee plans to hold a hearing Sept. 20 on San Francisco-based Wells Fargo, following last week's enforcement case in which regulators accused bank employees of opening deposit and credit-card accounts without approval to meet sales goals. Stumpf, 62, is among executives who've been asked to appear. Wells Fargo, which agreed to pay $185 million in fines, eliminated sales goals for retail bankers, effective Jan. 1, and instructed U.S. call center workers to temporarily halt cross-selling of financial products.Mary Eshet, a spokeswoman for the lender, said the U.S. Labor Day holiday was an additional incentive to drop the strategy for now because the days following it are traditionally a period of heavy call volume. Eliminating cross-selling was aimed at reducing the expected backlog, she said.The allegations have been a black eye for Wells Fargo, the biggest U.S. home lender and a marquee investment for billionaire Warren Buffett, whose Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) is the bank's largest shareholder.Chief Financial Officer John Shrewsberry said the bank will be able to adjust to changes needed to deal with the scandal."We think we can adapt our business model, take sales goals out and still have a growth culture with people trying to deepen relationships with customers," Shrewsberry said Tuesday at a conference in New York. "I think we can make this pivot in a way that protects our business model."Most of the employees involved were not motivated by the need to generate revenue, he said. "It was really more at the lower end of the performance scale, where people apparently were making bad choices to hang on to their job," he said.IBD'S TAKE: Bank stocks have rallied on more bullish remarks from Fed officials. While few are buys right now, read this story to find out which bank stocks are buys. About 10% of the 5,300 employees terminated as a result of the problem were managers, the CFO said, adding that the bank refunded $2.6 million in fees for about 115,000 unauthorized accounts, or about $25 per account. Two-thirds of those affected were in the U.S. Southwest, according to Shrewsberry.Wells Fargo declined 2.4% to $47.40 at 9:39 a.m. in New York, the worst performance in the 24-company KBW Bank Index, which dropped 1.4%. The lender's stock has lost 13% this year, while the KBW Index fell 2.4%.Revelations that bank employees had opened the accounts are "highly disturbing" and could hurt holders of the bank's debt, Moody's Investors Service said Monday.The "deficiencies" uncovered by the U.S. Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and other government investigators show that the bank's "vaunted cross-selling capabilities were inflated," Moody's said in a report. The bank encouraged "pervasive inappropriate practices" and managers didn't provide oversight of employees, Moody's said.Treasury Secretary Jacob J. Lew said the scandal should be a warning to critics of the CFPB, which was created as part of the Dodd-Frank financial reform legislation."There's a lot of talk in Washington these days about rolling back Dodd-Frank, about rolling back the law, changing the law that created the agency that uncovered and took action against this," Lew said Tuesday in an interview on CNBC. "This ought to be a moment where people stop and remember how dangerous the system is when you don't have the proper protections in place."The CFPB said last week that bank employees secretly opened the unauthorized accounts to hit sales targets and receive bonuses. The company agreed to resolve the allegations without admitting or denying wrongdoing.Wells Fargo has come under fire from politicians since the fines were announced Thursday. Presidential candidate Hillary Clinton on Friday praised the consumer watchdog for its work. She said that Donald Trump, her Republican rival, wants to dismantle the CFPB.The fines "probably should lead to a pay clawback" from Carrie Tolstedt, the Wells Fargo executive who ran community banking until the company announced her retirement in July, Mike Mayo, an analyst at CLSA, wrote in a note to clients Monday."These issues should have been caught sooner and dealt with more forcefully," he wrote.Tolstedt has unvested stock awards that would be worth about $17.8 million if the company hits certain financial targets. She'll also get $3.07 million in retirement benefits, according to data compiled by Bloomberg. That doesn't include previously vested stock options that would be worth $38.5 million if exercised at Monday's stock-market close. Tolstedt, 56, also holds about $53 million of shares amassed during her 27-year career.RELATED:Bank Of America Gains Share Globally, Vows Blockchain Embrace Where Do Millennials Bank? JPMorgan Says It Beats BofA, Wells FargoBank Stocks Hold Ground As Fed Buzz Builds: Which One Is A Buy Now?

The market was lower but trimmed its losses sharply in afternoon trading Wednesday.The Nasdaq was down 0.7% after falling as much as 1.3%. Still, the composite was below the 50-day moving average after gapping lower at the open. The S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average were down 0.5%.Volume was tracking higher in today's trading.Utilities, real estate investment trusts and other stocks most sensitive to interest rates were the better-performing stocks. The diversified utilities industry group was up 1.6%, although most stocks in it are barely coming off their lows. The Dow utilities average surged 1.7%, easily the best index for the day.The property REIT group was up 1%, but it also suffers from a lack of quality charts. Most remain below the 50-day moving average, and in some cases that line is curving downward now. Bond yields fell today, countering a rising trend on expectations of an interest-rate increase by year's end.Banking stocks were mainly lower. JPMorgan (JPM), Wells Fargo (WFC) and Citigroup (C) -- three banks that report earnings Friday -- were down 1% to 2%. Late Wednesday, Wells Fargo announced that CEO John Stumpf is stepping down. The bank has been roiled by a scandal in which bankers created accounts without customers' permission.Chips stocks also were weaker than most. The Philadelphia semiconductor index was down 1.5%, fighting to stay above a rising 50-day moving average.Taiwan Semiconductor (TSM) slid to its 50-day moving average in big volume. Shares appear to be finding support at that level, which could provide a new buy area. The chipmaker fell despite beating third-quarter sales and earnings. It also raised its guidance for the current quarter, thanks to a boost in chips for Apple's (AAPL) iPhone 7.Silicon Motion (SIMO) accelerated losses, tumbling nearly 7%. The stock is back to the lows of an irregular pattern and deeper below its 50-day line.Some energy stocks were leading the market. Oil prices were slightly higher, just above $50 a barrel on the NYMEX. The Energy Information Administration said Thursday oil inventories surged by 4.85 million barrels last week, well above the 300,000-barrel increase analysts were expecting.RELATED:Chipmaker TSMC's Q4 Guidance Points To Strong Apple iPhone 7 SalesU.S. Oil Tests $50 As Inventories Jumped Amid Hurricane Shutdowns

The number of stock buybacks announced in September came in at a monthly low not seen since 2011, with Microsoft (MSFT) and American Express (AXP) accounting for the bulk of the dollar value. Meanwhile, dividend growth in the last two quarters hit its weakest level since late 2009 and early 2010.Those findings, from research firm TrimTabs, come amid a bull market that has lasted some seven years and was often helped along by share repurchases. The firm expects share repurchases to continue to slow.The cooling buyback activity likely reflects growing caution among executives amid a volatile market trying to process mixed economic signals. S&P 500 earnings have fallen for several quarter, largely due to plunging energy profits."When repurchases fall it can also indicate that CEOs are feeling less confident and flush, less willing to spend more money to bolster the value of their stock-based compensations," Winston Chua, an analyst at TrimTabs, said in an email. "Buybacks often rise when CEOs are feeling good, because their bonuses are tied to EPS growth."For the third quarter, share repurchases announced by U.S. companies fell to $115 billion, a more than two-year low, TrimTabs said in a release. There were 39 buybacks announced in September, the least in a month since January 2011, according to the firm.While new buybacks recovered to $59.9 billion last month from a 3 1/2 year low in August, "underlying activity was not robust," TrimTabs said in a research report. Two-thirds of September's results came from a $40 billion share repurchase approved by Microsoft, while American Express also announced a $6.3 billion buyback during the month."The dearth of buybacks in the past month/quarter is particularly eye-opening because many companies don't care what price they pay for their shares because CEOs and CFOs aren't spending their own money," Chua added in the email. "They're spending shareholders' money."Microsoft dipped 0.3% to to close at 57.42 on the stock market today, going just below its 50-day line as it makes its way through a flat base begun in August.American Express shaved off 0.4% to end the trading day at 63.81. AmEx is trading in a narrow channel just below the 50-day line and above its 200-day. The credit-card issuer in July had been among the Dow's bigger laggards following the loss of partners like Costco (COST) and JetBlue (JBLU).Apple (AAPL), which also struggled to pace the Dow this summer, led the S&P 500 in buybacks in the second quarter. But buyback volume overall during that quarter was lowest in eight quarters, TrimTabs said in the report.
