Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen said Friday that the case for a rate hike has "strengthened" in recent months, as labor market slack is fading.The U.S. economy is "now nearing the Federal Reserve's statutory goals of maximum employment and price stability," Yellen said.Financial markets, which already have been pricing in a good chance of a rate hike in December, initially took her comments in stride. Investors are less concerned about the timing of the next hike than the one after that. Treasury yields initially rose a bit, then headed slightly lower after release of Yellen's speech transcript.That was before Fed Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer told CNBC that he saw Yellen's comments as consistent with a rate hike at the September meeting. Further, he said, a second increase could come as early as December, adding that the Fed won't know what's appropriate "until we see the data."Those comments caused a bit more turbulence, with the 10-year Treasury yield bouncing from an intraday low of 1.53% to 1.59%. Major stock indexes gave up modest gains stock market today and turned red, though afternoon losses were slim.After Fischer's comments market pricing still points to the next hike being in December, CME Group's FedWatch tool shows, though the odds of a hike in September edged up from 21% to 30%.But if Fischer's comments about two hikes this year begin to look realistic, bond market pricing will have to shift pretty markedly. Right now, markets are pricing in just a 31% chance of a second hike coming by the meeting on July 26, 2017.Yellen's speech and Fischer's comments both underscore just how unsure Fed policymakers are about the future. In addition to talking about economic data showing the Fed's goals of full employment and 2% inflation may be around the corner, Yellen highlighted arguments pointing to very low interest rates for a long time to come."By some calculations, the real neutral rate is currently close to zero, and it could remain at this low level if we were to continue to see slow productivity growth and high global saving," Yellen said.The neutral interest rate is the rate at which monetary policy is neither accommodative nor restrictive.The path of rate hikes next year is the big issue for investors. Even as markets have shifted in recent weeks toward expecting a rate hike as early as December, the 10-year Treasury yield has drifted slightly lower. The reason markets have been so calm about the next rate increase is that investors don't expect an ensuing hike until at least the fall of 2017.Yellen, as expected, didn't offer any precise timing for the next Fed interest rate hike. Markets had already moved up the expected timing after a run of mostly better-than-expected data, including the strong July jobs report, a jump in new-home sales and a surge in durable goods orders. New data on Friday were on the soft side, though, with second-quarter GDP growth revised down to 1.1%, and the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index slipping unexpectedly.Banks, which stand to benefit from higher rates, perked up with Yellen's comments about a stronger case for a rate hike, but later gave up much of their gains. JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) each saw minor gains, but Bank of America (BAC) was up 1.4%.

Bank of America (BAC) rallied after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen said the case for raising rates has improved, but JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and some other big banks pared Friday gains after her deputy back two hikes this year."Indeed, in light of the continued solid performance of the labor market and our outlook for economic activity and inflation, I believe the case for an increase in the federal funds rate has strengthened in recent months," Yellen said in Jackson Hole, Wyo.Fed Vice Chairman Stanley Fischer followed up, saying that Yellen's comments are consistent with a September rate hike, while he said he still sees two rate  hikes this year. Investors raised the odds of a near-term hike, but still see just one hike, in December.Bank of America climbed 1.7% on the stock market today. Citigroup (C) rose 0.8% and Morgan Stanley (MS) 0.6%. JPMorgan rose 0.2%, Goldman Sachs (GS)  climbed fractionally and Wells Fargo (WFC) advanced 0.3%.IBD'S TAKE: Low rates continue to be among the main challenges for the banking industry. A Federal Reserve rate hike would effectively give banks the green light to raise their own interest rates, allowing them to take in more money from loans. Learn more on how to evaluate stocks here.Some Fed officials have become more bullish on raising rates in recent weeks. St. Louis Fed President James Bullard told CNBC Friday that September could be a good time for a rate hike. Cleveland Federal Reserve President Loretta Mester told the network that the economy would get stronger in the second half of the year.Analysts and investors had expected Yellen to use the speech to prime the U.S. for an eventual interest-rate hike.RELATED:Fed's Yellen Says Rate Hike Case Has 'Strengthened' As Labor Markets Tighten

While Wells Fargo (WFC), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), U.S. Bancorp (USB) and other large financial institutions have been exiting the health savings account (HSA) business, HealthEquity (HQY), one of the nation's largest HSA administrators, continues to grow. Healthy Profits Despite fears that ObamaCare regulations would curtail or kill HSAs, deposits and investment assets have continued to grow in recent years, reaching $30.2 billion…

Warren Buffett-led Berkshire Hathaway’s (BRKB) investments took a hit in the first quarter as financial stocks pulled down the value of his "Big Four" companies.Berkshire's holdings in American Express (AXP) and Wells Fargo (WFC) both fell in value, partly offset by increases in the other half of the "Big Four" -- top food and beverage stock, Coca-Cola (KO), and IBM (IBM), which both grew in value. Coke closed down 0.2% Monday, and IBM ended virtually flat.Financials were among the hardest-hit industries in the first quarter as interest rates lingered near record lows and the energy slump continued. Berkshire Hathaway reported first-quarter financial results on Friday after the market closed.Berkshire reported an 8% increase in first-quarter revenue to $52.4 billion. Net earnings rose 8.1% to $5.66 billion.And railroad, utilities and energy revenue slid 11% to $8.85 billion amid a slump in the railroad industry. The company expects that to change."As of March 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015, we concluded that there were no unrealized losses that were other than temporary," Berkshire said in its report on Friday.The Big Four accounted for about 60% of Berkshire's stock holdings as of March 31, up a bit from 59% the prior quarter. The value of the holdings changed from the end of 2015 to March 31 for various reasons, including company stock buybacks that boosted share values.The value of Berkshire's Coca-Cola shares rose to $18.6 billion at the end of the first quarter from $17.2 billion at the end of 2015. Its holdings in IBM grew to $12.3 billion from $11.2 billion.However, the value of its Wells Fargo stock slid to $24.2 billion from $27.2 billion and American Express fell to $9.3 billion from $10.5 billion.Railroad, utilities and energy stock holdings rose to $1.29 billion from $1.24 billion even as revenue from Berkshire-owned companies in its Railroad, Utilities and Energy business fell 11% to $8.85 billion, including a sharp drop by its BNSF Railway, which has been battered by lower shipments of energy products including coal and oil.Berkshire total stock investments in finance companies' stocks declined 5% to $106.42 billion.Berkshire bought 425 million shares of H.J. Heinz, now a subsidiary of Kraft Heinz (KHC) in June 2013 and has added to those holdings, which it said in the report have a "liquidation preference of $8 billion" as of March 31. Aggregate costs for the Kraft Heinz stock investments was $12.25 billion. Kraft Heinz rose 0.2% to 84.19 Monday afternoon.It also has $2.1 billion worth of gum maker Wrigley, which is owned by privately held candy and snacks maker Mars. It has 3 million shares of plastics and agricultural products maker Dow Chemical (DOW), valued at about $3 billion, and owns 9% of Canada-based Restaurant Brands International (QSR), parent of the Burger King and Tim Hortons restaurant chains. Restaurant Brands was down 1%.Berkshire Hathaway shares closed down 1.2% in the stock market today. It fell to a 123.55 low on Feb. 3 before turning up.

Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) Chairman and CEO Warren Buffett will give his insight into the company and markets at Saturday's eagerly awaited annual shareholders meeting in Omaha, Neb.Buffett made Berkshire Hathaway's largest-ever purchase in January and reshuffled the company's portfolio.On Jan. 29, Berkshire announced it had completed the $37.2 billion (including debt) purchase of Precision Castparts, its biggest buyout ever.Berkshire's net worth rose by $15.4 billion in 2015 as the company bought more shares of favorites IBM (IBM) and Wells Fargo (WFC).Berkshire expects about 40,000 shareholders from around the world to attend the event. But you don't have to visit Omaha in person: For the first time ever, the so-called "Woodstock for Capitalists" will be streamed live, on Yahoo Finance. Buffett will offer his comments in what a press statement described as a "no holds barred" Q&A with him and Vice Chairman Charlie Munger.Buffett, 85, has said in the past that he and the board have agreed on a successor, but he hasn't disclosed who that is. Munger is 92.S&P Capital IQ analyst Cathy Seifert said in a recent report that Berkshire's growth strategy is continuing to pay off."Our buy opinion reflects our view that Berkshire's ability to grow its revenue base (both organically and through acquisitions) and maintain margins, despite a mixed economic outlook, will enable the shares to retain their premium valuation" vs. its peers and the broader market. S&P Capital IQ has a 152 price target on Berkshire's Class B stock.For the full year 2015, net earnings grew 21.2% to $24.08 billion, and revenue grew 8% to $210.8 billion, up from $194.7 billion in 2014. Net earnings for the Dec. 31-ended quarter climbed 31.8% to $5.478 billion. Earnings per share minus one-time items for Class B shares rose to $2.22 in the fourth quarter, well above analyst estimates of $1.75.The consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters is for EPS to rise 3% to $1.78 for the current quarter, up from $1.72 in Q1 2015. Berkshire's BNSF Railroad continues to be a drag on earnings amid an oversupplied energy market and plunging coal shipments. BNSF's total railcar units for the week ended April 16 fell by 21% vs. the same quarter a year earlier to about 81,000 units.Berkshire Class B stock hasn't formed a viable base recently. It dropped to an intraday low of 123.55 on Feb. 3 and has bounced nicely since then. It's risen about 18%, climbing above its 10-week average and 200-day line along the way. Berkshire's B shares closed up less than 0.1% at 146.18 in the stock market today.Berkshire Hathaway boasts a solid 81 IBD Composite Rating, meaning it's outperformed 81% of all stocks on key metrics such as sales and profit growth in recent quarters.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Energy remains a drag for Wells Fargo (WFC), which charged off $204 million in energy loans in Q1, up about 75% from Q4, and added $200 million to its energy loan-loss reserves, while the tally of oil sector bankruptcies climbed higher with a filing Thursday from Energy XXI (EXXI).Bank of America (BAC) boosted its energy loan-loss reserves by $525 million vs. Q4 levels to $1 billion in Q1.The collapse of crude oil prices since mid-2014 has battered energy companies. More than 50 North American oil and gas producers have filed for bankruptcy protection since early 2015, according to a Reuters analysis.Houston-based Energy XXI, one of the biggest shallow-water drillers in the Gulf of Mexico, sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection Thursday.Despite Wells Fargo's exposure to the oil bust, the San Francisco-based lender beat Q1 estimates, earning 99 cents a share, down 5% from Q1 2015 and topping views by 2 cents. Revenue rose 4.3% to $22.2 billion, beating views of $21.6 billion.Total loans grew 10% to $947.3 billion. Commercial loans rose 19% to $488.2 billion, due in part to Well Fargo's acquisition of General Electric's (GE) commercial lending and leasing unit, as well as its railcar leasing unit.Wells Fargo shares closed 0.5% lower on the stock market today. Energy XXI shares sank 80% to less than 13 cents. GE edged up 0.1%Long considered a bellwether for the housing market due to its robust mortgage portfolio, Wells said its mortgage applications rose 20% to $77 billion, while originations fell 6% to $44 billion. Mortgage fees increased 3% to $1.6 billion.Profit at Wells' community banking division fell 7% to $3.3 billion, while its wholesale banking division profit fell 2.7% to $1.9 billion. Its wealth and investment management division profit fell 3.2% to $512 million.The bank's net interest margin, a key gauge of profitability that measures the difference between what it pays out to depositors vs. what it charges in loan interest, narrowed to 2.9%, compared to 2.92% as of the end of Q4 2015.Meanwhile, Bank of America earned 21 cents a share in Q1, down 22% from a year earlier but beating by a penny estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue fell 8.6% to $19.6 billion, missing views of $20.3 billion.Bank of America's consumer and commercial banking units gained 16% year over year to $4.5 billion, Chairman and CEO Brian Moynihan said in a statement. Total loans and leases rose 3% to $901 billion. The bank issued 1.2 million new U.S. consumer cards in Q1, and total debit and credit card activity increased 5%.The positive numbers were enough to send BofA's shares up 2.5%.The downside wasn't that bad for Bank of America, since the result was expected, given stocks' horrendous start to the year. Total trading revenue fell 16% to $3.8 billion, with fixed-income trading falling 17% to $2.4 billion. Equities revenue fell 11% to $1.04 billion. Investment banking revenue tumbled 20% to $1.2 billion."It was a really bad quarter for the Street across the board," said Dan Burrows, a senior writer at InvestorPlace. "The banks pretty much performed as we expected them to."As of March 31, BofA's full-time employee count was down 3% to 213,183 workers. Total assets rose 2% to $2.2 trillion.Analysts weren't expecting great things from big banks in Q1, so it's mostly been a case of under-promising and over-delivering. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) beat Q1 estimates when it reported results on Wednesday, thanks to a strong performance in its commercial and consumer units overcoming weakness in trading revenue and energy loan losses.Citigroup (C) reports Q1 earnings on Friday. Investment bank behemoths Morgan Stanley (MS) and Goldman Sachs (GS) report first-quarter results on Monday and Tuesday, respectively.

The stock market opened modestly higher Thursday, but early gains faded about 15 minutes after the opening bell.The Nasdaq lost 0.2%, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 eased less than 0.1%.The market uptrend resumed Wednesday thanks to bullish gains. Both the Nasdaq and S&P 500 open above their 50- and 200-day moving averages and pecking out short-term highs. Small caps had an even better day than the general market on Wednesday, with both the S&P 600 and the Russell 2000 surging 2.2% (vs. 1.5% for the Nasdaq and 1% for the S&P 500).Thursday's economic calendar opened with consumer prices, which the Labor Department reported eked up 0.1% in March. That was an improvement over February's 0.2% decline, but short of expectations for a 0.2% rise. Core prices, minus energy and food, also rose 0.1%. Consensus estimates projected a 0.2% increase.Unemployment claims dropped sharply to 253,000 in the week ended April 9. That was nearly 5% below the prior week's downwardly revised number, and well below expectations for 267,000 claims.Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank President Dennis Lockhart said he changed his mind about an April rate hike and will no longer support it. Federal Reserve Governor Jerome Powell is also scheduled to speak this morning.Crude oil was steady. Gold slipped a fraction. The dollar was steady against the euro but up vs. the yen and most Asian currencies. The 10-year yield rose 2 basis points to 1.79%, as bonds slipped.Nike (NKE) outperformed early in the Dow, rising 1%.Nasdaq 100 firm and S&P 500 component Wynn Resorts (WYNN) was an early riser, up nearly 2%. The casino and resort operator has nearly doubled after hitting a low near 50 in January.Delta Air Lines (DAL) jumped 3.5%. It reported better-than-expected Q1 earnings, but revenue slipped 1.5% to undercut forecasts.Seagate Technology (STX) crumbled 14%, the worst decline among both S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 stocks. The digital hard drive manufacturer warned investors that its fiscal Q3 revenue and margins would undercut prior guidance. The company cited weak demand and inventory reductions.  Peer Western Digital (WDC) also caught the downdraft, slipping 7%.Financial stocks made headlines again. Bank of America (BAC) added 1% after reporting earnings. Wells Fargo (WFC) also reported. Shares fell nearly 1%. PNC Financial (PNC) slipped 1% after a Q1 revenue and earnings miss.

Stocks were slightly higher going into the noon hour Thursday, as big bank earnings announcements took center stage.The Nasdaq rose 0.1%, while the S&P 500 was also up 0.1%, and the Dow Jones industrial average gained nearly 0.2% in the stock market today. Volume was tracking lighter on both main exchanges.Bank of America (BAC) rose nearly 2% after reporting EPS of 21 cents a share, below estimates. The bank blamed low interest rates and declining trade revenue.Wells Fargo (WFC) dropped less than 1% after reporting EPS of 99 cents, a 5% decrease from a year earlier.But San Francisco-based First Republic Bank (FRC) galloped 7% higher after beating estimates. It reported EPS of 88 cents vs. estimates of 80 cents. It broke out of a consolidation.3D printer makers were hot following positive comments from BofA Merrill Lynch about 3D Systems (DDD). Analyst Wamsi Mohan expressed confidence in new CEO Vyomesh Joshi's ability to turn the company around. He upgraded it from underperform to buy and raised the price target from 11 to 26. The stock gapped up and was trading 13% higher on massive volume.Stratasys (SSYS), another 3D printer maker, rose 7%.Hawaiian Airlines (HA) hit a new high, up nearly 2%.Image provided by Shutterstock.

The first quarter of 2016 is being called the worst for U.S. banks since the financial crisis and the rest of the year doesn't look much better.This week, the big money center banks report first-quarter earnings and expectations are for them to be worse than the year-ago quarter. Since financials are the third-largest sector in the S&P 500, they could be a harbinger of the rest of the market.The biggest ETFs focused on financials are $15.71 billion Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF), down 5.41% year to date, $3.71 billion Vanguard Financials (VFH) -4.48% and $2.25 billion SPDR S&P Bank (KBE) down 10.25%.The headwinds facing the sector are strong. They include low interest rates and a flat yield curve, leading to slim interest margins, which make up a big part of a bank's earnings. Throw in slumping merger-and-acquisition activity, underreserved loans to the energy sector, higher capital reserve requirements and weaker trading revenue and it adds up to declining return on equity."Earnings expectations have come in," said David George, senior banking analyst at Robert W. Baird. "Given how poorly the stocks have done, the expectations are reasonable."JPMorgan Chase (JPM), the biggest U.S. lender by assets kicked off the proceedings Wednesday. Kicking off big banks’ earnings season, the New York-based lender’s Q1 earnings fell 7% to $1.35 a share, beating consensus estimates by 9 cents. Revenue slipped 3% to $24.1 billion, above forecasts of $23.4 billion.Investors were happy to see net income beat the consensus estimate. JPMorgan's shares surged 4%. The news sparked a rally in the financial sector.Have the banks bottomed out? Is this the beginning of a rally or just a head fake?"There are very few positives today except for the pure valuation," said Mark DeVaul, co-portfolio manager of Touchstone Large Cap Fund (TLCIX)). "JPMorgan's earnings weren't great, but expectations were so low the stock went up."Touchstone Large Cap had nearly 25% of its $302.8 million assets in financial services stocks as of Dec. 31.Of the four other big banks, the fund owns Bank of America (BAC) and Wells Fargo (WFC), but not Citibank (C). He said both Bank of America and Wells look cheap compared to their long-term history."The near-term environment is terrible, but it's hard to imagine it getting worse," said DeVaul. "If you buy banks when there is a lot of near-term negativity, that provides strong downside protection, especially if they have strong balance sheets."It's very interesting that the failure of the big banks to pass the regulators' "living wills" test had no effect on the rally, said Paul DeSisto, senior portfolio manager at M&R Capital Management a New York-based registered investment advisor.

DeSisto said the continuation of a rally depends oil prices increasing, the Federal Reserve raising interest rates, and weaker wage increases, but all this is unlikely in an election year."I expect the rally to be short-lived," said DeSisto. "But I see limited downside. Patient investors who buy now and hold until after the election, may be well rewarded."The banks haven't bottomed out," countered Sid Jain, president of AAAUM, an investment advisor in Hoboken, N.J. Jain worries about the Fed pushing interest rates negative like Europe and Japan. He said there's a 15% chance of it happening. But if it does, it will shock the stock market.

JPMorgan Chase’s (JPM) first-quarter earnings Wednesday pointed to the resilience of the U.S. consumer and economy amid recent stock market turmoil.Kicking off big banks' earnings season, the New York-based lender's Q1 earnings fell 7% to $1.35 a share, beating consensus estimates by 9 cents. Revenue slipped 3% to $24.1 billion, above forecasts of $23.4 billion.But while the top and bottom lines declined, net income at JPMorgan's consumer and community banking division rose 12% to $2.5 billion. Net revenue grew 4% to $11.1 billion.Shares jumped 4.2% and lifted stocks of other bank giants. Bank of America (BAC) and Wells Fargo (WFC), which report results Thursday, added 3.9% and 2.6% respectively. Citigroup (C), which reports Friday, surged 5.6%. Investment banking heavyweight Morgan Stanley (MS) popped 5.3% and rival Goldman Sachs (GS) added 3.6%.JPMorgan's lending during the January-to-March period surged 11% to $847.3 billion, powered by strength in auto loans, credit cards and commercial lending. Excluding credit cards, consumer loans gained 16%, suggesting that the consumer's appetite for spending and borrowing was undeterred by a tumultuous equities markets."Total loan growth was unbelievably strong," said Erik Oja, an equity analyst at S&P Global Market Intelligence. "That bodes well for global banks."Q1 usually is banks' strongest in terms of trading, but the horrific start to the year for stocks had Wall Street bracing for a disastrous quarter. In February, JPMorgan warned of a 20% plunge in trading revenue.But on Wednesday, the bank said fixed-income trading revenue notched a 13% drop, thanks to trading stabilizing in March.Still, there is room for caution as stocks have experienced two sharp downturns over the last 12 months. If the trading environment stabilizes, as JPMorgan has indicated, banks should do well enough through the remainder of 2016, analysts said. And the bank overall looks to continue building on its gains."They’re still serving clients. They’re still growing loans. They’re still doing well in a number of segments," said Shannon Stemm, an equity analyst at Edward Jones.The Federal Reserve's decision last December to boost interest rates for the first time since 2006 also helped. JPMorgan's net interest income rose 1% to $11.7 billion, mostly driven by strong loan growth and the impact of higher interest rates on cash. Reported expenses fell 3% and head count declined 2% to 237,420 employees.On the downside, the bank nearly doubled its loan loss reserve to $1.8 billion, including $529 million for nonperforming energy loans and $162 million in mining and metal loans.Compared to other big banks such as Bank of America and Wells Fargo, JPMorgan is more exposed to those sectors. Though crude oil has rallied to $41 per barrel from February's low of $26 per barrel, natural gas, mining and metals remain subdued.Despite the mounting losses, big banks are considered large enough and sufficiently diversified to endure the energy bust.Meanwhile, regulators at the FDIC and the Fed ordered JPMorgan, BofA, Wells Fargo, Bank of New York Mellon (BK) and State Street (STT) to make significant changes to their "living wills," or their detailed bankruptcy plans required under the Dodd-Frank Act.For now, the regulators' findings are expected to be a speed bump and not much more."We expect all these firms to aggressively address their short comings," wrote Jason Goldberg, a Barclays analyst, in a Wednesday note. "We do not expect material changes to operations or costs."

JPMorgan Chase (JPM) reported first-quarter earnings Wednesday morning that fell less than expected as consumer gains mitigated investment banking trouble. The lifted shares of JPMorgan and rivals such as Wells Fargo (WFC), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C), which all release Q1 results later this week.JPMorgan Chase earned $1.35 a share, down 7% from $1.45 a year earlier and the first decline in five quarters. Revenue fell to $24.08 billion vs. $24.82 billion a year earlier.The largest U.S. bank was expected to report Q1 earnings per share of $1.26 a share, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue was expected to fall about 5% to $23.4 billion."We delivered solid results this quarter with strong underlying drivers," CEO and Chairman Jamie Dimon said in a statement. "The consumer businesses continue to grow loans and deposits impressively, attracting deposits faster than the industry. The U.S. consumer remains healthy and consumer credit trends are favorable."The bank's consumer and community banking division reported a 12% rise in net income and 4% gain in revenue.JPMorgan shares rose 4.2% on the stock market today to a 3-month high.JPMorgan nearly doubled loan loss reserves to $1.8 billion from $959 million a year earlier. That included $529 million for energy loans and $162 million in metal and mining loans. It February the bank said  that it planned to boost reserves for potential loan losses by $500 million for energy companies and $100 million for mining and metals.Wells Fargo, Bank of America and Citigroup all have large outstanding loans, though most analysts have said banking giants have plenty of capital to absorb energy-related loan losses. Banks also have been cutting credit lines to oil and gas exploration and production companies to limit exposure, though that could create hardship in the oil patch.JPMorgan also said banking revenue fell 19%, with investment banking revenue down 24%. The bank had said previously that investment-banking fee revenue was likely to fall 25%, with trading revenue off 20%.But fixed-income trading revenue ended up down just 13% in Q1. JPMorgan said that trading stabilized in March and so far this month.Citigroup has said trading revenue would likely fall 15%.Separately, the Federal Reserve and FDIC said that JPMorgan, Wells Fargo, BofA, Bank of New York Mellon (BK) and State Street (STT) must make significant changes to their "living wills." Major banks were required to submit detailed bankruptcy plans as part of the 2010 Dodd-Frank financial reform. Meanwhile, the Fed on its own said that Goldman Sachs' (GS) living will fell short, while the FDIC on its own did not favor Morgan Stanley (MS). Citigroup did pass, despite "shortcomings."Bank of America stock popped 3.9%, Wells Fargo 2.6% and Citigroup 5.6%. Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley, which report earnings early next week, climbed 3.6% and 5.3%, respectively.

Early gains for the stock market faded badly Monday as jitters over first-quarter earnings season trumped a day of outperformance for material and financial stocks. For the seventh time in nine sessions, major averages closed near session lows. The Nasdaq erased a 1% intraday gain Monday, falling 0.4%. The S&P 500 dropped 0.3%, and the Dow industrials eased 0.1%. The…

The stock market rallied nicely at the open Wednesday as overseas factors, earnings reports and economic data all influenced early trade.The Nasdaq led the way, rising 0.9%. The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 picked up 0.7% each.The stock market today benefited from a positive mood started in Asia. China's March exports surged 12% from a a year ago, the first rise in eight months, according to the General Administration of Customs. Imports declined less than 8%, vs. a 14% drop in February. The export improvement was partially due to a sharp drop in exports in March 2015. Strong exports were also helped by a weaker yuan.Hong Kong's Hang Seng index responded with a 3.2% gain. The Shanghai Composite climbed 1.4%. In Japan, the yen continued lower against the dollar, helping send the Nikkei 225 ahead 2.8%.The positive tone carried over into Europe, where markets pushed strong gains in afternoon trade. The CAC 40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX traded up more than 2% each. London's FTSE 100 showed a 1.4% gain.The overseas momentum helped compensate for the drag caused by oil and gold, both of which traded briskly lower. West Texas Intermediate traded down 1%, but held firmly above $41 a barrel. Gold futures were off nearly 1% to $1,250 an ounce.In U.S. economic news, inflation received a tame report card, as producer prices eased 0.1% in March, the Labor Department estimated, well below the 0.3% increase expected by consensus forecasts. Declines in cost of services apparently offset rebounding energy prices. Core prices, minus energy and food, also dipped 0.1%, vs. forecasts for a 0.2% increase.Retail sales also dropped in March, down 0.3%, Commerce Department data showed. Consensus expectations called for a 0.1% increase. Minus automobiles, sales rose 0.2% -- below the consensus estimate for a 0.4% gain.The Census Bureau offers up February business inventories data at 10 a.m. ET, followed by the Energy Information Administration's weekly oil inventories report at 10:30. The Federal Reserve's beige book report is due out at 2 p.m.JPMorgan (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS) paced the Dow in the early going, rising 3% each.JPMorgan outperformed after its Q1 report showed earnings and revenue falling less than anticipated. JPMorgan's Q1 results showed consumer and community banking growing net income 12% on a 4% rise in revenue. Investment banking revenue dropped 24%.Other banks tapped into the momentum. Bank of America (BAC), Wells Fargo (WFC) and PNC Financial Services (PNC) -- all scheduled to report results on Thursday -- rose 2% apiece. Overseas banks were also in serious motion: Germany's Deutsche Bank (DB) leapt 6%, London-based HSBC Holdings (HSBC) swung up 5%. Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS), Lloyd's Banking Group (LYG) and UBS Group (UBS) all climbed 3%.Among other companies reporting quarterly results, Adtran (ADTN) jumped 4% after a positive report late Tuesday. Railroad CSX (CSX) rose 1%, as revenue missed and earnings just met analyst consensus estimates, but management reported firmer pricing and rising volumes in automotive and other segments.Beyond earnings, biotech drug maker Medivation (MDVN) sparked up 8% after Bloomberg reported the company had snubbed a buyout offer from French drug giant Sanofi (SNY). Shares of Sanofi added 0.6%.China's Baidu (BIDU) and JD.Com (JD) led the Nasdaq 100, up 3% and 4% respecitively. S&P 500 name Harley Davidson (HOG) rebounded 3.5%. The stock tanked 14% last week on a string of critical analyst notes.Early IBD 50 leaders included Facebook (FB). Shares added more than 1%. The social networking heavy found quiet support at its 50-day line on Tuesday, ending 6% below a 117.09 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.Coffee chain Starbucks (SBUX) added 2% after Tuesday's gap down in heavy trade. The stock managed to find support at the converged 50- and 200-day moving averages. That is a positive, but shares have been unable to rise clear of those lines of support as they've climbed the right side of a shallow six-month consolidation.

Even as Wells Fargo (WFC) CEO John Stumpf faced a grilling from the Senate on Tuesday about employees' alleged sales misconduct -- along with questions on Twitter (TWTR) about his bandaged right hand -- analysts appeared to remain bullish on the bank in the longer term, even if profits suffer through next year and regulations tighten."Yes, we could see more volatility ahead as headline risk persists, but Wells is rarely this inexpensive," Morgan Stanley analyst Betsy Graseck said of Wells Fargo's shares in a note on Tuesday upgrading the stock.Morgan Stanley upgraded Wells Fargo stock to overweight from equal-weight but cut its price target to 53 from 56.That stock, which finished up 1.2% in the stock market today, has tumbled this month after Wells Fargo agreed to pay a $185 million fine to regulators following accusations that its employees created up to 2 million unauthorized consumer accounts to jolt sales figures and hit sales targets.Wells fired 5,300 workers in connection with the matter, and the bank reportedly faces a Justice Department investigation.Still, the scrutiny of the bank's sales practices was unlikely to threaten Wells' dividend, Graseck wrote."WFC has received no objection from the Fed on its 2016 (capital plan), and the recent $185M fine had no material impact on EPS (<1%)," she said.Morgan Stanley said the fallout should cost Wells Fargo 4 cents, or 1%, worth of full-year estimated earnings per share in 2016. Morgan Stanley also cut its 2017 EPS target by 3% to $4.10 because of the situation."Additional fines are likely to be limited as Wells booked very little revenue from the opening of unauthorized accounts ($2.5-5.0M in total), hired a 3rd party to review its entire system, paid a fine that was more than 30x the revenues generated, and is changing its compensation system for its consumer bankers."But growth in credit-card fees and deposit service charges was likely to slow as the company does away with sales goals and adjusts incentives, she said.Stumpf on Tuesday told the Senate Banking Committee that he was "deeply sorry that we failed to fulfill on our responsibility to our customers, to our team members, and to the American public.""Wrongful sales practice behavior in our retail banking business goes against everything regarding our core principals, our ethics and our culture," he said.He said the bank "never directed, nor wanted our team members to provide products and services to customers that they did not want." Stumpf said management first learned of the fake accounts in 2013, and said they should have taken care of the matter earlier.Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., was not impressed."You should resign, you should give back the money that you took while this scam was going on, and you should be criminally investigated by both the Department of Justice and the Securities and Exchange Commission," she said.Earlier, Warren questioned Stumpf about the company's cross-selling practices -- or getting customers to use more of the bank's products. Stumpf, before Warren cut him off, said that cross-selling was "shorthand for deepening relationships."Holding up a thick stack of papers, Warren then offered select quotes from what she said were transcripts of 12 quarterly earnings calls from 2012 to 2014 in which management touted record cross-selling in Wells' retail banking segment. The sales tactics in question allegedly date back to 2011.Analysts at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in a research note last week said they believe Wells Fargo shares were "nearing a bottom of the relative underperformance" and that they were trading at a discount."Based on past incidences at high-quality banks, the overhang on valuation from scandals can last 3 to 10 months based on the severity of the negative actions," analyst Brian Kleinhanzl wrote in a research note dated Sept. 15."We would characterize Wells Fargo as being on the low-end of the severity in terms of potential losses," he continued, "but the company would be near the high end for reputational damage given management's position that they are not a Wall Street bank so improper activity is less expected."KBW also noted that Wells' cross-selling scandal, for now, had cost the bank some 0.07% of its overall market-cap value. That was far less than JPMorgan Chase's (JPM) "London Whale" derivative debacle, the losses UBS (UBS) suffered after its "rogue trader" scandal, Barclays' (BCS) LIBOR-rigging scandal or Volkswagen's (VLKAY) emissions-cheating, the firm said.IBD's TAKE: As Wells Fargo becomes the latest bank in recent years to face a financial scandal, other bank stocks have traded more tightly as Wall Street speculates whether the Federal Reserve will decide to hike rates this year. See more detail about which bank stocks might be in buy range. KBW analyst Brian Gardner, in a separate note, said the cross-selling scandal would affect the banking industry into next year. He added that the incident could kill congressional efforts to modify the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau's powers, raise the probability that lawmakers will try to break up the biggest banks, and affect executive compensation."At some point we would expect Wells' CEO to fall on the sword by forgoing compensation and trying to clawback compensation where possible," Kleinhanzl wrote in his note last week. "To us, that seems a path that is most palatable to investors."Shares of JPMorgan edged up 0.4%, while UBS dipped 0.9%. Bank of America (BAC) added less than 0.1%, and Citigroup (C) eased 0.1%. Goldman Sachs (GS) climbed 0.2%, and Morgan Stanley (MS) rallied 0.3%.RELATED:Where Do Millennials Bank? JPMorgan Says It Beats BofA, Wells FargoBank Of America Gains Share Globally, Vows Blockchain EmbraceCitigroup, Like BofA, Sets Sights Abroad, But Q3 View Mixed

Loading the player... Here's your Tuesday Investing Action Plan: what you need to know as an investor for the day ahead. Adobe Systems (ADBE) reports earnings on Tuesday, with the stock trying to regain a buy point. Also on tap with earnings: KB Home (KBH) and Lennar (LEN) and FedEx (FDX). Netflix (NFLX) and CBS (CBS) will present at Goldman Sachs' Communacopia…

Traders bracing for a heated U.S. presidential debate tonight had another element to contend with — a sell-off in global banks.Equities wiped out their monthly advance as Deutsche Bank (DB) tumbled to a record low on speculation that Germany's largest lender would need to raise capital. Treasury yields declined toward the lowest level in almost three weeks, while the yen led gains among its Group-of-10 peers. Emerging-market shares slumped after Turkey's credit rating was cut to junk by Moody's Investors Service. Oil surged as Saudi Arabia's offer to cut output opened the door to a future OPEC deal.Investors piled into safer assets as Deutsche Bank's plunge spurred a rout in global financial companies on concern the lender is struggling with tougher capital standards, negative interest rates and soaring legal bills. Havens were also in demand as traders awaited the first of three U.S. presidential debates ahead of the Nov. 8 election and a Bloomberg poll showed Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton deadlocked. Citigroup, which last month said that a Republican victory could lead to equity declines, warned Monday that such an event could cause heightened volatility in both gold and currency markets."There's a fear factor in the market that's very sizable and it's in the market overseas," Dan Fuss, vice chairman of Loomis Sayles in Boston, said in an interview with Bloomberg Television. "It's people hedging as to what on God's earth is going to come out of this U.S. election. That's the concern."Tonight's event at Hofstra University in New York starts at 9 p.m. local time and will mark the first time that voters see the major-party nominees on the same stage. The Republican and Democratic nominees each get 46% of likely voters in a head-to-head contest in the latest Bloomberg Politics national poll, while Trump gets 43% to Clinton's 41% when third-party candidates are included.The MSCI All-Country World index fell 1% at 4 p.m. in New York, heading toward a 0.1% decline in September. The Stoxx Europe 600 index dropped 1.6%, its biggest slide since early July, while the S&P 500 index slipped 0.8% to 2,146.42.JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and Wells Fargo (WFC) led losses in U.S. financial shares, while Deutsche Bank sank 7.5%. Chancellor Angela Merkel's government sees "no grounds" for speculation over state funding for the lender, her chief spokesman said, pushing back against a magazine report that the German leader has ruled out any such aid."The negative implications of what's happening at Deutsche Bank are weighing on sentiment," said Michael James, managing director of equity trading at Wedbush Securities in Los Angeles.A measure of emerging-market stocks slumped 1.4% as Turkish shares led losses among the world's biggest equity markets.Yields on 10-year Treasuries fell three basis points, or 0.03 percentage point, to 1.58%, according to Bloomberg Bond Trader data."U.S. politics are moving right to center stage," said Rene Albrecht, a rates and derivatives analyst at DZ Bank in Frankfurt. "There are rising uncertainties about the effects of the election results. And when you got uncertainty, you better rotate out of stocks and into safe havens."German 10-year bund yields fell four basis points to minus 0.12%, extending a drop of nine basis points from last week. The yield on Italian 10-year bonds retreated three basis points to 1.18%, while the yield for similar maturity Spanish debt slid five basis points to 0.9%.Mario Draghi said euro-area governments must act to stem rising public discontent, in his latest warning to politicians that the European Central Bank can't sustain the region's recovery alone. The central bank's program to buy 80 billion euros ($90 billion) a month of debt faces scarcity concerns and its negative interest rates have prompted criticism by banks and savers."Low rates are a symptom of the underlying economic situation," Draghi said. "Other policy actors need to do their part, pursuing fiscal and structural policies which will contribute to a self-sustaining recovery and increase the economic growth potential of the euro area."

Since 2015, Wells Fargo (WFC), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), U.S. Bancorp (USB) and other large financial institutions have been exiting the health savings account (HSA) business. But Utah-based HealthEquity (HQY), one of the nation's largest HSA administrators, continues to expand. Health savings accounts help people manage and lower their health insurance costs by making tax-free contributions into an account that can…

Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) saw second-quarter net earnings rise 25% to $5 billion, or about $2.03 per Class B share, a penny above estimates.The conglomerate late Friday said revenue grew 6% to $54.46 billion, though total revenue was lighter than analyst consensus for $56.44 billion. Revenue from Berkshire's flagship insurance businesses climbed 9.9% to $43.59 billion."Our insurance underwriting operations generated increased net earnings in the second quarter and first six months of 2016 compared to 2015," management said in a regulatory filing.That reflected foreign-exchange rate fluctuation for Berkshire's reinsurance activities overseas, as well as an increase in underwriting gains for its Geico business, partly offset by lower gains from General Re and Berkshire Hathaway Primary Group operations.Berkshire saw a 10.3% drop in its Burlington Northern Santa Fe railroad revenue to $8.85 billion, down from $9.87 billion in the second quarter of 2015, as railroads continue to be slammed by lower shipments of petroleum, coal and other products.IBD'S TAKE: While Berkshire Hathaway and other large diversified manufacturers have generally reported middling results, smaller rivals have outperformed the market. To find out which companies in the group are the highest rated, go to the IBD Stock Checkup.Berkshire earlier in the year made a roughly $1 billion investment in Apple (AAPL) at a time when sales of its iPhone seemed to be slowing. However, in its July 26 earnings report, Apple reported stronger-than-expected iPhone sales, driving its stock up nearly 7% on July 27. Other core Berkshire holdings include Coca-Cola (KO), Wells Fargo (WFC) and oil and gas refiner Phillips 66 (PSX).But Berkshire's investment in Kraft Heinz (KHC) fell to $15.75 billion as of June 30 from $23.42 billion on Dec. 31, the company said in its 10-Q statement. Since the beginning of the year, Berkshire's total shareholders' equity has increased $7.5 billion.Berkshire's Class B shares dipped 0.1% to 145.56 in the stock market today. Its stock dropped to a 2016 low of 123.55 on Feb. 3, in sync with the early-year market pullback, and then turned up. It's risen 19% since then and was trading above both its 10-week average and its 200-day line.Apple rose 0.8% to 108.37. Kraft Heinz fell 4 cents to 88.75 after climbing 3.8% Friday on strong earnings.

Deutsche Bank (DB) won't be profitable this year, its co-chief executive said at a London conference, and even warned that the German bank may suffer a "small loss" in 2016."We’ve said this year is not going to be a profitable year, we may make a small profit, we may make a small loss, we don’t know," co-CEO John Cryan said at the conference, according to Bloomberg.Under Cryan's leadership, Deutsche Bank has axed thousands of positions, eliminated its dividend for last year and this year, and has sold off assets. And they've been hurt by penalties such as the $2.5 billion settlement it agreed to pay over rate-rigging and the $258 million settlement it paid to U.S. regulators for doing business with sanctioned nations such as Iran, Syria and Libya.Last year, Deutsche Bank reported an annual loss of $7 billion, its first annual loss since 2008.The bank's U.S. shares closed down 4.2% on the stock market today.But Deutsche Bank's problems apparently didn't weigh on stocks of big U.S. banks as they experienced an upsurge in buying early Wednesday. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) dipped 0.5%, Wells Fargo (WFC) lost 0.9% and Bank of America (BAC) fell 1.9%.Among top European banks, Barclays (BCS) rose 0.6% and Banco Santander (SAN) fell 1%. HSBC (HSBC), Europe's largest bank, rose 0.7%.Credit Suisse (CS) shares fell 4.4% after lawyers for Georgia's former prime minister, Bidzina Ivanishvili, filed a legal complaint in Switzerland related to money laundering allegations, Reuters reported.Meanwhile, fellow Switzerland-based banking giant UBS (UBS) plans to cut about 300 of its European investment banking jobs in the coming weeks, Reuters reported. UBS shares dropped 4.6%.Market volatility has hurt banks so far this year, with JPMorgan and Bank of America cutting investment banking jobs in recent months. In January, Barclays said it would cut about 1,000 investment banking jobs.

Shares of big banks all fell in response to the Federal Reserve slashing projections for future interest rate hikes, as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC), Wells Fargo (WFC), Citigroup (C) and Goldman Sachs (GS) all finished lower Wednesday.In December, the central bank raised a key interest rate to 0.25%-0.5%, the first increase since 2006, and Fed officials such as Chair Janet Yellen talked about four rate hikes this year. On Wednesday, not only did the Fed pass on another rate hike, but implied just two quarter-point hikes to the federal funds rate this year.Markets still only see 1 rate hike in 2016, with the timing pushed back from June to September.The muted expectations are the result of a struggling global economy, a battered energy sector and stock market turmoil to start the year. Though the markets generally cheered the news, banks did not. JPMorgan shares fell 0.5% to 58.92 on the stock market today. Wells Fargo and Citigroup each tumbled 0.9%, Bank of America fell 1.9%,  U.S. Bancorp (USB) 0.6% and Goldman 1%.Bank of America fell back below its 50-day moving average after retaking that line last Friday. But JPMorgan, Wells, Citi and U.S. Bancorp held above that support level. Goldman found resistance just below the  50-day line.The lower-for-longer interest rate environment has cut into banks' net interest margins, a key measure of their profitability. It gauges the difference between what banks earn from interest paid to them from loans versus the interest banks pay out to depositors. The longer interest rates remain low, the more net interest margins get squeezed and the less profitable banks become.Coupled with squeezed margins is the lousy start to the year for banks' trading revenue. JPMorgan forecast a 20% drop in trading revenue in Q1. Citigroup said its trading revenue will drop 25% this quarter.Adding to the bad news are the nonperforming loans to energy companies, hurt badly by the collapse of crude oil prices since June 2014. JPMorgan boosted its Q1 energy loan loss reserves to $1.5 billion while Wells Fargo set aside $1.2 billion for potential losses in its energy loan portfolio. Morgan Stanley says 40% of its hefty energy loan portfolio are junk rated.Layoffs at Citigroup, JPMorgan, Bank of America, Morgan Stanley (MS) have hurt too.

Total mortgage applications rose a meager 0.2% as purchase applications and refinancings moved in opposite directions, the Mortgage Bankers Association said.The purchase index rose 4.2% for the week ended March 4 and notched a 30% gain compared to the same period a year earlier. Demand for refinancing fell 2.3% last week, following losses of 7% or more in each of the prior two weeks, but they remained 13% higher than a year earlier.The average interest rate for 30-year conforming loans ($417,000 or less) climbed six basis points to 3.89%.Since the Federal Reserve raised its target federal funds rate in December, additional interest rate hikes in the short term are no longer considered likely. Central banks in Sweden and Japan have got into negative rate territory -- as has the European Central Bank, which is expected to cut its negative rate further on Thursday.Shares of Wells Fargo (WFC), a major mortgage lender, fell 0.5% on the stock market today. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Bank of America (BAC) climbed 0.6%. Wells Fargo and and JPMorgan rose above their 50-day moving averages intraday, but Wells fell back below that level. Bank of America is tracking slightly below that downward-sloping line. All three are still down sharply in 2016 and well of their July peaks.As for homebuilders, D.R. Horton (DHI) rose 1.3%, and LGI Homes (LGIH) shot up 9.7%.D.R. Horton found resistance at its 200-day line late last week and is trying to stay above its 50-day average.LGI Homes on Wednesday reported that quarterly earnings more than doubled, topping views. Shares, which had tumbled last Friday to the 50-day line, briefly reclaimed their 200-day average intraday.

Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) CEO Warren Buffett's bet with a hedge fund may show that all you need is the pastoral eminence known as the S&P 500 -- rather than the fancy approach such funds use to beat the market.Buffett's 10-year bet that the Vanguard 500 Index Fund Admiral Shares (VFIAX), an S&P 500 index fund, could outperform five funds of hedge funds selected by Protege Partners appears to be paying off, says Fortune, which has followed the bet since first reporting on it in 2008.Protege's five funds of hedge funds rose 1.7% on average last year, in contrast to the 1.36% gain that the Vanguard fund brought in. However, Fortune notes, the Vanguard fund has gained 65.67% over the bet's first eight years, which include 2015, compared to 21.87% on average for the Protege funds of funds.Berkshire Hathaway's class B shares closed down 0.4% in the stock market today and are up 5% so far this year. The S&P 500 is down about 2.9% for 2016.The Berkshire Hathaway chief's hunch appears to be backed by S&P Dow Jones Indices, which said Wednesday that most small-, mid- and large-cap managers have been underperforming S&P indexes.Last year, 66.11% of large-cap managers, 56.81% of midcap managers and 72.2% of small-cap managers underperformed the S&P 500, the S&P MidCap 400 and the S&P SmallCap 600, respectively.Over five years, 84.15% of large-cap managers, 76.69% of midcap managers and 90.13% of small-cap managers lagged their respective benchmarks. And over 10 years, 82.14% of large-cap managers, 87.61% of midcap managers and 88.42% of small-cap managers failed to outperform.But if Warren Buffett is so smart, why not just invest like the legendary "Sage of Omaha"?Berkshire Hathaway's top stock holdings include American Express (AXP), Coca-Cola (KO), IBM (IBM) and Wells Fargo (WFC), and he has built up his position in Phillips 66 (PSX) in recent months.Many investors do try to mimic Berkshire Hathaway's investments, but Buffett thinks that's a bad idea.“I wouldn’t ever urge them to do anything based on what we do. If they want to do what Berkshire does, then they should buy Berkshire,” Buffett told CNBC last month. “I think they’re making a big mistake by piggybacking me or 10 other people whose names appear in the paper.”

The rough start to the year for banks, with subpar fourth-quarter earnings and a continuously tough revenue environment, could make mergers among regional, midtier and small banks more likely, Fitch Ratings said.Large regional banks have outperformed their smaller peers, but returns remain lackluster, still below pre-crisis levels, Fitch said in a statement. Regulatory and compliance costs, continuously low interest rates and the need to invest in new technology will continue to weigh on banks' earnings in the near future.Shareholder pressure for better returns may lead to more mergers, though depressed stock prices may prevent some deals going ahead, the ratings agency said. The average return on equity across the banking industry during the fourth quarter of 2015 was 9%, compared with nearly 13% during the first quarter of 2006.Banks generally underwhelmed in the fourth quarter and things aren't expected to get much better during this quarter. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) already has warned that it expects trading revenue to tumble 20% this quarter as stocks were pummeled by a horrible start to the year.JPMorgan, Wells Fargo (WFC), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) have given serious boosts to their energy loan-loss reserves as low oil prices have boosted the numbers of nonperforming loans in the energy sector. JPMorgan alone has boosted its loan-loss reserves to $1.5 billion in the first quarter.Also, near-zero interest rates and the unlikelihood of the Federal Reserve to immediately boost them further is cutting into banks' net interest margins, a key gauge of profitability that measures the difference between what they charge in loans and what they pay out to depositors."We do not think interest rate hikes will provide much uplift to overall bank earnings in 2016 as the operating environment remains challenging," Fitch noted. "M&A could lead to cost savings, which could support earnings."But given the political pressure on big banks, it's unlikely they'll be candidates for mergers and acquisitions. Bank mergers last quarter included Cleveland-based KeyCorp (KEY) agreeing to purchase Buffalo, N.Y.-based First Niagara Financial Group (FNFG) for $4.1 billion, and New York Community Bancorp  (NYCB) agreeing to buy Astoria Financial (AF) for $2 billion.

Banking giants such as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and Wells Fargo (WFC) are expected to report poor earnings this week as market turmoil hits investment banking and trading. But investors may pay more attention to banks' massive loans to now-embattled energy companies.Even though oil prices have rebounded from early 2016 lows, cash-flow woes persist for many shale companies that bet big when crude was trading at $100 a barrel. JPMorgan, Wells Fargo and several other banks already have set aside more funds for potential energy-loan losses. A key question is how much they will raise loan loss provisions now.Fitch Ratings, in an analysis released Tuesday, said that the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) will classify many high-yield loans to oil and gas exploration and production companies as Criticized -- specifically, as Substandard, Doubtful or Loss.Justin Fuller, Fitch's senior director of financial institutions, said that the troubles could worsen if nonbank lenders step in and buy Criticized loans, in which case "banks may see losses crystallize, given the low bid prices on some loans and uncertainty around oil prices."Meanwhile, banks continue to set aside billions in reserves to cover losses related to bad energy loans, Barclays said."The noise surrounding energy-related provisions trends in 1Q '16 reached deafening levels across the banking industry when JPM announced at its Investor Day on February 23 that it planned to add about $500 million to its oil & gas related reserve in 1Q '16," bringing its total up to about $1.3 billion, Barclays said in an April 1 report.JPMorgan's late February announcement that it would hike energy loan loss reserves was followed by Comerica (CMA), which disclosed in a regulatory filing that if current conditions persist, an estimated additional provision of $75 million to $125 million could result.Morgan Stanley (MS) on Feb. 23 said in an SEC filing that it has $15.9 billion in energy-related loans outstanding. Morgan Stanley added that 60% of the loans are investment grade, implying that 40% were junk-rated. Morgan Stanley reports earnings on April 18.Wells Fargo, which reports earnings Thursday, set aside $1.2 billion for energy-loan losses in Q4. It has $17.4 billion in energy loans, with $24 billion in untapped credit lines.Bank of America has about $21 billion in energy-related loans and about the same amount in credit lines yet to be drawn down. Bank of America also reports earnings Thursday.Citigroup (C) also has $21 billion in energy loans and $37 billion in credit lines yet to be tapped. Citigroup reports earnings on Friday.JPMorgan reports first-quarter earnings on Wednesday. JPMorgan shares closed up 1.85% on the stock market today, retaking its 50-day moving average. The stock fell to a 52.50 low on Feb. 11 before turning up, but it is still below its 200-day average.Wells Fargo stock rose 1.6%, Morgan Stanley 1.95%, Citigroup 1.9% and Bank of America 2.3%. All are below their 200-day lines.Fitch said that many energy companies with high levels of cash-flow and balance-sheet leverage are at risk of default. "Classified risk ratings from the OCC could amplify the pain that many leverage E&P borrowers are already feeling," Fitch Senior Director of Leveraged Finance Sharon Bonelli said in the report."However," Fitch offered in a positive caveat, "most large banks have manageable exposure to energy loans, averaging just 23% of tangible common equity in Fitch's portfolio."

It is POST TIME! That time defined as the 'specific time' when the race begins.....when all participants need to be locked and loaded in the narrow gates awaiting the starters call......Yes folks - its RACE day or rather RACE month....when the CEO's & CFO's must confess the financial condition of publicly traded companies....and on each race day - the grooms - in this case the IR guy/gal leads the 'horse' to the 'saddling paddock'. The identifier checks the horse's identity (listed company) to make sure that the results correspond with the proper 'horse'. Then the horse is saddled up and the jockeys (usually the CFO) are given instructions on how to proceed. The jockey adorned in the 'silks' of the horse's owner ( in this case the CEO) are given instructions on how to proceed and together the jockey and the owner take their places....And they are OFF!Last night - post close - we got the first taste of what is expected to be a tough race.....Alcoa (AA) comes out of the gate stumbling....1Q earnings of .07 cts/sh were down 92%, Yes - earnings BEAT the estimate but top line revenues missed big time......coming in at $4.95 bil vs. the expectation of $5.20 bil....... Klaus Kleinfeld (CEO) discussed weak aluminum prices (down 40% over the last 5 yrs) and the state of the global economy.....2000 jobs are on the line because of weak mkts around the world......The stock fell 4% in after hours trading and is currently trading at $9.34 down 0.40 cts off of last night's close....'and so it was written' the season has begun.....'Stocks popped at the open but the rally was short-lived....stocks failed to sustain the early upside spike and stocks turned lower...sellers dominating the day and selling into the rally. The pullback attributed to the beginning of what is predicted to be a disappointing earnings season.What also added to the sour mood was the double secret meeting between Yellen and the Fed governors. Following this surprise expedited meeting, Janet Yellen met with President Obama to discuss the state of the economy. Now just an FYI - this was the first time since November 2014 that the sitting Fed chair has met one on one with the president....and the media was not invited...so what did they discuss? Rate hike - nah, GDP - maybe, the real unemployment rate? Doubtful - as Obama thinks it's all a bed of roses.....How about the state of the banking industry and how the global contraction has affected the industry....How about the quality of assets, how about margin compression and growth prospects in this less than stellar environment....... especially after two central banks - the ECB and the BoJ initiated negative interest rates. Oh boy.....so much to say....Now as discussed - we are expecting earnings to be down y/y - and as of the end of March - that number has been 'adjusted' to -8.5%....(slight improvement...) Energy, financials and industrials to take the brunt of the blame...... this will be the 4th straight qtr of EPS (Earnings per share) declines....but do not be concerned.....because as usual - expect to see 70% of those earnings 'beat the estimates' - but like Alcoa - will they beat due to cost cutting or will they actually GROW top line revenues? The jury is still out - but my money says - the majority of the 'beats' will come from 'expense management' vs organic growth.....Today we get a bit of a reprieve before the financials line up in the starting gate.....Wednesday - look for JPMorgan Chase (JPM) followed by the usual suspects - Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo (WFC), Goldman Sachs (GS), Morgan Stanley (MS) and Bank Of America (BAC)..... Will weak earnings be discounted? Are we really expecting that 'hockey stick' recovery in the second half of 2016? And if so then this is a gift for the longer term investor...because if this as bad as it gets - then future action can only be UP......unless of course the mkt does not believe it and the guidance is less than stellar.....Now the VIX - is giving us a whole different storyline.....this index (otherwise known as the FEAR Index) - has fallen to a 7 month low.... What its telling us is that the mkts are not concerned about almost anything at the moment and some of the industry's recent surveys confirm this lack of concern.......The American Association of Individual Investors (AAII) reveals that pessimism is at a 5 month low of 32.2% - well below the historical average of 39%. Bank of America's "Bull & Bear" index recently surged to 4.1, up dramatically from the March low of 0.1......,suggesting the most bullish reading in 9 months. So when everyone is so bullish - what's left??? But buyer beware....this can change in a heartbeat - as any number of things could cause a change in psychology....or sentiment.Yes - it's all nice when everyone plays nice on the jungle gym....but as soon as we get something unexpected then we could see a rather swift and painful sell off...Remember - as I have pointed out - the next two months is traditionally weak and with the US in the middle of a nasty presidential election cycle - so much can happen that will change the direction of the conversation.Risk remains high.....FED policy is uncertain and if the FED is forced to raise rates too quickly - then prepare for the massacre, Europe's economy is on the edge, China is slowing, a Yuan devaluation is NOT out of the question, negative interest rates causing concern around the globe, and continued currency wars and the geopolitical risks of terrorism, war and immigration could easily ignite mkt volatility and are only a few of the risks that exist.US futures are higher by 5pts this morning - no matter what the Alcoa earnings say.....The mkt remains stuck in the 2040/2070 range but feels a bit heavier each day.....a decisive break below 2040 will take us back to support at 2014. Remember - the underlying tone of the mkt is suspect at best......Bank earnings are now the next big thing for investors to watch and mkts to digest.We have 3 FED speeches today....Philly's Patrick Harker at 9 am, San Fran's John Williams at 3 pm, and Richmond's Jeffrey Lacker at 4 pm. Can't wait to hear what prophetic words are on the teleprompter....How will mkts react or have the mkts now decided that all of this FED speak is just noise?Take Good Care

The horrendous start to the first quarter for stocks, coupled with losses in energy and commodities, is expected to kick bank earnings in the teeth as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and others report this week. Plunging oil prices in January and February sent the market into a tailspin, lodging its worst-ever start to the year. Accordingly, a…

The horrendous start to the first quarter for stocks, coupled with losses in energy and commodities, is expected to kick bank earnings in the teeth as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and others report this week.Plunging oil prices in January and February sent the market into a tailspin, lodging its worst-ever start to the year. Accordingly, a weak environment for trading and capital markets is expected to hurt banks. JPMorgan and Citigroup (C) are among the lenders who have issued warnings on trading revenue.JPMorgan, which reports Wednesday, is expected to see its earnings decline 13% to $1.26 a share, according to estimates compiled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue is expected to fall 5.5% from a year earlier to $23.4 billion. The New York-based bank’s shares tumbled 10.3% during the first quarter.In February, the nation's largest bank warned that its trading revenue should decline 20% in the quarter. The drop in trading revenue is expected to be exacerbated by the surge of the Swiss franc in January 2015, resulting in tough year-over-year comparisons. But CEO Jamie Dimon said at the time that improved market conditions in March could help.Dimon himself helped out in February, when he bought $26 million of JPMorgan shares.The bank also boosted its energy loan-loss reserves by $500 million for the quarter, though oil prices have rebounded somewhat since falling below $27 a barrel earlier in the quarter.Bank of America, which reports Thursday, is seen earning 21 cents a share in Q1, down 22% from a year earlier, while its revenue is expected to decline 5.2% to $20.4 billion. The Charlotte, N.C.-based lender’s shares plunged 20% in Q1.Q1 typically is the strongest quarter of the year, but weak trading and investment banking revenue this year "would set up for a tough operating environment through the rest of 2016," according to Jason Goldberg, an analyst at Barclays, in a research note last week.Wells Fargo (WFC), which is also slated to report on Thursday, is expected to earn 97 cents a share, down 6.7%. But revenue is expected to grow a modest 1.6% to $21.6 billion. Its stock slipped 11% in Q1.The San Francisco-based bank focuses more on lending to consumers and businesses. As a result, it isn't quite as exposed to stock market fluctuations as some of its rivals.But Wells Fargo set aside $1.2 billion last quarter for nonperforming energy loans.Also looming overhead is the constant concern over how many times the Federal Reserve will hike interest rates this year. After December's 0.25 percentage-point increase, some Fed officials talked about four hikes in 2016. But the stock market's gyrations, coupled with weak overseas economic growth, has led some to speculate that there will be two rate hikes -- or maybe even none.In a healthy economy, higher interest rates help boost banks' net interest margins, a key measure of profitability. A bank's net interest margin is the difference between the interest it pays out to depositors and the interest it charges borrowers."We want to see higher rates for the right reasons," said Jeffery Harte, an analyst at Sandler O'Neill & Partners. "If the economy is strong enough to handle higher rates, that’s good news for the banks as well."Analysts at Barclays said they're closely watching Wells Fargo's mortgage activity. UBS analysts last month rated Wells Fargo a sell, arguing that its portfolio is tilted toward risky energy and auto loans. Most analysts remain positive on Wells Fargo.Citigroup will earn $1.06 a share, a 30% decline, analysts expect. The revenue forecast is for a tumble of 11% to $17.6 billion. The New York-based bank’s stock fell 19% during Q1. Citi reports Q1 results on Friday.In March, CFO John Gerspach warned that fixed-income trading is expected to fall 15% in Q1 and investment banking revenue is seen declining 25%.Morgan Stanley (MS) and Goldman Sachs (GS) report Q1 results next week. Both investment banks are expected to post year-over-year declines in EPS and revenue.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Stocks closed positive for the 3rd consecutive week – as fresh signs that the US economy is solid - boosted by the supposed strong jobs report that surprised even the most seasoned analyst….the NFP report came in a whopping +242k jobs – or up 27% over street expectations….and at 8:30 am when the headline number hit – futures spiked higher and then sold off back to flat as reality set it….First – what kinds of jobs were they – temporary vs. full, leisure and hospitality or mining and manufacturing. Were they minimum wage jobs or were they more significant? And then – in the end - what did this strong report mean for FED policy?

Omair Sharif - Strategist at SG America's Securities had this to say -"The latest report should dispel notions of an impending recession...it underscores a resilient economy that continues to weather global headwinds..."Underscores a resilient economy???? The report went on to reflect that wages fell from the prior month and hours worked also declined.....Sectors that employ people at higher wages also continued to 'throw them out the door' as weak commodity and energy prices weakened. But this report is likely to cause a split among FED officials.....we have some that are screaming for higher rates while others continue to take the cautious approach keeping their eyes peeled on the effects of financial turmoil on the global economy.Yes - the labor participation rate did go up ever so slightly and the service sector seems to be the place to find a job if you want one....."labor demand is rock solid" .......as Amhearst Pierpoint Chief Economist - Stephen Stanley let us know (rock solid? REALLY?)....and to prove this point we hear from Scott Gittrich - Pres and founder of Toppers Pizza....a Wisconsin based pizza franchise store (24 locations) .....He is looking to employ bakers, delivery men and 'other workers' and he has raised wages - although he does not indicate what those wages are - (Minimum wage in WI is $7.25/hr) and he is still having trouble getting people to work - go figure!. At the same time his is also employing new technology to eliminate workers...to become more 'efficient'......Now that is all well and good - but aren't we better off hearing from some of the S&P 500 companies that continue to 'shed high paying jobs ( by the hundreds) along with all the benefits' as they look to deal with a slowing global economy? I mean it's great to hear from the small business guy in Wisconsin - but does he represent the American dilemma?Employment is a disaster in other sectors - sectors that typically pay much higher wages,...... - Financial Services-because of choking regulation, automation and a weaker global economy- Bank Of America (BAC) is just the latest to join, Goldman Sachs (GS), Flagstar Bancorp, Inc. (FBC), Deutsche Bank (DB)& Wells Fargo (WFC).....Mining - because of weak commodity prices and Manufacturing because of a stronger US dollar...Dallas Snider - 60 yrs old - who has worked at Noranda Aluminum in Missouri for over 29 yrs expects to lose his job and join the other 450 people laid off this year as the company filed for Chapter 11 - and at 60 yrs old - what hope does he have? As he said: "Me? I'm hung out to dry...there really ain't no one that will want to hire me..." (Go see Mr. Gittrich - he is actively looking.....)BUT - the numbers are what they are (and easily manipulated) ....the FED is not looking at the individual devastation taking place - they just look at the data- yet the data does not reveal the truth.As we pointed out early last week –it was the week where all major US equity indexes and oil finally broke above their 50-day moving averages – and this is significant. It speaks to the technical health of the mkt…..and while all of the major indexes have now pierced their initial levels of resistance – they all remain well below their 200 dma's – levels which represent a broad and significant resistance. In fact as I pointed out last week - I thought that the mkt would run into trouble at S&P 2000....as it would encounter enough resistance to send it lower.....and that is exactly what happened on Friday....we teased, we tried to pierce and we failed.This morning - we see Asian, European and US mkts coming under pressure. Over the weekend - we learned that China is now targeting a revised growth rate of 6.5 - 7% as they promise to 'do whatever it takes to achieve this growth. China rallied last night closing up 0.81%, dragging Australia with it....+1.08%, but that news did little to ignite Japan - 1% and Hong Kong - 0.08%.European mkts are all lower....as they await Thursday's ECB announcement....European banks under fire....Barclay's lower after a DB downgrade, and the Italian banks suffering over concern of more non-performing loans at Banco Populare and Intesa Sanpaolo.....the low inflation environment continues to put pressure on global banks as margins get squeezed.... So many of the stocks in the financial services have gotten beaten up, But we are starting to hear lots of chatter on the airwaves about how the sector is 'cheap'.....So pay attention....It could turn right under your nose.....In the US - futures are pointing lower - currently down 8 pts at 1986.....now to find real support you would have to go back to 1950....(probably not happening) as oil is up 1.8% this morning and we are due to hear from FED Vice Chair Fischer and FED Governor Lael Brainard later this afternoon about the state of the US economy....Expect everyone to be listening as the smart algos parse every word they say - looking for a range of definitions to support them - but can these algos' read body language or hear the intonation in their voices? Can they see the 'wink wink' or the sly smile as the speeches go on?A technical measure of the number of stocks above their 50 dma's shows that 80% of stocks are above these levels – a very rare occurrence – and one that signals short term overbought conditions.....The only way to deal with this is for the mkt to back off and churn a bit to catch up with the move.....So I expect the mkt to remain in the 1940/2000 trading range as we move into Thursday's ECB announcement - Any disappointment will give traders a reason to hit the SELL button in Europe - which then may cause some re-pricing here at home. There is no ECO data today nor anything this week that will drive the action...so expect the focus to return to global central bank policy.Take Good Care
