Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) has become much more diversified and thus "much less reliant" on Warren Buffett's stock-market clairvoyance, evolving into a company positioned to outperform the S&P 500 amid economic uncertainty, UBS said Monday in initiating coverage of the investment firm."We believe that the current uncertain economic and market environment plays into the hands of BRK, with its structural advantages of permanent capital, strong cash generation and industry-leading portfolio of businesses," UBS analyst Brian Meredith wrote in the initiation note, which gave Berkshire's A shares (BRKA) a buy rating and a 244,500 price target."This enables BRK to make acquisitions and/or invest in its operating units despite challenging environments, positioning it to grow earnings and book value faster than the S&P 500," Meredith wrote.Berkshire over the years has become more of a diversified conglomerate and less of an insurance and investment firm, UBS said, helping cushion the company against difficulties in the insurance business and minimizing risk associated with Buffett's eventual departure from the company."While Buffett's superior capital allocation skills and market 'clout' would be missed, as long as the culture does not change, we would expect the company to continue to outperform," Meredith said, adding that the market hasn't priced in a significant premium for him as CEO amid the shift to a diversified conglomerate.Berkshire Hathaway’s entry into insurance began with the 1967 purchase of National Indemnity. But over the years, it has diversified through acquisitions, growing into four main areas of operation that oversee such companies as Geico, Duracell and various energy, manufacturing and railroad companies.That diversification has cushioned the company against difficulties in the insurance business and would likely help minimize risk associated with Buffett’s departure from the company, UBS said.Berkshire's A shares closed up 0.8% in the stock market today. The more widely traded B shares also rose 0.8% Monday and have climbed nearly 14% since a Jan. 25 low.UBS' coverage comes as Buffett's stake in Wells Fargo (WFC) nears 10%, an amount that would necessitate a review from the Federal Reserve intended to protect against undue investor influence, Bloomberg reported.Meanwhile, Berkshire Hathaway has also been amassing a large stake in oil refiner Phillips 66 (PSX), possibly foreshadowing a huge acquisition.Wells Fargo dipped 0.4% Monday, while Phillips 66 lost 0.65%. Among Berkshire's other top holdings, Coca-Cola (KO) added 0.5%, while American Express (AXP) eased 0.3%.

At some prominent financial advisory firms, nearly 20% of the advisors have some misconduct in their past. That fact is among the findings in a study of 1.2 million U.S. advisor disclosure statements by researchers from the University of Minnesota Carlson School of Management and the University of Chicago Booth School of Business.Overall, “roughly 7% of advisors have misconduct records,” says the study, “The Market for Financial Adviser Misconduct,” published at the online Social Science Research Network. The study uses information from BrokerCheck, a database of advisors and firms from the federal Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (FINRA).The most common forms of misconduct are unsuitable investments (committed by 21.29% of those who misbehave); misrepresentation or misleading reports, often dealing with account activity (17.7%); and unauthorized activity (15.1%).Some firms tend to avoid misconduct. At Morgan Stanley (MS), only one in every 126 advisors, or 0.79%, has misconduct on his or her record. Other clean firms include Goldman Sachs (GS) (0.88%) and BNP Paribas Securities (1.17%).Other companies are not quite so strict. Nearly one-fifth (19.6%) of the advisors at Oppenheimer & Co. have one or more incidents of misconduct in their past. Other companies with a high proportion of rule breakers include First Allied Securities (17.7%) and Wells Fargo (WFC) Advisors Financial Network (15.3%).Wells Fargo Advisors Financial Network should not be confused with other Wells Fargo organizations; Wells Fargo Securities, for instance, has a low misconduct rate of 1.7%. And Oppenheimer & Co. is not the same organization as Oppenheimer Asset Management, Oppenheimer Capital and similarly named groups.Financial firms are often vigilant in punishing advisors. “Half of financial advisors lose their job after misconduct,” the report on advisors says. “Following misconduct, advisors face longer unemployment spells and move to less reputable firms, with a 10% reduction in compensation.”

The collapse in crude oil prices has slashed the U.S. oil rig count by 75%, but those expecting Texas to suffer an economic meltdown as it did during the 1980s should think again, economists say.First, the bad news. The Dallas Federal Reserve's region, which is more exposed to energy markets, had another bad month. While its general activity index improved slightly to -31.8 in February from -34.6 in January, it remains deep in contraction and at levels not seen since the recession.The production subindex was also up slightly but still negative, while gauges for new orders and employment were at their lowest since 2009.Layoffs in the energy sector began at the blue-collar level and are working their way up to the white-collar level, according to Patrick Jankowski, senior vice president of research at the Greater Houston Partnership.The Texas unemployment rate rose in December to 4.7%, thought it's still below the national average of 4.9%. A 70% plunge in crude oil prices since June 2014 has been a big culprit.Since 2014, Houston-based oilfield services giant Halliburton (HAL) has cut 22,000 employees worldwide, or 25% of its workforce. Rival Schlumberger (SLB), also based in Houston, has laid off 34,000 globally, or 26% of its workforce, since the end of 2014.Energy's problems are also impacting everything from homebuilders to restaurants. During their most recent quarterly earnings reports, KB Home (KBH), PulteGroup (PHM) and Lennar (LEN) each reported weakness for homes in the Houston market.Meanwhile, Olive Garden parent Darden Restaurants (DRI) reported seeing some weakness in its Texas chains, and Polaris Industries (PII), a maker of all-terrain vehicles and motorcycles, also found that oil and gas regions hurt Q4 earnings and predicted continued softness this year.So, while things are grim, it's important to keep some perspective. Texas has a population of more than 26 million people, spread out in 254 counties and living in several dozen metropolitan areas and countless rural communities. While Houston has a significant exposure to oil, major cities such as Dallas-Fort Worth, Austin, San Antonio and El Paso do not."The economic impact varies across the state," said Bud Weinstein, associate director of the Maguire Energy Institute at Southern Methodist University. "The oil-producing regions of the state have been hit the hardest."Texas also has a $16 billion rainy day fund, largely derived from the energy sector, which can cover any shortfalls in state tax revenue caused by the oil bust. Texas also relies less on oil and gas taxes than other energy-heavy peers do.The Lone Star State generates about 9% of its revenue from oil and gas taxes vs. more than 40% for states like Alaska and North Dakota.Texas is better suited to withstand sustained low prices than it was during the 1980s, when the bottom fell out of the oil market. With help from the rise of technology, health and other industries, the Texas economy is more diverse.Oil and gas represents about 14% of the state's economy vs. more than 20% in the 1980s, Comptroller Glenn Hegar told lawmakers last month.The Dallas-Fort Worth area, a laggard during the economic recovery after the recession, currently has thriving business services and technology sectors. Its tax incentives, major international airport, and affordable housing costs have attracted companies seeking to relocate their headquarters. For example, Toyota Motor (TMC) is moving its U.S. base to the Dallas suburb of Plano.The petrochemical sector, which often runs counter-cyclical to oil, is performing well, with Dow Chemical (DOW) and Chevron (CVX) building projects in the Houston area.Lastly, limits on interstate banking helped exacerbate the economic crisis in Texas during the 1980s, when collapsing oil prices as well as overbuilding in commercial and residential real estate led to smaller Texas banks failing.Today, big banks such as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Wells Fargo (WFC) and Bank of America (BAC) have footholds in Texas. Although each lender has boosted its energy loan loss reserves (JPMorgan alone increased its reserve to $1.5 billion for Q1), sustained low oil prices are unlikely to lead to widespread banking failures.Like any industry during a downturn, the Texas oil sector will be forced to become more efficient."The energy industry will be smaller," Jankowski said. "It will find a way to produce the same amount of oil with fewer people and more technology."

Warren Buffett said Saturday that the net worth of Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) rose $15.4 billion in 2015, boosting the per-share book value of both its Class A and Class B stock by 6.4%.Buffett was upbeat in his annual letter to shareholders, saying it's been a terrible mistake to bet against America for 240 years, and "now is no time to start.""America's golden goose of commerce and innovation will continue to lay more and larger eggs," Buffett said in the letter.In the 31-page missive, the chairman and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway said net earnings attributable to Berkshire shareholders in the fourth quarter, which ended Dec. 31, climbed 31.8% to $5.478 billion. Earnings per share for Class B shares rose to $2.22 in Q4, crushing consensus of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters for $1.75.For the full year, earnings grew 21.2% to $24.08 billion. Total revenue for the year rose 8% to $210.8 billion, up from $194.7 billion in 2014.Berkshire owns Geico Insurance, BNSF railroad, Dairy Queen, and as of January, Precision Castparts. Berkshire also holds significant holdings in companies such as Kraft Heinz (KHC), IBM (IBM) and  Wells Fargo (WFC).It should be no surprise that the company's Railroads, Utilities and Energy business fared the worst amid declining rail shipments and plunging gas prices.  Still, revenue for that business was down just 1.7% in Q4 at $40.004 billion. Earnings fell 2.9% to $1.507 billion.Total revenue for the company's flagship insurance businesses continued to show big gains, rising 10.9% in the quarter to $162.89 billion. But earnings fell to $4.9 billion in 2015 vs. $5.2 billion in 2014.  Earnings for the underwriting business soared 60% to $306 million, while earnings for the Insurance-investment income unit were up 17.4% at $1.033 billion.Earnings for other businesses and miscellaneous items climbed 36.3% to $1.827 billion.Buffett commented on the $37.2 billion purchase in January of aerospace components maker Precision Castparts, which he described as a newcomer to the "Powerhouse Six" businesses in the company's Railroads/Utility/Energy group. "PCC fits perfectly into the Berkshire model and will substantially increase our normalized per-share earnings power."He also commented on a proxy proposal regarding climate change that's on the agenda for the company's annual meeting, which is slated to be streamed live for the first time ever on the morning of April 30. Buffett said concerns about how climate change might affect the company's insurance payouts are unwarranted because Berkshire's insurance policies are typically repriced every year, factoring in increased risk such as climate change.Commenting on stock investments, Buffett said the company increased its interest in each of its top four holdings last year: American Express (AXP), Coca Cola (KO), IBM and Wells Fargo.  Coca-Cola and Wells Fargo shares were essentially flat in 2015, while IBM and American Express were big losers.Berkshire most recently has been buying big blocks of oil refiner Philips 66 (PSX) and as of Dec. 31 owned 55.38 million shares, giving it a 10.5% stake in the company, which has continued rising this year.Buffett also noted that in 2015 Berkshire invested $16 billion in property, plant and equipment, 86% of it deployed in the U.S.Berkshire Hathaway shares declined for most of 2015 and into early 2016, and hasn't been above its 200-day line since a brief spell last July. But the stock is up 7% from an intraday low of 123.55 on Feb. 3 and closed at 131.92 in Friday trading on the stock market today, down 0.3% for the day.

A provision of the 2010 Dodd-Frank law that takes effect in December forces banks to keep a stake in the commercial-property loans they package into securities and sell off to investors. The rule is intended to deter the type of risky lending that helped fuel the last decade’s boom and bust. Under the current business model, banks are encouraged to issue as many loans as they think they can securitize and sell, with underwriting standards sometimes falling by the wayside, said Lea Overby, a debt analyst at Nomura Holdings.“Originators know their product better than anyone, and they are less likely to underwrite really bad stuff if they have to hold it,” Overby said in an interview.The biggest players in the $550 billion market for commercial mortgage-backed securities, such as Wells Fargo (WFC), Deutsche Bank (DB) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM), are juggling multiple scenarios as they prepare for the new rule, according to bankers with knowledge of the deliberations. Banks may be required to hold as much as $50 million in capital for a $1 billion deal, a tough prospect to stomach with banks under pressure to keep their balance sheets in check. The rule also creates an opportunity for investors to team up with banks on the debt.Turmoil in global markets is exacerbating the uncertainty surrounding how lenders will adjust to the new regulations. The CMBS market is already on shaky ground as the rout in oil prices, slowing growth in China and uncertainty over the Federal Reserve’s course on interest rates spook investors in stocks and bonds around the world.The extra yield buyers demand to own commercial-mortgage bonds relative to benchmark interest rates has surged to the highest since 2011, meaning investors view the securities as increasingly risky, according to Morgan Stanley (MS). Since January, the spread between the benchmark and CMBS rated BBB-minus, the lowest investment-grade ranking, has jumped 240 basis points, or 2.4 percentage points, the bank’s data show. Morgan Stanley analysts led by Richard Hill cut their 2016 CMBS sales forecast to $70 billion from $100 billion as lenders pull back.Dealers are struggling to sell CMBS deals that have been in the pipeline for months, according to Leo Huang, who oversees commercial real estate debt at Ellington Management Group.“Money is being lost in amounts that haven’t been seen in years,” Huang said. “This should remind people there is substantial risk in this business.”The new requirement, dubbed risk retention, applies to all types of securitization, the process by which debt is pooled together and sliced into bonds of varying risk and reward. Such offerings backed by home loans were ground zero for the financial crisis.The changes are creating an opportunity for real estate investors. Industry lobbyists won a concession from lawmakers to create an exemption for the CMBS market, allowing a third party to take on the risk on behalf of lenders as long as they agree not to sell their investment for at least five years. Banks will be held legally accountable if the firm they sell to violates the rules.The CMBS market has a built-in cohort, called B-piece buyers, that buys the riskiest portions, absorbing losses first in exchange for a hefty yield. Firms including Ellington, DoubleLine Capital and KKR & Co. (KKR) have entered the space in recent years, which was dominated by a handful of specialists prior to the financial crisis. Several B-piece buyers are seeking to raise funds to step in for the banks, though it may be difficult to find investors willing to lock up their cash for five years or more, said Warren Friend, an executive managing director at Situs, a commercial real estate consulting firm.Wells Fargo, Deutsche Bank and JPMorgan are among lenders weighing the costs of tying up their own capital versus the economics of compensating B-piece buyers for buying and holding large chunks of new deals, according to bankers at the firms who asked not to be identified because talks aren’t public. Banks with larger balance sheets are more likely to take on the risk themselves, they said.Representatives for Wells Fargo, Deutsche Bank and JPMorgan declined to comment on regulatory issues.One option is for B-piece buyers to buy loans from the banks -- as opposed to just buying a slice -- with the banks selling securitized debt to investors on behalf of the B-piece buyers, said Huang of Ellington, the hedge fund firm founded by Michael Vranos. The bank’s role in the deal would be more of an agent, as opposed to taking on principal risk, Huang said.“Our vision is for banks to do what they do well: using the relationships they have to originate loans and distribute bonds through their sales and trading desks,” Huang said.Some lenders probably will get pushed out of the business by escalating costs, said Overby of Nomura Holdings. Recent volatility has already claimed at least one of the smaller firms. Redwood Trust (RWT) , a Mill Valley, Calif.-based real estate finance company, said this month that it’s exiting the business of making loans for CMBS deals, citing the challenging market and escalating risks. About 25 employees will be cut, the company said.Other lenders are likely to become pickier about the commercial-property loans they issue as the end of the year approaches, said Friend of Situs. That may make it harder for property owners to refinance just as a wave of loans made during the market’s 2007 peak starts to come due, and some borrowers will have to swallow higher costs passed along by lenders, said Friend, who spent more than 14 years as a managing director in the CMBS groups at Morgan Stanley and Deutsche Bank.“Rates will have to go up,” he said, “and the amount of equity they will have to put in the deal will increase.”Related:U.S. Property Companies See Israel As A Promised Land Of InvestorsMortgage Bankers Would Swap More Risk For Lower Fees

Wall Street banks have declared war on Silicon Valley mobile payments platforms, arming to do battle in the peer-to-peer mobile payments business.As the likes of Square (SQ), Facebook (FB) and PayPal (PYPL) have charged into the uncharted waters of peer-to-peer payments, Wall Street banks have spent five years stitching together an alliance among JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC), Wells Fargo (WFC) and U.S. Bancorp (USB) and others, according to a press release from Early Warning.Early Warning is a real-time payments and authentication firm that will manage clearXchange, a technology that lets bank customers make quick -- near-instant -- transactions. It now generally takes one to three days to transfer money between banks. Banks had been slow to innovate after the financial crisis, but now "what we are doing now is delivering payments in real time, which is what our customers have asked for," Mary Harman, managing director for payments at Bank of America, said in an interview with Reuters.The banks are starting to use clearXchange to allow customers to transfer money almost instantly to friends and family. Peer-to-peer payments have been popular among millennials for splitting dinner bills, cab fare and paying rent.Achieving a critical mass fast is important for the banks using clearXchange. The so-called network effects -- the value unlocked from having a large customer base -- were critical to PayPal's early success in online payments, for example.PayPal was early to the peer-to-peer market and snapped up the popular Venmo app as a part of its $800 million Braintree acquisition in 2013. Braintree had acquired Venmo in 2012. Last year, Venmo moved $7.5 billion between people, and in January alone it handled $1 billion, PayPal told Reuters.As of Wednesday, only customers at U.S. Bancorp and Bank of America will be able to send money via mobile devices with the clearXchange platform. JPMorgan and Capital One Financial (COF) told Reuters they plan to plug in to the platform "later this year."Citigroup (C) is among banks that have not joined the alliance, Reuters said.PayPal stock was up a fraction, near 38, in afternoon trading on the stock market today. The company is an IBD Leaderboard stock. Shares are just below an early entry at 38.62. A conventional buy point lies at 42.65.Square stock was down a fraction Wednesday afternoon, as the company was set to report its Q4 earnings after the close. Investors are likely going to focus on Square Capital, the company's financial services arm, as an area of growth.Square's peer-to-peer payments app Square Cash recently added a feature that let customers store money in it, much like a PayPal account already does.Facebook built its peer-to-peer payments play within its Messenger app, and it did so in-house. The company has said Messenger has more than 800 million customers. Facebook stock was up 1% Wednesday afternoon, near 107.

So the mkt does the dance (again).....we woke up yesterday with a renewed disaster story in oil - the commodity came under immediate pressure and by the opening bell - it was trading 4.% lower, which then caused all of the algo's to hit the sell button on stocks...and why again? Why is it that stocks are so connected to oil? Why are stocks trading in lockstep with oil?How about - the talking heads have married to the two - thereby forcing the movement on a daily basis...the thinking goes like this: If oil is weak then that MUST mean that the global economy is weak. Period - The end. Let's not even discuss the absurdity of this argument at all.....this is NOT a lack of demand issue, it is all about a huge over SUPPLY issue - and this issue is not going away anytime soon - the Saudi's have made that quite clear.The lunacy could not have been more obvious yesterday.....you see - we woke up to a buildup in crude oil supplies and the negative banking story about how JP Morgan (JPM) and others are building up reserves to cushion the blow of failing oil and gas companies and what is expected to be the next disaster for the global economy. Add in the not so vague commentary by the Saudi oil minister that they are prepared to slaughter the competition and you have every reason to think - 'Hey - this could get a bit ugly....' (never mind that none of this is new news - but that's another story).The mkt opens lower and then proceeds to trade even lower from there....by 10:30 am - the DOW was down 266 pts or 1.6%, the S&P down 30 pts or 1.5%, the Nasdaq lost 77 pts or 1.74%.....and then we got 'The News' that ignited the fire....sending oil and stocks higher.....The US Dept of Energy reported that the gasoline inventory drawdown from last week as 2.236 million barrels vs. the expected drawdown of 1.033 million barrels....so essentially we used double the amount of gasoline in one week vs. what the brain trust predicted...and this one piece of data, this one piece of fairly 'irrelevant' data (in the big scheme of things) sent the algos into a buying frenzy....Why? Because the geeks who program the computers can only think A or B. If A then do X, If B - then do Y.. in this case A & B are:IF: drawdown is bigger than expected - then initiate BUY ordersIF: drawdown is less than expected - then initiate SELL ordersSo - folks - this one data point - which on the face of it appears 'bullish' - bigger drawdown means that we are using more gas - which then means that businesses must be doing more business and consumer must be spending more money, and construction companies must be building more houses and car companies will surely be selling more cars and the summer driving season most assuredly will be full of families packing up their cars with bikes and surfboards and luggage racks and once again driving to the oceans and lakes around he country to celebrate a strengthening economy.... which then means that hotels and motels will raise prices to take advantage of this surge and KMart, Target (TGT) & Nordstrom (JWN) must be gearing up to sell more bathing suits and summer outfits and restaurants will have to remodel to handle the onslaught of Americans going out to eat.....(See how I did that...I connected all those dots with one weekly gasoline report)REALLY? We get all that out of one weekly gasoline inventory report? I mean what happened to oversupply in crude inventories that is about to bankrupt the country? It's almost comical, isn't it?Bottom line is that crude oil prices once again survived the $30 support level and now faces another test. That test is a challenge of the 50dma which is at $34.44.....A failure for oil to pierce this resistance level will ensure that oil and stocks will hit another road block. An advance up and thru the 50 dma will ignite another rally in stocks - taking us up and thru the 50 dma at 1946 on the S&P - which will then cause sellers to back off as the bulls will push the mkt back to 2000 - in what I still think is a 'counter cyclical rally inside of a bearish longer term trend - due to all of the uncertainty around the FED policy decision.Any more suggestions of multiple rate hikes will kill any move higher....one single hike will be hard enough for the mkt to swallow while other central banks move to negative rates. Multiple hikes in the face of weakening European and Asian mkts will cause investors to punish stocks in order to re-price them.And this morning we get these headlines:"Pressure on ECB Mounts as Euro-Area Inflation Revised Lower""The Big NEW Threat to Oil Prices: A GLUT of Gasoline - Several refineries in the Midwest have opted to reduce activity for economic reasons..." We are swimming in crude and refined gasoline products - which should only further undermine prices....."Banks Brace for Potential Energy Losses - Drop in oil prices is hitting lenders' energy loans; latest figures are a grudging admission of the truth..." - this is more of the Jamie Dimon story...but this time the featured bank is Wells Fargo (WFC)....and they released this statement:"If oil prices remain low for a prolonged period of time, there could be addition performance deterioration in our oil and gas portfolio resulting in higher criticized assets, nonperforming loans, allowance levels and ultimately credit losses..."Translation of that very sophisticated statement: "We are .....(insert word that begins with ?).And so - what do the smart logic algo's think about that? Do they even have the definition of that word programmed into their memory banks? I mean that word has so many meanings.....based on how it is used, so..... I'm just sayin....

Now this morning we are seeing European mkts in rally mode......after we saw that strong demand for gasoline yesterday....Reuters puts it this way:"Markets have taken comfort from the fact that US crude oil futures held steady in early trading on Thursday as strong demand for gasoline was offset by a new record in crude stockpiles..."How crazy is that? European investors are jumping in on stocks because Americans used more gas than expected. You can't make this up...who would really believe it? Never mind that Eurozone inflation was just revised lower - which only forces Uncle Mario's to consider MORE stimulus.....FTSE + 2.38%, CAC 40 + 2.41%, DAX + 1.47%, EUROSTOXX +2%, SPAIN +2.7% and ITALY +2.7%.US futures are now up 4 pts - teasing 1934.....resistance (1946) is now only 12 pts away....This will be the third time that we challenge it....(we challenged it on the 22nd and the 23rd) ...I would not be surprised to see us pierce it today.....It just feels like it wants to.....(it's a gut thing, nothing more).Today we will hear from Dennis Lockhart (Atlanta FED) at 8:15 am and San Francisco's John Williams at noon.Take Good Care

Individual investors won some but not all of what was hoped from a sweeping new rule that tightens conflict-of-interest standards for brokers. Those brokers manage trillions of dollars in retirement accounts such as 401(k)s and IRAs, creating compliance headaches and liability issues for the financial industry.Still, the new rules are more lenient than the financial industry had feared they would be. And that leniency led investors to bid up stocks on Wednesday of many asset managers, brokers and insurers.Life insurer Primerica (PRI) soared nearly 7%. Broker and financial adviser Ameriprise Financial (AMP) rose 1.5%. T. Rowe Price (TROW) rose 1.4%. "Several of these stocks are trading up today," said Morningstar analyst Greggory Warren. "The rule impact is being seen as not as onerous as feared."Despite industry relief, overall the rule is seen as a victory for individual investors.The final Labor Department (DOL) fiduciary rule, which follows months of public and industry views on its proposal, requires brokers to act in the best interests of clients when providing retirement advice. The Obama administration claims that will lower costs and boost returns for investors."Today’s rule ensures that putting clients first is no longer a marketing slogan," Labor Secretary Thomas Perez said in a conference with reporters. "It is the law."The fiduciary standard of behavior creates new grounds for complaints by investors who feel they have been short-changed by their broker. At the outset of a brokerage relationship, a broker can still require a client to agree to take any disputes to arbitration rather than to court. But now the broker has to meet a higher standard of professional behavior, says Andrew Stoltmann, a Chicago securities-fraud attorney."(The new rule) creates a strengthened cause of action for those suing their brokers," Stoltmann said. The new rule does not mean that DOL itself will become more active as a securities cop, Stoltmann added.The government made some concessions in its final rule after months of criticism from the financial industry.The Investment Company Institute, a group representing mutual funds, last summer called the proposal so complicated that it is unworkable. Brokerages charged that the requirement would add costs that make retirement advice unaffordable for many lower- and middle-income investors.Some financial firms will probably benefit, while others are expected to be hurt.Discount brokerages such as Charles Schwab (SCHW) and TD Ameritrade (AMTD) stand to be helped, Morningstar predicted. So are companies that sell a lot of index and exchange traded products, like State Street (STT), BlackRock (BLK) and Vanguard. And robo-advisors are also likely to gain business. Brokers would be compelled to use their low-cost products and services rather than high cost alternatives.T. Rowe Price stock was up because its funds are relatively good performers, meaning they are more likely to be acceptable investment recommendations by brokers, Warren said. Also, the firm has been bolstering its sales staff in recent months, to boost its IRA business, he added.In its new rule, the Labor Department addressed some industry concerns. The originally proposed eight-month deadline for compliance is gone, replaced by a longer, "phased" implementation timetable.Also modified is a requirement for new clients to sign a contract in which any broker conflicts are disclosed. These would include the broker disclosing that high-commission products might be offered even though lower-cost alternatives are available. The final rule says the contract does not have to be signed until a client actually opens an account. The proposed rule called for the contract to be signed when the client first had contact with a broker.Another item dropped from the final rule: a proposed list of acceptable assets that advisors can recommend instead of certain high-risk investments. And a widely expected prohibition of in-house investment products has been dropped."I'm a little disappointed the DOL has caved on the issue of whether firms can recommend proprietary products like annuities," Stoltmann said. "No real fiduciary could do this. I think the DOL caved on a very crucial issue."The new rule basically extends a fiduciary standard mainly to brokers when they provide investment advice for retirement accounts. A fiduciary standard requires brokers to act in the best interests of clients. Registered investment advisors (RIAs) are already subject to the fiduciary standard, but a stricter version than imposed by the new rule on brokers, said Stoltmann.The new rule takes aim at IRAs -- particularly on money that is transferred or rolled over into IRAs from workplace retirement accounts such as 401(k)s, says Skip Schweiss, TD Ameritrade head of investor advocacy.Under the old rule, brokers could recommend investments that were merely suitable for clients. The DOL says that the old standard allowed brokers to base recommendations on what would generate commissions for them, even if a better-performing, lower-cost investment was available.The White House -- which supports the tighter standard -- said in February 2015 that investments made on the basis of conflicted advice under the old rule returned roughly 1 percentage point less a year on average than investments made on the advice of fiduciaries.With an estimated $1.7 trillion of IRA assets invested in the type of products that generate conflicts of interest, the White House estimated that the aggregate annual cost of conflicted advice is about $17 billion."A retiree who receives conflicted advice when rolling over a 401(k) balance to an IRA at retirement will lose an estimated 12% of the value of his or her savings if drawn down over 30 years," read the White House report. "If a retiree receiving conflicted advice takes withdrawals at the rate possible absent conflicted advice, his or her savings would run out more than five years earlier."With a $100,000 rollover for people age 55 to 64 in 2012, a 12% loss would cost the average investor $12,000.Morningstar forecast a mixed impact for active asset managers, including AllianceBernstein (AB), Cohen & Steers (CNS), Eaton Vance (EV), Federated (FII), Janus Capital Group (JNS) and Legg Mason (LM). The same applies to full-service wealth managers, including Bank of America (BAC), Morgan Stanley (MS), Raymond James (RJF) and Wells Fargo (WFC).These companies have product lineups that include both higher and lower cost products.And some impact could differ from what's expected. Many full-service brokerages could replace commission-based IRA fund sales with IRAs that generate fees on assets. "As fee-based accounts can have a revenue yield upwards of 60% higher than commission-based, this could translate to as much as an additional $13 billion of revenue for the industry," Morningstar reported.Also, full-service wealth managers could stop serving clients with low IRA account balances. Those clients could take an estimated $250 billion to $600 billion in assets to robo-advisors. That could push a number of robo-advisors above the $16 billion to $40 billion asset base that Morningstar estimated they need to become profitable.Even within groups that could be hurt by the new rule, like active asset managers and insurers, some companies could benefit. "(Firms) with moats will gain market share from their less competitively advantaged peers or ... will be able to adjust their business model to offset the negative financial effects of the rule," Morningstar reported.

Bank of America (BAC), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Santander (SAN) are all returning more capital to shareholders ahead of the next round of stress tests that could determine if more generous capital plans on the way.Bank of America will repurchase $800 million of its common stock, coming in addition to the $4 billion in buybacks the Charlotte, N.C.-based lender authorized a year earlier.The Federal Reserve didn't object to BofA's proposed repurchases, the bank said Friday in a regulatory filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.“The move today is some additional confidence that the buybacks are going to continue,” said Mike Mayo, an analyst at CLSA.Bank of America shares closed up 2.9% on the stock market today.The news came one day after JPMorgan said it could boost its share buyback program by $1.9 billion through June after getting the OK from the Fed. Capital One Financial (COF) likewise added an authorization for $300 million in additional buybacks last month.The buybacks come as the annual stress tests for banks approach. Banks must submit their capital plans and stress test results to the Federal Reserve by April 5. The Fed will announce the stress test results before June 30.With the Federal Reserve stress tests coming, up the fact big banks are feeling confident enough to buy back their own stock is a good sign. The Fed’s decision not to object to BofA and JPMorgan’s buybacks also should be viewed positively, Mayo added.“This is certainly a step in the right direction,” he said. “The Fed is not a rubber stamp.”Mayo added, “This is the first time in 20 years that we’ve recommended all four of the biggest banks.”Meanwhile, Santander said it plans to boost its dividend 5% this year after having slashed it by more than 60% last year.Big banks' stocks reacted positively as part of the upsurge for shares in early trading, as the S&P 500 turned positive for the year after January and February's horrible slump.JPMorgan rose 2.9%, Citigroup (C) added 1.6% and Wells Fargo (WFC) also rose 1.6%. Capital One shares rose 1.5%, while Santander edged up 0.4%.

Oilfield service providers Schlumberger (SLB) and Baker Hughes (BHI) had their price targets hiked Monday, and UBS started Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) with a buy rating.Barclays raised Schlumberger's price target to 83 from 74 and boosted Baker Hughes to 54 from 50.Last week, Schlumberger said it sees first-quarter revenue falling 15% on spending cuts. Meanwhile, Baker Hughes and Halliburton (HAL) keep hitting roadblocks from European and U.S. antitrust regulators in getting their merger approved.Schlumberger shares closed up 0.3% in the stock market today. Baker Hughes lost 1.8%, and Halliburton dipped 0.4%.UBS started Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway's class A shares with a buy rating and a $244,500 price target. Shares rose 0.8%. Meanwhile, the more widely traded B class shares of Berkshire (BRKB) have risen nearly 14% since a Jan. 25 low and also rose 0.8% Monday.Dollar General's (DG) price target was raised to 110 from 90 by Stifel. Last week, Dollar General announced plans to expand its test of its smaller-format stores this year. Shares rallied 2.5%.Finish Line (FINL) was upgraded to buy by Monness Crespi Hardt and BB&T Capital. On Thursday, Finish Line reported strong Q4 results, but guided fiscal 2017 low. Shares jumped 12.2% Monday.

The Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates unchanged at the end of its two-day policy meeting on Wednesday, but policymakers may signal fresh monetary action in the next few months, perhaps in June.The Fed will issue its policy statement at 2 p.m. ET, along with new economic forecasts. Fed Chairwoman will hold a news conference at 2:30 p.m.The central bank raised rates for the first time in nearly a decade in December. But financial market turmoil, perhaps partially fueled by that December move, along with weaker economic data spurred policymakers to hold off on further tightening at its Jan. 26-27 meeting, noting in the post-meeting statement that they were "closely monitoring global economic and financial developments."But global stock markets and oil prices have steadied, while U.S. economic data generally have been more favorable, though retail sales data Tuesday were weak.Investors will be looking for signs that the central bank is leaning toward hikes once again, in either the policy statement, Fed forecasts or Yellen's presser. The Fed may indicate that it's no longer forecasting four tightening moves this year, though market forecasts have consistently been less aggressive -- and more accurate -- than the Fed itself.The European Central Bank last week pushed its key rate further into negative territory and expanded its asset buying program. Such action could boost global growth. Also, the euro unexpectedly rallied on the ECB's action, which should make U.S. exports more competitive, at the margin. (A similar pattern happened earlier this year, when the yen rallied on the Bank of Japan's decision to push its own rate into negative territory.Higher rates could help ease pressure on net interest margins for Bank of America (BAC), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo (WFC) and others. Bank of America, JPMorgan, Citigroup and Wells Fargo shares have all risen slightly above their 50-day moving averages in recent sessions.

When Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) discusses fourth quarter earnings on Saturday, the company's recent major investments will likely be high on the agenda.A company spokesperson said the company will discuss Q4 results when it releases its annual report that day.Buffett has been loading up on shares of oil refiner Phillips 66 (PSX). As of mid-February, Berkshire owned about 14% of that company's equity. The sometimes nearly daily purchases of millions of shares of Phillips 66 has fueled speculation that he might acquire the company outright, which would be one of Berkshire's largest ever purchases.Phillips 66's market value of roughly $42.16 billion would likely push the price above the $37.2 billion Berkshire paid in January for forged components and aerospace castings maker Precision Castparts.Buffett continues to like top U.S. home mortgage lender Wells Fargo (WFC) too, and last quarter bought another 9 million shares, according to the company's end of quarter filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Wells Fargo on Wednesday set aside $1.2 billion for energy-related loan losses.Analyst consensus is for Berkshire to report an 8.7% increase in Q4 earnings per share to $1.75. Anything above that could spur a stock rise after the company just met estimates the prior quarter and missed the quarter before that.Berkshire avoided a Standard & Poor's rating downgrade last week, when S&P left its "AA" credit rating for the Warren Buffett-led company alone, saying its diversification and "modest" financial risks indicated that a downgrade wasn't necessary despite red flags.S&P put Berkshire on review last August, citing the company's huge cash outlay for the Precision Castparts deal. But S&P in its latest report cited Berkshire's "consistently strong" profitability and liquidity, in addition to its cash flow from subsidiaries.Berkshire "B" type shares took a hit during the recent market correction, amid concerns about its cash outlays. But it's rebounded about 6% from a Jan. 15 low of 124.12 to close up 0.3% in Wednesday stock market trading to close at 131.03.Phillips 66 rose 0.5% to 79.09 and Wells Fargo slid 1% to 47.61.

Wells Fargo (WFC) on Wednesdsay set aside $1.2 billion in reserves for oil and gas loans gone bad, becoming the second big bank in two days to make such an announcement.Energy-related loans comprise 2% of Wells Fargo's overall loan portfolio, but make up about 10% of its total loan loss reserves, the San Francisco-based bank announced in a regulatory filing. If oil prices remain low for an extended period of time, there could be additional deterioration in its energy portfolio, resulting in nonperforming loans and credit losses, Wells Fargo warned.The filing came one day after JPMorgan Chase (JPM) boosted its energy-related loan loss reserves by 60% to $1.3 billion. JPMorgan  also warned of a "very tough" Q1 for investment banking.Meanwhile, Morgan Stanley (MS) late Tuesday disclosed that it has $15.9 billion in energy-related loans, with only 60% investment grade.Wells Fargo shares fell 1% to 47.61 on the stock market today after sinking to 46.56 intraday. JPMorgan stock rose 2 cents to 56.14 tumbling 4.2% on Tuesday. Morgan Stanley was flat after losing 3.2% Tuesday.Many regional banks such as Comerica (CMA) are believed to be much-more heavily exposed to energy sector woes. Comerica stock fell 0.2% Wednesday after tumbling 4.5% Tuesday.The crumbling energy sector has adversely impacted banks, hurt by loans to energy companies that have gone bad as oversupply and soft demand have gutted prices by more than 70% since June 2014.Earlier this month, Morgan Stanley said it doesn't expect oil to hit $70 per barrel until 2018. On Wednesday, U.S. crude rose 0.9% to $32.15 a barrel on Wednesday after falling more than 4% intraday.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Are there any signs that emerging market economies are less sick now? One clue may be found in the positive stock market action seen in certain overseas banks. IBD ranks 197 industry groups every day in terms of six-month relative price performance (see the entire table in Monday's paper on Page B15). Today, few finance-related groups rank in the top…

HSBC (HSBC) swung to a $1.3 billion net loss in Q4 from a year-ago profit of $511 million, as it faces slower economic growth in Asia and a Securities and Exchange Commission probe into its Asian hiring practices.Before taxes, HSBC reported a net loss of $858 million during the fourth quarter. The bank's net profit for 2015 fell 1.2% to $13.5 billion. As of Dec. 31, 2015, total assets fell 8.5% to $2.4 trillion.It boosted its Q4 dividend to 20 cents a share and its full-year dividend to 50 cents a share. Both dividends were raised a penny.HSBC shares were down 1.8% on the stock market today, and have tumbled 20% so far this year, pushing them to their lowest level since the Great Recession. HSBC currently has and IBD Composite Rating of 31 out of 99, meaning it is being outperformed by 69% of other companies.The performance of Europe's largest bank was "broadly satisfactory," said Chairman Douglas Flint, in a statement. But Flint noted that last year was marked by "seismic shifts in global economic conditions, most notably the continuation of a sharp decline in commodity and oil prices, in part attributable to growing concerns over China’s slowing economic growth."HSBC has axed jobs and trimmed operations as it pivots to the Asia-Pacific region and is selling off businesses in Brazil. The bank recently announced it is keeping its headquarters in London instead of moving it to Hong Kong, where it has maintained a big presence since its founding in the then-British colony 150 years ago. HSBC has been based in the United Kingdom since 1993.The bank also disclosed it is the subject of an SEC investigation into its employment practices of people connected to government officials in Asia-Pacific nations. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) already is facing a similar federal probe.HSBC also reported setbacks in its efforts to comply with a five-year deferred prosecution agreement reached in 2012 over charges that it ignored possible money laundering by drug traffickers. If HSBC doesn't fully comply with the agreement, it could face criminal prosecution and lose its U.S. banking license.Most bank stocks performed well Monday as markets turned upward. JPMorgan rose 1.3%, Wells Fargo (WFC) gained 2.3%, Bank of America (BAC) rose 3.4% and Citigroup (C) climbed 1.4%.European banks' U.S. shares performed well too. Barclays (BCS) rose 1%, while Deutsche Bank (DB) and Banco Santander (SAN) climbed 2.9% and 4.15%, respectively.Overall, 2016 has been a poor year for bank stocks, as global growth worries and the decision of some central banks to go further into negative rates has hurt them.

Financing for cars and trucks is setting records, and big banks such as Bank of America (BAC) want in on the action, even as JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and others blow the warning whistle.The average amount financed for a new car or truck in the fourth quarter rose 4.1% year over year to a record $29,551, Experian Automotive said. The average monthly payment rose 2.3% to $493, also a record, even as loan terms get longer.Average loan terms for new and used cars held firm in Q4, at an elevated 67 months and 63 months, respectively. Longer-term loans (with terms of 73-84 months) for new vehicles reached 29%, while longer-term loans for used vehicles climbed to 16.4%.New-car loans for subprime lenders rose to 10.7% in Q4 compared to 10.1% a year earlier, while new-car loans for deep subprime lenders rose to 0.78% in Q4 from 0.68% in the year-earlier period. For used car loans, the number of subprime and deep subprime lenders fell year over year in the fourth quarter, down 0.54 point for the former, and down 0.19 point for the latter.Other data show that subprime defaults and delinquency rates are the highest in several years.Nearly 86% of all new vehicles and 55% of all used vehicles sold during Q4 were financed.Boosted by cheap fuel, easy credit and increased financing, U.S. auto sales climbed to their best February performance in 15 years, with Ford (F) and Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) each reporting double-digit gains, as did Nissan (NSANY) and Honda (HMC). General Motors (GM) reported a 1.5% sales decline last month as it cut lower-margin shipments to rental fleets.But there are concerns that the auto industry's growth, based on subprime and longer loans, is not sustainable, pushing out the buying cycle.Still, Bank of America is making a big move into auto loans, an area where Wells Fargo (WFC) has been a strong performer in recent years.But there are concerns that there are problems in the auto lending market. Banks categorized $1.1 billion worth of auto loans as uncollectible in Q4, according to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., up 15% from Q4 2014 and a 39% increase since Q4 2011.In January, Jamie Dimon, chairman, president and chief executive officer of JPMorgan Chase, called the auto lending market "stretched."

As banks farm out more tech services and try to keep up with customers managing more of their money via their phones, Fiserv (FISV), a company that provides back-end technology to the finance industry, seems to be expanding at a solid, measured pace.Companies spilling over with triple-digit growth every quarter are drawing more adventurous investors, which is why many on Wall Street seem to like Fiserv’s steadiness. The company routinely generates single-digit sales gains and low-double-digit earnings growth, aided by share buybacks.Following the Fed’s rate hike last year and forecasts for fatter industry tech budgets, more of the same could be in store despite worries over a downturn and consolidation, the company and analysts say. That's due primarily to a steady income base.“When you have 85% of revenue recurring, it gives them a very good visibility into their numbers,” helping enable more accurate guidance and minimizing surprises when earnings season rolls around, Monness Crespi Hardt analyst Alexander Veytsman told Investor's Business Daily.“They do increase pricing, but given the longevity of those contracts and given the fact that these clients have been with them for a number of years, I would say they’re growing it slowly and steadily,” Veytsman said.The nature of the company’s contracts with clients helps Fiserv maintain its firm footing. Many deals are longer-term and retention is high, Morningstar notes in its research on the company. In addition, it’s costly and potentially hugely disruptive for financial companies to switch from one core-processing service to another, helping Fiserv keep customers in the fold.And even amid Wall Street’s hand-wringing over a possible recession, Chief Executive Jeffery Yabuki told IBD that he sees the trends in tech spending among Fiserv’s own clients continuing."Most of our revenue is based on non-discretionary, mission-critical technologies under longer term contracts and is not subject to dramatic fluctuation,” he said via email. “We are seeing stable and growing demand for newer technologies that enhance experiences in the increasingly digital world.”Brookfield, Wis.-based Fiserv serves 13,000 banks, credit unions, retailers and other clients around the world. If you’ve withdrawn money from an automated teller or transferred a balance from one account to another, there’s a good chance it went smoothly in part because of Fiserv.Created in 1984 through a merger, Fiserv handles everything from transaction processing to data analysis to person-to-person payment systems. With this year’s technology spending seen growing 4%-5% among banks and credit-union customers -- Fiserv’s bread and butter -- the company is set to follow, Argus Research says.“We believe that Fiserv remains well positioned to benefit from technology infrastructure spending among its primary customers (banks and credit unions), many of whom are working to improve processing efficiency for online bill payment and debit card transactions,” Argus analyst Stephen Biggar said in a research note last month.“This should help revenue to keep rising at a modest mid-single-digit pace,” Biggar said, adding that Argus sees 5.5% in sales growth this year.Shares are up 25% over the past 12 months. The company has a Composite Rating of 93 out of a best-possible 99, boosted most recently by its strong fourth-quarter results that were marked by better-than-expected operating margins.The company also has tried to stay relevant through acquisitions. In 2011, Fiserv snapped up mobile banking company M-Com and digital payments outfit CashEdge, which gave it Popmoney, a bank-based person-to-person payments system for participating institutions that has helped drive sales growth. The company in 2013 announced that it acquired Open Solutions, giving it real-time account-processing technology.“You don’t need a new product every day,” Biggar said, “but you need something fairly significant every 2-3 years that would have its own sort of life cycle.”Last month, Fiserv said the United Nations Federal Credit Union for U.N. employees, among the largest in the U.S. by assets, will begin using Fiserv’s core account-processing technology. Analysts say the Federal Reserve’s rate hike in December could help strengthen banks’ finances, potentially freeing up cash for their technology budgets.“We view the Fed rate increase for the first time in a decade as good news for banks and a way to help fund needed increases in IT spend, as institutions look for ways to keep up with the broad changes across the technology landscape,” CEO Yabuki said on the company’s fourth-quarter earnings call last month.Some concern persists that Fiserv could make less money if consolidation continues within the banking industry, either due to tightening regulations or an event like the 2008 financial crisis. Mergers and acquisitions could reduce client count and give those bigger, combined companies more muscle in negotiating cheaper contract prices with companies like Fiserv.However, the reduction in clients hasn't materialized, Veytsman said, and the prospect of more banks bringing tech operations in-house seems unlikely. Fiserv counts Wells Fargo (WFC) among its big clients, potentially signaling a stronger shift to outsourcing among larger banks.Monness Crespi's Veytsman said consolidation could actually accelerate the trend of tech outsourcing.“When they consolidate they also look to see what’s happening with the bottom line and what they’re doing around the costs,” he said. “And if someone was not considering using Fiserv as a client, maybe together, they will.”Yabuki sees consolidation continuing, but stressed that the number of accounts and transactions has kept rising for the company.Foreign exchange amid a stronger dollar could also hurt the company, although its international exposure is limited, Veytsman said. Jack Henry & Associates and FIS are among the company’s primary competitors. Concern also lingers about Fiserv’s debt, although Yabuki cites the company’s $1-billion-plus free cash flow last year.Still, both Biggar and Veytsman say the company’s acquisitions have been relatively focused and restrained.And one might be forgiven for wondering whether a person-to-person service like Popmoney can compete with PayPal’s (PYPL) Venmo, or payment-tech offerings from Facebook (FB), Alphabet (GOOGL) and, potentially, Apple (AAPL).However, Yabuki said P2P was in the early innings. And Veytsman said Popmoney is intended more as a side dish in its offerings to midcap banks than a main course."It’s very hard to challenge PayPal,” he said.

The head of the Minneapolis Federal Reserve on Tuesday urged lawmakers to go beyond Dodd-Frank's regulations and consider breaking up large banks to end the "too big to fail" phenomenon.Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari urged lawmakers to break up large banks such  into smaller, less connected, less important entities. Kashkari also proposed turning big banks into public utilities by forcing them to hold so much capital that they virtually cannot fail. He likewise proposed reducing systemic risks by taxing leverage throughout the financial system."The economy is stronger now, and the time has come to move past parochial interests and solve this problem," Kashkari said. "The risks of not doing so are just too great."Last year, analysts at Goldman Sachs called for JPMorgan Chase (JPM), currently the nation's largest bank and the world's sixth-largest lender, to be broken up into smaller units to provide more shareholder value. Analysts at UBS also have called for London-based HSBC (HSBC), Europe's largest bank, to break itself up in order to better serve investors.Under Dodd-Frank and other national and global regulations since the financial crisis, the largest banks such as JPMorgan have to hold extra capital, reducing some of the incentive to be bigger.Kashkari is a former executive at Goldman Sachs (GS) and Pacific Investment Management Co. who worked at the Treasury Department during the financial crisis of 2008. He oversaw the Troubled Asset Relief Program (TARP), a $700 billion bank bailout initiative. In 2014, he was the Republican candidate for California governor, losing to the Democratic incumbent, Jerry Brown.Bank stocks rose Tuesday afternoon. JPMorgan Chase improved by 1.5% on the stock market today, while Wells Fargo (WFC) advanced 2%, Bank of America (BAC) added 2.5%, and Citigroup (C) was higher by 3.6%. Bank shares have had a terrible start to the year, with major lenders hitting 52-week lows amid global headwinds such as negative interest rates in much of the world. BofA is down 28% so far in 2016, while Citigroup shares have declined 24%.Kashkari expressed skepticism that the current regulatory scheme would be useful to regulators in the event of another crisis, which he added, "we won't see ... coming."Kashkari's comments Brookings Institution in Washington, D.C. come amid increased rancor on the left from Vermont Sen. Bernie Sanders, a Democratic presidential candidate who has vowed to break up big banks within one year after taking office.But banks and other financial institutions have been slimming down in recent years, in part to avoid regulatory burdens, reduce expenses and cut headcount. General Electric (GE) has sold off much of its GE Capital unit, which in 2014 provided more than 40% of its profit. General Electric shares rose 2.1% Tuesday.MetLife (MET) says it will sell or spin off much of its U.S. life insurance unit to avoid higher capital charges assessed on entities declared to be "systemically important financial institutions." MetLife stock climbed 1.6%.

*Breaking News - Russia, Saudi Arabia, Qatar and Venezuela agree to hold oil production at January levels.....US Futures are up 25 pts....building on Friday's gains.......The sense is that although it is not a CUT, it should clearly help to stabilize the outlook - OIL up 1.5%* Mkts bounced hard on Friday – rising 300+ pts on the Dow – after…

Banks have lost ground this year as falling oil prices and volatile financial markets raised concerns about their health. The bank sector has fallen to No. 16 out of the 33 sectors that IBD tracks, down from No. 7 at the start of the year. Much of the decline has been due to big banks heavily exposed to the oil…

JPMorgan Chase (JPM) has added $500 million to its loan loss reserves for the first quarter, an increase of more than 60%, to guard against continuing losses in the energy sector.The New York-based lender's move brings its total energy-related loan loss reserves to $1.3 billion. It reported more than $800 million in energy loan loss reserves at the end of last year. At JPMorgan's investor day, the bank said if crude oil falls to $25 per barrel and stays there for 18 months, it could add an additional $1.5 billion to its reserve balance.Meanwhile, JPMorgan investment bank chief Daniel Pinto sees a "very tough quarter" so far, predicting investment bank fees will fall 25% vs. a year earlier. M&A activity is holding up, but debt and equity capital markets are struggling.JPMorgan shares fell 4.2% to 56.12 on the stock market today.Investment bank Morgan Stanley (MS) said late Tuesday in an SEC filing that it has $15.9 billion in energy-related loans, saying 60% are investment grade. That implies that 40% are junk-rated. Morgan Stanley shares were little changed late Tuesday after closing down 3.4%. Goldman Sachs (GS) is the largest pure-play U.S. investment bank. Goldman shares fell 2.6%.Wells Fargo (WFC), Citigroup (C) and Bank of America (BAC) are among the big U.S. banks bracing for more energy loan losses. Wells Fargo stock lost 2.2%, Citigroup 3.3% and Bank of America 3%.A slew of oil and natural gas companies have come under pressure as energy prices have plunged.Banks themselves are being hurt by low interest rates (which limit their ability to make profits off loans), regulatory pressures, global economic weakness and a battered energy sector.

Financial ETF investors are an irked lot. They piled into this asset class in late 2015, hoping for a turbo-charged ride on the coattails of Fed rate hikes. Instead, they've been stuck in the slow lane.Even much-maligned energy stocks have fared far better.The financial rout is cause for concern. The sector accounts for 16% of the S&P 500 index, second only to technology. It underpins business growth, so its troubles tend to trickle down the economy."My biggest worry would be related to oil-related loans," says Neena Mishra, director of ETF research for Zacks Investment Research.Big banks and regional banks lent aggressively at the height of the fracking boom. They dished out loans to oil and gas companies, as well to the hotels, homebuilders and related industries that sprang up to service them, from Alaska to North Dakota to Virginia.Now oil's fallen far, far more than anyone expected. And businesses tied to energy are a bagful of hurt.The issue isn't just that banks are going to make losses on those loans, Mishra said. It's that they haven't been entirely upfront about their vulnerability to the oil patch.One of the nation's largest banks recently gave a revised figure for its energy exposure that far exceeded its previous one, according to Mishra. It had previously left out approved lines of credit from its calculations."We don't have clear visibility on how much those losses are going to be," she added. "We need to know more about their exposure to the oil industry, directly as well as indirectly."The flagship Financial Select Sector SDPR (XLF) has given up 12% year to date. Its new sibling Financial Services Select Sector SPDR (XLFS) is down 14%. They're at the bottom of the heap of 11 peers tracking S&P 500 sectors.By comparison, SDPR S&P 500 (SPY), tracking the broad stock market, is down 5% so far in 2016.XLF sliced below its 50-day and 200-day moving averages Dec. 30 and has made two feeble attempts at a rally after hitting fresh 52-week lows this year. It's trading at roughly half its pre-financial crisis high of 38.15.Year to date, it's leaked $1.59 billion in investor outflow -- almost the entire amount it absorbed in Q4 last year.It's not just oil that's weighing on financial stocks. More than one or two rate hikes in 2016 seem a long shot as global growth falters. Higher interest rates boost banks' profit margins.In Europe and Japan, policymakers have toyed with zero and negative interest rates to stimulate growth. European banks face problems of their own making too. Deutsche Bank, mired in debt, saw its stock fall as much as 35% this year. Credit Suisse is caught in a money-laundering scandal."For the first time since 2008, there is a little bit of angst about the financial health of banks," says Marc Pfeffer, a senior portfolio manager at CLS Investments. "Domestic banks have been guilty by association."He finds the financial sell-off a little overdone. The likes of JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Wells Fargo (WFC) are "well capitalized, totally fine," he says.Post-financial crisis, the financial services sector has been subject to tighter control. That's been a mixed bag for them. The bottom line for investors, however, is that many U.S. financial companies have the strongest balance sheets they have had in years.The risk-off tone to the market has unduly impacted banks, says Dave Mazza, head of research for SPDR ETFs.He believes investors extrapolating the worst-case scenario from the headlines may be missing out on opportunities."Financials and energy are really trading in lock-step," Mazza said. "That's made financials become further undervalued compared to the broader market."Some pockets of financial services are faring better than others. Insurance is proving more resilient in a two-speed economy, where the services sector is holding up better than manufacturing. Capital markets have been harder hit. Their business is tied more to GDP growth and industrial strength.Pfeffer also likes the outlook for regional banks.One of the funds he manages has a big holding in XLF. He also has a smaller position in SPDR S&P Regional Banking (KRE).Domestic banks should benefit from a steepening yield curve in the second half of the year."As the dust settles, I would look to increase exposure to financials," Pfeffer said. He is, however, braced for a bumpy ride.

Standard & Poor's cut the ratings of four regional banks, including Comerica (CMA) and Texas Capital Bancshares (TCBI), because of their exposure to the battered energy sector and low crude oil prices.Cullen/Frost Bankers (CFR) and BOK Financial (BOKF) were the other two lenders whose ratings suffered a cut late Tuesday."We are in the early innings of the downturn, in our view, and we expect loan losses to rise over the next two years, even if energy prices rebound modestly from current levels," S&P said in a statement.Comerica and BOK Financial Corp were lowered to BBB+ from A-, while Cullen/Frost Bankers was cut to A- from A. Texas Capital Bancshares was lowered to BB+ from BBB-.In addition, S&P revised its ratings outlook to negative for the four banks, suggesting another downgrade is possible in the future.Shares of Comerica closed down 1.2% Wednesday but climbed 4% after hours, Texas Capital fell 2%, Cullen/Frost rallied 0.3%, and BOK gained 0.8%.Last week, Fitch Ratings said most U.S. banks can weather the cheap oil storm for now, but it warned that a prolonged slump in crude oil prices could cause problems for lenders, particularly mid-sized banks with exposure to the energy market.Last month, Wells Fargo (WFC) raised provisions against bad assets by 70%, nearly half of it for loans in the oil and gas sector. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) said its expenses related to credit losses rose 49% during the fourth quarter, mostly driven by bad energy loans.Citigroup (C) has set aside $250 million to cover energy portfolio losses, but it warned it would have to double the overall provisions if oil fell below $25 per barrel.Thanks to oversupply and weak global demand, oil prices have plunged more than 70% from their level in June 2014.

Direct exposure to plummeting oil prices is modest for U.S. banks, according to a study by Fitch Ratings, but it could intensify going further.Most U.S. banks are in a good position to withstand volatile energy markets despite several of them, including JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Wells Fargo (WFC), announcing energy-related loan provisioning in Q4, Fitch said."Losses to date have been minimal," said Doriana Gamboa, senior director at Fitch, in a statement.But if oil prices remain low for longer than expected, lenders -- particularly midsized banks  with outsized exposure -- could have problems with additional provisioning. Fitch said that it expects oil prices to increase to $45 per barrel on average this year and $55 in 2017. Crude oil currently trades around $30 per barrel."Larger U.S. banks should be able to weather loan provisions without rating pressures, but negative rating actions are possible for some midtier banks if oil prices remain depressed near or under the $30 per barrel range for an extended period," said Julie Solar, senior director at Fitch.Last month, Wells Fargo raised provisions against bad assets by 70%, nearly half of them for loans in the oil and gas sector. JPMorgan said that its expenses related to credit losses surged 49% in Q4, mostly driven by bad energy loans. JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon warned of some "stress" in energy loans as the bank reported its Q4 earnings last month.Citigroup (C) has set aside $250 million to cover energy portfolio losses but warned that it would have to double the overall provisions if oil were to fall to $25 per barrel for a sustained period. Comerica (CMA) increased its provisions for credit losses to $35 million in Q4, up 35% from the third quarter's total.JPMorgan Chase closed down 1.1%, Wells Fargo dipped 0.8%, Citigroup lost 2.3% and Comerica eased 1.1% in the stock market today.

Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) bought 26.5 million shares of Kinder Morgan (KMI) in the fourth quarter, adding to his recent string of oil industry share purchases. The Kinder Morgan buy represents an estimated 1.2% stake in the pipeline company, valued at $395.9 million as of the end of 2015, according to Bloomberg. Buffett's purchase came despite Kinder Morgan slashing its…

Wells Fargo (WFC) agreed to pay $1.2 billion to resolve claims of improprieties in connection with its Federal Housing Administration lending program between 2001 and 2010, shaving 3 cents a share off its 2015 earnings. The agreement was reached Monday between the San Francisco-based bank, the Justice Department, federal prosecutors in Manhattan and San Francisco, and the Department of Housing…

Major stock ETFs punched up Friday from this week's early bruising as investors cheered higher oil prices and upbeat retail data. U.S. crude futures spiked 12% to $29.44 a barrel after an OPEC official indicated that output cuts were still on the negotiating table. Energy and financials led the S&P 500 sectors higher. Alerian MLP (AMLP) vaulted 7% on the…

General Electric (GE) is reportedly nearing an agreement to sell its $115 billion asset management business to State Street (STT), as the conglomerate continues to shed its nonindustrial assets.A deal could come later this month and could value GE's asset management unit at as much as $500 million, sources told Reuters.State Street prevailed over Goldman Sachs (GS) for the business, and the negotiations are in their final stages, Reuters reported.GE Asset Management managed $115 billion in assets as of June 30, 2015, including the retirement plans for most of GE's 130,000 U.S. employees. It also manages assets for outside institutional investors.GE has been shedding much of its financial services units in order to refocus on its industrial roots and to avoid costly post-financial-crisis regulations. It has previously sold off chunks of its GE Capital unit to Wells Fargo (WFC) and Blackstone (BX).General Electric shares closed down 2.2% on the stock market today and have been trading between their 50- and 200-day moving averages since Jan. 7.State Street stock slipped 1.25%. It has been trading steadily below its 50-day line since December. The Boston-based bank's 50-day line fell below its 200-day line in September.
