Stocks tumbled, accelerating to the downside yesterday as another shift in oil prices, weaker earnings from 2 very big oil companies and more talk of rates HIKES by Kansas City Fed Pres - Ester George Now Ms. George has a pedigreed background for sure.....she got her BSBA from Missouri Western State University, her MBA from Univ of Missouri- Kansas and…

A $5 billion legal settlement Goldman Sachs (GS) reached with regulators slashed its Q4 profit along with less-than-stellar trading revenue.The New York-based bank earned $1.27 per share, down 71% from a year earlier and missing by $2.26 estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. The settlement concerning residential mortgage backed securities reduced earnings by $3.41 per share. Including this total, Goldman Sachs would have earned $4.68 a share, easily beating analysts' expectations of $3.53 a share.Many other banks, including JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C), reported lower litigation-related costs vs. a year earlier.Goldman Sachs revenue fell 5.4% to $7.3 billion, beating estimates of $7.1 billion. It's the third consecutive quarter of declining revenue.Goldman stock fell 2% to close at 153.75 the stock market today as the major averages plunged and pared losses Wednesday.Trading revenue fell 9% from a year earlier to $2.9 billion as big banks were hindered by stock market volatility. Revenue in stock trading tumbled 9% to $1.8 billion. Fixed income, currency and commodity trading revenue fell 8% to $1.1 billion, thanks to slumping commodity markets. There have been reports that Goldman will cut a significant number of bond traders and salesmen this quarter.M&A advisory revenue surged 27% to $879 million, Goldman's best performance in that area since 2007. Last year saw $4.7 trillion in announced deals, and Goldman was the No. 1 Wall Street advisor in 2015.The bank's compensation and benefit expenses were $12.7 billion last year, essentially unchanged from 2014's total.Full-year EPS was $12.14, down 28.9% from 2014's total, and missing views by $2.46. Full-year revenue fell 1.3% to $33.8 billion.Big Bank Earnings Season OverGoldman rounds out earnings season for the six largest U.S. lenders. JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo (WFC) and Citigroup reported last week. Bank of America and Morgan Stanley (MS) reported their results on Tuesday.JPMorgan fell 2.6%, Wells Fargo 1.8%, Citigroup 3.3%, Bank of America 2.8% and Morgan Stanley 3.5% Wednesday. Concerns about loans to the energy sector are also hurting banks.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter @IBD_CMcEvoy and on Facebook.

Tuesday - January 12th....as night turned to day - European mkts were higher....US futures were pointing up and the it looked like a new day was upon us......as the futures suggested a strong opening.......in my note I discussed how we could test 1950 before we hit our heads on resistance..... and like clockwork within mins of the opening trade — we tested 1948 ish — hit resistance — churned and gave it all back and then some as the bears once again went on the attack.........  The usual concerns once again became the talk of the morning.....OIL became the focus.....it had been weaker overnight.....broke $31/barrel and tested the mid $30's.......the chatter began......Would ‘they’ try to break oil today?  (Exactly who are 'they'?) Well - that's a loaded question......and if you believe in the conspiracy theory - 'They' could be any one of the big investment banks that have put their walnuts and reputation on the line with calls of $25, $20 and even $10 a barrel oil in 2016.    Or 'they' can be anyone like — your next door neighbor, your brother or sister in law, it could be your dad or your son & daughter… 'They' cold be anyone who is a commodities trader, with access to sophisticated trading systems and algorithms….men/women who consistently test the bounds for weakness or strength.… (now ‘they’ also exist in other asset classes as well….stocks, derivatives, other commodities, sectors….anywhere where ‘they’ can cause trouble…).     ’

Now conveniently — the EIA (Energy Information Administration) came out and CUT their global 2016 oil demand forecast to 95.19 million barrels/day  (down from 95.22 million in December’s outlook) while INCREASING their forecast for global production to 95.93 million barrels a day,  and this gave those clowns what they needed — an excuse to test the psychological $30/barrel number and this is when the mkt went from being up strongly to giving it all back - it immediately felt heavy, lethargic and the whisper was - "Will they test it today?"……  Recall the thinking……. $30 was the last bastion of support - but this was not NEW news......….once it breaks $30 then ‘it’s over’…….it would plummet into the high $20’s on its way to $10 — taking stocks (around the world) with it!  And for some other reason - it seemed that yesterday predictions of doom and gloom for stocks permeated the airwaves....calls for 'Sell EVERYTHING' were all over the web......Predictions of down 25%, 30% and even 50% for stocks were flying around the globe via social media outlets that allow for instantaneous publication....  This only added to the negative mood.......

And so what happened?  'They' went to work........and started to sell oil with abandon......the commodity  went from $30.60 to $30.03 rather quickly (unlike how it usually trades)  and then stopped — but only for a min — stock traders prepared for the sell algo’s to go into overdrive, while the buy algo’s retreated……then ‘they’ did it…….the commodities traders — pushed it…….and BANG — the quotron machines (now known as Bloomberg Terminals or Reuters terminals……) published the news……..”Oil had broken $30/barrel”  (GASP!)   The media was covering the story tick by tick as ‘they’ pushed it to $29.95……….it was like a funeral for the ‘Head of State’ with all the pomp and circumstance…..the somberness, the black limos, the open casket and the line of citizens waiting in the frigid winter air to say their good bye's —……or was it really a GOOD BUY?  (notice the play on words..)

No folks — the world did not end…the mkt did not implode, the panic did not ensue……the algo’s got confused…..what should they do now?  No one panicked…..and then the BULLS took control and started to pick away…..the Dow, S&P and Nasdaq all  rallied only to get hit again as the BEARS who were hiding in the trees pounced......the BULLS temporarily knocked off their feet managed to get up again and rally stocks into the closing bell…..ending the day nearer the highs…….and the mkt breathed………and day turned into night…..   Today - Wednesday January 13th -

Overnight mkts around the world continue to advance -  Asian mkts mostly higher, Emerging mkts enjoying a bounce and this morning European mkts are all up broadly......and US futures are pointing higher again.....wanting to retest the 1950 level as the sun rises over the Atlantic and night turns into day...    The China and OIL story that has managed to wipe some $5 trillion off the face of the earth showing signs of calm......   Technically the mkts are in well oversold territory.....McClennan Oscillator suggest a deeply oversold mkt and when this happens - we can expect what is known as a 'counter cyclcal rally'  or  a 'Bear Mkt Rally' - a rally that runs counter to the longer term trend....  These rallies tend to be swift and sometimes violent  as shorts get squeezed causing them to throw in the towel and just cover rather than suffer the larger losses.....longer term bargain hunters also jump into the fray only adding to the demand.....so sellers disappear and buyers trip over each other to buy stocks......- but these usually end with badly........

We are now in the beginning of earnings season and the mood is mixed about what to expect... Tomorrow brings us JP Morgan (JPM) and Wells Fargo (WFC) while the rest of the banks will follow in the days after....WSJ front page article about JPM yesterday....besides more layoffs - they continue to CUT COSTS to shore up their numbers.....and now are -re-considering their commitment to all of the Bloomberg Terminals that have.....these glorified data centers runs at a minimum of $24k/yr per user.....so do the math......(let's go easy...and just say they have10k terminals at the base rate of $24k/yr - that alone is $240,000,000.....but remember - JPM usually doesn't do the BASE rate......Bloomberg charges you for every bit of data so rates for terminals can be much higher..... and  Mikey (Bloomberg) makes no bones about it - laughing all the way to the bank).

So will earnings surprise us and be the catalyst to change the trend or will they disappoint and only add to the angst?   The bigger picture remains murky.....Eco data later on in the week may provide a bit of a distraction - but will do little to change the mindset.....
US Futures are up 12 pts now suggesting another attempt at a sustained rally.......Are the bears laying in wait at 1950?  Will they pounce yet again drawing new blood from an already weakened bull?
Take good care.
Kp

Bank of America (BAC) and Morgan Stanley (MS) reported Q4 and full-year earnings that highlighted big banks' tough revenue environment amid low interest rates and a sagging energy sector.Charlotte, N.C.-based Bank of America earned 28 cents a share in Q4, up 12% from a year earlier and beating by two cents estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue rose 3.2% to $19.6 billion, missing estimates of $19.8 billion.Full-year EPS was $1.38, beating views by three cents. EPS for 2014 was 36 cents, due in large part to massive legal bills, including a mortgage-related settlement worth nearly $17 billion that BofA paid out to regulators. Full-year revenue was $84.2 billion, down 1% from 2014's total but beating views of $84.1 billion.As of Dec. 31, 2015, total assets rose 1.9% to $2.14 trillion. Total deposits rose 7% to $1.2 trillion. Excluding an accounting adjustment, trading revenue rose 11% year over year to $2.65 billion, but tumbled 16% compared to Q3's total.Consumer banking revenue barely rose — just 0.4% — to $7.8 billion. Global banking revenue inched upward 0.9% to $4.4 billion.Non-performing loans, leases and foreclosed properties fell 22.1% to $9.8 billion. Allowance for loan and lease losses fell 15.2% to $12.2 billion.Reflecting declining oil prices, commercial loan defaults rose by $75 million, and BofA has set aside $144 million to prepare for future defaults in its portfolio. CFO Paul Donofrio said during BofA's earnings conference call Tuesday that the bank's $21.3 billion energy portfolio comprises only 2% of its overall loans.Expenses fell 2% to $13.9 billion. Headcount fell 5% to 213,280 employees. The number of BofA branches fell 3% to 4,726.Shares fell 2.3% to 14.13 on the stock market today, trading well below their 50- and 200-day moving averages. Bank of America currently has an IBD Composite Rating of 45, meaning it is outperformed by 55% of other publicly traded companies. Investors have been concerned that a slumping stock market will stay the Federal Reserve's hand in further raising interest rates, which could harm banks' profitability. Other investors are worried about banks' potential exposure to bad loans from the tumbling energy sector.Meanwhile, Morgan Stanley earned 43 cents a share excluding items during the fourth quarter, beating estimates by 10 cents. The New York-based bank earned 39 cents a share once costs were included. In Q4 2014, the bank reported a loss of $1.6 billion, or 91 cents a share, as a result of a $2.6 billion settlement over the sale of mortgage bonds.Fourth-quarter revenue fell 1.8% to $7.9 billion excluding items, beating views for $7.6 billion. With items included, Morgan Stanley earned $7.7 billion. Full-year EPS was $2.70, compared with $1.39 in 2014. Full-year revenue rose 2.8% to $34.5 billion, missing estimates of $35.1 billion.Investment banking revenue fell 10.3% to $1.31 billion. Fees from advising on deals rose 5.7% to $516 million, while underwriting debt fees slumped 25.1% to $346 million. Employee pay and benefits fell 10% to $16 billion. Fixed-income trading revenue fell 8.2% to $550 million.Morgan Stanley shares rose 1% to 26.23 Monday, well below their 50- and 200-day lines. The bank's current IBD Composite Rating is 20.Big banks' earning season wraps up Wednesday when Goldman Sachs (GS) reports. JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Wells Fargo (WFC) and Citigroup (C) reported their Q4 and full-year results last week.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter @IBD_CMcEvoy and on Facebook.

JPMorgan Chase (JPM) saw double-digit bottom-line growth in the fourth quarter, thanks to lower litigation expenses and a strong performance from its consumer bank division.The nation's largest bank earned $1.32 a share, up 10.9% from a year earlier and 7 cents ahead of estimates from analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Net income was $5.4 billion. Revenue rose 0.8% to $23.7 billion, topping views for $22.9 billion.Full-year earnings per share rose 13.4% to $6 a share. Full-year revenue declined 1.3% to $96.6 billion.JPMorgan is the first bank to report quarterly and full-year earnings after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates by a quarter point last month. Wells Fargo (WFC) and Citigroup (C) report Friday.JPMorgan's net interest margin, the difference between the interest it charges on loans vs. what it pays out to depositors, increased to 2.23% compared with 2.16% in the third quarter.The bank's shares rose 1.5% to 58.20 after sinking nearly 3% on Wednesday and 13% in 2016 to an 11-month closing low. Wells Fargo climbed 1.8% to 50.64, and Citigroup advanced less than 1% to 45.38.Energy 'Stress'In a prepared statement, JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon saluted the bank's "strong loan growth and credit quality" but warned of "some stress in energy."Tumbling oil prices have been blamed in part for the year's awful start in the stock market, which hurt banks' trading revenue. Also, if the Fed doesn't raise interest rates as quickly as originally thought, that may hurt banks' profitability this year.The bank's provision for credit losses was $1.3 billion, up 49%, reflecting an increase in reserves of $149 million, with $124 million in the oil and gas portfolio and $35 million in mining.The fact that its energy credit reserves are modest suggests that JPMorgan isn't hitting the panic button when it comes to commodities, said Jeffery Harte, an analyst at Sandler O'Neill & Partners. "The fact they're not building more reserves ... suggests they don't see the need to build more. The commentary on energy credit was pretty supportive."As of Dec. 31, JPMorgan's total assets fell 9% to $2.4 trillion. Total loans grew 11% to $837.3 billion. Excluding credit card loans, consumer loans surged 17% to $344.8 billion. Wholesale loans rose 9% to $361 billion. Credit card loans rose a fraction to $131.5 billion.Deposits DownTotal deposits fell 6% to $1.3 trillion. Head count dropped 3% to 234,598 employees.Legal expenses for Q4 were $644 million, down more than 41% from a year earlier. For 2015, legal expenses were $3 billion.Consumer banking net income rose 10% to $2.4 billion. Total non-interest expenses fell 7% to $14.3 billion as JPMorgan and other banks looked to curb expenses in a slow environment.The bank's estimated Common Equity Tier 1 capital ratio — which measures core equity capital and indicates a bank's financial strength — was 11.8% in the fourth quarter compared with 10.2% the year before.Net income at JPMorgan's corporate and investment bank surged 80% to $1.7 billion, thanks to lower legal expenses.Investment banking revenue fell 11% to $1.5 billion. Lower debt underwriting fees were offset in part by higher advisory fees. Fixed-income trading revenue fell 3% to $2.6 billion due to reduced activity in commodities and credit markets.Rounding out the six largest U.S. banks, Bank of America (BAC) and Morgan Stanley (MS) report earnings on Tuesday. Goldman Sachs (GS) reports fourth-quarter results on Wednesday. Goldman Sachs is mulling big cuts to its fixed-income staff, reports say.Bank of America rose 0.6% to 14.99. Goldman Sachs tacked on 1.5% to 161.39. Morgan Stanley was up nearly 1% to 27.15.

General Electric (GE) aggressively moved towards winding down its GE Capital financial services unit last year, signing deals to sell off $157 billion in assets and closing $104 billion of those deals, the company said.

GE Capital is on track to file for de-designation as a systemically important financial institution during the first quarter of this year, GE Capital Chairman and CEO Keith Sherin said in a statement. The Fairfield, Conn.-based General Electric has said that it plans to reduce its financing unit to less than 10% of its total earnings, down from the 42% that it comprised in 2014.

In the closing weeks of 2015, GE Capital closed several deals that added $1.4 billion of capital to the overall target of $35 billion in dividends expected to be paid to GE under its capital exit plan. So far this year, it closed the sale of its railcar leasing unit, GE Capital Railcar Services, to Wells Fargo (WFC).
The exit plan is expected to be complete by the end of this year, GE said.

GE shares ended down 4.2% to 28.97 on the stock market today, as part of a broad market sell-off. GE stock fell below its 50-day moving average. The company's current IBD Composite Rating is 69 out of a possible 99, which means that it trades better than 69% of publicly traded companies.

Stocks rushed ahead in the last 90 minutes of trade Tuesday, turning moderate losses into solid gains. The Nasdaq finished with a 1% pop after being down 0.4%. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.8% and 0.7%, respectively. However, the small-cap S&P 600 added only 0.3%. Volume in the stock market today was higher on the NYSE but lower on the Nasdaq, according to preliminary data.Blue chips were a little better than evenly mixed. Coca-Cola (KO) showed the best price-and-volume action in the Dow. Coke popped 1.3% in volume almost 50% above average.The best price-and-volume action in the IBD 50, a list comprised of the strongest stocks in fundamentals and technicals, belonged to chipmaker Macom Technology Solutions (MTSI) . The stock surged 7% in volume 80% above average. Macom affirmed earlier Q1 guidance.While the stock market has struggled recently, it's important to remember the sky isn't falling — at least as far as some of the most respected investors are concerned.Wells Fargo (WFC), the biggest holding of Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB), has shown strong action the past two days, rising 1% Monday and almost 3% Tuesday.George Soros' biggest holding in Soros Fund Management is Adecoagro (AGRO), a provider of agricultural products in Latin America. The stock is a turnaround candidate. After losing 21 cents a share in 2013 and making only 2 cents a share in 2014, the Street expects a profit of 36 cents a share in 2015 and a 47% pop to 53 cents a share this year.Adecoagro has held up fairly well during the market turbulence and gained 2% Tuesday.Will Danoff's biggest holding in Fidelity Contrafund is Facebook (FB), though he lightened the holding in Q4. The stock has shown positive action and high closes the past two days.The best stance in troubled markets like this one is to decide what stocks should be cut and which stocks the investor has enough conviction in to hold through some trouble.On Wednesday, the Fed's Beige Book is released at 2 p.m. ET. Petroleuum inventory numbers come out at 10:30 p.m.Follow Paul Whitfield on Twitter. @IBD_PWhitfield

Apple's (AAPL) stock price moved higher Monday after the iPhone maker received an analyst upgrade, while Under Armour (UA) was downgraded and megabanks JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Wells Fargo (WFC) also saw action.

Mizuho Securities upgraded Apple to buy from neutral and raised its price target on the stock to 125 from 120. The move comes despite mounting signs that demand for Apple's iPhone is slowing, with key chip suppliers also cutting guidance.
Even so, technology metrics company comScore last week reported that Apple held two spots among the top 15 smartphone apps. Facebook (FB) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) dominated the list.
Apple shares closed up 1.6% in the stock market today. Facebook and Alphabet both finished slightly higher.

Under Armour was downgraded to underweight at Morgan Stanley, which has a 62 price target on the stock. Shares of the athletic apparel maker sank 6.7% to 69.96 Monday and are down 34% from the high of 105.89 set on Sept. 17.
That's the case even though both Under Armour and Nike (NKE) scored double-digit gains in athletic shoe sales in the post-Christmas week, according to a report issued last week.
Nike's stock price rose 1.2% Monday.
JPMorgan Chase lost 0.1% after it was downgraded to neutral by Goldman Sachs. JPMorgan is due to report quarterly earnings early Thursday.
Fellow banking giant Wells Fargo rose 1% following an upgrade to buy at Goldman Sachs. Wells Fargo is scheduled to report before Friday's open.
Discover Financial Services (DFS) was upgraded to buy from hold at Evercore ISI Group. Its shares rose 1%.
Analog Devices (ADI) climbed 2.4% after it was upgraded to outperform by Wells Fargo.
Shares of auto maker General Motors (GM) also rose 2.4% after it was upgraded to outperform from neutral by Credit Suisse, which raised its price target on the stock to 38 from 33.

Exposure to energy in Wells Fargo (WFC) and an underwhelming global banking performance for Citigroup (C) factored in as they, along with U.S. Bancorp (USB) and PNC Financial Services Group (PNC) reported fourth-quarter and full-year earnings Friday.

Wells Fargo said it earned $1.03 a share for the quarter, up 1% from a year earlier and beating by a penny the estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue rose 0.7% to $21.6 billion, missing estimates of $21.8 billion. Full-year EPS was $4.15 a share, up 1.2% from 2014's total and matched views. Full-year revenue rose 2% to $86.1 billion, missing views of $86.5 billion.

As of Dec. 31, total assets rose 6% to $1.8 trillion compared with a year earlier. Total loans rose 6.3% to $916.6 billion. Total consumer loans grew 2.7% to $460 billion. Commercial loans grew 10% to $456.6 billion.

Wells' net interest margin, the difference between what banks earn in loans vs. what they pay out to depositors, slipped to 2.92% from the third quarter's 2.96% and 3.04% a year earlier. The Federal Reserve's decision to boost interest rates by 0.25% last month — the first interest rate hike since 2006 — is seen as helping boost banks' profitability. But the brutal start to the year for stocks, weak global growth and underwhelming inflation numbers could mean that further hikes could be delayed.

The sagging energy sector also weighed on Wells Fargo to some degree. The San Francisco-based bank reported $831 million in credit losses in the fourth quarter, up 18.2% from the quarter before, primarily due to $90 million in higher oil and gas portfolio losses as well as seasonal increases in non-real estate consumer portfolios. Costs decreased 2% to $12.4 billion from $12.65 billion, reflecting savings on employee benefits and commissions.

Shares tumbled 4.2% to 48.51 on the stock market today. Wells Fargo's IBD Composite Rating is 64 out of 99, meaning it is outperforming 64% of other publicly traded companies. It is trading well below its 50-day moving average, and that fell below its 200-day line back in September.

Meanwhile, Citigroup reported quarterly earnings of $1.06 a share, also beating views by a penny. The New York-based bank earned 6 cents a share in the year-ago quarter because of legal expenses. Revenue rose 4% to $18.6 billion, beating estimates of $17.9 billion. Full-year EPS was $5.35 a share, missing views by 9 cents, but during the year the bank earned $17.2 billion, its biggest profit in nearly a decade. For all of 2014, Citigroup earned $2.20 a share. Full-year revenue fell 1.5% to $76.1 billion, but beat estimates of $75.6 billion.

Allowance for loan losses was $12.6 billion at the end of the quarter, or 2.1% of total loans. A year earlier, that total was $16 billion, or $2.5% of total loans. Citi set aside $250 million to cover losses to its energy portfolio.

Operating expenses fell 23% to $11.1 billion, driven by lower legal costs. Loans fell 4% to $618 billion while deposits rose 1% to $908 billion. Net interest margins slipped to 2.92% compared with 2.94% in the third quarter.

Profit at Citi Holdings, Citigroup's "bad bank" that has housed the company's sour assets since the 2008-09 financial crisis, soared to $704 million from $87 million a year earlier, thanks in part to the sale of OneMain Financial Group, Citi's subprime lending unit. Net income at Citi's global banking unit fell 20% to $1.3 billion and income from its institutional clients group dropped 18% to $1.4 billion.

Citi has sought to become leaner and meaner since the financial crisis. It has sold off a number of its overseas assets in order to slim down. Total assets as of Dec. 31 were $1.7 trillion, putting it behind Wells Fargo in that department.
Citi's shares sank 6.5% to 42.43, well below its 50-day line, which fell below its 200-day moving average in October. Its IBD Composite Rating is 48.

Elsewhere, U.S. Bancorp earned 80 cents a share for the quarter, up 1.3% and beating views by a penny. Revenue fell 0.2% to $5.2 billion, beating estimates of $5.1 billion. Full-year EPS was $3.16, up 2.6% from the previous year, matching views. Full-year revenue rose 2.5% to $20.1 billion, missing views of $20.2 billion.
The Minneapolis-based bank earned $294 million in fees from credit and debit cards, up 8.1% and helping to offset declines in mortgage banking and investment product revenue.

Net interest margin rose to 3.06% compared with the third quarter's 3.04%, but fell from Q4 2014's 3.14%. Average total loans grew 4.2% from a year earlier to $256.7 billion while total deposits grew 6.9% to $294.5 billion. As of Dec. 31, 2015, total assets were $421.9 billion, up 4.8%.
U.S. Bancorp.'s provision for credit losses rose 5.9% to $305 million. The allowance for credit losses was $4.3 billion, down 1.6% from a year earlier.
Shares fell 3% to 38.72, well below its 50-day average. U.S. Bancorp's IBD Composite Rating is 64.

Finally, PNC Financial Services Group earned $1.87 a share, up 1.6% year over year and beating quarterly views by 7 cents. Revenue fell 2.4% to $3.9 billion, beating estimates of $3.8 billion. Full-year EPS was $7.39 a share, up 1.2% from 2014, and beat views by 9 cents. Full-year revenue was $15.2 billion, a 1% decline, but ahead of estimates of $15.1 billion.

The Pittsburgh-based bank's net interest margin was 2.7%, down from 2.89% a year earlier, but an improvement over the third quarter's 2.67%. Total assets were $358.5 billion as of Dec. 31, up 3.9% from a year earlier. Total loans grew 1% to $206.7 billion. Total deposits grew 7% to $249 billion.
Provisions for credit losses were $74 million compared to the third quarter's $81 million while PNC's allowance for loan and lease losses fell 18% to $2.7 billion.
Shares fell 1.4% to 85.66, below both their 50- and 200-day moving averages. The company's IBD Composite Rating is 57.

Big banks' earnings season resumes Tuesday when Bank of America (BAC) and Morgan Stanley (MS) report their Q4 and full-year results. Goldman Sachs (GS) reports on Wednesday. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) issued its quarterly and annual earnings report on Thursday.

The volatility that shook Wall Street during the second half of last year is expected to adversely impact big banks' results both for the fourth quarter as well as 2015, as earnings season kicks off in earnest on Thursday when JPMorgan Chase (JPM) reports. The volatility that roiled stock exchanges in 2015 hurt banks' fixed income trading revenue in Q3…

The Federal Reserve's recent decision to boost its benchmark interest rate finally brought some certainty to U.S. banks, but investors shouldn't expect a blockbuster 2016 for the sector. The reason: A modest rate hike like the Fed's recent quarter-point increase isn't likely to boost loan growth or trading revenue at JPMorgan Chase (JPM) or elsewhere, analysts say. Second Hand News - Fleetwood Mac - Rumors Album....

"I know there's nothing to say, Someone has taken my place, When times go bad, When times go rough, Won't you lay me down in the tall grass and let me do my stuff.....One thing I think you should know, I ain't gonna miss you when you go......."

And that is just what the mkt is going to do.....it has to 'do its stuff' and while it may not be pretty right now - it has to happen.....The tossing and turning continues as the mkt tries to find its footing.....

Yesterday - US stocks rallied sharply.......in a typical 'rubber band snap back rally'.....  Stability in global mkts,  the oil mkt and the 'better than expected' earnings from JP Morgan  (JPM).....caused excitement.....and bargain hunters and traders sprung to life....sellers let them run.....laying in at the 1925 level - ready to let them have all they wanted.......

Let’s not be delusional here.  The big banks may have stepped in to buy stocks yesterday.....but there is still something very fundamentally  wrong with our economy - no matter what Barack Obama tells us.....Gov Chris Christie nailed it last night when he  told us "it was like watching story time with Barack Obama"  on Tuesday night.... We can all understand the gov'ts need to fill our minds with noise.....but does he think we are all bunch of trolls who have no clue?  Even the Fed’s latest GDPNow forecast only forecasts a 0.8% growth rate for the 4th quarter and this is after they 'modified' the equation and changed the data points!!!

Higher taxes, a failed healthcare policy, expanded social welfare programs, falling wages - otherwise known as Socialism - are killing us slowly..... Roberta Flack summed it up this way - "Strumming my pain with his fingers, Singing my life with his words, Killing me softly with his song.... I heard he sang a good song, I heard he had a style, and so I came  to see him To listen for a while....."

Now while we were all looking for that bounce.....put it in perspective.....after Wednesdays trashing - the US stock mkt - defined by the indexes -  entered into official 'correction' territory.....which is a 10% move off the highs.. CHALLENGE.....    BeSpoke Investment research informs us that as of Wednesday's close - the average S&P 500 stock is down over 24% from their 52 week highs.......this paints a much different picture suggesting that we are really in a BEAR mkt - no matter what the indexes tell us............

Headlines this morning suggest that the FED is becoming a bit more cautious is what they say and how they say it.  WSJ runs with - "Global Malaise Spurs US Growth Worries - Concerns are mounting over whether the US economy and the markets can remain upright while most of the world teeters..."Mkts in decline - again....

US futures are once again under pressure - currently down 30 pts - essentially taking back all of yesterday's gains..... (remember this is a long weekend here in the states so a RISK OFF tone would not be a surprise) ............. Chinese new loan data and money supply growth both missed their targets - igniting a renewed sell off in Asia......Oil falls back below $30/barrel - sending European mkts into a tizzy and causing US futures to dive.....

Oil sanctions against Iran are due to expire on Monday allowing for new supply to hit the mkt......(not new news....but in a negative environment - it only adds to the angst)Ric Spooner - Chief analyst at CMC Markets in Sydney, Australia had this to say - "Lower oil prices have been a sentiment leader for the recent market selloff and will again be in focus with Iranian sanctions expected to be lifted next week.  How fast Iran can put oil back on the market will now be a key issue for oil markets, with many skeptical that it will be able to do this nearly as fast as it has forecast.”

While  Iran is trying to regain lost market share, they tell us that they do NOT intend to pressure prices with any EXPORT INCREASE  when the sanctions are removed - and we are supposed to believe them - WHY?  They have trouble with the truth - and that has been demonstrated time and time again.....so this time is different - HOW?  They will though attempt to increase their daily production by 100,000 barrels a day, or 3.7%, in the month after sanctions are lifted and by an additional 400,000 barrels a day within six months after the sanctions are lifted....which leaves us to ask - OK....then what do you intend to do with all that extra oil - bathe in it?  Eco data today includes Retail Sales exp of  -0.1%,  ex autos and gas of +0.2%, PPI final demand exp at -0.2%, ex food and energy of +0.1%....Empire State Manf of -4......Ind Prod of -0.2% and Cap Util of 76.8%......None of these reports will make any difference at all unless they really surprise.....otherwise the focus will be on earnings and oil....Earnings today include BLK , C, WFC, USB, .....

Two FED speakers due out - Dudley at 9:00 a.m. and Kaplan at 1:00 p.m.  Dudley is the more important because he’s “leadership” and obviously his comments regarding recent volatility will be important.
Take good care.
Kp

Major index ETFs surged back bullishly after a choppy start Thursday, but didn't quite erase Wednesday's deep losses. Oil nudged higher even as it continues to trade near multiyear lows. West Texas Intermediate crude settled just above $31 a barrel. Stocks gained as the key commodity showed hints of recovery after eight losing sessions.All 11 Select SPDR ETFs tracking S&P 500 sectors gained Thursday. Energy and biotech climbed most.All but two of the 30 blue-chip stocks in the Dow Jones Industrial Average advanced.Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) rose 5% each, and Apple (AAPL) and Intel (INTC) more than 2% each.Intel fell nearly 5% in after-hours trading despite reporting better-than-expected earnings and sales.There was more corporate earnings news today.SPDR S&P Bank (KBE) popped 1.1% on the stock market today. The ETF holds 62 equal-weighted stocks, but shuts out nonbank financial institutions, such as REITs, insurance companies and pure-play investment banks.KBE slumped sharply in January along with the broad stock market. It is sitting 18% off its 52-week high of 37.28.Its holdings include JPMorgan Chase, the nation's largest bank, which early Thursday reported double-digit bottom-line growth in the fourth quarter. The firm benefited from lower legal expenses and a strong showing from its consumer bank unit.Earnings were up 10.9% from a year earlier, and revenue rose 0.8% to $23.7 billion, both topping estimates.More banks are set to report quarterly and full-year earnings in the coming days, marking their first reports after the Fed's historic decision to raise interest rates by 0.25% in December.Wells Fargo (WFC) and Citigroup (C) report Friday; Bank of America (BAC) and Morgan Stanley (MS) are slated for Tuesday; and Goldman Sachs (GS) is due Wednesday.Besides JPMorgan Chase, KBE also holds Wells Fargo, Citigroup and Bank of America.Financial Select Sector SPDR (XLF) advanced 0.9% in above-average volume.Despite gains Thursday, the broad U.S. stock market is an unsettled state.Anxiety about the relentless commodity slump and volatility out of China precipitated a sharp sell-off in January.The Dow and Nasdaq Composite indexes are 10% and 11% off their 52-week highs, respectively. In stock parlance, that marks correction territory.The S&P 500 is 9% off its old high.Small-cap stocks have fared worse: The Russell 2000 is 21% off its June high, indicating a bear market.Gold And DollarHaven assets got a setback as investors piled into stocks Thursday.Gold ETFs sliced below their 50-day lines as the dollar gained. They are 17% off their one-year highs, set last January.ETFs tracking the value of the euro, yen and British pound vs. the greenback all posted losses.10 Bellwether ETFs:Here's a look at how the major exchange traded funds tracking various asset classes performed today.Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), +1.6%, RS 64PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), +2.1%, RS 71SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), +1.4%, RS 62IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), +1.1%, RS 49IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), +1.4%, RS 45IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), +1.3%, RS 52Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), +1.3%, RS 31SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), -1.6%, RS 62IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), 0%, RS 78PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), +0.3%, RS 86Follow Aparna Narayanan on Twitter @IBD_ANarayanan.

And the FLUSH continues......by now I am even wondering....who is the TAIL wagging the DOG?   Have we just allowed the roles to reverse?  Can the Chinese stock mkt really hold this much sway over global mkts?   I mean - it's the Chinese stock mkt..... it says nothing about the state of the Chinese economy.......their mkt is not connected to their economy the way Europe and the US is.....I mean our mkts are developed, liquid and thick......everything the China mkt is NOT.(Let me remind you....it is an EMERGING mkt, not very thick and not very liquid, difficult to trade and subject to rule set changes on the fly......)That being said - the Chinese economy IS important to the global economy - no doubt - but my argument is that the Chinese economy is NOT nearly as gloomy as the most recent performance of the Shanghei Index.The Shanghei Index shot up 40% from February 2015 to June 2015   (4 months),  the same move in the S&P at that time would have meant....we went from 2,020 to 2,828  - a bit ridiculous no and very unlikely...............and it was not like the concerns about a slowing China did not exist.....they  did - but no one seemed to care......Chinese RETAIL investors  and some global asset managers were tripping over each other to buy stocks as the search for yield continued..........So what happened?  Well - oil started to crack in June -  when it was trading at $60/barrel, global investment banks began to forecast a break in oil and concerns over weaker commodities, concerns over a slowing Europe (or so they told us), and the increasing likelihood of a change in US FED policy etc. all contributed to a change in mind set.........Aisle 1 - REALITY CHECK!So as the global weakness story builds - they start to run for exits - the Chinese authorities then impose new regulations on the fly....causing more anxiety and  concern.....so that 40% move higher in 4 months does a 180 and collapses under its own weight - taking that mkt right back to where it was almost 1 yr ago....but has the Chinese economy story really changed that much?  No - and that was made clear in the Alcoa  (AA) earnings on Monday......Klaus Kleinfeld is looking at China as an opportunity and not as a drag on his businesses....What will other earnings reports say?  We are about to find out......In spite of deeply oversold mkt, investors continue to be fearful..... The fear trade continues to be gain momentum  - 'selling begets more selling......and it becomes a self fulfilling prophecy...... fear of the 'possible' of weak earnings, fear of an imploding China (unlikely), fear of the FED (overblown), fear of a slowing Europe (in fact not happening),  never mind fear over renewed geo-political issues - all coming together - to paint a picture of doom and gloom.....Remember - mkts tend to overshoot especially when the HERD mentality takes over.....Technically, the S&P is now testing the August lows and is in a deeply oversold  condition.  Note that on January 8th - the 50 dma crossed over the 200 dma - sending out that 'death cross' signal......an indicator that signals a bear mkt on the horizon.....but I have found that by the time the death cross happens - most of the move lower has already happened and in fact it tends to find support and begin the process of repair......I am still willing to bet that this will be the case here as well....That does not mean it rallies right back to S&P 2000. it just means that it churns as the mkt assesses the latest damage vs. the outlook........and the outlook  will become  clearer over the next couple of weeks as the qtrly confessional period heats up.......... Earnings will have to completely blow up for the mkt to implode....Speaking of -

JP Morgan  (JPM) just announced.......4th qtr profit RISES, expenses DECLINE - earnings 'BEAT THE ESTIMATE' -  The biggest US investment bank reported that 4th qtr profits rose 10%, Net Income at $5.43 bil vs. $4.9 bil yoy...... Analysts looking for $1.27 (adjusted) and JPM reports $1.32....the stock is up 80 cts in pre-mkt trading....

Eco data today includes - Import Price Index exp of -1.3%, Initial Jobless Claims of 275k, Cont Claims of 2.21 mil.  Look for a revision to the Philly Fed Index at 8:30 am.European mkts are all a bit lower this morning - but again are they reacting to our action yesterday , or Asian action overnight, or are they leading global mkts thru this turmoil......My sense is that they are reacting....the BoE (Bank of England) voted today to leave rates at 0.5% (no change) while Reuters reports that the ECB is standing pat - choosing not to do any more at the moment - this is NOT new news....Terrorist threats and action in Jakarta, Indonesia calling attention once again to the  'idiots'....causing renewed angst for investorsUS futures are up small - currently +2 pts.. trading at 1882......after having tested 1873 overnight and holding.   They are not GAPPING HIGHER like they have done for the past 2 days only to fail....... The focus will surely be on JPM today and what it says about its peer group - GS, MS, WFC, C, BAC, etc.....  The other biggie today is INTC and they report after the closing bell... - what will they say about China?

Now on the bright side - think  about all the benefits that will accrue to so many industries with lower commodity prices - and that is across the board....lower lumber, copper, steel, along with oil... Housing, construction, manufacturing, consumer retail - discretionary and non-discretionary.... at some point - all the weakness has to translate into a positive for so many industries -  and for the long term investor that has the vision and the iron stomach - this may very prove to be a silver lining.......Now - we need leaders - in DC on BOTH sides of the aisle -  that can institute solid fiscal policy initiatives that will take advantage of this opportunity.Tonight is another GOP debate - FOX is culling the field....Tonight will only feature the top 7 - Trump, Cruz, Rubio, Bush, Kasich, Christie and Carson and out of that group the focus will be on the expected fight between Trump and Cruz.....Get the popcorn....

Special Report: Personal Finance Action Plan For 2016ETFs are investing sledgehammers, opening up wide swathes of global regions or asset classes in one fell blow. They're equally precision tools, allowing investors to make tactical sector bets, to equitize cash or to hedge against market declines.That malleable quality is a key reason why exchange traded funds continue to blast their way into investors' strategies.Perhaps you're hearing about ETFs for the first time. Or maybe you're fine-tuning your financial action plan for 2016. As you check on your investing progress last year or prime your portfolio for the new one, ETFs are certainly worth considering.The numbers speak for themselves.More than $201 billion in new money flowed into U.S. ETFs and exchange-traded products in the first 11 months of 2015, according to independent research firm ETFGI.com.That's up 5% from last year's record asset-gathering pace for the same period.Unsurprisingly, more and more money managers want to get in on the ETF game, says Matt Hougan, CEO of ETF.com."That trend has absolutely accelerated this year," he told IBD. "It's actually breathtaking in its scope."Goldman Sachs and John Hancock in October launched their first ETF products that aim to beat traditional indexes. Oppenheimer Funds, New York Life Investment Management and Janus Capital Group (JNS) bought out small ETF shops. T. Rowe Price (TROW) and Legg Mason (LM) have filed for the regulatory nod to offer ETFs. A unit of Eaton Vance (EV) plans to introduce a newfangled, hybrid ETF-mutual fund product.Hougan describes the trend as a matter of simple math. From 2009 to 2015, investors poured roughly $1.1 trillion in net new money into ETFs, while mutual funds absorbed $200 billion."If you're the director at any major mutual fund company, you have to wake up every day asking yourself why," he said.Best-Performing ETFs Of 2015Investors scored big wins last year from small ETFs tapping into niche market segments.Market Vectors China AMC (CNXT) and Deutsche X-trackers Harvest CSI 500 (ASHS) rocketed 43% and 28%, respectively.Both hold small-cap China A shares, listed on the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock exchanges. Until quite recently, these equities could only be bought by Chinese citizens.Many successful investors also tapped into the potential of narrowly focused technology ETFs.First Trust Dow Jones Internet (FDN) soared 22% in 2015.KraneShares CSI China Internet (KWEB) jumped 18%.FDN has massive stakes in IBD Leaderboard stocks Alphabet (GOOGL), Facebook (FB) and Amazon (AMZN).Online retailer Amazon was a standout stock of 2015, more than doubling in price as it reinvents itself as a powerhouse in cloud computing and on-demand video streaming.Meanwhile, KWEB holds Chinese giants Alibaba (BABA), Baidu (BIDU) and JD.com (JD).The ETF also has smaller companies with stellar IBD ratings such as NetEase (NTES), Qihoo 360 (QIHU) and TAL Education (XRS).Investors did much better with large-cap ETFs last year than with small-cap peers.Several winners are "smart beta" ETFs, which aim to outperform traditional benchmarks.Among them, iShares MSCI USA Momentum Factor (MTUM), iShares MSCI USA Quality Factor (QUAL) and iShares MSCI USA Minimum Volatility (USMV) withstood a choppy and challenging year for the stock market.The trio leaped 9%, 6% and 6%, respectively.By comparison, traditional, cap-weighted ETFs tracking the S&P 500 index advanced 1%.International ETFs got beat up in 2015.The iShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), holding developed market stocks, shed 1%. The iShares Emerging Markets (EEM) sank 16%.Outlook And PositioningExpect smart beta products to continue to find their way into investors' ETF strategies in 2016.A recent BlackRock (BLK) iShares report on institutional investors' use of ETFs found 19% of respondents were likely to use smart beta ETFs this year.Only 10% reported allocating to the asset class in 2015.Volatility was the main concern for investors, the report found.Smart beta ETFs can be an effective way to manage volatility, says Heidi Richardson, head of U.S. investment strategy for iShares.These strategies rejigger the traditional rules of index investing to boost returns or reduce risk.Rather than weighting holdings by market capitalization, smart beta ETFs select and weight stocks using alternative methods.For example, iShares MSCI USA Minimum Volatility ETF holds stocks with less downside risk.And iShares MSCI Quality Factor ETF aims to enhance returns — it holds U.S. stocks with high return on equity, stable earnings growth and low levels of debt.Investors could "pair the two" for better risk-adjusted returns, while getting broad exposure to the U.S. stock market, Richardson told IBD in a phone call.In contrast, an S&P 500-tracking ETF would match the returns of the broad market with the same amount of volatility.The iShares report also found investors are using ETFs in almost equal measure for tactical bets and strategic allocations.An ETF such as iShares Core S&P 500 (IVV) could serve as the foundation of one's portfolio, Richardson said.IVV basically replicates the broad market for a razor-thin 0.07% expense ratio. That's $7 in annual fees for every $10,000 invested.Then investors could get more tactical with ETFs, Richardson added.With interest rates set to rise in steps in 2016, cyclical sectors such as financial services and technology may hold better opportunities.Many tech companies, such as Apple (AAPL), are flush with cash. As a result, they are less vulnerable to increasing rates than, say, debt-loaded utilities.They can continue to roll out shareholder-friendly M&As, share buybacks and dividends.Unlike some peers, iShares U.S. Technology (IYW) is a pure-play technology ETF with almost no exposure to indebted telecom firms.Financial firms such as Wells Fargo (WFC) also benefit from rising rates. They're able to charge clients more on loans, boosting net interest margins.Investors could also consider overweighting positions in Japan and Europe as those countries stimulate their economies, Richardson said."You can make an active decision about where the market is going to go to generate alpha," she added.Fixed-income investors may want to consider defined maturity bond ETFs, short duration ETFs and bond-laddering ETF investing strategies."They hold attractive opportunities" in a rising rate environment if you can live with some volatility, Bill Belden, managing director at Guggenheim Investments, said during a Dec. 18 media call.

Warren Buffett is called the Oracle of Omaha for a reason — so it's always interesting to take a close look at his holdings. Many of the stocks he owns pay a dividend, and some make IBD's Dividend Leaders screen as well. Here are five Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA) holdings that make the cut. All pay yields above the S&P; 500's 2.08% average.

AT&T; (T), with a 5.5% annualized yield, topped IBD's Dividend Leaders in Wednesday's issue. The telecom services giant made up 1.5% of Buffett's portfolio in Q3. He acquired shares when DirecTV was bought by AT&T; in July. AT&T; has retaken its 10-week and 40-week moving average lines as it shapes a potential new base.

Verizon Communications (VZ), a smaller position at 0.5%, offers a 5% annual yield. Shares have been moving sideways-to-lower much of the year. They're slightly underwater for the year and about 8% off a 52-week high.

Procter & Gamble (PG), which pays a 3.3% dividend, accounted for nearly 3% of Buffett's Q3 holdings. The consumer products maker, like AT&T;, is an S&P; 500 Dividend Aristocrat, companies that have raised their dividends every year for 25 consecutive years. The stock has been consolidating for most of the year.

Fellow Dividend Aristocrat Coca-Cola (KO) offers a 3.1% annualized yield. The beverage giant, at 12.6%, was one of Berkshire Hathaway's top-five holdings. The stock, up about 4% year to date, is slightly ahead of the overall market. Coca-Cola's three-year Earnings Stability Factor is the best of the five stocks: 1 on a scale from 0 (most stable) to 99 (least stable).

Wells Fargo (WFC), was Buffett's biggest Q3 holding , at 19%. The top-five holdings made up more than two-thirds of his portfolio. The San Francisco-based bank pays a 2.7% annual dividend. Shares have been consolidating since July and recently retook the 10-week and 40-week lines. They're up 2% this year.

Wells Fargo (WFC) warned of "stresses" in the bank's energy portfolio, while its energy unit took over Cubic Energy (CBNR), which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

San Francisco-based Wells Fargo has been in contact with clients about reducing their borrowing limits and saving cash, Kyle Hranicky, Wells' head of corporate banking told the Financial Times. Although some of the bank's clients have the liquidity to survive the current downturn, others may be forced to sell off assets or recapitalize under significant economic pressure, Hranicky said.
"We've been in the energy business for over 30 years, so we're comfortable with cycles," he told FT. "But this one feels deeper and broader and could last longer."

Since the summer of 2014, oil prices have been falling by about two-thirds to under $36 a barrel, hitting seven-year lows. While overall loans at banks are in decent shape, last month the Federal Reserve, Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., and Office of the Comptroller of the Currency warned that loans in danger of default to the energy sector had ballooned to $34.2 billion this year compared with $6.9 billion in 2014.

The high-yield bond market also faces stresses, in part due to concerns about junk-rated energy and materials firms reeling from low prices. The SPDR Barclays High Yield Bond ETF (JNK) fell 1% near midday after tumbling 2% to a 6-year low on Friday.

Meanwhile, Dallas-based Cubic Energy filed for bankruptcy protection in federal bankruptcy court in Wilmington, Del., blaming its problems on low oil prices and operational problems. Shares in the company will be canceled. Cubic also said that it reached a deal with its lenders by which it will hand over control of the company to Wells Fargo Energy Capital.

Wells Fargo shares fell 0.8% to 52.88 on the stock market today. Wells has been trading below its 50- and 200-day moving averages since last week. The bank currently has an IBD Composite Rating of 61 out of 99, meaning it trades better than 61% of other publicly traded companies. Wells shares have fallen 3.5% so far this year.

Nicole Bennett wanted to pull cash out of her house in Antioch, Calif., to reduce a growing mound of debt. When Bennett's mortgage lender, Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC), refused the social worker because her credit score was too low, she turned to a technology startup called Point Digital Finance.

In October, Bennett got the almost $40,000 she needed to pay down debt that was costing her more than $1,900 a month in car, personal-loan and credit-card payments. In return, Palo Alto, Calif.-based Point — which is backed by investors including Greylock Partners, Andreessen Horowitz and Vikram Pandit, the former chief executive officer of Citigroup Inc. (C) — wanted to own a piece of her property.

"I have all this equity in my house, but I couldn't use it because of my credit score," said Bennett, whose FICO score was less than 600, on a scale of 300 to 850. "I can breathe now because all my money isn't going out the door."

Financing to homeowners is loosening up after a 30% increase in property values nationally since the 2012 trough. While many lenders have been letting the most credit-worthy borrowers tap their homes' equity, Point is targeting customers who have been largely unable to trade accumulated wealth for cash or don't want to take on the additional monthly payments associated with traditional loan s.

In the years leading up to the real estate crash, easy financing helped people buy homes they couldn't afford and then borrow against their equity as property prices rose. The collapse in home values ripped through banks that bought mortgage securities, helping trigger the U.S. recession. At Citigroup, CEO Charles O. "Chuck" Prince was ousted in 2007 in the face of mounting losses tied to subprime mortgages and replaced by Pandit, who himself left three years ago.

Since home prices bottomed in 2012, banks have reduced the percentage of cash that borrowers can take out when refinancing and tightened credit standards for home-equity lines of credit, HELOCs — requiring higher FICO scores and full documentation.

A typical HELOC is a second mortgage, repaid monthly with interest, that homeowners can use in full or draw on as needed. Point is making an investment in the form of equity, so customers have no obligation to pay the firm back until they sell or refinance their homes, for as long as a decade.
That type of funding could ultimately cause financial issues for the homeowner, said Sarah Edelman, director of housing policy at the Center for American Progress.
The Risk For Consumers

"While it may be appealing to get an upfront lump sum of cash, the risk here appears to be that a consumer could end up with a more expensive product with harsher repayment terms than they would with a more conventional loan," said Edelman, whose Washington-based policy institute promotes economic mobility.

Many Americans with high debt-to-income ratios and low credit scores have limited financing options. For personal loans, both LendingClub (LC) and Prosper Marketplace customers have average credit scores of 700 or above. And the traditional home-equity lending market has been open primarily to borrowers with good credit.

"The home-equity market is still very restrictive," said Greg McBride, senior financial analyst for personal-finance data provider Bankrate (RATE), adding that FICO scores are a key factor in determining whether a person qualifies for financing. "It starts getting tougher below 680. Below 620 it is both really hard and really expensive."

With Point, credit scores can be less than 620, but homeowners must have at least 25% to 30% equity in their houses. Point adjusts the cost of its investment based on the owner and the property, taking a larger percentage of price appreciation from riskier customers. Should the homeowner not pay Point, the firm has the right to sell the home to recoup its investment and take its portion of the gains.

Those deciding not to sell their homes have to pay Point back at the end of the 10-year period, similar to a loan, with an annual effective interest rate that's capped at about 15%, comparable to rates on some credit cards or unsecured consumer debt. Annual rates at LendingClub range from 5.32% to almost 30% on three-year personal loans.
Selective About Properties

Point is investing in properties it expects to appreciate in value, initially focusing on California, with plans to fund homeowners in other states next year, according to a company marketing document. Home prices nationally are set to rise about 5.5% this year and may increase an additional 5.9% in 2016, according to CoreLogic (CLGX).

"If your home does well, we both do well," Point CEO Eddie Lim, who previously co-founded a payments platform acquired by Visa (V), said in an interview. "If your home doesn't do that well, then this was one of the cheapest sources of financing that you could have obtained."

For investors, the firm is trying to unlock some of the equity in residential real estate and make it a more liquid asset class that can be traded, Lim said. He's raised money from investors — separate from the company's venture-capital backers — to fund the equity products. The firm already is selling them to family offices and hedge funds that buy residential-mortgage bonds and has plans to securitize them as well.
Seeking Financial Stability

Part of Point's plan is to improve the financial stability of its customers because the firm transfers funds directly to pay off their debts, according to the marketing document. Other backers of the company, which Lim started in January, include Ribbit Capital, SV Angel and Bloomberg Beta, the venture-capital arm of Bloomberg LP, the parent company of Bloomberg News.

Point's customers, aside from Bennett, include homeowners such as an Apple (AAPL) employee who makes $128,700 a year and owns a Mountain View, Calif., house appraised at $1.38 million, according to the firm's marketing document. The logistics program manager, who owes about $715,525 on the property and has a credit score of 644, wanted $85,000 from Point to pay off debt from home renovations, the document shows.

In addition to Point, two firms — San Diego-based EquityKey Services and San Francisco-based FirstREX Agreement — are back in the equity-sharing business after they stopped doing deals when property values collapsed.

Restrictive lending standards are driving investors to come up with more creative solutions for people to leverage home equity, said Daren Blomquist, vice president of RealtyTrac. Firms like Point operate with less oversight than banks and other lenders, because they're offering products that are structured as equity rather than debt.Nicole Bennett wanted to pull cash out of her house in Antioch, Calif., to reduce a growing mound of debt. When Bennett's mortgage lender, Wells Fargo & Co. (WFC), refused the social worker because her credit score was too low, she turned to a technology startup called Point Digital Finance.In October, Bennett got the almost $40,000 she needed to pay down debt that was costing her more than $1,900 a month in car, personal-loan and credit-card payments. In return, Palo Alto, Calif.-based Point — which is backed by investors including Greylock Partners, Andreessen Horowitz and Vikram Pandit, the former chief executive officer of Citigroup Inc. (C) — wanted to own a piece of her property."I have all this equity in my house, but I couldn't use it because of my credit score," said Bennett, whose FICO score was less than 600, on a scale of 300 to 850. "I can breathe now because all my money isn't going out the door."Financing to homeowners is loosening up after a 30% increase in property values nationally since the 2012 trough. While many lenders have been letting the most credit-worthy borrowers tap their homes' equity, Point is targeting customers who have been largely unable to trade accumulated wealth for cash or don't want to take on the additional monthly payments associated with traditional loan s.In the years leading up to the real estate crash, easy financing helped people buy homes they couldn't afford and then borrow against their equity as property prices rose. The collapse in home values ripped through banks that bought mortgage securities, helping trigger the U.S. recession. At Citigroup, CEO Charles O. "Chuck" Prince was ousted in 2007 in the face of mounting losses tied to subprime mortgages and replaced by Pandit, who himself left three years ago.Since home prices bottomed in 2012, banks have reduced the percentage of cash that borrowers can take out when refinancing and tightened credit standards for home-equity lines of credit, HELOCs — requiring higher FICO scores and full documentation.A typical HELOC is a second mortgage, repaid monthly with interest, that homeowners can use in full or draw on as needed. Point is making an investment in the form of equity, so customers have no obligation to pay the firm back until they sell or refinance their homes, for as long as a decade.That type of funding could ultimately cause financial issues for the homeowner, said Sarah Edelman, director of housing policy at the Center for American Progress.The Risk For Consumers"While it may be appealing to get an upfront lump sum of cash, the risk here appears to be that a consumer could end up with a more expensive product with harsher repayment terms than they would with a more conventional loan," said Edelman, whose Washington-based policy institute promotes economic mobility.Many Americans with high debt-to-income ratios and low credit scores have limited financing options. For personal loans, both LendingClub (LC) and Prosper Marketplace customers have average credit scores of 700 or above. And the traditional home-equity lending market has been open primarily to borrowers with good credit."The home-equity market is still very restrictive," said Greg McBride, senior financial analyst for personal-finance data provider Bankrate (RATE), adding that FICO scores are a key factor in determining whether a person qualifies for financing. "It starts getting tougher below 680. Below 620 it is both really hard and really expensive."With Point, credit scores can be less than 620, but homeowners must have at least 25% to 30% equity in their houses. Point adjusts the cost of its investment based on the owner and the property, taking a larger percentage of price appreciation from riskier customers. Should the homeowner not pay Point, the firm has the right to sell the home to recoup its investment and take its portion of the gains.Those deciding not to sell their homes have to pay Point back at the end of the 10-year period, similar to a loan, with an annual effective interest rate that's capped at about 15%, comparable to rates on some credit cards or unsecured consumer debt. Annual rates at LendingClub range from 5.32% to almost 30% on three-year personal loans.Selective About PropertiesPoint is investing in properties it expects to appreciate in value, initially focusing on California, with plans to fund homeowners in other states next year, according to a company marketing document. Home prices nationally are set to rise about 5.5% this year and may increase an additional 5.9% in 2016, according to CoreLogic (CLGX)."If your home does well, we both do well," Point CEO Eddie Lim, who previously co-founded a payments platform acquired by Visa (V), said in an interview. "If your home doesn't do that well, then this was one of the cheapest sources of financing that you could have obtained."For investors, the firm is trying to unlock some of the equity in residential real estate and make it a more liquid asset class that can be traded, Lim said. He's raised money from investors — separate from the company's venture-capital backers — to fund the equity products. The firm already is selling them to family offices and hedge funds that buy residential-mortgage bonds and has plans to securitize them as well.Seeking Financial StabilityPart of Point's plan is to improve the financial stability of its customers because the firm transfers funds directly to pay off their debts, according to the marketing document. Other backers of the company, which Lim started in January, include Ribbit Capital, SV Angel and Bloomberg Beta, the venture-capital arm of Bloomberg LP, the parent company of Bloomberg News.Point's customers, aside from Bennett, include homeowners such as an Apple (AAPL) employee who makes $128,700 a year and owns a Mountain View, Calif., house appraised at $1.38 million, according to the firm's marketing document. The logistics program manager, who owes about $715,525 on the property and has a credit score of 644, wanted $85,000 from Point to pay off debt from home renovations, the document shows.In addition to Point, two firms — San Diego-based EquityKey Services and San Francisco-based FirstREX Agreement — are back in the equity-sharing business after they stopped doing deals when property values collapsed.Restrictive lending standards are driving investors to come up with more creative solutions for people to leverage home equity, said Daren Blomquist, vice president of RealtyTrac. Firms like Point operate with less oversight than banks and other lenders, because they're offering products that are structured as equity rather than debt.

It's widely expected that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates at its next meeting, scheduled for Dec. 15-16. It would be the first rate hike since 2006.Banks, who've endured near-zero rates since the height of the financial crisis in December 2008 are expected to benefit. Higher interest rates will allow them to expand their margins.In terms of getting in on the action early during this holiday season, investors may be behooved to look at the following IBD 50 stocks:This bank has a Signature brandSignature Bank (SBNY), based in New York City, has notched at least 19 consecutive quarters of double-digit earnings and revenue growth. Record deposit and loan growth were cited in its Q3 results.The bank's total assets were $31.9 billion as of Sept. 30. Its Composite Rating is 98. Its Composite Rating is 99.Noah seeing no arc to its growthWealth management firm Noah Holdings (NOAH) serves wealthy clients in China, who may already be shifting assets ahead of the expected U.S. rate increase. The provider of fixed income, private equity and securities investment products has posted 13 straight quarters of EPS and revenue growth. Its stock has risen nearly 50% this year and its IBD Composite Rating is a solid 96.This company's stock is SterlingSterling Bancorporation (STL) has posted double-digit earnings growth for six straight quarters and 15 consecutive quarters of revenue growth. Its total assets were $11.6 billion as of Sept. 30. The Montebello, N.Y.-based bank's shares have gained 20% this year. Its Composite Rating is 98.Big banks should gain tooWhile U.S. banking giants aren't on the IBD 50, JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Wells Fargo (WFC), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) have patiently waited for the Fed to make its move, and their shares have rallied steadily since late September.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter @IBD_CMcEvoy and on Facebook.
