On a recent afternoon in Prince George's County, Md., a bleak economic trend met a tantalizing investment thesis. Inside the community center at the Regency Pointe Apartments, a complex of 599 units set in low-slung buildings about 20 minutes from Washington, D.C., nurses from a nearby medical clinic were screening residents for cholesterol and high blood pressure.Just outside, a Zumba instructor was leading two dozen neighborhood children in an exercise class. A uniformed Sheriff's Department officer looked on, chatting with residents and tracking police radio reports that a suspect wielding an AR-15 assault rifle was wandering nearby streets.It's part of an effort by Turner Impact Capital, which acquired the property in June, to make money for investors while keeping rents stable for low-income residents. At Regency Pointe, the typical renter earns less than 80% of the area median income, and the average two-bedroom unit costs less than $1,200 a month.Since launching the Santa Monica, Calif., firm last year, Bobby Turner has used a two-pronged appeal as he seeks to raise $300 million to sink into affordable housing, from investors including the University of Michigan endowment and Citi Community Capital, which invests in community development for Citigroup.The pitch: The fund will help fill a pressing need to preserve affordable apartments in places like Prince George's County, where 4 out of 10 renters spend more than 35% of their income on rent. At the same time, it will target returns of 10% to 12%.That's a far more modest return than what investors look for in traditional real estate funds, which can shoot for 20% or so, but Turner says it can be a hedge against higher-yielding investments. Luxury construction projects typically need a rising economic tide to lift affluent renters or condo buyers into increasingly expensive apartments — and get hit hardest when the economy sours. Turner's model doesn't depend on that tide. Because there's a shortage of housing affordable to poor and working-class renters, the theory goes, landlords committed to keeping rents cheap won't have to lower them in a bad economy."The vast majority of real estate investors are speculators, hoping someone will patronize stores or buy their condos," he said. "Social impact is not speculating."Turner, 52, said he began to see the social potential of real estate investing in the 1990s when he was part of a group of investors that bought a former wire factory in New York City's East Harlem neighborhood and transformed it into a shopping mall. Later, he raised $2 billion with basketball Hall of Famer Magic Johnson to invest in inner-city real estate projects. In 2013, he left Canyon Capital Realty Advisors, where he had overseen a $12 billion real estate portfolio, to focus on social impact investing, which he said offers a better way to create change than pure philanthropy.'Emerging Middle Ground'In addition to rental apartments, Turner Impact is set up to invest in health care facilities in underserved areas and is seeking to raise $400 million to invest in charter schools with retired tennis star Andre Agassi.That model places the firm among a group of 16 leading social impact real estate investors that have launched funds aiming to raise more than $3 billion. They have already acquired, rehabilitated or developed more than 60,000 apartments for poor and working-class tenants, according to a forthcoming report from the Urban Land Institute (ULI), a nonprofit research group. They include below-market debt funds, which offer low-cost loans to entice property owners to keep rents low, and real estate investment trusts seeded by charitable foundations, as well as private equity funds like Turner."There is this emerging middle ground between traditional subsidized and market-rate housing," said Stockton Williams, the author of the ULI report. "These are investors who see an economic rationale for keeping apartments affordable for blue- collar tenants."One such equity fund, Irvine, Calif.-based Avanath Capital Management, specializes in rent-regulated apartments whose construction was funded by the U.S. government's Low Income Housing Tax Credit program.By contrast, Turner is aiming to preserve what the industry calls naturally occurring affordable housing — cheap rentals that are cheap because of where they're located or how they were built, not because of government subsidy programs. Which makes him sound like an environmental activist.Good Returns, Positive ChangeSixty thousand units is a drop in the bucket, with 11.8 million U.S. households currently spending more than half of their income on rent, according to a recent estimate by the Harvard Joint Center for Housing Studies. And the rent squeeze could get even worse, given projections for increased renter demand. The supply of affordable housing could take another hit, with 400,000 government-subsidized rental units eligible to be converted to market-rate rentals or condominiums by the end of 2017.A group of 146 investors surveyed by JPMorgan Chase (JPM) expects to allocate $12.2 billion to impact investment funds this year, up 16% from last year. Since the recession, banks have shown interest in funds dedicated to preserving affordable housing as a way of meeting their obligations under the federal Community Reinvestment Act."These funds are producing good returns, doing it in a way that's having a positive impact," said Tim Rafalovich, a senior vice president at Wells Fargo (WFC), who manages about $60 million of investments in private equity vehicles that preserve affordable housing. "We'd like to deploy more, but there's not as many funds as we'd like to see on the market."As these funds seek to expand, here's one big challenge: The same rising rents driving them to keep units affordable are also attracting interest from more traditional real estate funds, which seek to buy, renovate, and jack up rents."How do we continue to compete with the conventional acquirer?" asked Chris Herrmann, who manages a $35 million fund for Enterprise Community Investment, which seeks 7% returns for its investors in properties that are affordable to renters earning less than 80% of the area median income.Increasing The AppealThat's where the health screenings and fitness classes come in. To goose returns, Turner is making small investments to make the complex a more appealing place to live, sponsoring community activities and offering free and reduced rents to teachers, nurses and police officers — who are in turn expected to organize services like a neighborhood watch or tutoring sessions."If you do that, you dissuade gangbangers, prostitutes and drug dealers from doing business on your property," he said. By offering free or reduced rent on 3% of units, he thinks that he can increase profit margins by 15% to 20%.Like everything about the model, it's easier said than done. Raymond Appling, 47, said he's been through six ownerships during two decades living at Regency Pointe."The new owners always come in making promises," he said, as his son and daughter talked with friends at a recent community fair. "If they can build on this, that will be a good start."

The prospect of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike does have a bright side in some circles of the economy, as it has helped propel regional banks to rank among the stock market's best performers in recent weeks.Of the 197 industries tracked by Investor's Business Daily, 4 of the 13 highest-rated are regional banking groups from the Southeast, Midwest, West/Southwest and Northeast. Along with the prospect of a rate hike, these banks have also benefited from a strong commercial loan environment in many parts of the country.Among stocks, leaders include Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK), Home Bancshares (HOMB), First Citizens Bancshares (FCNCA), PrivateBancorp (PVTB), Signature Bank (SBNY) and PacWest Bancorp (PACW).With rising share prices and strong financial growth in recent quarters, these firms thrived even before chatter arose that the Fed will raise interest rates this month after years of keeping rates near zero to bolster the economy. If the Fed does raise rates, regional banks should get an additional lift.Feeling The Fed MoreSmaller banks tend to benefit more from higher rates than industry giants like Bank of America (BAC), Wells Fargo (WFC), Citigroup (C) and JPMorgan (JPM), analysts say. The reason is regional banks rely more on spread income — the difference between assets such as loans and securities and the cost of deposits and other funds — than big banks, which have a bigger focus on trading and investment banking."Depending on how their balance sheets are structured, they could see more of a benefit from changes in margins and changes in interest rates," Keefe, Bruyette & Woods analyst Brian Zabora told IBD.D.A. Davidson analyst Gary Tenner agrees regional banking groups have moved higher on expectations of an interest rate hike."There's an expectation that it could occur in December, and that it will be a gradual and moderate pace of increase," Tenner told IBD. "It's not a huge tailwind, but the current market psychology around banks has certainly been a positive."Economy TiesAnother positive is that regional banks are more tied to the U.S. economy than large international players like BofA and Citigroup, which have much more exposure to the global economy. The relative strength of the U.S. economy vs. other countries partly explains why regional banks are doing better financially than large banks.Most of the big players have struggled to produce consistent revenue and earnings growth. In contrast, top regional banks have strung together at least a couple years' worth of double-digit revenue and earnings growth.Financial results have been particularly robust in regions of the country where commercial lending and housing are strong. Tenner's coverage universe stretches mainly from Texas to California, where he says net loan growth has been strong for a couple of years."The growth has predominately been in commercial real estate," Tenner said. "Multifamily lending has been a particularly strong driver in California."Single-family home loans have been another growth catalyst for regional banks in certain areas of the country, Zabora says."It really depends on the region," he said. "In Southern California, regional banks have shown good loan growth. Bank of the Ozarks has a national lending platform, and that's been a nice source of strong loan growth for them. (Arkansas-based) Home BancShares did a lot of acquisitions in Florida, where there's some construction going on and commercial activity is better than it was a couple years ago."Acquisitions have been a big part of the growth story for many regional banks. Home BancShares, parent of Centennial Bank, now has 56 branches in Florida, thanks to an aggressive buyout program there.Bank of the Ozarks has made more than a dozen acquisitions over the past five years to extend its reach, particularly in the Southeast. Its latest buyout came in October, when it announced plans to acquire Atlanta-based Community & Southern Holdings and its wholly-owned bank subsidiary, Community & Southern Bank, for around $800 million.Also in October, PacWest finalized its $850 million buyout of Square 1 Financial, a North Carolina-based banking company with a heavy focus on venture capital loans used to finance tech startups.Even with those and other deals, 2015 hasn't been an especially busy year for mergers and acquisitions in the banking industry, Tenner says."M&A activity has been fairly steady the last few years," he said. "You generally see anywhere from 230 to 250 M&A transactions per year within the bank space, and I don't know that it's deviated much from that year to date."He doesn't see a big change in 2016 either, in terms of the number of deals. But there is one thing that's different about the current round of deals."M&A valuations have picked up from what they were a couple years ago, so that might play a part in some of the rising stock valuations we've seen," Tenner said.

With U.S. companies headed for a record year of share repurchases, experts are split over whether buybacks are the logical result of excess capital, or if they come at the expense of growth initiatives.
A number of high-profile companies have implemented aggressive buyback programs in recent quarters, spanning all sectors of the economy.

They include tech giants such as Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT), health care leaders like Express Scripts (ESRX) and AbbVie (ABBV), manufacturers like Boeing (BA) and General Motors (GM), financial leaders like Wells Fargo (WFC), and consumer stocks such as Nike (NKE) and Wendy's (WEN).
Nike announced a $12 billion buyback program on Thursday, along with a 14% dividend hike.
Apple bought back $36 billion in shares in fiscal 2015 after buying $45 billion in stock in 2014.
Not surprisingly, buybacks have become the focus of intense media coverage in recent weeks.

Critics say more of that money should be reinvested into research and development initiatives as well as new products, technologies and services. This would contribute to long-term growth and feed economic expansion, they say. Critics also say that executives use buybacks to flatter financial results.
But defenders say returning money to shareholders is a good use of money that's left over after capital has already been allocated to normal business expenses.

In today's environment, many companies are "still left with a large amount of excess capital," even after investing in growth initiatives, said Michael Arone, chief investment strategist for State Street Global Advisors' U.S. Intermediary Business Group.
"They are choosing to redeploy the money to investors," he told IBD. "When done the right way, buybacks are a good capital allocation. There are a lot of misperceptions around share buybacks."
Record Buyback Pace
What's certain is this: A whole lot of money is going toward buybacks and dividends lately.
The total dollar amount of dividends and stock buybacks is on track to reach a new high this year and could soar above $1 trillion for the first time, according to industry estimates.

The percentage of operating cash flow used to buy back shares is at its highest level since 2007, Arone says. He calls that a "watershed year" for buybacks. That was also just before the U.S. fell into a sharp recession and bear market.

"Some look at 2007 as a kind of peak year," he said. "This year's percentage of operating cash flow used for buybacks is still below 2007. But (2015) would be the largest year of all time in absolute dollar terms."
A recent investigative report from Reuters noted that nearly 60% of the 3,297 publicly traded non-financial U.S. companies it examined have bought back shares since 2010.

In fiscal 2014, spending on buybacks and dividends surpassed the companies' combined net income for the first time outside of a recessionary period, Reuters said. Spending kept climbing higher for the 613 companies that have already reported for fiscal 2015. That suggests that corporations are relying more heavily on cheap interest rates to use debt to fund buybacks and dividends.

FactSet Research reports that 75% of all companies in the S&P 500 bought back shares and paid dividends in the trailing 12 months at the end of the second quarter, the most recent data available. About $555 billion was spent by S&P 500 firms on share repurchases in the same period.
The information technology sector spent the most money on buybacks in the second quarter, FactSet said, led by Apple, Microsoft, Qualcomm (QCOM) and Oracle (ORCL).
Meanwhile, U.S. companies issued $107.9 billion in dividends during Q3. That was up 23% from Q2 and established a new record, according to data from Henderson Global Investors.
Why is all this money going toward buybacks and dividends?
The most basic answer is that the money is there, and something has to be done with it.
"You have low interest rates and record profits," Arone said. "This has resulted in corporations at peak levels in terms of having a lot of cash on hand."

In some cases, activist investors are pressuring companies to reward investors with that money, analysts say. In others, executives are simply gun-shy about investing in products and services that might not pay off over the long term.
Another reason some companies are buying back outstanding shares is that doing so fattens up per-share earnings.
Innovation Shortchanged?
The worry in some quarters is that buybacks come at the expense of product development, innovation and long-term growth.

"The U.S. is behind on production of everything from flat-panel TVs to semiconductors and solar photovoltaic cells," Gary Pisano, a professor at Harvard Business School, told Reuters. He's also the author of "Producing Prosperity: Why America Needs a Manufacturing Renaissance."

Reuters reported that among the 1,000 or so firms it tracked that buy back shares and report R&D spending, the share of net income spent on innovation has averaged less than 50% since 2009. That com pares to over 60% during the 1990s.

But not all data show such a grim view, Arone said. "There's a bunch of data showing R&D growing at its fastest level in 50 years. There's this misperception that companies are not reinvesting or spending on business growth. But many companies do continue to reinvest in their businesses."
He also says that while buybacks can boost a company's EPS, research from S&P Dow Jones Indices shows that on a weighted basis, recent S&P 500 EPS gains "are built on profits — not buybacks."

A recent report from Deutsche Bank found that S&P 500 per-share profits since 2012 have risen by 6.2% annually on average, of which just 1.6 percentage points are from buybacks. That fell to 1.2 points in Q3.
Misperceptions about buybacks are due to a couple of factors, Arone says.

"Global economic growth has been sluggish, and therefore folks equate that sluggishness with a lack of business investment," he said. "There's also been a lack of any meaningful wage growth. There's this view that we would be accelerating much more quickly had businesses been investing more, but I'm not convinced that's accurate."
If economic growth is sluggish, the return on capital may be low, so returning cash to shareholders may be a sound decision.
That's not to say there aren't cases where companies issue buybacks and dividends at their detriment.

"If a company is borrowing aggressively or levering its balance sheet to buy back stock, that is not necessarily a good strategy," Arone said. "Or if a company buys back its stock to offset the dilutive effects of stock-based compensation of employees, that's not a good strategy, either."

But those are the exceptions rather than the rule, he said. "To say that's what's happening broadly is, in my mind, an exaggeration."With U.S. companies headed for a record year of share repurchases, experts are split over whether buybacks are the logical result of excess capital, or if they come at the expense of growth initiatives.A number of high-profile companies have implemented aggressive buyback programs in recent quarters, spanning all sectors of the economy.They include tech giants such as Apple (AAPL) and Microsoft (MSFT), health care leaders like Express Scripts (ESRX) and AbbVie (ABBV), manufacturers like Boeing (BA) and General Motors (GM), financial leaders like Wells Fargo (WFC), and consumer stocks such as Nike (NKE) and Wendy's (WEN).Nike announced a $12 billion buyback program on Thursday, along with a 14% dividend hike.Apple bought back $36 billion in shares in fiscal 2015 after buying $45 billion in stock in 2014.Not surprisingly, buybacks have become the focus of intense media coverage in recent weeks.Critics say more of that money should be reinvested into research and development initiatives as well as new products, technologies and services. That fell to 1.2 points in Q3.Misperceptions about buybacks are due to a couple of factors, Arone says."Global economic growth has been sluggish, and therefore folks equate that sluggishness with a lack of business investment," he said. "There's also been a lack of any meaningful wage growth. There's this view that we would be accelerating much more quickly had businesses been investing more, but I'm not convinced that's accurate."If economic growth is sluggish, the return on capital may be low, so returning cash to shareholders may be a sound decision.That's not to say there aren't cases where companies issue buybacks and dividends at their detriment."If a company is borrowing aggressively or levering its balance sheet to buy back stock, that is not necessarily a good strategy," Arone said. "Or if a company buys back its stock to offset the dilutive effects of stock-based compensation of employees, that's not a good strategy, either."But those are the exceptions rather than the rule, he said. "To say that's what's happening broadly is, in my mind, an exaggeration."

Stocks lost their grip on most of the day's gains Thursday as the indexes headed into the final hour of trade. The Nasdaq was up 0.3%, after being up 1.5% at midday. The S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average held pops of 0.7% and 0.9%, respectively. Volume in the stock market today was running much slower than the previous session.Among widely held issues, AT&T (T) thrust about 2% higher in volume 55% above average. While the Nasdaq and S&P 500 are down about 10% and 8% respectively so far this year, AT&T has held steady with a 1% gain.AT&T's dividend might be part of the reason. In an ugly market, dividend stocks start looking good to some investors. AT&T has increased its dividend for 32 consecutive years. The current annualized yield is 5.6%.The stock price, though, has been rangebound for more than two years. AT&T stock has found repeated resistance at the 36-37 area and support at the 31-32 level. The stock is trading just under 35.In the IBD 50, a list of stocks with the best ratings via fundamentals and technicals, Carter's (CRI) gained 1% in volume a third faster than normal. The marketer of clothes for babies and children is working on a stage-two base. However, the stock needs to do more work on the right side. Carter's is 17% off its high.A stage-two base means the stock is forming its second consolidation since starting an advance. Breakouts from the first two consolidations are more likely to work than those from a later stage.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, coal and oil stocks grabbed the biggest gains. Core inflation held just below the Federal Reserve's 2% target, while core services inflation crept up to the highest since 2008, the Labor Department reported Tuesday.
As energy stops being a drag on consumer prices, overall inflation likely will ramp up quickly, giving Fed policymakers reason to act soon.
Consumer prices rose 0.2% in October after two months of declines, as energy prices edged up 0.3%. Core consumer prices, which exclude food and energy, climbed 0.2% for a second straight month.
Higher interest rates should be good news for profits at Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo (WFC), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and more.

The overall consumer price index rose 0.2% vs. a year earlier after being flat in September. Core inflation remained at 1.9% for the second straight month, though it edged up fractionally for a fifth straight month.

Goods prices fell 3.4% vs. a year earlier, largely reflecting a 17.1% plunge in energy prices. But the over the next few months, that energy decline will likely moderate substantially, reflecting plunging crude oil costs in late 2014 to early 2015.
Meanwhile, services prices rose 2.4% vs. a year earlier, the most this year. Services inflation excluding energy crept up to 2.8%, the highest since November 2008.
With underlying inflation edging higher and energy deflation about to wind down, the Fed likely will see today's CPI report as another reason to begin raising interest rates at the December meeting.
As New York Fed President William Dudley said last week, "I don't favor waiting until I see the whites of inflation's eyes."

Bank of America, Citigroup, Wells Fargo and JPMorgan Chase have generally outperformed the overall market since the Fed's relatively hawkish statement on Oct. 28, followed by other Fed hints of a looming rate "liftoff." Higher rates should boost banks' net interest margins, the spread between their borrowing costs and their lending rates. BofA shares, Wells Fargo, Citigroup and JPMorgan all fell fractionally Tuesday.

Meanwhile, real hourly earnings rose 2.4% vs. a year earlier, the fourth straight month of acceleration and the highest since April. Nominal wage gains have picked up, but low inflation is the biggest reason for the solid real pay gain. That should support consumer spending. On the downside, as inflation picks up, real pay increases likely will moderate unless nominal wage gains accelerate.Core inflation held just below the Federal Reserve's 2% target, while core services inflation crept up to the highest since 2008, the Labor Department reported Tuesday. A few years makes a big difference. That's the key lesson — and the key benefit — in the latest annual retirement study by Wells Fargo (WFC).
The earlier you start, the easier it is to build a big retirement account.
But wait — you already knew that, you say? OK, but did you know how big of a benefit to your retirement planning it is to start as soon as possible?
Seeing how big the benefit is might give you the added motivation that you need to take advantage of key steps.
Wells Fargo found that the median savings of working Americans age 55 to 59 is $150,000.
That's three times greater than the median of $50,000 for workers who are age 60 or older.
How have the younger workers managed to save more even though they've been in the work force a shorter time?
They actually started to save earlier.
The younger workers started saving at age 31 on average. That's six years earlier than the older workers, who began at age 37 on average.
So the younger workers' savings have had six more years to mushroom, thanks to compound earnings growth. Compound growth is the key to their dramatically greater success as investors.
The bulk of assets in retirement accounts is in mutual funds.
The Wells Fargo study also casts a spotlight on another way to turbocharge your retirement nest egg: Sock away dough in your 401(k).
The benefit is clear in the dollars and cents.
People who have been saving for retirement since they started working and who have access to a 401(k) plan:
Have saved four times as much for retirement — a median nest egg of $200,000 — as workers who also started early, but have not had access to a 401(k).
Of those "consistent" savers with 401(k) access:
A big majority — 84% — feel more secure about their retirement.
More than 6 in 10, or 61%, say that they will be able to save enough through their 401(k) to live comfortably in retirement.

Among the reasons that 401(k) plans are helpful is because they automate workers' savings, many provide a company match, and workers tend to save a higher percentage of their pay when they use a 401(k) account than when they do not.
Wells Fargo is in the 401(k) business. It operates 3,598 defined contribution plans, which include 401(k) plans, with 3.3 million participants and a combined total of $213.3 billion in assets.

Stock futures signaled a flat-to-slightly weaker open Wednesday amid worries about China and an influx of corporate earnings. Nasdaq 100 futures edged up a fraction of a point vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures slipped a little more than a point. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 20 points.
Stocks took a breather Tuesday, with the Nasdaq closing back below its 50-day moving average.

Global stock markets were lower after the rate of consumer inflation in China cooled off more than expected. The Shanghai composite fell about 1%, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng lost 0.7%. Germany's DAX lost 0.5%, and France's CAC-40 was fractionally lower.

In earnings news, Bank of America (BAC) posted third-quarter earnings of 37 cents a share, topping views by 4 cents. Results were helped by sharply lower expenses, but trading revenue fell. Its shares rose 2% in premarket trading.
Wells Fargo (WFC) reported earnings of $1.05 a share, up from $1.02 a year ago. It topped views by a penny. But shares fell about 1% in premarket trading.

Late Tuesday, JPMorgan Chase (JPM), the nation's largest bank, posted Q3 earnings that missed expectations. Its shares were lower by more than 1% in Wednesday's premarket trading. Bank of The Ozarks (OZRK), a much smaller regional bank, also reported quarterly earnings below views.

Delta Air Lines (DAL) posted earnings of $1.74, up from $1.20 in the year-ago period, helped by lower fuel prices. It beat views by 3 cents. But revenue eased to $11.11 billion from $11.18 billion. Still, shares cruised up nearly 2% in premarket trading.

In economic news, producer prices fell 0.5% in September vs. views for a 0.2% decline. Retail sales edged up 0.1% in September, matching views. But excluding autos, sales fell 0.3% vs. expectations for a 0.1% dip.
Netflix (NFLX) and Xilinx (XLNX) will report earnings after the close in the stock market today.

Shares of General Electric (GE) moved lower Tuesday despite an analyst upgrade, while JetBlue Airways (JBLU) was one of several airlines to receive analyst downgrades ahead of third-quarter earnings reports.

William Blair upgraded General Electric to outperform from market perform with a 32 price target, citing upside potential from its Alstom energy-unit acquisition and data-analytics business, as well as the possibility of shares doubling to 60 by 2020.

GE reports Q3 earnings on Friday. The industrial conglomerate is expected to earn 26 cents a share, down 31.6% from a year earlier, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue is expected to slide 20.8% to $28.6 billion.

Also on Tuesday, GE confirmed that it agreed to sell its Commercial Distribution Finance business, its North American Vendor Finance unit and its Corporate Finance business to Wells Fargo (WFC). Terms weren't disclosed, but the assets are worth about $32 billion.
GE shares closed down 0.8% on the stock market today.

Spending trends on U.S. credit cards slowed in the third quarter from the prior quarter, while U.S. debit-card spending on the biggest cards picked up.Credit card spending growth for Visa (V), MasterCard (MA), Discover (DFS) and American Express (AXP) networks fell 30 basis points from Q2 to 8.4%, which analyst Robert Napoli of William Blair attributed to a 27% decline in fuel prices and soft retail sales.Meanwhile, combined debit spending volume rose 190 basis points from the prior quarter to a 5.5% gain, even with a 10.8% decline at Discover, which lost a sizable partner.Still, credit quality trends at card issuers, which include American Express and many of the largest banks, such as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C), are impressive, Napoli says, with record-low charge-offs and generally stable though slightly increasing delinquency rates. Visa and MasterCard do not issue credit."We believe credit quality could remain much better than average for the industry as a whole until at least 2017," Napoli said.American Express had the industry's lowest delinquency rate at 1%, followed by JPMorgan Chase at 1.38%, Citigroup at 1.54%, Discover at 1.65% and Bank of America at 1.71% — all below the industry's weighted average of 2.17%.Credit-card loan growth picked up slightly in the the quarter, with U.S. Bank (USB), American Express and Capital One Financial (COF) reporting positive and accelerating portfolio growth, especially compared to relatively weaker trends at Discover, Wells Fargo (WFC), JPMorgan, Bank of America and Citigroup."Credit standards are being slightly loosened, credit lines are being increased, the economic and employment environment is improving and the consumer leverage ratios seem to be forming a bottom," Napoli noted.Shares of JPMorgan, BofA, Citigroup all rose 2%-3% near the market close, also buoyed by hawkish Fed minutes. Visa, MasterCard and American Express rose about 1%-2%.
Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Wells Fargo (WFC) and other bank stocks were rallying Wednesday on hopes a rate hike could come in December.

The Federal Open Market Committee voted to keep its its zero interest rate policy on weak exports on a slow down in global economic growth from China and strong dollar and soft inflation. The Fed hasn't voted for a rate hike in nine years and but the market seemed to think a rate hike is a possibility in December.
The Fed said in a statement it would consider "in determining whether it will be appropriate to raise the target range at its next meeting."

A rate hike, even a small one, could boost banks' net interest margins by allowing them to lend at a higher rate. Bank of America, Citigroup, Wells and other banks' profit margins are squeezed when rates are kept low.
Bank of America shares climbed 5% to close at 17.28 in the stock market today. Wells Fargo shares closed up 2.5% to 55.45. Citi shares jumped 4% to 54.73. JPMorgan advanced 2.9% to 65.50
Citi, BofA and Wells Fargo all jumped above their 200-day lines. JPMorgan bounced higher after finding support at the 200-day line.

The Federal Reserve Board proposed long-awaited rules for reining in losses from institutions deemed "too big to fail." It requires the eight largest banks to raise a total of $120 billion in debt that could be converted into equity in a crisis.New guidelines, known as "total loss-absorbing capacity," or TLAC, will increase the amount of capital, defined as a combination of shareholder equity and debt, that large banks will need to have. Regulators believe that banks need bigger cushions in case of crises like the one in 2008 that required taxpayer bailouts.The Fed set the TLAC at a minimum 18% of risk-weighted assets. Banks affected by the rules will have until January 2022 to comply, although a months-long comment period will occur before the Fed issues a final rule.Some of the largest banks will need to have more capacity. JPMorgan Chase (JPM), the largest by assets, will see its ratio rise to 23.5%. Citigroup (C) will have a 21.5% minimum. Bank of America (BAC), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS) will have 20.5%, with Wells Fargo (WFC) at 18.5%.JPMorgan, Citigroup, Bank of America, Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and Wells Fargo stocks all fell 1%-2% Friday.

General Electric (GE) reached a major milestone in its efforts to scale down GE Capital by selling its $30 billion commercial lending and leasing unit to Wells Fargo (WFC). It's GE Capital's largest transaction to date and is expected to close during the first quarter of 2016. The portfolio of leases and loans is worth $32 billion in assets and…

General Electric (GE) signaled it may take on more debt to buy back shares, just a few weeks after Trian Fund Management took a 1% stake and urged such a move, though GE's M&A plans may clash with the activist investor's concerns.

The Fairfield, Conn.-based conglomerate also reported industrial operating earnings rose 16% to 29 cents a share, topping analyst estimates of 26 cents. Industrial segment operating margins jumped 100 basis points to 17.3%.

Revenue fell 22.7% to $27.9 billion, missing views of $28.6 billion, as revenue from the oil and gas unit tumbled 16% to $3.9 billion. But GE's power and water revenue rose 1% to $6.5 billion. Aviation revenue climbed 5% to $6 billion, transportation grew 3% to $1.6 billion, and appliances rose 8% to $2.3 billion.
Industrial backlog rose 5% to $270 billion, while orders tumbled 26% to $23.2 billion.
GE shares closed up 3.4% to 28.98 in the stock market today.

Earlier this month, Trian disclosed a $2.5 billion stake in GE, after acquiring 98.5 million shares. The fund, which is headed by Nelson Peltz, is largely onboard with GE's industrial focused strategy, but said it wants management "to deliver on its commitments."
Trian also wants GE to expand its margins, explore more share buybacks, be disciplined in its acquisitions and mull additional ways to consider scaling back GE Capital.
GE CFO Jeff Bornstein told the Financial Times Friday that the company is open to borrowing money to buy back shares.

Meanwhile, Bornstein told Bloomberg that GE is exploring up to $10 billion in dealmaking in order to boost its newly created digital unit. Whether that fits into Peltz's vision of more disciplined M&A remains to be seen.

The company has heeded the urging of investors as well as its own desire to avoid tougher federal financial regulations. This month, it sold $32 billion worth of assets in commercial lending and leasing to Wells Fargo (WFC). It has $126 billion in total signed deals to date, GE CEO Jeff Immelt said in a statement.

GE also is launching a share exchange to spin off Synchrony Financial (SYF), its consumer finance subsidiary, next week. The company plans to return $30 billion to shareholders next year via share buybacks and dividend payouts.
Synchrony shares finished down 3.7% to 30.15 Friday after reporting quarterly results. Wells Fargo shares edged up 0.4% to 52.88.

Industrial segment operating margins jumped 100 basis points to 17.3%.Revenue fell 22.7% to $27.9 billion, missing views of $28.6 billion, as revenue from the oil and gas unit tumbled 16% to $3.9 billion. But GE's power and water revenue rose 1% to $6.5 billion. Aviation revenue climbed 5% to $6 billion, transportation grew 3% to $1.6 billion, and appliances rose 8% to $2.3 billion.Industrial backlog rose 5% to $270 billion, while orders tumbled 26% to $23.2 billion.GE shares closed up 3.4% to 28.98 in the stock market today.Earlier this month, Trian disclosed a $2.5 billion stake in GE, after acquiring 98.5 million shares. The fund, which is headed by Nelson Peltz, is largely onboard with GE's industrial focused strategy, but said it wants management "to deliver on its commitments."Trian also wants GE to expand its margins, explore more share buybacks, be disciplined in its acquisitions and mull additional ways to consider scaling back GE Capital.GE CFO Jeff Bornstein told the Financial Times Friday that the company is open to borrowing money to buy back shares.Meanwhile, Bornstein told Bloomberg that GE is exploring up to $10 billion in dealmaking in order to boost its newly created digital unit. Whether that fits into Peltz's vision of more disciplined M&A remains to be seen.The company has heeded the urging of investors as well as its own desire to avoid tougher federal financial regulations. This month, it sold $32 billion worth of assets in commercial lending and leasing to Wells Fargo (WFC). It has $126 billion in total signed deals to date, GE CEO Jeff Immelt said in a statement.GE also is launching a share exchange to spin off Synchrony Financial (SYF), its consumer finance subsidiary, next week. The company plans to return $30 billion to shareholders next year via share buybacks and dividend payouts.Synchrony shares finished down 3.7% to 30.15 Friday after reporting quarterly results. Wells Fargo shares edged up 0.4% to 52.88.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter @IBD_CMcEvoy and on Facebook.

New highs can tell an individual investor a lot about the market, a sector and a stock. IBD's list doesn't include stocks trading under 10 a share or trailing more than 40% of the market in earnings performance. This is appropriate because there's little to gain by buying low-priced junk.Or as a comedian said about the junk-bond fiasco of the late 1980s: Shouldn't the word "junk" have been a clue?Here are four ways to gain quality market clues from IBD's new highs list. The overall tally: Intraday Tuesday, new highs had an edge over new lows. In a healthy market, combined new highs (Nasdaq + NYSE) lead new lows by a wide margin.From July through September, total new lows dominated new highs. This was a bad sign. Beginning in October, the balance shifted. In the first 14 sessions of October, new highs led in 11 sessions.However, the new-highs tally — which recently has been barely scoring triple digits — could use a boost. Sector representation: Early Tuesday, real estate investment trusts and insurance were scoring the most new highs. The medical sector had the most new lows.This is a good way, though not a conclusive way, to look for signs of sector rotation. Reversals: April 2014 initial public offering Paycom Software (PAYC) posted a new high early Tuesday and then reversed to close off 2.27 at 38.57 in triple its usual volume. Facebook (FB) also reversed, closing down 1.47 to 97 after being up 1% in early trade. Volume, though, was average.If a stock notches a new high and then reverses in fast trade, that's a bad sign. In many cases, though, it's a reflection of the overall market. The Nasdaq early Tuesday also made a gain and then reversed lower.Note that the list doesn't show reversals, so the individual investor might want to punch in some tickers to see how the stocks closed after hitting the new high. Volume: A new high made in low volume is a different story from one made in strong volume. The key, though, is not to make too much out of one day's action. Look for patterns. Is the stock making a batch of new highs in low volume, or is it just pausing? Has the stock scored several new highs in strong volume, or is this a one-shot deal?Click here to view the full list of 52-Week New Highs & Lows

General Electric (GE) and Yahoo (YHOO) were given higher price targets Monday, while Oracle (ORCL) was downgraded, and SolarCity (SCTY) was started at sell.RBC Capital Markets raised its price target on GE to 32 from 30. Stifel also lifted its GE target to 32 from 30. On Friday, the industrial conglomerate's stock price rose 3.4% after it beat Q3 earnings views. Shares ended essentially unchanged at 28.99 on the stock market today.Also last week, GE reached a major milestone in its efforts to scale down its GE Capital unit, selling its $30 billion commercial lending and leasingbusiness to Wells Fargo (WFC).Yahoo shares closed up 0.4% after Axiom Capital raised its price target on the stock to 45 from 41. Yahoo's stock price has been on a downward spiral this year as the Internet portal has produced three straight quarters of double-digit earnings declines.Enterprise-software and database giant Oracle lost 1.3% after it was downgraded from overweight to sector weight by Pacific Crest.Solar-energy systems provider SolarCity fell 6.5% after it was initiated at sell by Axiom.Buffalo Wild Wings (BWLD) rose 1.5% following an upgrade to buy from hold at Maxim Group, which maintained its 217 price target on the stock.Seagate Technology (STX) was downgraded to neutral from positive by Susquehanna, which also cut its price target on the stock to 45 from 60.Last week, the data-storage provider preannounced fiscal Q1 revenue that missed Wall Street expectations and projected a gross profit margin that was short of the company's own forecasts. Seagate shares dipped 2% Monday.Wunderlich downgraded Urban Outfitters (URBN) to hold from buy and slashed its price target to 30 from 49. The retailer's shares lost 3.7%.Meanwhile, Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) rose 2.7% after it was upgraded to hold from sell by Wunderlich, which raised it price target on the stock to 21 from 15.Ecolab (ECL), which set a new stock high of 122.29 on Friday, was downgraded to hold from buy at Deutsche Bank on Monday. Ecolab shares fell 2.2%.British telecom giant Vodafone Group (VOD) fell slightly despite being upgraded to outperform by Macquarie.Follow Vance Cariaga on Twitter: @IBD_VCariaga.

If you go on Facebook (FB) talking about how you got trashed last weekend, you might be trashing your credit score. Credit rating agency FICO (FICO) is adding new ways to assess creditworthiness, including looking at smartphone records and information volunteered on social sites such as Facebook. Although it doesn't use data from social sites, TransUnion (TRU) is also using…

Card-purchase volumes are typically reported by bank issuers ahead of quarterly results from Visa (V) and MasterCard (MA), providing a preliminary window into a big slice of the two card processors' business. What do volume trends suggest? Reports from bank issuers for their September-ending quarters should "bode well" for Visa and MasterCard's same quarters, noted Cowen and Co. analyst George…

A sagging energy sector and a strong dollar promise to weigh on General Electric (GE) when it reports third-quarter earnings Friday before markets open. The Fairfield, Conn.-based industrial conglomerate is expected to earn 26 cents a share in Q3, down 31.6% from a year earlier, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue is expected to slide 20.8% to $28.6…

Revenue — and how to grow it — were the name of the game for Wells Fargo (WFC) and Bank of America (BAC) in Q3, and one bank succeeded where the other didn't.San Francisco-based Wells Fargo earned $1.05 a share, up 2.9% from a year earlier, on a profit of $5.8 billion. Earnings per share beat analysts' estimates by a penny. Revenue rose 2.6% to $21.9 billion, topping estimates of $21.8 billion.The bank's net interest margin fell 1 basis point from Q2 to 2.96%. A year earlier, that number was 3.06%. The net interest margin measures banks' profitability from interest charged on loans vs. interest paid out in deposits. Banks' margins have been squeezed as the Federal Reserve has kept benchmark rates near zero since December 2008.Loans rose 7.7% year-over-year to $903.2 billion, with commercial and industrial lending up 15%, commercial real-estate mortgages up 8.2%, total consumer loans up 3%, and auto loans up 7.1%.Wells Fargo's mortgage business generated $1.6 billion in fees, down 2.7%. Total assets expanded by 7% to $1.8 trillion as of Sept. 30. Expenses grew 1.2% to $12.4 billion.Shares were down 0.7% to 51.50 in the stock market today.Wells Fargo has been buying some General Electric (GE) assets and recently announced the purchase of GE Capital's $30 billion commercial leasing and lending unit. Earlier this year, the bank bought $9 billion worth of General Electric property loans.Bank of America swung to a profit of 34 cents a share in Q3, beating estimates by a penny, from a year-ago loss of 4 cents a share. Net income in Q3 2015 was $4.5 billion.Revenue fell 2.4% to $20.9 billion, beating estimates of $20.8 billion but marking the sixth time in seven quarters that BofA has posted a revenue decline.But shares rose 0.8% to 15.68.Total assets grew 1.4% to $2.2 trillion as of Sept. 30. Residential mortgage and home-equity loan originations rose 13% to $17 billion. Excluding an accounting adjustment, trading revenue fell 3.8% to $3.2 billion — better than the predicted fall of 5% to 6%. Fixed-income, currencies and commodities sales and trading revenue dropped 11%, hurt by declines in credit-related businesses.Expenses sank 31% to $13.8 billion. Legal expenses plunged to $231 million from $6 billion a year earlier, primarily because of the $17 billion settlement Bank of America paid to regulators last year.BofA is seeking to boost its revenue while waiting for the Fed to raise rates. Cost-cutting has been among the methods applied.The bank's core net interest margin fell to 2.10% from 2.37% in Q2 and from 2.29% in Q3 2014.It was an eventful quarter for BofA, which saw its CEO Brian Moynihan successfully fight off an effort by some shareholders to strip him of his chairmanship. The bank also had to resubmit a stress test to the Federal Reserve.Citigroup (C) and Goldman Sachs (GS) will report third-quarter earnings Thursday. Rounding out the big six, Morgan Stanley (MS) reports Q3 results on Monday. Citigroup stock fell 1% Wednesday, Goldman lost 0.8% and Morgan Stanley 0.2%JPMorgan Chase (JPM) reported its quarterly results late Tuesday, with revenue falling in a number of its units. JPMorgan shares were down 2.5% Wednesday.Follow Ciaran McEvoy on Twitter @IBD_CMcEvoy and on Facebook.

Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) may be able to avoid the dreaded designation of "systemically important," which would require it to set aside additional capital to hedge against failure and subject the company to more regulations. General Electric (GE) separately appears on the verge of getting out from under the label after selling about $30 billion worth of commercial-lending and…
Plunging oil prices and weak global demand are weighing heavily on U.S. industry, fresh economic data and gloomy corporate earnings confirmed Friday.

Industrial production fell 0.2% in September, its second straight decline, the Federal Reserve reported. Output rose only 0.4% vs. a year earlier. Manufacturing slid 0.1% vs. August, the fourth decline in five months.
The energy slump that began last year has battered production. In September, mining was down 6% from 2014, and drilling activity was less than half its year-earlier level.

Oilfield services firm Schlumberger (SLB) late Thursday reported another quarter of sharply lower earnings and sales, both below views. It warned of further declines in drilling activity by exploration and production firms. Schlumberger will cut more jobs, it said Friday, after already laying off thousands of workers. Its stock fell 2.2%.

Pain, and a lack of confidence, is rippling across the industrial landscape. Supply retailer W.W. Grainger (GWW) on Friday reported weak earnings and lowered guidance, citing a "challenging industrial economy in North America." Many customers have announced job cuts, "and there are indications of extended year-end holiday shutdowns. We have begun the process of aggressively adjusting our cost structure to reflect the weaker economic environment."
W.W. Grainger stock fell 6.3%.

A stronger dollar and a tepid global economy aren't helping, either. September's ISM manufacturing index teetered close to the 50 mark that separates contraction from expansion, with exports below that line. "North American business steady. International business trending bearish," one respondent told ISM. "Overall business is slowing. Consumers are nervous. Not sure what is coming next," said another.

General Electric (GE) and Honeywell (HON) reported better-than-expected profit but missed on sales, with the energy sector a drag for both. But investors, cheered by GE's industrial focus, sent its shares up 3.4% to a 7-year high. Honeywell, which cut its full-year revenue target, fell 1.5%.
While industrial output fell, analysts had forecast worse. Economists expect the sector to continue struggling, but some saw green shoots in the data.

Jennifer Lee, senior economist for BMO Capital Markets, said in a note Friday that she sees "strength within," noting that consumer goods production rose 1.3% in Q3, "the best reading in nearly two years."Plunging oil prices and weak global demand are weighing heavily on U.S. industry, fresh economic data and gloomy corporate earnings confirmed Friday.Industrial production fell 0.2% in September, its second straight decline, the Federal Reserve reported. Second-quarter earnings season begins this week but really kicks into gear next week when some big names — including dividend leader Wells Fargo (WFC) — reports on Tuesday. Wells Fargo's quarterly dividend fell from 34 cents to a nickel in the second quarter of 2009 amid the financial crisis. Earnings slipped in 2010. The company began notching up the dividend…

The world looked a bit flat from a market standpoint early Tuesday, with global markets and commodities largely unmoved and stock futures steering the U.S. market toward a mixed open.Dow futures were down 65.4 points, with IBM (IBM) pulling hard to the downside. S&P 500 futures were off a fraction. Nasdaq 100 futures were up 5.4 points.The focal point of the stock market today. Microsoft (MSFT), Yahoo (YHOO) and Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) also report after the close, as do a number of leading stocks, including Blackhawk Network (HAWK), Illumina (ILMN) and GoPro (GPRO).The economic calendar is blank Tuesday, but big names in motion after early earnings reports included Verizon (VZ) (down 2%), Travelers (TRV) (up 2%), Lockheed Martin (LMT) (unchanged) and United Technologies (UTX) (down 4%).IBM dragged 5% lower after reporting its Q2 earnings beat but revenue fell slightly more than analysts had expected. It was the tech giant's 13th straight quarter of declining revenue, and profit margins in its software division — the source of about half the company's profit — narrowed during the quarter. IBM shares have been in a gradual uptrend since January, fighting to climb out of a 10-month consolidation.Tesla Motors (TSLA) slumped nearly 4% ahead of the open. The stock may have been nicked by a UBS downgrade to sell, in a note that reportedly questioned the company's battery storage and auto delivery targets. Shares rose almost 3% in strong trade Monday. The stock is extended after a rebound from 10-week support and above a 258.85 cup-with-handle buy point.India-based software engineer Infosys (INFY) surged 12%. The country's second largest software developer reported better-than-expected Q2 earnings and raised its full-year revenue guidance above consensus expectations.Management said the company signed six contracts during the quarter with a total value of $688 million. Infosys has been consolidating sine February and battling to retake its 10-week line of support for the past five weeks.The dollar was mixed and commodities were generally flat. Mining stocks, which had dragged hard on the S&P 500 on Monday, were rebounding, with Agnico Eagle (AEM), Barrick Gold (ABX), Yamana Gold (AUY) and Newmont Mining (NEM) posting solid premarket gains.
Stocks opened mixed, then hammered out narrow gains in early trade Tuesday.
The Nasdaq led, up 0.4%. The S&P 500 added 0.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average edged up 0.1%.
Volume was mixed on the stock market today, down 15% on the NYSE and up about 1% on the Nasdaq, compared with action at the same time Monday.
Overseas, Europe's major indexes continued to struggle in narrowly mixed territory in afternoon trade.
Prices on U.S. imports and exports slipped in June, with exports down 0.2% and imports off by 0.1%, the Labor Department reported. Consensus views projected a 0.1% increase for each.
Business inventories increased 0.3% in May, the Commerce Department said. That was below April's 0.4% increase, but a tad better than the 0.2% expansion projected by economists.
The day's big earnings reports came from JPMorgan (JPM) (up 0.6%), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) (down 0.8%) and Wells Fargo (WFC) (up 0.1%).
Bolt and screw distributor Fastenal (FAST) slumped 2% after beating earnings views but coming up shy on sales.

Micron Technology (MU) rumbled up 8% on news reports of a possible $23 billion takeover bid from Tsinghua Unigroup, China's largest state-owned chip developer. Yahoo Finance reported the company denied it had received an offer. Standard & Poor's Capital IQ said a deal was unlikely due to the size of the bid and probably regulatory hurdles. Intel (INTC) reportedly paid $1.5 billion for a 20% stake in Tsinghua last year. Micron is trading 19% below a December high. Intel shares rose 0.6%.

GoPro (GPRO) muscled up more than 6%, boosted by a Barclays upgrade to overweight from equal-weight. The note also raised the stock's price target to 65, from 50, citing strong execution, acquisitions and continuing brand strength, among other factors. The stock is in the sixth week of a possible cup base, although the consolidation is occurring well below the stock's 52-week high, a possible weakness.
The prevailing mood among IBD 50 stocks was positive. Among the few posting losses, only CyberArk Software (CYBR), down 1.4%, fell more than 1%.
Ambarella (AMBA) led the group, rising 4% in heavy trade, rebounding from a test of support at its 10-week moving average.
Gray Television (GTN), Fleetmatics (FLTX) and Newlink Genetics (NLNK) all rose more than 1%.

Earnings reports due out after the close include railroad CSX (CSX) and Pizza Hut, Taco Bell, KFC owner Yum Brands (YUM).Stocks opened mixed, then hammered out narrow gains in early trade Tuesday.The Nasdaq led, up 0.4%. Stock futures knocked out healthy gains ahead of Monday's open after a probationary deal from the eurozone opened the door to possible bailout funds for Greece.

Dow futures were 122.6 points above fair market value and ticking higher. Nasdaq 100 futures were up a solid 33.5 points. S&P 500 futures jumped 13.3 points. Small caps were less impressed, with Russell 2000 futures edging up 3.5 points.

Greece was (again) the leading early influence on the stock market today. An accord fashioned between eurozone creditors and Greece's leaders following an all-night session cleared the path for the struggling country to receive as much as $96 billion, to be released as Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras proves his government able to implement so-called austerity measures.

The plan is enough to keep Greece, for now, within the euro currency bloc. Tsipras must enact tax hikes and pension changes by Wednesday. Both steps were refused by Greek voters in a referendum just a week ago.

Global markets were positive, with China's top indexes blocking out solid gains — Shanghai Composite up 2.4%, Hong Kong's Hang Seng up 1.3%. In Europe, the CAC-40 in Paris surged 2%. Frankfurt's DAX climbed 1.4%. London's FTSE 100 added 0.8%.

U.S. markets open the day with the Nasdaq and S&P 500 staring at the underside of their 50-day moving averages. Moves above those lines would be positive, but would still leave the market within the range that has contained trade since March. The Nasdaq starts Monday's session 3.3% below its June 24 high. The S&P 500 starts 2.8% below its high, from May 20.

The Treasury Department serves up its June budget numbers at 2 p.m. ET. The earnings calendar gets a slow start Monday. IBD 50 stock Bank of the Ozarks (OZRK) reports after the close. The pace picks up on Tuesday, with reports due out from JPMorgan (JPM), Wells Fargo (WFC) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ).
In stocks, United Continental (UAL) climbed 2%. Wynn Resorts (WYNN) tacked up a 5% gain.
Medical sector stocks small and large were hammering out big premarket moves.

Anacor Pharmaceuticals (ANAC) spiked 48% after announcing its eczema skin rash lotion Crisaborole met endpoints in two late-stage clinical trials. The Palo Alto, Calif.-based biotech said it would submit a new drug application to the Food and Drug Administration early in 2016. Anacor ended Friday at a new high, up 9% in July and with a 162% gain this year.
ConforMis (CFMS) leapt 9%. The market of surgical knee implants, a July 2 new issue, ended Friday 17% below its high and 49% above its IPO price.

Edwards Lifesciences (EW) notched up 3% after RBC Capital upgraded the stock to outperform from sector perform. The Irvine, Calif.-based company announced Friday it would pay $400 million to acquire privately held heart device maker CardiAQ Valve Technologies. Edwards ended Friday just below a 147.40 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

In other trading, the dollar gained vs. the euro and the yen while the yen rose vs. the euro. Oil prices slipped a bit less than 1%. Like they say at the Opera - "It ain't over till the fat lady sings" Well - can you hear her singing? Greece and the EU strike an 11th hour deal! The Opera is over….or is it?
(Who is kidding who? It's never over.)
This morning global investors are waking up to the headlines:
"Tsipras Capitulates to Creditor's Demands to Keep Greece in the Euro"
"Greece and Eurozone Thrash out Rescue Deal"
"Agreekment! Overnight Talks Result in Aid-for-Reform Deal"

This is like a sequel to the 1994 comedy - "Dumb and Dumber" Only this one stars Alexis Tsipras and the whole Greek Parliament...I mean have you ever seen anything so breathtakingly stupid? Alexis Tsipras was elected on the platform of "Screw the European Union" - Remember - he was the one that claimed that he would not accept one more ounce of austerity, or cuts, or tax increases (not that anyone in Greece pays taxes - so what difference does that make?)

Following months of ranting and raving against Germany and the Troika (IMF, ECB and EU) - He rejected plan after plan then forced a referendum vote in his country, campaigned for his citizens to vote 'NO' - and when they 'overwhelmingly agreed' that last week's deal was a bad one - he then sold them down the river! He made such a dramatic reversal that it's almost laughable.....and to make it more ridiculous - the latest 'final offer' is far worse than ones he had turned down! We now have a new word that is sure to light up the Twitter sphere - "Gridiot".
Paul Krugman - an American Economist and Professor of Economic and Int'l Affairs at Princeton University - summed it up this way:

"This goes beyond harsh into pure vindictiveness, complete destruction of national sovereignty, and no hope of relief. It is, presumably, meant to be an offer Greece can't accept; but even so, it's a grotesque betrayal of everything the European project was supposed to stand for."

Global markets, now all relieved (at least for today), have moved into positive territory. Beginning in Asia - markets there sensing relief on the Greek front caused investors and traders to review recent market action. Add in some positive economic data across the region and it was Risk On. China - which has been the focus of late - reported trade figures showing that exports rose 2.8%, substantially beating the expectation of +0.2%.....on a side note - Gov't officials tried to temper the mood saying that 'exports are likely to face relatively big pressure in the coming months'. (Because - How long can they keep up this façade?)

China ended the day up 2.4% extending Friday's gain of better than 6%. Clearly the market has been boosted by the recent 'reforms' instituted by Beijing….Brokerages were told in 'no uncertain terms' on Sunday to use real names and national identification numbers on all trades - Imagine that - no more imaginary brokerage accounts! Who would have thought of using real names? Over the weekend - Xinhua - the state owned news outlet - reported that some brokerage houses were 'suspected of manipulating futures prices and other malicious practices. Like I said last week - China is not a free market and while the measures recently imposed have caused the markets to rally - what happens once they are removed? Are foreign investors really feeling any better? Not so much….

In Japan - money poured into the Yen - as the safe haven trade. Equities also moved higher as investors got the 'all clear' sign on a Greek deal while the GPIF (Gov't Pension Investment Fund) released performance figures showing a 12% return in the 12 months ended March 31st. Shoji Hirakawa, Chief equity strategist at Oksan Securities, did say that the fund looks like they still have another 4 or 5 trillion Yen left to put to work in the Japanese stock market - Ah…Hello??? 5 Trillion more Yen going into stocks....Anyone want to stand in front of that train?

In Europe this morning - as you can imagine - markets there are on a tear….FTSE + 0.61%, CAC 40 + 1.78%, DAX +1.32%, EUROSTOXX +1.64%, SPAIN +1.25% and ITALY +1.26%. Good for today - but if Tsipras can't deliver - then expect it to all fall apart mid-week. Even if he does deliver - and that is a big "IF" - will he be able to hold onto his position as PM? Relief- sure.....Greece now has 72 hours to vote in the reforms. There is already trouble brewing in Parliament - you can imagine the rage among those that supported Tsipras in his efforts and now feel like he turned his back on them.

German Chancellor Merkel had this to say: "Trust has to be rebuilt, the Greek authorities have to take on responsibility for what they agreed to, It now hinges on step-by-step implementation of what we agreed."
And that agreement is for more spending cuts, pension cuts, and tax increases - everything that the country voted against.....Are you beginning to see the Dumb and Dumber reference?

U.S. futures are soaring - currently up 14 points - at this rate we will be banging our heads on S&P 500 2100 before lunch. There are no economic reports for today but later in the week we get a slew of data points - Retail Sales, PPI, Empire State Manufacturing, Industrial Prod, and Capacity Utilization......

We are now well into earnings season...Tomorrow starts the beauty pageant....JPMorgan (JPM), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Wells Fargo (WFC) - later in the week - we get US Bancorp (USB), Bank of America (BAC), CSX (CSX), Yum Brands (YUM) to name just a few.....The focus now will turn to the earnings and future guidance.....The Greek-think is a bit exhausting....but will remain simmering on the back burner.

Look for the S&P 500 to test both the 100 and 50 DMA's (2095 & 2099). Those will be tough resistance points for the market to breach....that is where the economic data and earnings will play their part....Investors want to know if we are finally really making headway - Any perceived failure will cause markets to find support once again at 2056....

This week also features an annual event - Semicon West (July 14-15th) - a 'must see' event - a two-day innovation conference at the Moscone Center in San Francisco - featuring startups/investor and research forums.... Look for presentations from some of the big boys - IntelINTC, OracleORCL, IBMIBM, Texas InstrumentsTXN, San DiskSNDK along with some new and exciting startups - The market is sure to be getting all kinds of positive data and presentations coming out of this conference so expect positive market action in the publicly-traded names.
Take Good Care
KP

Overnight Talks Result in Aid-for-Reform Deal"This is like a sequel to the 1994 comedy - "Dumb and Dumber" Only this one stars Alexis Tsipras and the whole Greek Parliament...I mean have you ever seen anything so breathtakingly stupid? Alexis Tsipras was elected on the platform of "Screw the European Union" - Remember - he was the one that claimed that he would not accept one more ounce of austerity, or cuts, or tax increases (not that anyone in Greece pays taxes - so what difference does that make?)Following months of ranting and raving against Germany and the Troika (IMF, ECB and EU) - He rejected plan after plan then forced a referendum vote in his country, campaigned for his citizens to vote 'NO' - and when they 'overwhelmingly agreed' that last week's deal was a bad one - he then sold them down the river! Banks can't be blamed if they feel like they've been waiting for Godot, as the Federal Reserve has deliberated — and deliberated some more — when it comes to raising rates from near-zero levels. As a result, banks have taken matters into their own hands by cutting costs or acquiring other businesses to grow revenue. Those moves also help offset…
The stock market erased small gains and was modestly lower in early afternoon trading Tuesday. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 were down 0.2% each, while the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.1%.
Volume was tracking higher — no surprise after Monday's Columbus Day slowdown. Declining stocks led advancers by a 7-to-5 ratio on the NYSE, and by 6-to-5 on the Nasdaq.

Among widely held stocks, Wells Fargo (WFC) was slightly lower after the bank agreed to acquire GE Capital's lending and leasing business, which total $32 billion in assets. General Electric (GE) shares were nearly flat.
A smattering of medical, media, Internet and cyclical stocks led the stock market today.
UnitedHealth Group (UNH)climbed 2% in heavy volume. The HMO is nearing the 126.31 buy point of its base, but topped an alternative entry at 125.22.
Weakness in airlines, railroads, trucking and air freight made the transportation sector the day's weakest. The Dow transportation average tumbled 1.6%.

JPMorgan downgraded JetBlue (JBLU) to neutral from overweight. The stock slid 7% but may be finding support at the 50-day moving average. Also, Evercore ISI downgraded both American Airlines (AA) (L) and Alaska Air (ALK) to hold. American pared losses to less than 1%, while Alaska Air was down 3% and trading below its 50-day moving average.
Delta Air Lines (DAL) reports third-quarter results Wednesday morning. Analysts expect a profit of $1.71 a share, up 42%. Shares remain near the 48.40 buy point, which Delta topped Monday.
One day after it broke out of a base, Skywest (SKYW) sank right back into its pattern, falling 9% in heavy trading.

A surprise uptick in home foreclosures by banks might mean that the long-discussed "shadow inventory" is finally coming to the residential housing market. Thirty-eight states posted year-over-year increases in real estate owned (REO) properties in May, according to a report released on June 18 by RealtyTrac, an industry researcher and consultant. The list includes heavily populated states such as New…

The sailing looks pretty smooth for big banks as they prepare to report second-quarter earnings. Robust mergers and acquisitions fees, initial public offering activity and expense cutting are expected to offset continued squeezing of net-interest margins.
Stock prices more or less have been flat for the year and the housing market continues to grow. But capital markets are expected to be the big driver for the big banks.
They report Q2 earnings beginning with JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Wells Fargo (WFC) on Tuesday morning before markets open for trading.

The nation's largest bank, JPMorgan is expected to earn $1.44 a share, down 1.4% from a year earlier, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue is expected to fall 3.2% to $24.5 billion. The enormous legal settlements that the New York-based lender paid for a variety of alleged misdeeds in recent years appear to be behind it. Currently, analysts are watching how much JPMorgan cuts down on expenses and accelerates loan growth.
Analysts also will keep an eye on JPMorgan's capital markets activity in advance of the Federal Reserve's expected interest rate hike.

JPMorgan stock has risen 7% so far this year. The company currently has an IBD Composite Rating of 72 out of 99, meaning it trades better than 72% of other publicly traded companies. It's the highest such rating for the nation's six big banks.

Continued pressure on net-interest margins — which measure the difference between interest paid out to depositors and interest received from loans — is expected to impact Wells Fargo. But higher income from stronger mortgage, deposit, insurance and card fees should offset any margin difficulties.
Wells Fargo is expected to earn $1.03 a share, up 2% from Q2 '14, with revenue forecast to grow 3% to $21.7 billion.

"If mortgage banking activity comes in better than the ... current forecast and loan growth accelerates from our expectations, it could reach the high end of its 1.3%-1.6% (return on assets) target in 2015," noted Barclays analysts in a Friday report.
The San Francisco-based lender's shares have risen 3% in 2015 and dipped below their 50-day moving average on July 7. Wells' IBD Composite Rating is 68.

Bank of America (BAC), which reports Q2 on Wednesday, is expected by analysts to have earned 36 cents a share, an 89.5% gain from a year earlier. Revenue is expected to have fallen 3% to $21.3 billion.

The Charlotte, N.C.-based bank's stock has fallen 6% so far this year — the worst performance of any of the six big banks — and dropped below its 50-day average on July 7. BofA's IBD Composite Rating is 58.
Analysts will be focusing on how well BofA adjusts to compressed net-interest margins, cuts expenses — as evidenced by its "Simplify and Improve" program, and boosts its markets revenue.
Bank of America is required to resubmit its federal stress test by Sept. 30.

"No net asset growth expected over the next few years due to the $50 (billion-plus) run-off portfolio coupled with capital levels lagging peers, create headwinds for the stock as management grapples with legacy and mortgage issues," Barclays analysts reported Friday.

Bolstered by easy year-over-year comparisons because of last year's $7 billion mortgage-related settlement with the Justice Department,Citigroup (C) is expected to post $1.35 in EPS, up 89.5% from Q2 '14. Analysts have forecast that Citi's revenue will fall 1.2% to $19.1 billion when the bank reports its Q2 results Thursday.
Citigroup has spent much of the year closing some of its overseas operations and passing the federal government's two stress tests back in March.
The New York-based Citi's shares are more or less flat for the year, rising a mere 1% in '15. Its Composite Rating is 54.

Goldman Sachs (GS), which also reports quarterly results Thursday, is expected to be the victim of difficult annualized comparisons due to its stellar Q2 last year. Earnings are forecast to show a 5.4% decline to $3.88 a share on revenue of $8.8 billion, a 3.8% drop from a year earlier.

Strong M&A activity as well as an abundance of IPOs and secondary offerings should have boosted Goldman's performance, which is expected to have been adversely affected by jettisoning some commodities units due to regulatory pressure.
"It should clearly be a beneficiary of the capital markets activity," said Stephen Biggar, an analyst at Argus Research, adding that having such a strong quarter a year ago is a good problem.
"It's not a reflection of bad business," Biggar said. "Being flat is kind of a win for them."
Goldman's shares have risen 7% this year and the New York-based bank has an IBD Composite Rating of 71.
Morgan Stanley (MS) is expected to earn 73 cents a share, up 21.7% from a year earlier, on revenue of $9.1 billion, up 6.8%.
The New York-based bank is in the midst of a plan to grow its lending and deposits while keeping expenses down.

"If (Morgan Stanley) is able to show it can manage expenses while growing loans then we would be more confident that (it) could see the benefit of higher interest rates fall to the company's bottom line," wrote analysts at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in a June 24 report.
The New York-based lender's shares are flat for the year, up a measly 0.1%. Morgan Stanley's IBD Composite Rating is 61.

Stocks put in a fourth day of solid gains, although volume flagged. The Nasdaq rose 0.7%, the S&P 500 gained 0.5% and the Dow Jones industrial average jumped 0.4% in the stock market today. Volume was lower on both exchanges, but down less than 1% from Monday's level on the Nasdaq, according to preliminary data.Amazon.com (AMZN) rose nearly 3% in strong trade after UBS analyst Eric Sheridan upgraded shares from neutral to buy and raised his price target from 450 to 550. Growth, he said, is driven by Amazon's Prime and Fulfillment businesses. The stock broke out of a flat base Monday with a 452.65 buy point.Semiconductors and energy issues were among the top-performing industry groups. Micron Technology (MU) rose 11% on a bid from Tsinghua Unigroup, China's largest state-owned chip-design company. Oil prices rose despite a nuclear deal with Iran, which could result in the eventual return of Iranian oil to world markets.Monster Beverage (MNST) broke out of a cup-with-handle base with a 139.75 buy point, but volume was poor and the stock made little headway past that level, rising less than 1%.Wearable sports action camera maker GoPro (GPRO) rose 5% after a Barclays upgrade, and Ambarella (AMBA), which makes chips for its cameras, jumped 8%. That made Ambarella the top performer among IBD 50 stocks.Gray Television (GTN) broke out of a flat base with a 16.77 buy point. It gained 3% in heavy volume.Wells Fargo (WFC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) jumped 1% each after reporting upbeat earnings and revenue.
