And we're off! Yes folks - it's official……no more speculation, she IS running and SNL made the announcement on Saturday night.....with the opening skit devoted to Hill & Bill......tag line:
"Buckle up America - The Clintons are backkkkkkk".........

Then on Sunday - Hillary took to the social media airwaves.....Using all available outlets - Twitter (TWTR), YouTube (GOOGL), Instagram, Facebook (FB), Match.com, EHarmony and "OurTime" (The 55 and older dating website) announcing that:
"I'm getting ready to do something too…I'm running for President and am hitting the road to earn your vote...."

And the trumpets blared …..Chelsea congratulating Mom on Twitter telling her how proud she is, Chuck Schumer - NY's Senior Senator throwing his weight behind her while NYC's mayor de Blasio refusing to support her unless she promises to 'raise taxes on the wealthy and redistribute to the not so much...(and just fyi - he is starting to travel the country to 'build his brand and he is a disaster).

Republicans? Well they launched into overdrive……the mud already started flying…..Rand Paul - telling us all how 'She' represents what is wrong with Washington - ( he may want to look in the mirror as well), Ted Cruz running with TV ads telling us how we need to embrace far right wing conservatism vs. her liberal agenda and Jeb Bush - of the Bush dynasty - (who is not running yet) sent out this email within mins of the announcement -
"Moments ago Hillary Clinton officially announced her White House bid - and it's up to us to stop her.

I'm going to be straightforward with you, this isn't going to be easy. Hillary plans to raise $1.7 billion to win the White House and she already has 135,000 donors at the ready......8 years of Democrat control has already done untold damage, 4 more years of Clinton control will only make it worse. To do this, we'll need you to step up like never before, and right now I need you to give $5 to show you're ready to defeat Hillary in 2016.
This is going to be a long fight, but together, we will stop her. Thank you for your help, you'll be hearing from me again soon".
Jeb

Did he say a long fight? And did he say I would be hearing from him again soon? Do these actions by the GOP scream of desperation already? She wasn't out for 15 mins before the attacks started….. Oh boy…..18 more months of this? Is anyone else exhausted yet?

Now - welcome to the presidential election cycle......and while none of this will have any effect on the mkts today - it will provide for so much of the discussion as the race is now underway....watch for Marco Rubio, Martin O'Malley, Joe Biden, Elizabeth Warren, Chris Christie...to name just a few other possible candidates to star in the show.....

Ok - back to the action - or lack of……- stocks marched higher on Friday just as earnings season gets underway…… The big news of the day was that General Electric (GE) is getting out of the banking business…. this news sent shares of GE soaring by 11% - adding some $28 billion to the company's mkt cap……add in a couple of M&A stories and the mood was buoyant..... But aside from this - there was very little in the way of any directional driver, and this was reflected in the volume and the VIX yet stocks moved mostly higher over the course of the trading day in what is known as 'FED style manipulation' causing the mkt to build on the gains made earlier in the week - just ahead of tax day and earnings.

Yes folks - Earnings season is upon us.. and it has not started out so bad......concern over the dollar has not reared its ugly yet.....in fact Alcoa (AA) showed us that big multinationals that have operations overseas will benefit from weaker currencies... so net/net.....maybe not the disaster that analysts have been singing about......

That being said - we all know that earnings are expected to be DOWN by some 4+% yoy - that is an 8% reduction in estimates over the course of the 1Q - but is this setting the stage for investors to be disappointed? Has the mkt already priced this in? Now all of this has been well televised and so for the most part - the market is prepared for it - so unless some company has so misguided the street analysts or is so out of touch with their businesses we can most likely expect about 75% of companies to 'meet or beat' their lowered estimates..... Look - at this point - any company that misses big is just so out of touch with reality.

Remember that by the time they announce earnings - they are already history.....so as usual - investors want to know what the future looks like - listening for any hint that the future is brighter as companies try to insulate themselves by being more cautious on the outlook going forward due to a rising dollar and a mixed global economy.....

And the rising dollar is resetting the landscape around the world - as the boys are now being separated from the men.......This week - Washington plays host to the IMF and the World Bank - as global central bankers and finance ministers from around the world discuss what exactly a stronger dollar will do to the global economy. The FED caught between a rock and a hard place, must assess the drag a stronger dollar will have on a still weak US economy as they scale back expectations of rising rates anytime soon. ...... We have seen dramatic moves in global mkts over the 12 month cycle.........European mkts approaching and making new highs -with the Eurostoxx Index +22%, Asian mkts also clocking massive gains.....Japan +40%, China +96% and Hong Kong +39%.....all this vs. the S&P at +12%.

This morning - US futures are off slightly - currently down 3 pts trending at 2092 - but still right up near all time highs...but we have a busy week ahead.....Earnings to take center stage with names like JPMorgan Chase (JPM),American Express (AXP), General Electric, Wells Fargo (WFC), Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Kellogg (K), Goldman Sachs (GS)...to lead the hit parade.....

On the eco front it is a big week.....- on Tuesday - we get retail sales - exp of +1%, ex autos and gas of +0.6% - these would be a huge improvement over last month.....PPI of +0.2%, Ex food and energy of +0.1%...later on in the week we get Empire State Manf of 7.17, Industrial Production -0.3% , Capacity Utilization 78.6%, Fed Beige Book, Housing starts 1.04 mil, Building permits of 1.08 mil and CPI of +0.3%.

The mkt does feel a bit tired and I think we continue to hit our heads here on resistance at all time highs of 2011 ish.....but also do not expect to see any meltdown in the broader mkt with investors finding support at the 50 dma of 2075.

In Europe this morning - mkts are all trading around the flat line....as investors/traders take a breath ahead of a packed week. FTSE -0.45%, CAC 40 flat, DAX flat, EUROSTOXX +0.18%, SPAIN +0.57% and ITALY +0.50%.....

In Asia - mkts there all higher - with China rocketing +2.1% even in the face of some weak macro data.... March Chinese trade balance was worse than expected, as exports dropped -15% yoy vs. (E) 11%. (think more stimulus)..... Japan flat, China +2.1%, Hong Kong + 2.73% and ASX -0.14%.

All but three of the 31 big banks examined by the Federal Reserve won approval of any plans to return capital to investors in the second round of annual stress tests. In other words: more payouts for shareholders.

The U.S. units of Spain's Banco Santander (SAN) and Germany's Deutsche Bank (DB) failed round 2 of the Fed's stress tests, while the Fed ordered Bank of America  (BAC) to resubmit its capital plan by the end of the third quarter.
It's the second straight year Santander failed the test. And the Fed cited "numerous and significant deficiencies" in Deutsche Bank's capital planning.
Meanwhile, Wells Fargo (WFC) and Morgan Stanley (MS) boosted their dividends and Morgan approved a new buyback plan, joining other banks that received the Fed's OK of their capital plans.
Shares of BofA fell 1% late, while Morgan Stanley rose 2% and Wells Fargo edged up 0.1%.

The second round of the exams — the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review (CCAR) — is more stringent than round one, the Dodd-Frank Act Stress Tests (DFAST), because it examines banks' abilities to pay dividends, buy back shares and still serve borrowers during times of severe economic distress.

This year, the Fed examined 31 banks, each with assets exceeding $50 billion. All 31 banks passed DFAST last week, which means they met the Fed's minimum capital requirements. It was the first time they all passed since the test's 2009 inception.
A More Likely Place To Trip

Round 2 is where banks are more likely to stumble. Michael Corbat, the CEO of Citigroup (C), should be breathing easier, since the New York-based lender passed this year's tests after failing two out of the last three years. Last year's failure resulted in Citi's selling overseas branches as well as selling its consumer finance unit, OneMain Financial, for $4.25 billion.

This is the first year Citigroup will be able to boost its dividend since the financial crisis. Corbat and Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach's jobs reportedly were on the line during this year's stress tests. Citi's passage comes as a big win for them. Citi shares rose 3.7% in after-hours trading.
HSBC (HSBC) and Zions Bancorp (ZION) failed last year's CCAR but passed this year's exam.
Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Morgan Stanley met minimum capital requirements on a post-test basis after submitting adjustments.

"This is becoming less and less an adversarial process between the organizations," said Ernest Patrikis, a former New York Fed official now with the White & Case law firm. "I think for the banking system as a whole, we should feel a bit better."
Musing Over Board Control

While CCAR has become the key test of banks' health since the Great Recession, Patrikis said he'd like to see the day when a bank's board — not the Fed — again has the power to return money to owners. "Banks should be allowed to have more freedom to raise dividends," he said.

In addition to the banks listed above, the Federal Reserve had no objections to the plans of Ally Financial (ALLY), American Express (AXP), Bank of New York Mellon (BK), BB&T (BBT), BBVA Compass (BBVA), Bank of Montreal Quebec (BMO), Capital One Financial (COF), Citizens Financial Group (CFG), Comerica (CMA), Discover Financial Services (DFS), Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB), Huntington Bancshares (HBAN), Keycorp (KEY), M&T Bank (MTB), MUFG Americas Holdings (MTU), Northern Trust (NTRS), PNC Financial Services (PNC), Regions Financial (RF), State Street (STT), SunTrust Banks (STI) and U.S. Bancorp (USB).All but three of the 31 big banks examined by the Federal Reserve won approval of any plans to return capital to investors in the second round of annual stress tests. Some of the nation's big-bank executives could be feeling anxious this week about the release of the Federal Reserve's stress tests, scheduled for Thursday afternoon.

Perhaps most under the microscope is Citigroup (C), which failed last year's Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review, an annual exam performed each year since 2009 to evaluate how banks would endure another financial crisis. The tests were written into the Dodd-Frank Act the following year.

The New York-based lender's chief executive officer, Michael Corbat, and two other senior executives are expected to face increasing pressure to resign if Citigroup fails the stress test for a second consecutive year.

Corbat, John Gerspach, the bank's chief financial officer, and Brian Leach, Citigroup's head of financial risk and strategy, would face increasing calls from investors to resign and little sympathy from the Citigroup board of directors, according to a report from the Financial Times, citing two unnamed executives.

The first part of the test determines whether the company being tested has enough capital to endure nine quarters of difficult economic conditions. Part two of the test analyzes the companies' ability to pay dividends, repurchase stock or make acquisitions during economic difficulties.
Round 1 results are scheduled for release Thursday. Round 2 results are scheduled for March 11.
Despite the Citigroup scrutiny — it currently maintains an underwhelming IBD Composite Rating of 35 — analysts are optimistic about its 2015 stress test results.
"We believe (Citigroup) has made progress in improving its qualitative approach, while quantitatively it is in a strong capital position, in our view," wrote Barclays analysts.

Citigroup has also improved its standing since last year by scaling back its global consumer banking business, exiting 11 more markets. It cut back institutional clients and is about to sell its consumer lending unit, OneMain Financial Holdings.
"This may help reduce the complexity of the bank in the eyes of the regulators," Barclays said.

Skeptical regulators also have turned to Bank of America (BAC), which UBS analyst Brennan Hawken downgraded, cutting it to "neutral" from "buy." BofA noted in a Feb. 25 filing that it was discussing some internal models with federal regulators.
Since that filing was made public, Bank of America has traded below both its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.
Last year, the Fed made the Charlotte, N.C.-based lender resubmit its capital plans after a mistake was discovered in the original plans.

Goldman Sachs (GS) resubmitted its capital plan last year after failing to meet a minimum leverage ratio. As a result, the New York-based bank scaled back lines of business with low returns, reducing total assets as of June 30, 2014, by $56 billion to $860 billion.
The nation's largest bank, JPMorgan Chase (JPM), which is facing calls for its breakup, is also expected to pass the tests, and analysts aren't expecting anything dramatic from it.

"We do not expect the company to push the envelope beyond its recent and steady 50% payout of earnings in the form of dividends and share buybacks," Keefe, Bruyette & Woods (KBW) reported in a research note.

But JPMorgan is already implementing plans to slim down its operations and raise capital ratios. Last week, the company said that it will close 5% of its bank branches, impose surcharges on some large, uninsured deposits and shed $100 billion of such deposits.
Wells Fargo (WFC), one of the more conservatively managed big banks, is expected to pass. KBW analysts remain optimistic that Wells Fargo — along with Morgan Stanley (MS) — will pass the stress test.

Of the foreign banks to fall under the Fed's stress test, the U.S. units of Germany's Deutsche Bank (DB) and Spain's Banco Santander (SAN) are expected to fail as a result of weaknesses in their methods of predicting and measuring potential losses and risks, the Wall Street Journal reports.

If these banks fail the tests, their failure would mark the second consecutive year that large foreign banks stressed out on risk management grounds. Big foreign banks were drawn into the Fed's stress tests beginning last year.

Last week, the European Union's financial services commissioner, Jonathan Hill, said that U.S. capital requirements on foreign banks may be too onerous.Some of the nation's big-bank executives could be feeling anxious this week about the release of the Federal Reserve's stress tests, scheduled for Thursday afternoon.Perhaps most under the microscope is Citigroup (C), which failed last year's Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review, an annual exam performed each year since 2009 to evaluate how banks would endure another financial crisis. The tests were written into the Dodd-Frank Act the following year.The New York-based lender's chief executive officer, Michael Corbat, and two other senior executives are expected to face increasing pressure to resign if Citigroup fails the stress test for a second consecutive year.Corbat, John Gerspach, the bank's chief financial officer, and Brian Leach, Citigroup's head of financial risk and strategy, would face increasing calls from investors to resign and little sympathy from the Citigroup board of directors, according to a report from the Financial Times, citing two unnamed executives.The first part of the test determines whether the company being tested has enough capital to endure nine quarters of difficult economic conditions. Part two of the test analyzes the companies' ability to pay dividends, repurchase stock or make acquisitions during economic difficulties.Round 1 results are scheduled for release Thursday. Round 2 results are scheduled for March 11.Despite the Citigroup scrutiny — it currently maintains an underwhelming IBD Composite Rating of 35 — analysts are optimistic about its 2015 stress test results."We believe (Citigroup) has made progress in improving its qualitative approach, while quantitatively it is in a strong capital position, in our view," wrote Barclays analysts.Citigroup has also improved its standing since last year by scaling back its global consumer banking business, exiting 11 more markets. A company that is raising its dividend certainly has its shareholders in mind. So which companies today have been raising them the fastest over the past three to five years?

IBD scoured its Dividend Leaders Screen (see a partial list on this page) to find the firms that are showing at least double-digit growth in the cash payout. Twenty-nine make the cut. The average long-term increase is 26%.

Imagine owning a stock that not only has excellent earnings stability (which is critical for dividends) and sound fundamentals but also has the potential for decent capital appreciation and a bigger dividend. For an income investor, it's the best of all worlds.

Novartis (NVS) heads the list. IBD calculates that the Swiss ethical drug giant has grown its dividend by 60% over the past three to five years. The annualized dividend is $2.39 a share, equivalent to a 2.3% yield, which beats the S&P 500's 1.87% yield.
Novartis also boasts a three-year Earnings Stability Factor of 2 on a scale of zero (highly stable) to 99 (highly volatile).
In 2014, Novartis earned $5.23 a share on revenue of $58 billion, flat vs. a year ago.
Wells Fargo (WFC) ranks second in IBD's Dividend Leaders with a 57% dividend growth rate. The annualized cash dividend is $1.40 a share, yielding 2.6%.

The bank's business is centered on the U.S. consumer, mortgage and commercial markets. So it takes somewhat less of a hit on the income statement when overseas economies sour. The stock has recently rallied back above the key 50-day moving average. Upside resistance lingers near the 55 price level.

Media giant Gannett (GCI) sports the third-best dividend growth at 56% and is followed by CME Group (CME) at 49% and U.S. Bancorp (USB) (47%). Rounding out the top 10 are PNC Financial Services (PNC) (44%), Cisco Systems (CSCO) (38%), Accenture (ACN) (33%) and Quest Diagnostics (DGX) (33%). ACE Limited (ACE) and Lorillard (LO) tie for 10th at 30% growth.A company that is raising its dividend certainly has its shareholders in mind. Shares of big banks gapped up Friday after the Labor Department reported a strong employment report, raising speculation that the Federal Reserve would soon begin raising short-term interest rates, thereby expanding banks' net interest margins.
The U.S. economy added 257,000 jobs last month, better than expected, with big upward revisions to November and December.

"This report helps the case of those at the Fed arguing for starting the normalization process sooner (June) rather than later," Jim O'Sullivan, chief U.S. economist of High Frequency Economics, said in a statement.
The banks' strong showing in the stock market today wiped away the declines they suffered after reporting mostly disappointing quarterly results last month.

Bank of America (BAC) stock rose 4.8% to 16.74, retaking its 200-day line and just shy of its 50-day average. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) advanced 3.4% while Citigroup (C) rose 2.8%, Wells Fargo (WFC) climbed 2.5%, Goldman Sachs (GS) 1.9% and Morgan Stanley (MS) 3.8%.
The banks' quarterly results were hit by greater market volatility and weaker trading revenue.

The employment figures released Friday were stronger than expected. The U.S. unemployment rate inched up to 5.7% from 5.6% in December, but that reflected the re-entry of more people into the labor force to look for jobs.

Hourly wages in January rose 0.5% from December, topping expectations and marking the strongest growth in six years.Shares of big banks gapped up Friday after the Labor Department reported a strong employment report, raising speculation that the Federal Reserve would soon begin raising short-term interest rates, thereby expanding banks' net interest margins.The U.S. economy added 257,000 jobs last month, better than expected, with big upward revisions to November and December."This report helps the case of those at the Fed arguing for starting the normalization process sooner (June) rather than later," Jim O'Sullivan, chief U.S. economist of High Frequency Economics, said in a statement.The banks' strong showing in the stock market today wiped away the declines they suffered after reporting mostly disappointing quarterly results last month.Bank of America (BAC) stock rose 4.8% to 16.74, retaking its 200-day line and just shy of its 50-day average. U.S. stock mutual funds lost ground for a third straight week, losing 3.13% for the week that ended Jan. 15. The drop brought U.S. diversified stock funds' year-to-date loss to 3.38%. The setback was sparked by investor jitters over weak December retail sales figures. They contracted 0.9% from a year ago. Also damaging was a fourth-quarter earnings miss from JPMorgan…

Gargantuan legal expenses and sagging trading revenue pushed Citigroup's (C) earnings to a pittance compared to a year earlier as the New York-based lender missed already-low Wall Street expectations.

Citigroup earned $350 million, or 6 cents a share, in the fourth quarter, 93% lower than a year earlier, and missed by 3 cents the estimates of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue fell 0.1% to $17.8 billion, missing views of $18.5 billion.

Litigation and repositioning costs reached $3.5 billion, compared to $1 billion in Q4 2013. Citigroup, along with several other big banks, agreed to pay a total of $4.3 billion to settle allegations by U.S., Swiss and British regulators that they manipulated foreign-exchange currency markets. CEO Michael Corbat disclosed the legal expenses last month.
Deposits fell 7% year to year to $899 billion.
The bank's net interest margin increased to 2.92% from 2013 levels. Full-year expenses rose 14% to $55.1 billion.

A volatile start and finish to the fourth quarter hurt Citigroup's trading revenue more than analysts expected. Trading revenue fell 14% year to year to $2.46 billion. Equity markets revenue dropped 3% from Q4 2013 to $471 million, driven by lower trading revenue in cash equities in Europe, the Middle East and Africa, the bank said.

With greater exposure to overseas markets such as Europe, which has been struggling as of late, a goal for the bank is to sell off some of its global units, making it "less sprawling and more controlled," said Erik Oja, an equity analyst at S&P Capital IQ. "They're trying to rationalize their global footprint."
Last year, the bank was moving to sell its Greek and Spanish units as well as its Japanese retail subsidiary.
Ahead on the bank's schedule is the federal government's March stress tests for U.S. banks, which Citigroup failed last year.

Citigroup is the third big U.S. bank to underwhelm Wall Street this week. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Bank of America (BAC) both disappointed analysts with their Q4 results. Wells Fargo (WFC) largely met Wall Street expectations.

Shares had traded down 3.6% to 47.27 by midafternoon in the stock market today. Last year, the bank's shares rose 3.8%, but have dropped 13% so far this year, trading below Citigroup's 200-day moving average.

Stocks ended modestly lower Wednesday after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen said there was a "live possibility" of an interest-rate hike next month.The S&P 500 fell 0.4%, the Dow Jones industrial average edged down 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%. Volume was mixed, dipping about 1% on the NYSE and rising 4% on the Nasdaq compared to Tuesday, according to preliminary data.Makers of consumer telecommunications stocks were among the biggest losers in the stock market today. Motorola Solutions (MSI), which makes two-way radios and other communications products, plunged more than 8% despite better-than-expected Q3 profit and sales results. The stock, which had been working on a flat base, crashed through its 50-day moving average before finally steadying just above its 200-day line.Tesla Motors (TSLA) led shares of automakers higher, soaring 11% as the electric vehicle maker's Q4 delivery outlook trumped a weaker-than-expected quarterly earnings report. The stock is testing resistance at its 200-day line but remains 19% off its 52-week higher.HomeAway (AWAY) rocketed in post-session trading after Expedia (EXPE) agreed to buy the online marketplace for vacation rentals for $3.9 billion. The deal, which is expected to close in the first quarter of next year pending regulatory approval, is expected to help Expedia compete against home-rental businesses such as Airbnb.Meanwhile, Facebook (FB) rose in after-hours trading following its Q3 earnings report. Profit for the period rose 33% to 57 cents a share on a 41% gain in revenue to $4.5 billion. Both topped Wall Street estimates.The company said the number of daily active users rose 17% from a year ago to 1.01 billion on average for September. Mobile daily active users jumped 27% to 894 million on average during the month.Facebook rose 1% during the regular session. It's out of buying range from a 96.59 buy point.Qualcomm (QCOM) was down sharply after hours after its outlook for the fiscal first quarter that ends in December trailed analysts' estimates. That outweighed better-than-expected results in the latest period.Disney (DIS), Celgene (CELG), CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Nvidia (NVDA) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings Thursday.Economic reports due Thursday include initial jobless claims for the week ended Oct. 31 and Q3 productivity data.
Stocks sagged into a slow open Monday, with second-quarter earnings season just around the bend.

The Dow Jones industrial average, Nasdaq and the S&P 500 fell 0.2% each. The stock market today got off to a quiet start, with volume down sharply on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE compared with the same time Thursday.
Chatter was busy on the world-news front early Monday, but it was not triggering significant reactions in global markets.

Ukraine's government forces reportedly gained the upper hand over pro-Russian separatists during the weekend. The Ukraine military forced rebels from their stronghold in Slovyansk. Rebels retreated to the regional capital, Donetsk, to which Ukraine authorities apparently plan to lay siege. Russia has thus far not intervened in the offensive begun last week.
Libya announced Sunday that it was preparing to restart oil exports from two ports returned from rebel control last week. The two ports normally ship more than 500,000 barrels of oil per day.

In stocks, Applied Materials (AMAT) nosed up more than 1%, boosted by a JPMorgan upgrade. It raised the stock to outperform from neutral and lifted the price target to 30 from 19. The upgrade cited, among other things, the planned completion of the company's merger with Tokyo Electron later this year.
Qihoo 360 Technologies (QIHU) added 2% in the early going. The China-based online software and services provider has been working on the right side of a base.

Ambarella (AMBA) dipped 3%, becoming the heaviest loss on the IBD 50. The maker of chips used in GoPro (GPRO) cameras has been toggling above and below a 33.35 buy point in a deep cup-with-handle base.

JPMorgan Chase (JPM) placed a bet that U.S. housing market recovery will continue, agreeing to buy $45 billion in mortgage servicing rights after the nation's biggest banks rushed to shed exposure to that sector.Financial terms weren't disclosed for the rights to 266,000 loans from Ocwen Loan Servicing, a unit of Ocwen Financial (OCN).The purchase comes after other top banks like Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC) sold hundreds of billions of dollars in servicing rights amid tougher regulatory requirements prompted by the financial crisis.Kevin Watters, CEO of JPMorgan Chase's Mortgage Banking unit, said that the Ocwen deal "will improve the quality of our servicing portfolio and will help drive a stronger and less volatile mortgage business."He added that the high-quality loans could lower Chase's overall delinquency rates.Chase will begin contacting the new customers later this month and start managing the loan portfolios on June 1. Half of them already have a banking relationship with JPMorgan Chase, the company said.JPMorgan shares were up about 1% on the stock market today. Ocwen Financial fell 1.4%. Wells Fargo, Bank of America and Citigroup were all up less than 1%.Follow James DeTar on Twitter: @IBD_JDeTar .

General Electric (GE) reportedly is talking with Wells Fargo (WFC) about selling its commercial lending and leasing portfolio, a week after it sold its commercial real estate to the bank.The industrial conglomerate is in early-stage talks to sell its $74 billion U.S. commercial portfolio. The boundary is down between work and home. How executives and businesses make the most of flex, virtual and temporary job approaches: Hustle. "Technology has expanded the 9-to-5 workday into the 24/7 workday, which has made it extremely difficult for employees to have personal time."So says Dan Schawbel, founder of WorkplaceTrends.com, a research and advisory service for HR professionals. In fact, 65% of employees report that managers expect them to be reachable outside the office by phone and/or email. That's according to a survey conducted by WorkplaceTrends.com and outplacement firm Career Arc. Bend. With work demands stretching into home time, almost half (45%) of employees feel they don't have enough hours to complete personal tasks. Some firms address that by offering flex programs that let staffers periodically work from home. Three-quarters of workers responding to the survey rank it as a top benefit vs. half of employers. "In the future, every company will have a flexibility program, and those that don't will lose the battle for the top talent," Schawbel told IBD.The survey found almost 70% of employers tout work-from-home programs during recruitment, and 54% say those programs positively affect their ability to hire talent. Manage it. Telecommuters know shifting to home has its static. Nearly 70% of America's virtual employees say managers need to communicate more. That's according to a national Harris survey commissioned by leadership communication consultancy Interact. "Leaders must be intentional and strategic about building a sense of connectedness with virtual workers to keep them engaged and ensure productivity and growth," said Lou Solomon, founder of Interact, which boosts communication skills. Speak up. More than half of respondents — 55% — say bosses keep in touch exclusively by email.That less personal route can lead to a disconnected feeling. "People are wasting hours managing email that does nothing to build connections, much less trust," Solomon said. She suggests chatting via Skype and the phone. "Consider 'No Email Fridays' and 'No Email Weekends' for virtual teams." Think small. Avoid large, far-flung work groups."Pare down the number of people on project teams to allow for intimacy and trust," Solomon said.Bring teams together twice a year for face-to-face meetings. "Use this time to decide how the team wants to work and communicate with one another," she said. Go there. To keep in touch, Wells Fargo (WFC) Capital Finance CEO Henry Jordan sends a daily thought via video to his employees.Solomon recommends similar face time on a regular basis."Hold in-person town hall meetings, allow people to ask questions and telecast them to the entire organization," she said. Break molds. Imtiaz Patel, managing partner of IQ Strategy Associates, tells professionals to think outside of organizational norms.His on-demand talent firm takes an Uber-esque approach to connecting companies with experienced, temporary professionals, including former CEOs. "One of my friends works nine months a year. The rest of the time, he travels," Patel said. "Another friend says he will never go back to the rigors of a rigid corporate lifestyle." Make matches. Patel's short-term pros pitch-in at established and young firms. "A large number of people who had permanent executive positions are telling us that they like their new lifestyles and want to keep them," Patel said.
Stock futures cut sharply lower ahead of Wednesday's open, as global markets reacted for a second day to currency policy decisions made in China.
Dow futures bobbed between losses of 100 and 126 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures hung 34.5 points in the red. S&P 500 futures were off 14.8 points.

The stock market today once again opens with eyes toward China, where the currency slipped nearly 2% for a second straight day as the central bank holds to its new policy of letting the yuan adjust according to market forces.

The two-day contraction raises questions over how much adjustment is in store and what the impact of the currency shift will be on China's domestic demand as imported goods suddenly become more expensive. The currency shift also clouds the view into a possible Federal Reserve rate hike in the U.S.

Global markets showed their dread of uncertainty, with Europe's leading indexes down hard near midday, led by 2.2% declines each for the DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris. In China, Hong Kong's Hang Seng dropped 2.4%. The Shanghai Composite shed 1.1%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 fell 1.6%.

The fears spread to the U.S. premarket session, though losses were moderating on the approach to the opening bell. Still, Apple (AAPL) was down more than 1% after diving over 5% on Tuesday. Alcoa (AA) was down more than 1%, but Caterpillar (CAT), Exxon Mobil (XOM) and General Electric (GE) trimmed losses to less than 1% over the prior hour.
Against that backdrop, earnings reports continued to roll out.
Watch maker Fossil (FOSL) tanked 9% after reporting weak Q2 revenue and Q3 guidance. Internet retailer Wayfair (W) surged 11% after trampling analysts' Q2 earnings and revenue expectations.
China's Alibaba (BABA) swooned 6% ahead of the opening bell after earnings narrowly beat and a 28% revenue gain stopped short of analyst consensus views.

Gross merchandise volume — a measure of the goods sold through all of Alibaba's online channels — rose at its slowest rate in three years, up 34% to $105 billion. Management also launched a two-year, $4 billion share buyback program. Alibaba ended Tuesday 36% below a November high and 13% above its September IPO price.
CDK Global (CDK) punched up 9%, apparently on news reports that the company is exploring the possibility of a sale to private equity groups.

Bloomberg reported that the provider of software to auto dealerships and manufacturers, spun off last year from Automatic Data Processing (ADP), was working with Morgan Stanley. Neither CDK nor Morgan Stanley commented.

Sachem Head Capital Management and Elliott Management are among CDK's largest shareholders. The stock ended Tuesday in a test of support at its 200-day moving average, 16% below its June high and up more than 56% from its October IPO.

In economic news, New York Federal Reserve chief William Dudley was scheduled to speak at 8:30 a.m. ET. The Labor Department reports its Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey at 10 a.m. and the Energy Information Administration releases its weekly petroleum status report at 10:30.

The dollar dipped vs. the euro and the yen. The 10-year yield dropped 4 basis points to 2.10%. Commodities were generally higher. Oil bounced 1%, but not nearly enough to lift West Texas Intermediate back to $44 a barrel. Gold added 1% to $1,117 an ounce. Copper and silver were narrowly higher.Stock futures cut sharply lower ahead of Wednesday's open, as global markets reacted for a second day to currency policy decisions made in China.Dow futures bobbed between losses of 100 and 126 points below fair market value. Nasdaq 100 futures hung 34.5 points in the red. S&P 500 futures were off 14.8 points.The stock market today once again opens with eyes toward China, where the currency slipped nearly 2% for a second straight day as the central bank holds to its new policy of letting the yuan adjust according to market forces.The two-day contraction raises questions over how much adjustment is in store and what the impact of the currency shift will be on China's domestic demand as imported goods suddenly become more expensive. The currency shift also clouds the view into a possible Federal Reserve rate hike in the U.S.Global markets showed their dread of uncertainty, with Europe's leading indexes down hard near midday, led by 2.2% declines each for the DAX in Frankfurt and the CAC-40 in Paris. In China, Hong Kong's Hang Seng dropped 2.4%. The Shanghai Composite shed 1.1%. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 fell 1.6%.The fears spread to the U.S. premarket session, though losses were moderating on the approach to the opening bell. Still, Apple (AAPL) was down more than 1% after diving over 5% on Tuesday. Alcoa (AA) was down more than 1%, but Caterpillar (CAT), Exxon Mobil (XOM) and General Electric (GE) trimmed losses to less than 1% over the prior hour.Against that backdrop, earnings reports continued to roll out.Watch maker Fossil (FOSL) tanked 9% after reporting weak Q2 revenue and Q3 guidance. If there is a price to be paid for being successful, Wells Fargo (WFC) could see it this week as it reports fourth-quarter earnings amid analysts asking if its growth is sustainable.

When it reports Q4 performance on Wednesday, before the market opens, the San Francisco-based lender is expected to say it earned $1.01 per share, up one penny from a year earlier, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue is expected to rise 2.7% year-over-year to $20.7 billion.

Wells Fargo shares rose 20.7% last year, making it the top performer, from investors' perspective, among the nation's four largest banks. Shares hit an all-time high of 55.94 on Dec. 29. But Wells' stock has fallen 4.7% so far this year, dropping below its 50-day moving average last week. On Monday, shares fell 1.2% to 52.05.
The company currently has an IBD Composite Rating of 55, meaning its stock is outperforming 55% of other publicly traded issues.

A $1 billion inflection in loan loss provisions — or 13 cents a share — is the main driver behind the modest EPS growth expected in 2015, according to a report by Keefe, Bruyette & Woods. Lower tax rates and big gains in its private equity segment promoted Wells' strong stock performance last year.
"We simply don't believe a provision expense of just 0.15% of average loans in 2014 (and resulting reserve releases) can be sustained in 2015," the report said.
Analysts at Robert W. Baird downgraded Wells from "outperform" to "neutral," citing their belief that shares were "due for a breather."

Nevertheless, Wells Fargo, being the biggest bank player in the more stable mortgage sector, makes it less vulnerable to stock market volatility, unlike its competitors JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Citigroup (C) and Bank of America (BAC). JPMorgan reports Q4 earnings Wednesday morning while BofA and Citi follow suit Thursday morning.

Wells continued to take deposits even with interest rates remaining near zero for an extended time. Like other lenders, Wells has endured compressed net interest margins. It also has endured litigation headaches stemming from Wachovia, which it rescued during the depths of the financial crisis in 2008.
As the nation's biggest mortgage lender, loan growth will be key, said Christopher Mutascio, an analyst at Keefe Bruyette & Woods.
"The bar is higher for Wells Fargo than it is for JPMorgan," he said, citing Wells' strong stock performance, spurred in part by a lower tax rate and gains in private equity operations.

Stocks were poised for a higher open on this first trading day of November as a round of merger activity offset weak data out of China. Nasdaq 100 futures rose 12 points vs. fair value and S&P 500 futures climbed 2 points.
Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average rallied 23 points.
Stocks rallied for a fifth straight week last week and closed out the month of October with solid gains.

Over the weekend, China reported lackluster manufacturing data. The preliminary Caixin China manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) came in at 48.3 in October, up from 47.2 in September. But readings under 50 signal contraction. China's official PMI came in at 49.8 in October, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. This marked the third straight monthly drop for the world's second largest economy.
Asian stock markets were lower, with the Shanghai composite and Hong Kong's Hang Seng losing 1.7% and 1.2%, respectively. Japan's Nikkei fell 2.1%.
In stock news, several companies announced deals.
TreeHouse Foods (THS) agreed to buy ConAgra Foods' (CAG) private brands business for $2.7 billion in cash. ConAgra shares surged 13% in premarket trading, while TreeHouse shares eased a fraction.

Visa (V) announced that it would acquire Visa Europe in a deal valued at more than $23 billion if certain targets are met. Visa Europe split from its parent company in 2007 before the credit card firm's initial public offering.

Separately, Visa also reported mixed quarterly results. It posted fiscal Q4 earnings of 62 cents a share, up from 55 cents a year ago. But it missed views by a penny. Sales climbed to $3.571 billion, barely edging views for $3.57 billion.
The firm also announced a $5 billion stock buyback program. Visa shares fell about 2% in premarket trading. The stock has had a tough time making progress from a 77.02 entry in a consolidation.

Dyax (DYAX) soared 33% on news that it would be acquired by British drug giant Shire (SHPG) for an initial $5.9 billion, or $37.30 per share, in cash. Shareholder may receive an additional $4 a share, depending on approval for its hereditary angioedema treatment.

Elsewhere, Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) fell 4% in premarket trading on news that it closed stores in the Northwest due to an outbreak of E. coli. Shares have already been under pressure recently on weak quarterly earnings.

On the economic front, reports on factory activity from Markit and the Institute for Supply Management will be out at 9:45 a.m. and 10 a.m. ET, respectively. Data on construction spending is also due at 10 a.m. ET in the stock market today.

Stocks seesawed to a lower finish on Veterans Day Wednesday. The Dow Jones industrial average, the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 all ended down 0.3%. According to preliminary data, volume was lower across the board in the stock market today.After the close, shares of Popeyes Louisiana Kitchen (PLKI) jumped more than 5% after the company posted Q3 results that beat views. The fried chicken chain reported earnings of 47 cents a share on sales of $61.1 million. Views were for 45 cents a share on revenue of $61.9 million. It also slightly raised its full-year profit outlook to a range of $1.86 to $1.91 a share, vs. views of $1.90.In the regular session, Horizon Pharma (HZNP) gapped down and plunged nearly 20% after pharmacy benefits manager Express Scripts (ESRX) filed a lawsuit against the company for $140 million over a contract dispute.AmTrust Financial Services (AFSI) gapped below its 50-day line and slumped 8% after pricing a secondary offering of 5 million shares. The insurance firm said that it would take in $315 million before expenses. Intraday, it fell more than 8% below a 69.84 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.Despite a rather lackluster session, TAL Education (XRS) rallied 3% and scored a new high in fast trade. It followed through Wednesday after clearing a 38.75 buy point from a late-stage cup-with-handle Tuesday. The company provides tutoring in China.Luxoft (LXFT) gapped up and jumped 7% after beating views and raising guidance. Late Tuesday, the company reported adjusted fiscal Q2 earnings of 84 cents a share, up 45% from a year earlier. Profit growth has now accelerated for two quarters. Sales rose 29% to $161.5 million. Luxoft lifted its full-year profit outlook by a nickel to $2.60 a share. The stock is now extended 9% past a 68.95 buy point from a flat base.Weekly jobless claims will be out Thursday morning. A host of central bank officials will be speaking throughout the day, including Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen, St. Louis Fed chief James Bullard and Richmond Fed President Jeffrey Lacker.Advance Auto Parts (AAP) and Cisco Systems (CSCO) are a couple of notable companies reporting earnings Thursday.Follow Vincent Mao on Twitter @IBD_VMao.

Double-digit gains in automobile financing led Ally Financial (ALLY) to accelerate to solid third-quarter earnings growth as the auto lender moves to jettison the U.S. government's stake in its business.The Detroit-based company, formerly known as GMAC Inc., swung to a profit of 53 cents a share, beating views by 12 cents, from a loss of 27 cents a share a year ago, when results were hit by legal settlements with U.S. regulators over mortgage issues.Shares rose 0.9% on the stock market today. The company's stock is down 10% since its initial public offering in April.Commercial auto loan balances rose 12% year-over-year to $31 billion in Q3. Consumer auto financing originations totaled $11.8 billion in Q3, a rise of 23%, driven by a record quarter for used car loans.Auto finance results were driven by higher portfolio growth and lower provision expenses, the company said.The U.S. government bailed out Ally in 2009, spending $17.2 billion in the process. Earlier this month, the federal government owned an 11.4% stake in Ally, down from the 74% interest it held a year ago. The government has estimated that taxpayers have made more than $1 billion as it has made $18.3 billion from selling Ally shares.Banks such as Wells Fargo (WFC) increasingly have gotten into the auto lending market as car demand remains robust. On Tuesday, the Comptroller of the Currency, a division in the Treasury Department, warned that lax standards in auto loans are leading to more losses for banks.

"This is a great country and a greater people," exclaimed Henry Wells upon visiting California during the Gold Rush era.Wells (1805-78) believed passionately in America. Where others saw pitfalls in the expanding country, he saw limitless opportunity.Wells, who played a critical role in launching American Express (AXP) on the East Coast and Wells Fargo (WFC) on the West, was the classic American entrepreneur.He combined foresight with hard work as he helped pioneer America's first wide-scale delivery and banking services, then shared his wealth through innovative philanthropy.New EnglanderBorn in Vermont, Wells, after a spell as a farmer and shoemaker, became acquainted with the transportation industry on the East Coast through his work as a freight agent on the Erie Canal.That proved formative in opening his eyes to the lucrative opportunities for delivering mail, money, valuables and goods to Americans.Blessed with a relentless work ethic, Wells became indispensable during the infancy of the delivery service industry in the 1840s.He was famous for making tricky and improbable deliveries, such as bringing fresh oysters to Buffalo restaurants.Thanks to his familiarity with the railroads and shipping, he also had a knack for identifying the quickest route to deliver a package, often reducing shipment time by weeks.In 1850, he spearheaded the formation of American Express.He impressed upon his employees the importance of speed and loyal service. Knowing that his customers depended on his reliability, Wells didn't let anything stop him, not even dangerous weather.He would risk storms on the Great Lakes to make sure that his customers received their packages.As he explained to his team, "It was the duty of the express to go," and "You are expected to get there, that is all."The sluggish federal government had trouble competing with an efficient businessman like Wells.The public prized his express delivery, which was cheaper and faster than the U.S. postal system's. Such was the success of Wells that the post office, reeling from public disfavor, had to reduce its rates.Wells endured government harassment via regulations, which he shook off easily, calling himself the "people's postmaster." He considered his express delivery a "peaceful revolution." His philosophy was that the "government should do as little as possible" in those areas of life where the private sector could supply service.Solid ExecutionAs head of American Express for almost 20 years, Wells enjoyed the respect of America's executive class. Businessmen marveled at the steadiness of his firm's delivery.As means of shipment went, said one businessman, "none equaled Wells' trunk!"Wells was also renowned for his eye for innovation, appreciating long before other businessmen the value of inventions such as the telegraph. He is credited with starting some of the first telegraph lines on the East Coast.Wells became a business star despite suffering from a stutter."He worked around it," Robert Chandler, author of "Wells Fargo," told IBD. "He did not let it define him, and he could use it for emphasis and advantage when he wished. He took a liability and turned it into a positive."Walk The TalkWells set up a string of speech therapy centers. Friends would often note, said Chandler, that "he cured everyone but himself."Other people, suffering from such a problem, might have withdrawn from life. Wells plunged into it. He was a gregarious risk-taker who saw in the expansion of the country and the discovery of gold in California in the mid-1800s a chance to do on the West Coast what he had done on the East.Staid colleagues at American Express pooh-poohed his plans for expansion across the country, but he disregarded the carping. "Westward, ever westward," he said.Teaming up with railroad freight agent William Fargo, Wells founded Wells, Fargo & Co. in 1852. They established its headquarters in San Francisco.Wells saw that the gold miners and the businesses that served them would need banking and mail-delivery services.As California and the other Western states grew, the demand for Wells' offerings expanded too.The miners came to rely on his fabled stagecoach network, which spanned thousands of miles, for the delivery of everything from their gold to their wives and children.Do It RightAlong the way, Wells popularized the philosophy that the customer comes first. That legacy of sound conduct is still prized at his firm, according to Wells Fargo spokesman Matthew Wadley.Wells told his associates: "There was one very powerful business rule. It was concentrated in the word 'courtesy.'"Take advantage of no one, he told his employees."He didn't stand for any foolishness from his employees," said Chandler. "The slime balls failed."Indeed, Wells made sure everyone in the firm from the lowliest clerk to members of the board of directors adhered to high standards."Because of Wells, the company had ethical directors, observant directors," according to Chandler.Wells Fargo instructed its employees: "The most polite and gentlemanly treatment of all customers, however insignificant in their business, is insisted upon. Proper respect must be shown to all — let them be men, women or children, rich or poor, white or black — it must not be forgotten that the company is dependent on these same people for its business."Wells approached his business with unusual care for an executive of that era, as was evident in his willingness to take the dangerous, months-long trip from New York to California to inspect his offices and employees personally in 1852.He found the frenetic economic activity of Gold Rush California invigorating and wasn't above laughing at himself. "I am an old fogy here," he said, though he was only in his 40s.Wells' insistence on sound business practices and refusal to cut corners served the company well in times of panic, of which that wild frontier period had many.During a banking collapse in the 1850s, people sought refuge in Wells Fargo, as it was the only bank that made sure to keep enough funds on hand for such occasions.Almost anybody could open a bank at that time, but Wells Fargo, owing to its dependability, cleared the field easily.In the 1860s, Wells turned his attention increasingly to philanthropy. He had no intention of dying rich. He was eager to give his money away to worthy causes.Chief among them was education. Wells called the founding of a college the "dream of my life."In 1868, the dream came true when he opened the doors for Wells College in Aurora, N.Y.It was one of America's first colleges for women. Some of his peers considered an institution of higher learning for women a frivolous act of charity. Wells didn't care."Give her the opportunity," he told his critics.Sharing The WealthBy the time of his death just shy of age 73, Wells had given much of his money away. Even so, he left an estate of $400,000 — worth almost $10 million today.Due to his stammer, he couldn't give the Founder's Day address at Wells College in 1875, but he could write it. He used it to sum up his life:"Our lives are not measured by the number of years and days we exist, but by what we accomplish while we live, and the good we may render to our fellow men."

Stocks reversed lower at midday Friday, wiping out a promising start to the day. The Nasdaq, which was up as much as 1.1%, was down 0.4%. The S&P 500 also was off 0.4% while the Dow Jones industrial average lost 0.3%.
Small caps were getting routed, with the Russell 2000 tumbling 0.9%. Volume was tracking lower.
The market started reversing lower after the wholesale trade report came out at 10 a.m. ET. It showed a 0.3% decline for November, indicating that manufacturers are working off inventories.
Facebook (FB) and Amazon.com (AMZN) were among the bellwethers rising in heavy trading in thestock market today.
Facebook recovered 1% and continues to work on a base-on-base pattern.

Amazon climbed 1% as it sought to end a six-day losing streak in which it lost 12%. But the online retailer remained below the 50-day moving average and its Accumulation/Distribution Rating is at a lowest-possible E. In short, the stock still needs to muscle up.
Some stocks bounced off key levels on their charts, in a sign of relief.
LGI Homes (LGIH) gapped up 13% and climbed back above its 200-day moving average.

The homebuilder announced Thursday that it reached a record for closings during a single month with 433 homes closed in December. Its Q4 and full-year closings also were records. The 3,404 homes closed for 2015 were an increase of 44.5% from 2014.

But Acuity Brands (AYI) plunged more than 4% in heavy volume, piercing its 50-day moving average. The maker of LED lighting products beat profit views but reported quarterly sales that were disappointing.

Good morning..... It was an interesting day yesterday with the major indexes finishing mixed; Dollar drop sharply, oil surges, International Monetary Fund cuts global growth, Federal Reserve cuts 1Q forecast for GDP, JPMorgan (JPM) beats, Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) beats, Wells Fargo (WFC) disappoints (just a bit), Avon Products (AVP) considers a sale of the company, China's economy grows at…

Stocks on Monday failed to hold onto the early gains — as worries over the macro data, dollar strength and earnings once again weighed on traders' minds. All of the averages pulled back to end the day in negative territory. In my opinion — the action was more about profit taking after the move higher late last week and yesterday morning - all ahead of what could be more volatility and weakness in the days ahead. Will reports play on the strong dollar as a reason for the weakened earnings? Will they blame the consumer? Will it be global economic weakness? I mean estimates have already been slashed for all of these reasons — so will it just be more of the same?

Today brings us JPMorgan Chase (JPM) & Wells Fargo (WFC) — later in the week they will be joined by Bank of America (BAC) and Goldman Sachs (GS) …. in what will the 1st qtr look like for the financials. Rising legal and regulatory expenses, slowing mortgage lending, a decrease in trading revenues, a collapsing energy space all will play into the mix… YTD - though, financials have underperformed the broader mkt.....down about 2% for the group....followed only by energy and utilities.......

But like we said — earnings represent history — what is important is what the future looks like….and recently the Credit Managers Index (CMI) has reported an increase in rejected credit applications — this spike coming only in the last month — too late for any real impact on 1st qtr earnings but a clear indicator of what may be in store. With credit tight once again — will it bring the country to a grinding halt? Look — lending can be a risky business and with the global economy still struggling, along with the exposure created by the collapsing oil mkt, coupled with the threat of rising US interest rates — the future is anything but clear. But remember — investment bankers are keen to play with the numbers - they are well known for redefining common accounting practices...but hey.....it works for them and the regulators don't seem to mind.....……so what rabbit will they pull out of the hat? I do not expect them to 'miss the numbers' JPM announces early - and earnings are expected to +8% at $1.39/sh on revenues of $24.4 bil or a 2% increase yoy, WFC on the other hand is due to report a bit weaker numbers... 98 cents/sh - a 7% decline on revenues of $21.2 bil.

In healthcare — Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) is the bellwether...and they are also due to report....here investors will be keenly aware of the $ impact - but remember - like Alcoa (AA) - Johnson & Johnson should also see a benefit from overseas operations that are helped by weaker currencies abroad - it's not all about the $.....I'm just sayin.....

Last night after the bell - we heard from Norfolk Southern (NSC) - in pre-release commentary - they prepared investors for a disappointment - not because of the dollar ..Oh No....it was because of 'lower fuel SURCHARGE revenue'.....(and lower coal shipments).....but isn't this just a kick in the pants? Oil declines in price bringing untold benefits to transportation companies along with a host of others and now Norfolk Southern tells us that earnings could be down 15% because they CAN'T charge higher fuel surcharges?

(A surcharge is an ADD'L charge or payment on top of a regular cost.....so if investors are buying Norfolk - because they are able to increase revenues by increasing surcharges - then someone should think about a new portfolio manager......Surcharges do not represent organic growth, or an improved outlook - they only represent the ability of companies to fleece their clients with add'l fees etc...... Where is the investment theory in that?) The stock traded down some 4% in after hours as the algo's punished it.....

This morning - US futures are a bit lower as the drama unfolds.....currently - 2 pts at 2085.....like I said yesterday - I expect the mkt to find stability at the 50 DMA of 2075......unless the banks so screw it up - then I would expect sentiment to remain fairly upbeat......remember - the mkt is expecting earnings GROWTH in healthcare, 10%, Financials, 8%, consumer disc, 6%, and the industrials of 5%.....the disappointments are expected to come from energy - down some 60% (but that is not a surprise), materials down 5%, telecoms down 4%, IT down 1.5%......

The forward guidance is the key.....US companies that book large volumes of int'l sales will likely be a bit more cautious in the face of the strong dollar (as they cover their backsides), but those same multinationals that also have overseas operations will benefit from the weaker local currencies. Add in the continued monetary policies of global central banks and BOOM.....the mkt can never really correct..... and by correct I do not mean a 5% move off the highs -

Today we get retail sales....analysts expect to see a surge......making last month's reading a non issue....they will argue the weather story and then tell us how healthy and strong the consumer is......etc.....that will then cause the pundits to re-hash the rate increase conversation, which will then spook the algos....and it is a vicious circle.....Do not get drawn into the rate increase story....it ain't happening in June, nor in September.....Speaking of the FED - watch for NY Pres Dudley to speak at 8:40 am and Minneapolis Pres Kocherlakota to speak at 8 pm.....well after the mkts close - but remember - he is an ultra uber dove....so the algo's will be listening......

European mkts are a bit lower even on strong data.....EMU Industrial Production (European Monetary Union) easily beat the estimates...coming in +1.1% vs exp of +0.3%.....Italian and British CPI both met the expectations and the ECB continues to feed the beast.....the small pullback we are seeing only represents some profit taking as these mkts have exploded to the upside in the past 3 months...so caution ahead of earnings is prudent....taking some money off the table - while keeping a core position in stocks you like is never a bad investment decision.....FTSE +0.16%, CAC 40 - 0.57%, DAX - 0.60%, EUROSTOXX -0.94%, SPAIN -01.02% and ITALY -1.12%.

In case you missed it - Florida's Marco Rubio (43 yrs old) launched his campaign for President last night.....and boy is he picking a fight....did you hear his speech - very good in fact - but he is taking no prisoners....emphasizing age over experience....(haven't we had enough of that?) taking a direct shot at Bush (62 yrs old) & Hillary (67 yrs old) .....Saying :
"The time has come for our generation to lead the way towards a new American century"...... Wait....help me out here......Wasn't that what Obama was supposed to do?
In a direct shot at Hillary - he had this to say:
"Just yesterday, a leader from yesterday began a campaign for president promising to take us back to yesterday......Yesterday is over and we are never going back".....
And the blood continues to pour out..... Sit back, grab some popcorn - the night is young.......
Take good care.

Will reports play on the strong dollar as a reason for the weakened earnings? Will they blame the consumer? Will it be global economic weakness? I mean estimates have already been slashed for all of these reasons — so will it just be more of the same?Today brings us JPMorgan Chase (JPM) & Wells Fargo (WFC) — later in the week they will be joined by Bank of America (BAC) and Goldman Sachs (GS) …. in what will the 1st qtr look like for the financials. General Electric (GE) said Friday it will sell the bulk of GE Capital over the next two years amid a refocus on its industrial core, though some analysts see risks involved with the divestment's size.

The conglomerate receives nearly half of its profit from the finance business, but the banking operations come with heavy risks and threatened the company during the financial crisis. Under the plan, GE expects to generate over 90% of its earnings from its industrial businesses by 2018, up from 58% in 2014.
GE can accomplish its plan on schedule, though there are execution risks, given the size of GE Capital, says Logan Purk, senior equity analyst for Edward Jones.
"Before, it was selling slivers here and there," he told IBD. "They say they have interested parties, but I tend to be more 'I'll believe it when I see it.' It's not small."

GE's two-year time frame comes during a "decent market," barring a global economic setback, but "pricing is a wild card," he added, noting there's a chance buyers won't pay book value for GE Capital's assets.
Shares jumped 7.4% in the stock market today to their highest level in more than a year.
GE said its industrial businesses are on track for operating EPS of $1.10-$1.20. But not all its financial businesses are going away.
It's keeping its aircraft leasing operations, GE Capital Aviation Services, and lending arms for energy and health care, as they are smaller operations that support GE's industrial focus.

"This is a major step in our strategy to focus GE around its competitive advantages," GE CEO Jeff Immelt said in a statement. "The team is executing a detailed plan to boost margins and returns. We are allocating capital to grow the company and benefit investors."
The move comes after GE spun off its private-label credit card provider, Synchrony Financial (SYF), last year.
In an initial step to shed GE Capital, the company plans to sell $26.5 billion in office buildings and other commercial space to Blackstone Group (BX) and Wells Fargo (WFC).
The board also authorized a $50 billion share buyback as GE expects to reduce its share count to 8 billion -8.5 billion by 2018.

A sharp reduction in legal costs and strong mortgage growth weren't enough to help Bank of America (BAC) meet Wall Street's first-quarter expectations despite posting a nice profit.

The Charlotte, N.C.-based lender earned $3.36 billion, or 27 cents a share, a 32-cent turnaround from Q1 '14 but missing analyst estimates by 2 cents. The bank posted a net loss of $246 million a year earlier. Revenue fell 5.9% to $21.42 billion, missing views of $21.51 billion.

BofA missed estimates despite analyst expectations that it would do well because of easy comparisons to the first quarter of 2014, when it reported a 5-cent loss per share on a $6 billion litigation charge stemming from mortgage-related settlements.

Overall, Q1 costs declined 29% year to year to $15.7 billion, with legal expenses plunging 94% to $370 million. BofA, which paid $16.65 billion last year to settle a Justice Department probe into alleged wrongdoing related to mortgage-backed securities, has said the bulk of its financial crisis-related legal woes are behind it.

Bank of America said its revenue slide was due to $211 million in market-related adjustments on its debt securities portfolio as a result of low long-term interest rates. A $757 million drop in equity investment income included a gain on a partial sale of an investment.
The bank's net interest margin — the spread between what it pays on deposits and what it makes on loans and other interest-earning assets — slipped 12 basis points to 2.17%.
Having struggled to pass the Federal Reserve stress test that concluded last month, the bank said it expects $100 million in additional costs related to the test process.
It originated $13.7 billion in mortgages in Q1, a 55% increase from a year earlier.
Client brokerage assets grew 18% to $18.3 billion.

Trading revenues dropped 5% from Q1 '14 to $3.9 billion, lagging peers such as JPMorgan Chase (JPM), which reported Q1 earnings on Tuesday. Wells Fargo (WFC) also reported its first-quarter results Tuesday.

Fixed-income currency and commodities trading fell 7% from Q1 '14 to $2.75 billion, but the drop was partially offset by strong foreign exchange currency results stemming from increased market volatility.
Total assets at March 31 were $2.14 trillion, down 0.3% from a year earlier.

Shares fell 0.9% to 15.68 by early afternoon trading in the stock market today. The bank's shares have fallen 11.6% so far this year. BofA currently maintains an IBD Composite Rating of 42, meaning its shares are outperformed by 58% of other publicly traded businesses. The stock is trading below both its 50- and 200-day moving averages.

Earnings season continues Thursday for big banks, with Citigroup (C) and Goldman Sachs (GS) reporting their quarterly results. Wells Fargo (WFC) agreed to sell $8.5 billion of its federally guaranteed student loans to Sallie Mae spinoff Navient (NAVI), extricating itself from that type of lending as it focuses on private lending to students, which is significant.

The San Francisco-based bank hasn't issued federal student loans since 2010 in response to increasing competition from U.S. government programs and increased regulatory scrutiny. JPMorgan Chase (JPM) cited those reasons when it disclosed its exit from student loans last year.

Navient said it expects the majority of the purchased loans will be converted to its servicing platform next year and that most of the deal will be completed this quarter. A sale price was not disclosed, but Wells will provide Navient with financing to complete the deal. Proceeds reportedly will not be material to Wells' earnings.

As a former unit of Sallie Mae (SLM), Navient is the nation's largest servicer of federal and private student loans. When the purchase from Wells is digested, Navient will service about $310 billion in student loans.

The sale did not come as a surprise, as Wells Fargo Chief Financial Officer John Shrewsberry said earlier this year that the bank was seeking to shed its portfolio of government-guaranteed student loans because they are low-yielding and "not strategic."
In July, Wells said it moved $9.7 billion in government-backed student loans to its held-for-sale portfolio with the intent of selling them all.
Wells still remains a major player among U.S. banks in the field of private student loans, having outstanding loans of nearly $12 billion.
Wells Fargo shares initially rose in morning trading, but was down 0.3% to 53.39 by late morning in the stock market today. That's near its 52-week high.

The bank's IBD Composite Rating is 69, meaning it trades better than 69% of other publicly traded companies. Navient shares rose 1.3% to 20.39, nearly a record high since its May IPO. Rising interest rates and better market and lending conditions bode well for the U.S. banking sector in 2015, though regulatory and legal headwinds will persist, said financial services specialist Keefe, Bruyette & Woods in a banking outlook report on Thursday.Along with higher short-term interest rates, KBW expects market volatility to boost trading activity at large U.S. "universal banks," those viewed as globally important.But KBW rates only two names of eight as outperformers for 2015 in the universal-bank group: Goldman Sachs (GS) and State Street (STT).KBW thinks benefits are already reflected in earnings and valuations in most of the universal-bank group, which includes some of the largest banks, such as JP Morgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C) and Wells Fargo (WFC). It sees upward earnings revisions as the main drivers of stock performance next year.As for large regional banks, KBW likes names that can grow net interest income regardless of the Fed's action on interest rates. It cites two in particular — Huntington Bancshares (HBAN), based in Columbus, Ohio; and Atlanta-based SunTrust Banks (STI).In the small to midcap group, it'll come down to the "direction of estimates," KBW said. Despite its so-so view on the group itself, KBW has several "favorite plays" for 2015.They include Signature Bank (SBNY), Private Bancorp (PVTB), Eagle Bancorp (EGBN), Talmer Bancorp (TLMR), First Merchants Corp. (FRME) and Western Alliance Bancorporation (WAL). Those stocks are also rated highly by IBD, with Composite Ratings of 90 or above out of a possible 99. Composite Ratings factor in earnings growth, stock price gains and other metrics.KBW, a subsidiary of Stifel Financial (SF), is a boutique investment bank and broker-dealer.
